related.body:
Police started reinforcement tactics this week and yesterday visited six tattoo studios which had not complied with new legislation requiring an operating licence and police background checks. Studios and tattooists had until Monday to lodge paperwork for a licence to the Office of Fair Trading but some still hadn’t completed it.

Superintendent Jim Keogh said police were doing rounds visiting local studios whose paperwork had not yet been received.

MORE GOLD COAST NEWS & GALLERIES 

“We’re going around making sure that they’ve complied,” he said.

“Those who haven’t, we’re asking them if they are having difficulties in complying. We’re reinforcing the message with them that they must comply with the registration of the tattoo shop and tattoo artists.”

Supt Keogh said the objective was not to close the studios down but rather a check-up.

“Some of the places we spoke to said ‘Look, we have sent it away but we’ve only just sent it away’,” Supt Keogh said.

“Eventually, we’ll go through all the places that haven’t complied and those without justification will be prosecuted.”

The legislation provided an opportunity for legitimate business operators in the industry to possibly extend and take over companies that close in light of the legislation, he added.

Tattoo businesses which don’t comply face fines of up to $55,000 for a first offence and up to $110,000 and 18 months’ jail for subsequent offences.

related.body:
POLICE are investigating after a number of separate petrol drive-offs at service stations across the Gold Coast in the past two months.

On April 16 a man wearing a blue and yellow long-sleeved work shirt pulled into a Broadbeach Waters petrol station before using the bowser and failing to pay.

On June 13 a man drove a dark blue vehicle to a petrol station in Upper Coomera, filling his car with an amount of fuel and leaving the store without attempting to pay.

The next day a man drove away from a Parkwood petrol station, failing to pay for the fuel he had used.

Officers would like to speak to any of the three men pictured and anybody who has information which may assist police is urged to contact Crime Stoppers.

CHINA’S RICHEST MAN TO BUY BILLION DOLLAR DEVELOPMENT SITE 

STEALING — SOUTHPORT

Police are hunting a woman who pushed past staff at a Southport liquor store and fled with a number of items.

About 2.15pm on February 2 the female entered the store and removed a number of items, concealing them under her clothing.

As she went to leave the woman was blocked by staff, but managed to push past and flee without paying for the items.

Police believe the person pictured may be able to assist with their investigation.

Anyone with information which could assist with this matter should contact Crime Stoppers via 1800 333 000 and quote QP1400179831.

STEALING — BROADBEACH

Police would like to speak to this man after a number of business shirts were stolen from a Broadbeach store last month.
About 11am on June 10 the male suspect entered a large department store and selected a number of shirts from the displays before proceeding tot eh change rooms.
A short time later the man exited the change rooms without the shirts and was instead carrying a full bag.
The man then left the store without paying for the items.

Anyone with information which could assist with this matter should contact Crime Stoppers via 1800 333 000 and quote QP1400806332 

STEALING — BURLEIGH HEADS

Officers are investigating after a woman stole a number of grocery items from a Burleigh Heads supermarket last month.

About 1.15pm on June 13 a woman entered the supermarket and filled a trolley with grocery items.

The woman then left the store without paying for the items and loaded them into a awaiting vehicle.

Police would like to speak to the woman pictured who may be able to assist with their investigation.

Anyone with information which could assist with this matter should contact Crime Stoppers via 1800 333 000 and quote QP1400787443

Multi-billionaire Wang Jianlin, chairman of Beijing super corporation Dalian Wanda, visited the Gold Coast last month, speaking with international property broker Roland Evans and Mayor Tom Tate.

Steven Haggart, CEO of Ridong Group’s Australian arm, yesterday couldn’t confirm a deal had been struck with Wanda or any other prospective buyers or investors.

NEWS: SLOW GOING ON JEWEL TOWERS 

MORE GOLD COAST NEWS & GALLERIES 

“Things have been positively progressing with Jewel, and there will be further clarity by the end of the month,” he said.

Once finalised, Mr Wang’s Gold Coast buy would be the latest in an international spending spree for his company, which owns 85 shopping plazas, 51 five-star hotels and 75 department stores and is also the world’s largest cinema company.

Other Wanda representatives are expected to fly to the Coast later this month to look for even more properties to add to their portfolio.

Neither Mr Evans nor Cr Tate would comment on the speculation.

The three-tower Jewel development, on 1.13ha of prime beachfront land at Old Burleigh Rd bought for $81.8 million, was called in by the State Government and had its approval fast-tracked in 2012.

When it was announced in 2011, the plan featured three towers of 45, 41 and 35 storeys, housing 939 bedrooms – including 298 six-star suites and apartments.

There were to be two restaurants, shops, a ballroom, kids clubs, health spas and nine swimming pools.

The Jewel design, meant to symbolise three crystals on a beach, was created by award-winning US architect Chad Oppenheim in collaboration with Coast firm UPS Design.

A hotel operator for the project has never been publicly named.

In May alone, the Wanda group opened another two massive Chinese shopping plazas and a hotel, and it has bought billion-dollar properties in London and New York in recent years, converting them to five-star hotels.

The man was taken to Gold Coast University Hospital in a stable condition with minor injuries.

Queensland Fire and Rescue Service crews isolated power to the building and police are organising for the vehicle to be removed.

The extent of damage to the building is not known.

More to come.

related.body:
Mayor Tom Tate claimed, in a confidential email, that the move by him and chief of staff Wayne Moran would not create an extra financial burden on ratepayers.

However, councillors suspect there’ll be hidden costs in both travel and furnishings.

MORE GOLD COAST NEWS & GALLERIES 

Gold Coast Residents and Ratepayers Association president Tom Bleier, when told of the shift was not concerned about the costs, but he believes it signals the Mayor doesn’t want to be with his councillors.

“I think the Mayor is trying to get away from his councillors. He wants to be with his staff. I think if he wants to do that, he should go all the way to Brisbane,” Mr Bleier said.

The historically listed two-storey art deco Town Hall building was built in 1935 and last used as the Gold Coast City Council’s headquarters in 1976 before the city’s elected representatives moved to Evandale.

The Bulletin understands Councillor Tate, in the email on Tuesday, foreshadowed the move by only himself and Mr Moran, explaining personal staff would remain at Evandale.

Senior city councillor Dawn Crichlow, based on the ground floor of the Southport building, yesterday confirmed Cr Tate and Mr Moran would be moving in upstairs.

“He sent an email to the councillors and directors yesterday about moving into Southport, into the old council chambers. There are offices upstairs,” she said.

“The town planning and economic development officers go over there and have visits to do business. The Mayor will take two rooms there.”

Cr Crichlow suggested the move was sparked by the opening of light rail, the $6 billion Broadwater Cruise Ship project being planned on Southport’s doorstep and the business partnerships created by the $2.5 million Chinatown development.

“I think it’s a pretty good move. He’s fairly smart, isn’t he,” Cr Crichlow said.

But other councillors aren’t convinced and stunned why the Mayor would remove himself from the main administration at Bundall.

“It’s a bizarre move. It is taking the Mayor away from the councillors’ home. It means the rest of his office will be left at Evandale,” a councillor said.

“It’s puzzling and could be overly expensive. There was no consultation. It has left all the councillors stunned.”

Another councillor told the Bulletin: “He says it will come at no cost but we’re worried there will be hidden costs like the travel from Evandale for the councillors, and then there are the furnishings.”

Other council insiders suggest the move is an attempt by Cr Tate to appease the Southport business community and will win him further support from Cr Crichlow who is a key player with the vote on the cruise ship terminal split between warring councillors.

The office move will help Southport in its bid to be recognised as the city’s CBD and reduce the claim of Robina.

Both the Mayor and Cr Crichlow have clashed with Robina-based councillor Jan Grew on several issues leading to arguments inside and outside the chamber.

Cr Tate’s office was contacted but did not provide a comment before deadline late yesterday.
related.description: The Gold Coast’s mayor and his chief of staff are shifting from the Evandale headquarters to the historic Southport Town Hall, shocking and dividing his councillors.
related.standFirst: Councillors are divided over the Gold Coast’s mayor and chief of staff quitting the Evandale HQ for a Southport base.
related.subtitle: Gold Coast mayor Tom Tate and chief of staff Wayne Moran quit council HQ for Southport

related.body:
Mayor Tom Tate has issued the challenge to Transport Minister Scott Emerson, calling on him to get the trams, er, running for people during the Gold Coast Airport Marathon.

Cr Tate said marathoners should get a free ride on the trams, which are already running along the coastal strip for final testing.

NEWS: TRAMS AT A STANDSTILL 

NEWS: GOLDLINQ ADMITS MAJOR LIGHT RAIL RECONSTRUCTION 

The Gold Coast City Council would cover the difference between the cost of testing the near-empty trams and operating them with passengers on board, Cr Tate added.

“When there’s an event at Suncorp Stadium you get extra trains and buses there — the light rail should be activated freely for all marathon runners,” he said.

“That’s in line with state policy and goodwill.

“It will benefit the city and all those out-of-towners from Brisbane and overseas and be fantastic goodwill.”

However Mr Emerson’s office last night said it was still waiting on service providers to give their final tick-off — including the council.

“The independent verifier is unable to state when services can commence until it has received the sign-off from major utilities, including Telstra and Energex,” a statement said.

“As of this afternoon we are also still waiting on sign-off from Gold Coast Water, an entity of the Mayor’s own council.”

Major traffic disruptions are expected during the two-day event, which gained gold level status in January, placing it in the same category as the blockbuster New York, London and Berlin marathons.

Large swathes of the Gold Coast Highway, including the Sundale Bridge, will be closed for various times between 3.30am and 11am on both days of the event and runners have been encouraged to take advantage of free shuttle buses and regular Surfside routes.

Cr Tate said he did not believe the trams’ launch delay was due to safety concerns.

“There have been so many dignitaries, councillors, the State Government and media riding the light rail during the trial and if it wasn’t safe I’m sure those people wouldn’t have been allowed on.”
related.description: “BE like Nike and just do it.”
related.standFirst: GOLD Coast’s mayor wants the long-awaited tram service running for the city’s marathon weekend - with free rides for entrants.
related.subtitle: Gold Coast mayor Tom Tate says council would cover costs of free trams during marathon

Saint Stephen’s College principal Jamie Dorrington put forward the ideas to bypass Exit 54 yesterday during a meeting with Assistant Minister for Infrastructure Jamie Briggs and Federal Member for Forde Bert van Manen.

“This has been going on for years,” Mr Dorrington said. “What we need is for people to look outside the square.

“If we can’t get the intersection fixed then maybe we need to look at using drop off zones on the M1 and ferries, then run shuttle buses for the kids.”

Coomera Anglican College principal Mark Sly said he feared someone would be killed at the busy interchange because people often ignored the road rules and cut across the roundabout to avoid traffic.

“We have lots of young, inexperienced drivers from our school negotiating that intersection each day,” he said.

“Even buses cut across.”

Coomera Springs State School teacher Taylor Haley agreed, saying a death or major injury could happen any day.

Highland Reserve State School parents and citizens president Christine Main said there was a near miss on the spot between merging vehicles about every five minutes.

Teressa Foster, who started up the popular Coomera Community Facebook page and is LJ Hooker Coomera principal, said the problem interchange had a serious impact on business in the area.

Her views were supported by Gold Coast Marine identity Bill Barry-Cotter.

Mr Barry-Cotter told the Bulletin that his $530 million mixed-use development, earmarked for the Gold Coast marine precinct on the eastern side of the highway, would not go ahead until the problems at Exit 54 were solved.

The development, which is a joint-venture between Mr Barry-Cotter and developer Property Solutions, will create 4800 jobs during construction and 4600 jobs when complete.

“We are waiting for a deal to be done on Exit 54 before we move ahead,” he said.

The development of the $500 million Coomera Town Centre, which is estimated to generate 1200 construction jobs and a further 1600 permanent positions, has also been stalled because of the interchange.

Yesterday, Mr Briggs agreed to consider finding Federal Government funding for the $60 million road project, but said it should be a State Government responsibility.

He also visited one of the city’s worst intersections during his trip, Bundall and Ashmore roads, and was asked to help with the upgrade.

As the two men got to talking about their vices and what their poisons were, they both discovered they were methamphetamine users, the Supreme Court in Brisbane was told.

Soon after that ‘a gentleman by the name of Bat’ asked Mark Ramon Ashton if he could store some boxes at his townhouse and cook drugs inside.

EIGHT ARRESTED IN BURLEIGH DRUG RAID 

POLICE CRACK DOWN ON TATTOO PARLOURS 

Ashton, 44, this morning pleaded guilty to eight charges including allowing his home to be used to produce drugs as well as having a blank firing pistol, chemicals and glassware.

When police raided Ashton’s home in March last year they found the boxes had everything that was needed for a clandestine lab and the benches tested positive for meth.

Ashton told police “Bat” had twice cooked the drug in the garage and given him $1000 worth of product in exchange but he knew nothing about how to make it himself.

Ashton was sentenced to two years and nine months in jail, with immediate parole.

related.body:
The legal action will be a test case for the Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC), which wants to draw a line in the sand under short-term credit providers trying to dodge consumer protection legislation.

ASIC has launched civil proceedings in the Federal Court against Gold Coast-based Teleloans Pty Ltd and Finance & Loans Direct Pty Ltd after each claimed it was exempt from various consumer credit laws.

MORE GOLD COAST NEWS & GALLERIES 

The move is part of a crackdown by ASIC on payday lenders - ASIC aims to bring them into line with legislation relating to responsible lending and overcome avoidance of consumer protection laws and misleading advertising.

In the past two years, the corporate regulator has launched a string of legal actions against short-term lenders it said were overcharging customers with massive fees, using false or misleading advertising and breaching consumer credit laws.

The crackdown comes as the Federal Government last month moved to tighten lending laws to stop payday lenders exceeding caps on fees set a year ago, amid huge growth in the online payday lending ­sector.

The Government and consumer groups have raised concerns similar to ASIC’s that payday lenders who give credit to borrowers with poor credit histories and who can’t get a credit card are taking advantage of those who are most vulnerable.

Finance Minister Mathias Cormann last month said payday lenders, which can only lend up to $2000 for short periods, had found ways around the caps on fees set in July 2013 and were contravening 2009 laws which require them to assess whether borrowers would face significant hardship if granted a loan.

ASIC said yesterday that Teleloans and Finance & Loans Direct claimed they did not have to comply with certain consumer protection laws under the National Credit Act because their loans came under a short-term credit exemption.

ASIC alleges the companies, based on their business models, are not exempt and must comply with the obligations under the National Credit Act relating to caps on fees and charges for payday loans.

ASIC said in order for credit providers to meet the short-term credit exemption, a customer cannot be charged more than 5 per cent of the loan amount in fees and 24 per cent in interest per year.

It will allege the Gold Coast payday lenders had issued five loans in which the combined fees and charges were as high as 160 per cent of the loan amount.

ASIC deputy chairman Peter Kell said: “These proceedings will ensure that payday lenders do not deliberately structure their businesses to circumvent laws that protect consumers.

“This is particularly important as the consumers who access these small-amount loans can be financially vulnerable.”

The proceedings against Teleloans and Finance & Loans Direct are listed for a directions hearing in the Federal Court in Brisbane on July 25.
related.description: THE country’s corporate watchdog is taking legal action against two Gold Coast payday lenders, accusing them of avoiding responsible lending obligations after they charged customers fees as high as 160 per cent of the original loan.
related.standFirst: THE country’s corporate watchdog is taking ‘test case’ legal action against two Gold Coast payday lenders.

Rapid Action Policing commander Superintendent Jim Keogh said police had executed a search warrant at the Newcastle Street address following a tip-off.

“The Gold Coast Rapid Action Patrols received information which they enacted upon and that resulted in a search warrant being prepared and executed,” he said.

“They located dangerous drugs, a stolen motorbike, two rifles and a male person actively avoiding police who was arrested on return to prison warrants,” he said.

Supt Keogh said eight people were detained on site, with three people arrested in total on charges including possession of dangerous drugs, possession of stolen goods and firearms related offences.

The 12-year-old can’t get enough of the game and plays for hours every day, his eyes fixed on the screen. Love it or hate it, a series of Minecraft camps will be hosted on the Gold Coast for the first time these school holidays, a dream come true for Mitchell and fellow players.

Educational consultant Tim Wicks has been touring Australia for the past 18 months hosting BuddyVerse camps for budding gamers.

During the one-day camp, Mr Wicks uses Minecraft as an educational tool for children aged six to 14.

“When my son was seven years old, I watched him play the game,” Mr Wicks said.

“He gave me a tour and I watched him building a castle. I quickly realised Minecraft could be used in education so I launched these camps.”

Also a former assistant principal in a special school, Mr Wicks said the camps were very popular with autistic children.

The camps will be held on July 5 and 8 in Surfers Paradise and on July 7 and 8 in Broadbeach.

The cost is $80 per child per day, and family discounts are available.

For more information and to book visit http://minecraftcamps.net/events/
categories: /display/goldcoastbulletin.com.au/Gold Coast Bulletin/Gold Coast News and Galleries/

The Bruce Bishop carpark on Beach Rd in Surfers Paradise was free parking for the first two hours but now drivers are slugged $2.30 an hour.

CHINA BIG-WIG ON VERGE OF SURFERS PARADISE JEWEL DEAL 

A Gold Coast City Council spokesman said the free parking was introduced as a temporary measure while construction work was under way on the light rail system.

Surfers Paradise is not the only area to face parking fee hikes — with all other council carparks going up 40 an hour on July 1.

Traders warn the price increase will be bad for business as customers struggle to find any free parking in Surfers Paradise.

John Manson, who manages Za’ba Bottle Shop said many customers used the Bruce Bishop carpark.

“It obviously affects business — they’re not going to come here for a bargain then go and pay $4 or $5 for a car park. It ceases to be a bargain then,” he said.

Mr Manson said the business had already suffered with the light rail construction.

Pete McLaughlin said he used the Bruce Bishop car park regularly as he took clients to Timezone.

“It cost $9.20 today and it normally costs us $4.80, so it’s nearly double. I don’t think I’ll be coming back — I think I’ll try the parking out the front.”

Surfers Paradise Alliance chief executive Mike Winlaw said it was decided about 18 months ago the free parking would support traders during the light rail construction.

“We’ve always known it was going to come off post-light rail,” he said.

“It’s a commercial decision and charging $2.30 an hour for a CBD environment is very cheap compared to Brisbane.”

The Chevron Renaissance Shopping Centre is the only free undercover carpark in Surfers. Circle on Cavill also offers two hours for customers who spend more than $10.
categories: /display/goldcoastbulletin.com.au/Gold Coast Bulletin/Gold Coast News and Galleries/

The 22-year-old P-plater had been partying on Orchid Avenue in a midweek blow out on June 12 and was four times over the legal limit when he was busted behind the wheel of a Holden Cruise, driving past a no entry sign without P-plates showing.

TITANS FORWARD STOOD DOWN OVER DRINK DRIVING INCIDENT 

Police on foot patrols stopped the car outside the Orchid Avenue police station and recorded his blood alcohol level at 0.193.

The moment of stupidity cost the rookie lock dearly with the Titans slamming him with $12,000 in fines and a two match suspension costing him $6000 in fees which ended this week.

He will also have to complete an enforced alcohol management course.

The pain kept coming for Carter today in the Southport Magistrates Court.

Solicitor Campbell MacCallum said Carter was repentant and said he had an incentive to change his ways, as the club had threatened to tear up his contract if he didn’t meet condtions of the club’s sanctions.

He also knew he would suffer hardship with a mandatory licence disqualification.

“He is very embarrassed and ashamed about the incident,” he said.

Magistrate Michael O’Driscoll said his risk-taking behaviour could have cost the lives of Queenslanders and also his career.

He sentenced him with a $1400 fine and disqualified him from driving for 12 months.

The Titans club is expected to make a statement later today.
categories: /display/goldcoastbulletin.com.au/Gold Coast Bulletin/Gold Coast News and Galleries/

related.body:
You fear they are going to sound glib, that they won’t do that person justice. And you know the person you are talking about wouldn’t want to be labelled with those terms either.

That he saw himself as just a regular bloke.

But Scott Sullivan wasn’t ordinary.

He was brave, he was selfless, he was inspiring. He was the one that covered my rent when as a broke backpacker, I moved into a share house in London. He was the one with the questionable affection for the Spice Girls. Yes, seriously.

The one with his yellow bomb called “Betsy” parked out the front of that southeast London home that ferried us to rugby games. A home filled with the optimism of being in your early 20s with barely a responsibility in the world with Europe and beyond at your doorstep. The kind of freedom you later realise is fleeting, a place where friendships are forged.

Scott or Sully, as everyone knows him, and I became mates in that house. I was just one of his many. Sully was also a son, a brother. He was to become a loving husband to Sarah, a father of two beautiful children, Abbey and Charlie.

He played rugby, an energetic half-back for Sunnybank, he loved to bark orders at the forwards. He had a special affection for the Rabbitohs, the Reds and Wallabies. He enjoyed a beer or, occasionally, some kind of fruity cocktail. Yes, seriously. He loved his Suncorp job. He loved his life.

But tragically, that life was cut short. Sully died two months ago. It was the end of a more than three-year battle with motor neurone disease, a cruel condition that kills the nerves that send signals to the muscles that allow us to move, eat, speak and breathe.

There is no known cure and life expectancy is three to five years after diagnosis. In late April, Sully fell and hit his head at his Brisbane home. He never recovered.

In the two months since his death there has been tears and laughter, as those that knew and loved Sully started to come to terms with him no longer being here. We’ve all thought a lot about Scott, about friendship and family and what is important in life. It’s been a confronting experience for many of us in our 30s and 40s who had never experienced the grief of losing a friend.

Now I have had a chance to reflect on the life of Scott Sullivan, if there is one word that I believe does sum him up, it is “teacher”. And we will still be learning the lessons he taught us for years to come.

During a speech at the inaugural MND Gala Ball in Brisbane in 2011, one of his many initiatives, he mentioned that he often told the risk team he managed at Suncorp that “setbacks were an opportunity to learn”, This was his approach to his diagnosis. Regardless of the outcome he was going to make every moment count.

Once Sully was told he had a terminal illness in 2010 he exposed his life to the world to give them greater understanding of what he and his family were going through.

In a similar situation I and probably many others would have retreated into their shell.

Not Sully. He did this, not for his own sake, but for others.

Realising that there was not enough support for those suffering MND, resources for their family members or funds for research, he established the MND and Me Foundation.

Not knowing where to turn himself, he immediately set about putting in place a structure to help ease the stress for others when confronted with the same diagnosis as him.

He was being educated and we in turn by him.

His fundraising efforts were tireless. Gala balls, corporate swimming and golf days, media appearances, he even rode a specially modified bike with fellow sufferer Ian Davis, a Melbourne doctor, from Brisbane to Sydney to spread the MND message.

I see the smile on his face as he and Ian cycled into Manly in Sydney, just over 12 months ago. The beers were well earned that night.

Two weeks pedalling took a toll on his health but, realising time was of the essence, Sully was desperate to ride to raise funds for and awareness about MND.

For the same reason he completed two Gold Coast Half Marathons after being diagnosed, the first in 2011 and then again in 2012 and, as his legs started to lose strength, he managed the 5.7km challenge last year.

Hundreds of thousands of dollars has been poured into research and on June 21 Sully’s vision, the Queensland MND Centre, a place for sufferers, carers, researchers and volunteers, officially opened.

To me, this resource, which will help thousands of people cope with the most traumatic event in their life, will be a way that they too will come to know Sully in the same way his friends and family knew him.

Despite not being with us anymore, this centre is testament to his generosity and desire to help others. The kind of bloke that would pay the rent of a broke backpacker at a share house in London.

The last time I saw Scott was the day after the most recent MND Gala Ball in March. Everyone was aware of the toll that the disease was having. He had already had a fall which he was unable to break because his arms no longer functioned. His speech was becoming increasingly hard to understand. For all of us it was heartbreaking but if Sully and his amazing wife Sarah could cope then so could we.

That afternoon we sat chatting at his house as he drank some sickly alcoholic cider out of a straw. “It’s my new drink,” he told me. He was like that with his drinks. Last time I joined him for breakfast he ordered an iced chocolate with whipped cream. That day, our kids played together and we watched the footy. He was more than likely secretly enjoying the fact that my Eels lost in the last minute.

I realised how lucky I was just to have an hour to sit there and chat and enjoy his company.

When I was leaving I said I was looking forward to seeing him on the Gold Coast as one of the dozens of his friends and family that were going to hit the road and raise money for the foundation at the marathon weekend.

Sully’s fall happened a month later. We have mourned and continue to but while he won’t be at the starting line this week as he has been for the past three years, trust me, he will be right there running every step with us.

related.body:
But local councillor Daphne McDonald said there was nothing Gold Coast City Council could do because the beach was theirs to take.

Cr McDonald said official surveys showed that the boundary of the blocks owned by several residents went well past the waterline and they paid rates on the whole space – including the beach section. “They are quite entitled to claim that bit of beach,” she said.

NEWS: ‘NOT THE NICEST’ BUT NO CAT KILLER 

NEWS: KATELYN’S LAST HOURS 

WEATHER: SO COLD EVEN THE DOGS ARE RUGGING UP 

Cr McDonald said residents might have also taken the step of putting up fencing because they were legally responsible for the beach portion of their block.

Long-term resident Leonie Clarke, who owns a modest property on Jefferson Lane, said she would be willing to give the sand back if it meant getting a discount on her rates.

“We pay about $10,000 a year here,” she said.

“When I found out that we owned part of the beach as well, I went to council to see if it was right. We thought that we could not own past the watermark.

“We were willing to give it back to council, but they said it was our responsibility and we had to pay for it.

“If we could get a discount, we would still give it back. It is expensive and a hassle to look after.”

Ms Clarke said she did not bother fencing off the beach she owned, but understood why her neighbours went to the effort.

“I am happy for people to sunbake on our bit of beach,” she said.

“I don’t care ... just as long as they don’t bother us. But I think it is important for people to understand that it is our property.”

Shane Watt, who has lived at Palm Beach for more than 20 years, said he would take the same step if he was lucky enough to own a property near the city’s rich and famous on Jefferson Lane.

“I would like to see no development on the beach at all,” she said.

“But that is not possible and if I owned one of those houses, I would have the beach fenced off too.”

Mitch Golledge agreed, saying he would love to have one of the prime spots on Jefferson Lane with a partial beach of his own.

Council first became aware of the boundaries of the properties on Jefferson Lane when they fined a dog owner for having the animal off the leash a few years ago.

They later found out that the dog owner also owned the section of beach where the fine was delivered and it could not be enforced.

related.body:
By 7am it has risen to 12.5C, with a “feels like” of 11C and the Bureau of Meteorology predicts there be a top of 22C on the Coast today.

MORE GOLD COAST NEWS & GALLERIES 

As lifeguards were put through their paces yesterday morning temperatures dropped to a bitter 3.4C, but meteorologists say the next warmer.

“The next few days will be warmer and mostly sunny,” Weather Zone meteorologist Brett Butschkie said.

But the warmer temperatures will bring rain with a 50 per cent of a shower tomorrow and a 30 per cent chance of one on Saturday.

Meanwhile, a Gold Coast lifeguard’s life might seem glamorous but it’s not all fun and games.

On one of the coldest days we have had this year, all the city’s lifeguards battled their way through their gruelling annual winter fitness test at Greenmount.

Every one of our beach and surf watchers was tested through a tough 750m swim, 1.6km run and 800m board paddle.

The course had to be completed in 26 minutes which all managed to do, despite the tog-shrinking cold.

The test starts with a swim from Greenmount to Coolangatta, followed by a run to Greenmount and back. 

The test finishes with an 800m rescue board paddle to Greenmount. City of Gold Coast chief lifeguard Warren Young said the permanent lifeguards have to pass tough ­physical tests twice a year.

“Our lifeguard service is recognised as a benchmark service, so it’s vitally important we have these tests regularly to uphold our high standards,” he said.

“It is a very challenging course, but our city lifeguards are great athletes and fitness is very important for them to do their job.”

Peta Newbold, 19, was the youngest female lifeguard to take the test and she was proud to have beaten a few of the guys around the challenging course.

“Running was the toughest for me because I’ve never really trained for it,” she said.

“All the lifeguards are pretty fit all year long but it’s good to test yourself.

“We all want to impress the bosses so there might have been some extra training going on.”

Mayor Tom Tate said the test was another way to make sure beachgoers were kept safe.

“Our lifeguards are some of the best on the planet, and this tough winter fitness test really keeps them up to scratch,” he said. “When people come to relax and play on our world-famous beaches, they know they’re being looked after by an elite team of professionals.”

related.body:
One tram has been sitting near the intersection of Surfers Paradise Blvd and Clifford St, guarded by security for four days.

How long do you think it will take for the tram to take passengers? Let us know below. 

GOLDLINQ ADMITS LIGHT RAIL CONCRETE CUT AND BASE MODIFIED 

Since Saturday, trams have been forced to run on a shortened track from the Gold Coast University Hospital to Southport Station.

The hurdle comes as speculation continues about when trams will start taking passengers with no official launch date set.

Surfers Paradise traders were told by email of a July 13 launch date for the light rail but then later told the launch date was still to be determined.

GoldLinQ said the incident would not delay trams from taking passengers.

Gold Coast Water work on the burst main finished on Sunday and GoldLinQ is now in the process of repairing the footpath and roadway.

Grace Selway, who works at the BWS on Surfers Paradise Boulevard, said the tram had been sitting in the same spot for the last four days.

“I think it’s a joke, the whole thing.” “I thought it would have been fixed by now.”

She said no one had come to let them know why the tram was stopped opposite the shop.

related.body:
Christie, 19, is accused of killing a cat, cutting off its paws and head and torching a car outside a home in Arundel on June 17.

After the bail application was rejected in Southport Magistrates Court his friends were quick to defend Christie – whom they described as a “decent bloke”.

NEWS: ACCUSED CAT KILLER LOSES JOB 

Josh Westhead said Christie was a good mate who was “incapable of mutilating a cat”.

“He’s not the nicest guy but there’s not a chance he’d mutilate a cat,” he said. 

“He loves to get on the (drink) and he loves to have a good time. I’ve only come up here today to support him as I don’t believe he’s done it at all.”

Another friend, Matt Cooper, said while Christie “didn’t look like the nicest person” he was a good person inside.

“He’s always tried his best to be a decent bloke,” he said.

“I’m really upset that they think he’s a threat to society – he’s a good bloke and I don’t think they should have held him in jail until his next court case. It takes a twisted person to do that to an animal and that’s not Jordan.”

Mr Cooper said Christie would be “devastated” to lose his job following the incident.

“As long as I’ve known him he’s always been working – he’s always been a hard worker, always been to work on time,” he said.

Christie applied for bail yesterday but the application was rejected because of an “unacceptable risk” of him reoffending.

The additional charge of extortion was added yesterday morning to the three other charges against Christie – including arson, killing of an animal and wilful damage.

The maximum penalty for the arson charge is life in jail.

Christie’s concrete rendering boss Nathan Avery has been charged with extorting Lewis Hallam and using a phone or internet service to harass him in the lead-up to the attack. Mr Avery was released on bail on condition that he does not contact Christie.

The court was told Christie was put on an 18-month probation on November 8 last year for assault occasioning bodily harm.

No conviction was recorded from the incident but Christie was given 150 hours of community service – of which he had completed 42 hours.

The court also heard Christie had lost his job as a result of the bail conditions for Mr Avery.

Christie’s lawyer Andrew Moloney told the court the charges against his client didn’t involve any “actual physical violence towards any person”.

Mr Moloney suggested his client would be at risk in custody because of his injuries – stating as he has five plates in his jaw he was “going to be a target”.

Christie will next appear in Southport Magistrates Court on August 22.

The 19-year-old mother was robbed at knifepoint in broad daylight while pushing her 15-month-old baby in a pram in Southport on Monday.

The robber approached the mother in Eugaree Street near the intersection with Spendlove Street about 1pm.

RECOGNISE THIS FACE? CLICK HERE TO CONTACT POLICE 

It is alleged he demanded cash before pulling a knife.

The frightened woman handed over $500 and the man fled the scene on foot, last seen running towards Ferry Road.

He is described as being in his early 20’s, Caucasian in appearance, of thin build with strawberry blonde shoulder length hair.

He was wearing a dark hooded jumper with “Compton” insignia on the front (similar to that pictured), black long pants and thongs at the time of the heist.

The woman was shaken but fortunately no one was physically injured as a result of the robbery.

Anyone with information which could assist with this matter should contact Crime Stoppers anonymously via 1800 333 000 or crimestoppers.com.au 24hrs a day.

Police have been told that a man entered Provincial Home Living on Ryrie St on June 21 at 3.15pm.

A Victoria Police spokeswoman said a man browsed the store until a number of other shoppers paid for their goods and left.

The man selected two glass jars and approached the counter, where a shop assistant wrapped his purchases.

While standing at the counter, the man allegedly produced a pair of scissors and demanded cash from the female attendant.

He then took an amount of cash from the till and ran from the store about 3.40pm.

The wanted man is described as being aged in his mid teens to his early 20s, unshaven with blonde hair.

At the time of the robbery he was wearing a hooded top and black pants.

Anyone with information is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

related.body:
The Geelong Magistrates’ Court heard Daniel Lee, 30, sold the rental goods and reported the thefts to raise money for a night out.

He pleaded guilty to three counts of theft, obtaining property by deception and making a false report.

Police prosecutor Sergeant Peter Beard said Lee signed a three-year lease agreement for a Sony 3D home theatre system and blue ray player in November last year before taking them to Cash Converters two weeks later.

“He was loaned $40 against the goods and never returned for them,” Sgt Beard said.

“On December 17, 2013, Lee entered another lease agreement for an LG TV.

“On March 14, this year he rang Radio Rentals and asked if the goods were stolen would they be replaced by (the company’s) insurance, and they informed him they would.”

Two days later Lee reported both televisions stolen to the police and later the rental company.

Paul Houston, for Lee, said his client let himself down after three years crime-free.

“We acknowledge he planned and thought about this but he was bound to get caught,” he said.

Mr Houston said Lee, a former drug addict, was “battling” on the disability pension and wanted to raise funds to “have a good time”.

He said Lee realised he was risking a jail term given his prior convictions.

Magistrate John Lesser sentenced Lee to three months jail wholly suspended for a year.

“I accept life is not easy for you but your behaviour is totally unacceptable,” he said.

“You can’t get out of your financial problems that way.”

In Touch magazine is claiming the actor entered the Passages rehab facility in May and was visited by her wife Ellen DeGeneres every weekend.

The US publication does not speculate as to why the Arrested Development star sought treatment, though she has publicly detailed prior battles with an eating disorder.

Last December on her talk show, Ellen DeGeneres slammed rumours her marriage to Portia (formerly de Rossi) was in trouble.

“There’s not one ounce of truth to any of it. I’m very happily married,” DeGeneres said.

“The only thing we ever argue about is who loves who more.”

Born Amanda Lee Rogers, Portia DeGeneres had her big break playing Nelle Porter in late 90s show Ally McBeal.

The actor and Ellen DeGeneres married at their LA home in August 2008. They tied the knot during the brief window when it was legal for same-sex couples to get married in the US state of California. At the time of the wedding, Ellen DeGeneres described herself as the luckiest girl in the world.

“She’s (de Rossi) officially off the market. No one else gets her,’ the talk show host told People magazine.

related.body:
The department is appealing for people who may never have considered a prison career, including those with experience in trades and services.

Jamie is one prison worker which Corrections Victoria hopes will serve as an example to potential employees.

The 29-year-old spent over a decade in the forklift industry before deciding to apply for a job as a prison officer.

For Jamie, the lure of greater job security and the chance to progress his career were what cemented his decision.

“I enjoy being a positive role model to prisoners and other officers, and having the self-satisfaction of performing my duties in a professional manner,” he said.

Corrections Victoria chairman Jan Shuard hopes Jamie’s story will appeal to those who have constantly dismissed the idea of working in a jail.

“When it comes to prisons, people have preconceived ideas about the work and the environment, which are often based on stereotypes you might see in a Hollywood blockbuster,” Ms Shuard said.

“They don’t match the reality of Victoria’s modern prison system, so we want people to look beyond the stereotypes and see the benefits of this rewarding career.”

Barwon Prison general manager Jonathan Howe said the opportunity to make a difference was a major drawcard.

“You might be a teacher who needs a change of direction, or an office worker who’s tired of spending their days behind a desk,” he said.

“These roles offer a change of pace, tapping into each person’s existing skills and experience.”

The recruitment drive is part of a broader expansion of Victoria’s correctional system, with a new 40-bed high security unit at Barwon Prison expected to be completed in the next two years.

Corio firefighter Nick Callan said a mechanical business in Seaforth St appeared to have been hit by vandals with about 300 litres of oil spilling into the semi-residential street, off Seabreeze Pde.

A valve at the bottom of reinforced plastic containers storing the oil had been opened.

“It was largely contained early on and didn’t spill into the storm water drains,’’ Mr Callan said.

“We were assisted by the City of Greater Geelong in the clean up.”

Firefighters and council officers were called about 7am Wednesday.

Anyone with information is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

related.body:
Geelong Magistrate Ron Saines yesterday found Carl Bolton “crossed the line” when he “chested” Luke McGinty and punched him in the face in August last year.

The 33-year-old was stood down without pay following the watch-house incident but is now able to apply to be reinstated after being spared a conviction.

Mr Saines said while Bolton had shown no remorse for his behaviour, which was captured on CCTV and witnessed by five other officers, and had taken up valuable court time with his two-day hearing, it would be “wrong to deprive (him) of the opportunity to continue in the police force”.

Victoria Police will decide Bolton’s future.

In finding Bolton guilty, Mr Saines said the victim Mr McGinty was “clearly and obviously uncooperative”, abusive and taunting but no other officers believed he was a threat.

He found Bolton’s evidence was “less than reliable” and couldn’t accept his claim that he didn’t realise Mr McGinty was handcuffed until after four officers had restrained him on the floor.

“The accused sought to exaggerate or overstate the sense of danger he felt,” Mr Saines said.

“Even if (Mr McGinty) did say he hated police, taunted some or all of them, I find it was confined to verbal (abuse) and he was not a risk of causing harm to them at any time.”

Mr Saines found of the four episodes that made up the charge, only two could be proved beyond reasonable doubt.

He found Bolton’s alleged attempt to knee Mr McGinty and Mr McGinty’s responding alleged bid to kick Bolton were made in the context of both believing they had to defend themselves.

The court heard Bolton, the most senior officer on staff that night, tried to punch Mr McGinty twice, but accidentally hit a police colleague the second time.

Mr Saines said even Mr McGinty’s response to being assaulted and further restrained was “more lighthearted than sinister”.

Bolton’s lawyer described the assault as “15 seconds of behaviour uncharacteristic to 33 years of service”.

“He’s achieved a great deal of good in the Colac community,” he said, listing the creation of the Beechy Trek with disadvantaged youth and anti-drugs competition Ride to the Rock and numerous certificates of appreciation.

Mr Saines said Bolton’s good character and years of service in an “onerous and thankless job” mitigated against his poor decision.

“You crossed the line; you didn’t cross it by a terribly long way or in a way that caused any significant injury but nevertheless you crossed a line that everyone in the criminal justice system understands,” he said.

Bolton was fined $1500 without conviction.
related.description: A COLAC police sergeant found guilty of punching a handcuffed prisoner may still keep his job.
related.standFirst: A COLAC police sergeant found guilty of punching a handcuffed prisoner may still keep his job.
related.subtitle: Colac sergeant Carl Bolton guilty of striking handcuffed man

related.body:
Victorian Greens leader Greg Barber said it was important the 400,000 regional Victorians living along the line had access to fast and frequent train travel to places other than Melbourne.

“The Greens support a staged reintroduction of passenger services with existing stations reopened if possible and other new low-cost stations constructed where required,” Mr Barber said.

“We know that people want to travel between regional cities for work, education, health and recreation, so it isn’t enough for trains to only connect with Melbourne.”

However the party has not provided any of their own costings for the project, except to say that consultant and lobby group activist Noel Laidlaw completed an independent study which found reopening the line to a basic service would cost around $90 million. 

The state government Rail Revival Feasibility Study estimated the cost of a full reopening would be between $760-$935 million.

Mr Barber said the first stage should be to reopen the Geelong to Ballarat rail line, with new low-cost stations at Bannockburn and Meredith to provide a commuter service for those fast-growing communities.

They estimate a 65-minute moderate-speed service could be achieved with some new tracks, upgrades to level crossings and one passing loop.

Stage two would be to repair and rebuild the train line between Maryborough and Castlemaine and stage three would include upgrading to a faster and more regular service that could continue on existing tracks to Bendigo. 

“While we would love super-fast Goldfields trains, an affordable basic service would be preferable to none at all and still fast enough to compete with car travel,” Mr Barber said.

“V/Line buses are the only public transport for many towns along the line but they are unable to offer a viable commuter service.”

Mr Barber said freight trains still use sections of the track and could share some of the upgrade costs.

He said a return to train travel would encourage more people to move to regional Victoria and be more beneficial for residents than the $18 billion East-West toll road.

Community group Rail Revival Alliance has been lobbying the Government to reopen the line since last year.

About 200 people attended a rally at the now unused Carisbrook Station, about 150km north of Geelong, in December last year.

related.body:
Using specially modified infra-red cameras and image-enhancement techniques, Mr Moore, 53, has been shining a new light on local landmarks from the Waterfront bollards to Balyang Sanctuary.

He has recently compiled hundreds of stunning images into an 82-page book prototype titled Unseen Geelong, which he is hoping to launch later this year.

“Geelong I think is really undervalued, there’s a lot of beauty there with or without infra-red, and honestly people miss it, they just don’t see it,” he said.

“I like to capture things you can’t see, or show a different view of things you can see.”

Geelong’s “Lightsmith” started taking photography seriously in 2007 when he took a redundancy from Ford, and said most of his photos are taken on his travels between Lara and Geelong to visit his elderly parents in hospital.

“I was always interested in general light photography but I have to say I wasn’t very good at it, it was almost as though something was missing and I could never really work out what it was until I started taking infra-red,” he said.

“I saw my first infra-red picture and said ‘that’s it, that’s what I should be doing’, so I look for opportunities everywhere.”

Mr Moore said he sat down with Geelong mayor Darryn Lyons last week who was supportive of the project, and Moore hoped others would appreciate the images.

“It came to me that I had all these pictures of Geelong, I don’t want them to just sit there I want people to see them,” he said.

“I thought I should put them together in a book as a way of making Geelong more accessible, and maybe it will make people notice things a little more.”

To check out more of Mr Moore’s striking photographs visit thelightsmith.com.
related.description: LARA hobby photographer Christopher Moore wants to reintroduce locals to the city they live in.
related.standFirst: A LARA snapper has used specially modified infra-red cameras to shine a new light on Geelong.

related.body:
The internet is swarming with rumours about what features the iPhone 6 will offer.

With the new device expected to be launched in two months, news.com.au has pulled together the best early indications of what to expect with the new model.

Although Apple hasn’t confirmed any of these rumours, leaked images suggest these are the most likely features.

Here’s what to expect from the iPhone 6.

1. Super-size me

The most prevalent rumour about the new iPhone 6 is that Apple will, in fact, release two versions of the smartphone. There is set to be two different-sized models to be launched at the same time: a standard 4.7-inch model and an oversized 5.5-inch. The larger version is expected to be $100 more expensive but offer a better camera and a higher storage capacity.

2. More brain power

The larger iPhone could have up to 128GB in storage capacity, according to Mac Rumours. Tech site 9to5Mac reports that the smaller version is expected to be released with 32GB and 64GB storage options.

3. Size matters

A larger body means a larger screen. As we reported early in the week, Australian market research firm Telsyte has found that Apple could lose almost half its potential iPhone 6 customer base if it simply pumped out another smartphone with roughly the same screen size. So it’s pleasing to hear the customers will have the choice of a 4.7-inch or a 5.5-inch display, which eclipses the iPhone 5S’s four inches. This will allow the iPhone 6 to better compete with the Samsung Galaxy S5 (5.1 inches), Sony Xperia Z2 (5.2 inches), LG G3 (5.5 inches) and Nokia Lumia 930 Windows 8 (5 inches). The screen could also go virtually to the edges of the phone for the first time.

iPhone 6 leak: metal case reveals same new #iPhone #design lines - http://t.co/3tL468vYfg pic.twitter.com/E6HKn3YLLs

— HiddenRadio (@HiddenRadio) July 2, 2014 

4. This baby’s got curves

The new model is likely to do away with the flat edges on the iPhone 4 and 5 and adopt a more curvaceous body. Expect a rounder design with curved edges.

5. Slimline 

The body of the phone is also expected to be much thinner than the iPhone 5S and more closely resemble the iPod touch. The slimline design is also expected to result in a lighter device.

6. Glossy 

Leaked photographs show that the screen and body has a sleek, glossy finish. There are also rumours that the screen will be made of sapphire crystal, which will make it more resistant to scratches.

7. What shall I call thee?

The new model is believed to be called the iPhone Air.

8. Snap happy

The iPhone 6 is expected to have a better camera with more megapixels so it can better compete with its rivals. The phone is also likely to have superior image stabilisation, which helps users take clearer pictures while moving.

9. I can see clearly now

The 4.7-inch screen is rumoured to have a clearer 1704-by-960 pixel resolution.

10. Camera switcheroo

The front-facing camera appears to be back on the left-side of the ear speaker, similar to where it was for the iPhone 4. (It was above the earpiece for the iPhone 5.)

The latest rumours suggest the iPhone 6 will be launched on September 9.
related.description: A BIGGER screen. A choice of sizes. A curvaceous new design.

related.subtitle: 10 things you need to know about the new Apple iPhone 6

Video shows that the man pulls out in front of the pack of bikies at which point they block the couple’s car in and furiously start shoving him around.

When they throw him on to the bonnet of the car his girlfriend gets out of the vehicle.

Just as things looked set to get worse, the man gets down on one knee and asks the stunned girl to marry him.

Not only that but these rough and tough bikers reveal a bouquet of flowers for the woman and start applauding.

The video was posted in Russia and while the couple has not been identified, their love story has clocked up more than 800,000 views.

Unconventional? Sure. But it is one wedding proposal this bride-to-be will never forget.

related.body:
55-year-old Sue Wilkins said she was sorry for mocking the language and facial features of an Asian woman on a Sydney to Newcastle train on Wednesday afternoon.

The incident was filmed by a passenger and posted on YouTube. The woman became angry at two young children when they didn’t give their seats up for her.

She then began to abuse other passengers, including a man who was sitting next to an Asian woman. “Who is this little jerk-off? He can only get a gook - he can’t even get a regular girlfriend. It is so sad,” she said, as passengers groaned in offence.

“Is it really that small that you can’t get an Aussie girl? Poor man. Look at this bogan, he has got a gook.”

After she caused a scene inside the carriage, police spoke to the woman when she alighted at Strathfield in Sydney’s west.

“There were police patrolling from a local area command,” police transport command assistant commissioner Max Mitchell told reporters.

“They were there for another matter, unaware of the full circumstances of this situation.

Police spoke to the woman but decided to let her “go about her journey”, Mr Mitchell said.

Mr Mitchell didn’t know why she was allowed to walk free but stressed the woman would be charged for her “abhorrent and unacceptable behaviour”.

“The person responsible will be prosecuted,” he said.

If found guilty of offensive behaviour, she faces a $500 fine.

“This person has committed offensive behaviour,” Mr Mitchell said.

“It is a crime that we will not tolerate, particularly in regards to the racial motivation behind this incident.”

The woman told ninemsn she had a rotten day and had been scammed out of $100,000 from a man she had met on a dating website.

Sydney Trains chief Howard Collins said he was “shocked” by the rant and the company would be working with police to investigate.

“I’m just amazed - we’ve got to stamp this out,” he said.

In April, Rebecca Blessington, 28, was charged after allegedly racially abusing two Asian women on a train from Town Hall to Bondi

Jade Marr boarded the train at Central Station when Ms Wilkins told her two children and two nephews, aged between four and 10, to get off the seats.

“I was in shock at the time. I’m probably more angry today that someone could be that low and attack a child or anyone else.

“Everyone took it seriously but it actually became quite comical, it was just ridiculous.”

“We were just thinking ‘what are you doing’? It was unbelievable.

“She called the police and her goal was to get my children removed from the train because they were sitting on a seat.

“We don’t catch the train very often so the kids were worried they had done the wrong thing. 

POLICE CHARGE WOMAN OVER RACISTS RANT 

RACIST RANT ON SYDNEY BUS CAUGHT ON CAMERA 

TAMARAMA SURF VICTIM WAS FATHER OF TWO 

THREE CHARGED OVER CROWN WITNESS KILLING 

“They were frightened that the police were coming to get them. I just kept telling them that they hadn’t done anything wrong and that this woman was not responding the way that normal people do.

“My nephew was really concerned about the words she was using and the way she spoke to the other woman.

“The kids just didn’t understand why someone would say that.”

Ms Wilkins was in apologetic mood this afternoon.

“I had a rotten day,’ she told Ninemsn . ‘I’ve been chasing work for quite some time now,” she said.

“It’s awful what I said to that woman, I do agree,” Ms Wilkins said.

Wilkins became enraged at some young children after they did not give into her demands for a seat on a morning Central Coast train.

She then started abusing passengers including an Asian woman and a man who stood up for her.

“Who is this little jerk off he can only get a gook, he can’t even get a regular girlfriend — it is so sad,” she said.

“Is it really that small that you can’t get an Aussie girl? Poor man. Look at this bogan he has got a gook — look at it. She probably thinks he is rich.”

The video was posted onto YouTube by user Kareem Abdul.

“On the Central coast & Newcastle line in peak hour during school holidays,” Abdul wrote.

“I started filming as the woman became aggressive toward some children (ages 12 and under) who refused to vacate their seats when she had demanded.

“This video begins just after she had started screaming expletives into the face of the upset kids and the mother of the children got up to stand in between the lady and her kids.

“The lady then assaulted the mother and a young dude who gave up his seat for her and now the lady is calling the police … Because the kids didn’t move?”

More than 1200 people braved wet and cold conditions to see Fevola pull on a Cheetah’s guernsey on Saturday and West president Simon Cavallo said the club would consider luring another marquee man.

“I won’t say no to anything,” Cavallo said.

“I’d like to leave our options open. He’s probably the biggest drawcard, I don’t think there’s any bigger than Fev.”

Rain put a dampener on the Cheetahs’ plans to lure thousands to West Oval for the EJ Whitten Foundation fundraiser.

“It could’ve been spectacular, but it was 11C and the showers came at one o’clock when everyone would’ve been decided whether or not to go,” Cavallo said.

“So it was a bit disappointing but we’ll definitely try something similar in the future.”

Fevola was spotted at Home House nightclub in the early hours of Saturday morning but Cavallo said the club was unfazed but his late night out.

“Fev’s been in the business a long time and he knows his capabilities and he has a bit of a rock star attitude,” Cavallo said.

“We would trust that he undertakes his actions knowing his capabilities. On the day he was completely fine, so we’ve got no problems with anything the night before as far as his performance was concerned.

“The delivery and conditions and the quality opponents that he played on made it difficult for him, so I’m not sure that if he went to bed at 8.30pm it would’ve made much of a difference.”

Fevola missed a club breakfast but Cavallo said the former AFL star was not required at the function.

“There’s a lot of rumours going around and I’m not sure what’s true but from 12 noon when he arrived, Fev was a complete professional,” Cavallo said.

“He was everything and more than we could’ve asked for. He signed close to 100 autographs and posed for an equal amount of photos with his fans. He was awesome.

“He was enthusiastic and positive and never said no to anyone. He gave his complete time and attention to everyone.”
related.description: GEELONG West has not ruled out bringing Brendan Fevola back into the fold in the future after what the club described as a successful one-off appearance.

related.body:
Before his death in December last year, William “Bill” Howard amassed a huge range of collectables that auctioneers expect to fetch more than $500,000.

Howard’s items ranged from the valuable to the bizarre, with possessions including stuffed bears and a 1920s strongman machine.

Geelong businessman Mark Ward is one of the few people the 84-year-old spoke to.

He will host the auction at his Ballarat Mill Markets venue after being approached by Howard’s wife, Barbara.

“I was one of the very few people who Bill invited inside for a cup of tea,” Ward said.

According to Ward, the sale has created international interest.

“It’s probably the best collectable auction to ever be sold from one vendor in Australia,” Ward said.

One of the antiques expected to receive strong bids is a giant handpainted poster from the Palais Theatre, which Ward anticipates will be sold for more than $10,000.

While Howard’s treasures were eye-catching and rare, Ward said his friend did not often show them to people.

“Everyone knew of Bill’s collection, but the real quirky thing is no-one was ever able to see it,” he said.

Howard’s obsession with collectables dated back to the early 1970s, when he settled in Ballarat with his wife and four children after years spent travelling the world.

Shortly after becoming an auctioneer at Mid Western Auctions, Howard bought out the business.

He regularly held general auctions which became known for his top hat and the 1935 Dodge hearse parked outside, where an artificial leg protruding from a coffin was a common sight.

Howard eventually retired and sold his business in 1984, but continued collecting items until his death last year.

During his lifetime, his home near Sovereign Hill became known as an overflowing “Aladdin’s Cave” filled with some of the most unique collectables.

But despite the money Howard could have made by selling his possessions, Ward said that was not an option for the hoarder.

“All his life, he never sold anything,” Ward said. “He just collected.”

The man tasked with auctioning off Howard’s prized collection is renowned seller Graham Lancaster, who has flown with a team from Queensland for the two-day sale.

More than 880 lots will be sold across Saturday and Sunday.

Taking pride of place in the auction room as items go under the hammer will be Howard’s trademark top hat and his beloved penny-farthing — each of which are up for grabs.

related.body:
In 2020 how will our code look? I’ve gazed into a crystal ball and some things I liked and some things I didn’t.

What I do like is having the field cleared of everyone except players and umpires when the ball is in play.

At the moment the runners and waterboys are getting in the way. This year cutting the runners from two to one for each club has meant delivering coaches’ messages is a bit tougher. But there have still been incidents where runners are getting in the way of the play.

I think it’s just a matter of time before no one is allowed on the field except after a goal is kicked. It’ll declutter the field and that’s good for footy.

Another decluttering tool I think the AFL will have trialled is introducing zones. Former West Coast premiership coach John Worsfold would not have mentioned bringing in this critical game changer if his new colleagues on the AFL Rules Committee hadn’t given it serious consideration.

Coaches and fans are crying out that the game looks ugly with 36 players following the ball around without having the traditional backmen on forwards and wingmen sticking to their side of the ground.

I don’t think zoning will be implemented into the AFL but I do see it being trialled in preseason competitions and being used more and more at junior levels.

Another crucial change I believe will continue to be manipulated will be the number of interchange rotations. I see the cap being reduced to as low as 40 by season 2020.

These days players are fitter, stronger and have greater capacity to run out games and these attributes will be viewed so highly by clubs because they’ll need players to still be running at full pace in the dying moments of the fourth quarter.

I don’t see 10 rotations a quarter being a problem. When I was playing there were some games when players sat on the pine the whole game. It wasn’t a problem then and I can’t see it being a massive problem in the future.

One rule I do like, which incorporates the rotation figures, is the concussion rule. As research into this area of sports medicine continues to improve I think we may see more players wearing helmets. The experts are saying that at the moment wearing a helmet doesn’t decrease the likelihood of concussion, but with another six years of studies we may have different outcomes.

What I do know is more players, here in the AFL and over in the NFL, will have developed significant brain injuries from playing the sport with such intensity and getting knocked out numerous times. We are in the hands of the doctors with this one, but the more research that can be done, the better.

This week the AFL has cancelled any future plans for Sunday night football. Good. They’ve listened to the fans on this one. I think we’ll see the game played more on Thursday nights, and I’d love to see a return to the tradition 2.10pm start on a Saturday.

Engaging the fans will be the legacy of Gillon McLachlan’s legacy as chief executive. He’s started very well in his first six weeks in the job.

McLachlan will have to be really strong in his leadership as soccer will continue to increase in popularity in the country.

The efforts at this year’s World Cup have given the round ball game a significant boost and the FFA will have another big boost if Australia can win the Asian Cup next year.

AFL will have to look at the junior sports to ensure kids are still coming through the ranks because the dollars on offer for talented youngsters to play soccer overseas will be such a lure for them.

AFL salaries are nothing to be sneezed at, but if a kid has the chance to play for Manchester United or Hawthorn, it’d be a significant business decision for the young bloke.

And a couple of quirky predictions as we look to 2020. All the players were wearing black boots. Remember them?

It used to make news when a player, like the flamboyant Warwick Capper sported white boots. Wow, what a showman he was. Dermott Brereton loved to show off his white leather feet.

How things change, now you look out of place if you don’t have white ones, or blue ones, or yellow ones, or if you’re Bernie Vince you wear one pink boot and one blue boot.

I can foresee the players going “retro” and returning to the days of black.

Greater Western Sydney will have won back-to-back premierships, every player will have a tattoo and Dustin Fletcher will still be playing for Essendon.

You never know, I might be right on some of this. Time will tell.
related.description: AS the AFL gets ready to instigate a Charter to protect the fundamentals of our great game, I think it’s time we look to the future and make some predictions of where our game is headed.
related.standFirst: I HAVE looked into my crystal ball and I see the cap on interchange being reduced to as low as 40.
related.subtitle: My 2020 vision for the AFL

The Geelong Magistrates’ Court heard yesterday Neil Hogg, who is on the sex offenders register for life, was spotted sitting opposite the primary school drinking a can of beer while children passed close by to exit the grounds on April 30.

Days later the 54-year-old was again seen in the area, this time talking to two five-year-old girls.

The police prosecutor told the court Hogg admitted to police his actions were “pretty dangerous”.

The court heard Hogg’s history of offending was well known and that a large number of people in Winchelsea are now fearful of their children’s safety.

Hogg’s lawyer Tim Fitzgerald said his client suffered from extremely low cognitive function and there were grave fears for his safety if jailed.

“It’s readily apparent that alcohol plays a significant contributing role. It’s a blight that’s been cast on Mr Hogg’s life,” he said.

Mr Fitzgerald said his client had previously been unable to complete any community service work handed down to him as part of his community corrections order due to two assaults in four months, one that left him with life-threatening head injuries.

In January, Hogg was flown to a Melbourne hospital after allegedly being assaulted with a shovel in Geelong West.

Mr Fitzgerald said, while Hogg was recovering in hospital, his house was set alight.

Magistrate Ron Saines said a suspended jail term was crucial in preventing repeat offending, but told Hogg he would head straight to prison if he failed to comply or follow treatments.

“This is a very serious matter, being drunk outside a school in Winchelsea after being sentenced many times for loitering and offences that make many people concerned about their children’s safety,” Mr Saines said.

“Were it not for the difficulties you have in understanding, with your disabilities, you’d go to jail for a long time.

“In circumstances where a guilty plea has been given at an early date, a jail sentence should not be imposed unless there is no other option.”

Mr Saines also imposed a revised two-year community corrections order that will see Hogg required to do 100 hours of work during 12 months, and undergo treatment for alcohol abuse.
related.description: A CONVICTED sex offender has been handed a two-month suspended jail term after he pleaded guilty to twice loitering while drunk near a Winchelsea primary school.

A new Yarra St pier would inject more than $61 million into Geelong’s economy and create 430 new local jobs, the business case found.

Geelong mayor Darryn Lyons launched the independent business case at the Royal Geelong Yacht Club.

He was joined by Portuguese cruise line Portuscale’s Oceania general manager Rosalea Ryan.

The pair had earlier signed a letter of intent to run cruises to Geelong if the city builds a new Yarra St pier.

Ms Ryan said her cruise ship company was looking to bring up to 12 cruise ship visits a year to Geelong.

‘‘We are looking at a mid-sized vessel and we are looking very much to work through regional sites,’’ she said.

‘‘We believe it’s a good size fit for our operation, the personality of a city such as Geelong is also an excellent match.

‘‘We are offering a smaller, more intimate, more personal type of experience for our passengers and we think that’s what people will experience when they first arrive in Geelong.’’

Ms Ryan said Portuscale’s vessels would also bunker in Geelong and the city would virtually be the company’s local headquarters.

Cr Lyons said the Yarra St pier was the top priority for Geelong. “Our CBD sits on a stunning north-facing bay — we have an enormous opportunity on our hands,” he said.

“The cruise ship industry is big business. In fact it’s the largest growing travel sector in the world. Australian cruise passenger numbers have risen by 500 per cent since 2002.

“But in order to capitalise on this opportunity we need a new pier that can accommodate cruise ships.

“Last year five cruise ships visited Geelong, this summer we have nine confirmed. And if we had a pier we could attract a further 19.”

We know news stories, particularly breaking news, is the staple of our digital offering.

Some suggestions include:

related.body:
The Geelong Magistrates’ Court heard Daniel Lee, 30, sold the rental goods and reported the thefts to raise money for a night out.

He pleaded guilty to three counts of theft, obtaining property by deception and making a false report.

Police prosecutor Sergeant Peter Beard said Lee signed a three-year lease agreement for a Sony 3D home theatre system and blue ray player in November last year before taking them to Cash Converters two weeks later.

“He was loaned $40 against the goods and never returned for them,” Sgt Beard said.

“On December 17, 2013, Lee entered another lease agreement for an LG TV.

“On March 14, this year he rang Radio Rentals and asked if the goods were stolen would they be replaced by (the company’s) insurance, and they informed him they would.”

Two days later Lee reported both televisions stolen to the police and later the rental company.

Paul Houston, for Lee, said his client let himself down after three years crime-free.

“We acknowledge he planned and thought about this but he was bound to get caught,” he said.

Mr Houston said Lee, a former drug addict, was “battling” on the disability pension and wanted to raise funds to “have a good time”.

He said Lee realised he was risking a jail term given his prior convictions.

Magistrate John Lesser sentenced Lee to three months jail wholly suspended for a year.

“I accept life is not easy for you but your behaviour is totally unacceptable,” he said.

“You can’t get out of your financial problems that way.”

Police have been told that a man entered Provincial Home Living on Ryrie St on June 21 at 3.15pm.

A Victoria Police spokeswoman said a man browsed the store until a number of other shoppers paid for their goods and left.

The man selected two glass jars and approached the counter, where a shop assistant wrapped his purchases.

While standing at the counter, the man allegedly produced a pair of scissors and demanded cash from the female attendant.

He then took an amount of cash from the till and ran from the store about 3.40pm.

The wanted man is described as being aged in his mid teens to his early 20s, unshaven with blonde hair.

At the time of the robbery he was wearing a hooded top and black pants.

Anyone with information is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

In Touch magazine is claiming the actor entered the Passages rehab facility in May and was visited by her wife Ellen DeGeneres every weekend.

The US publication does not speculate as to why the Arrested Development star sought treatment, though she has publicly detailed prior battles with an eating disorder.

Last December on her talk show, Ellen DeGeneres slammed rumours her marriage to Portia (formerly de Rossi) was in trouble.

“There’s not one ounce of truth to any of it. I’m very happily married,” DeGeneres said.

“The only thing we ever argue about is who loves who more.”

Born Amanda Lee Rogers, Portia DeGeneres had her big break playing Nelle Porter in late 90s show Ally McBeal.

The actor and Ellen DeGeneres married at their LA home in August 2008. They tied the knot during the brief window when it was legal for same-sex couples to get married in the US state of California. At the time of the wedding, Ellen DeGeneres described herself as the luckiest girl in the world.

“She’s (de Rossi) officially off the market. No one else gets her,’ the talk show host told People magazine.

related.body:
The department is appealing for people who may never have considered a prison career, including those with experience in trades and services.

Jamie is one prison worker which Corrections Victoria hopes will serve as an example to potential employees.

The 29-year-old spent over a decade in the forklift industry before deciding to apply for a job as a prison officer.

For Jamie, the lure of greater job security and the chance to progress his career were what cemented his decision.

“I enjoy being a positive role model to prisoners and other officers, and having the self-satisfaction of performing my duties in a professional manner,” he said.

Corrections Victoria chairman Jan Shuard hopes Jamie’s story will appeal to those who have constantly dismissed the idea of working in a jail.

“When it comes to prisons, people have preconceived ideas about the work and the environment, which are often based on stereotypes you might see in a Hollywood blockbuster,” Ms Shuard said.

“They don’t match the reality of Victoria’s modern prison system, so we want people to look beyond the stereotypes and see the benefits of this rewarding career.”

Barwon Prison general manager Jonathan Howe said the opportunity to make a difference was a major drawcard.

“You might be a teacher who needs a change of direction, or an office worker who’s tired of spending their days behind a desk,” he said.

“These roles offer a change of pace, tapping into each person’s existing skills and experience.”

The recruitment drive is part of a broader expansion of Victoria’s correctional system, with a new 40-bed high security unit at Barwon Prison expected to be completed in the next two years.
