“It was largely contained early on and didn’t spill into the storm water drains,’’ Mr Callan said.

“We were assisted by the City of Greater Geelong in the clean up.”

Firefighters and council officers were called about 7am Wednesday.

Anyone with information is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

related.body:
Geelong Magistrate Ron Saines yesterday found Carl Bolton “crossed the line” when he “chested” Luke McGinty and punched him in the face in August last year.

The 33-year-old was stood down without pay following the watch-house incident but is now able to apply to be reinstated after being spared a conviction.

Mr Saines said while Bolton had shown no remorse for his behaviour, which was captured on CCTV and witnessed by five other officers, and had taken up valuable court time with his two-day hearing, it would be “wrong to deprive (him) of the opportunity to continue in the police force”.

Victoria Police will decide Bolton’s future.

In finding Bolton guilty, Mr Saines said the victim Mr McGinty was “clearly and obviously uncooperative”, abusive and taunting but no other officers believed he was a threat.

He found Bolton’s evidence was “less than reliable” and couldn’t accept his claim that he didn’t realise Mr McGinty was handcuffed until after four officers had restrained him on the floor.

“The accused sought to exaggerate or overstate the sense of danger he felt,” Mr Saines said.

“Even if (Mr McGinty) did say he hated police, taunted some or all of them, I find it was confined to verbal (abuse) and he was not a risk of causing harm to them at any time.”

Mr Saines found of the four episodes that made up the charge, only two could be proved beyond reasonable doubt.

He found Bolton’s alleged attempt to knee Mr McGinty and Mr McGinty’s responding alleged bid to kick Bolton were made in the context of both believing they had to defend themselves.

The court heard Bolton, the most senior officer on staff that night, tried to punch Mr McGinty twice, but accidentally hit a police colleague the second time.

Mr Saines said even Mr McGinty’s response to being assaulted and further restrained was “more lighthearted than sinister”.

Bolton’s lawyer described the assault as “15 seconds of behaviour uncharacteristic to 33 years of service”.

“He’s achieved a great deal of good in the Colac community,” he said, listing the creation of the Beechy Trek with disadvantaged youth and anti-drugs competition Ride to the Rock and numerous certificates of appreciation.

Mr Saines said Bolton’s good character and years of service in an “onerous and thankless job” mitigated against his poor decision.

“You crossed the line; you didn’t cross it by a terribly long way or in a way that caused any significant injury but nevertheless you crossed a line that everyone in the criminal justice system understands,” he said.

Bolton was fined $1500 without conviction.

related.body:
Using specially modified infra-red cameras and image-enhancement techniques, Mr Moore, 53, has been shining a new light on local landmarks from the Waterfront bollards to Balyang Sanctuary.

He has recently compiled hundreds of stunning images into an 82-page book prototype titled Unseen Geelong, which he is hoping to launch later this year.

“Geelong I think is really undervalued, there’s a lot of beauty there with or without infra-red, and honestly people miss it, they just don’t see it,” he said.

“I like to capture things you can’t see, or show a different view of things you can see.”

Geelong’s “Lightsmith” started taking photography seriously in 2007 when he took a redundancy from Ford, and said most of his photos are taken on his travels between Lara and Geelong to visit his elderly parents in hospital.

“I was always interested in general light photography but I have to say I wasn’t very good at it, it was almost as though something was missing and I could never really work out what it was until I started taking infra-red,” he said.

“I saw my first infra-red picture and said ‘that’s it, that’s what I should be doing’, so I look for opportunities everywhere.”

Mr Moore said he sat down with Geelong mayor Darryn Lyons last week who was supportive of the project, and Moore hoped others would appreciate the images.

“It came to me that I had all these pictures of Geelong, I don’t want them to just sit there I want people to see them,” he said.

“I thought I should put them together in a book as a way of making Geelong more accessible, and maybe it will make people notice things a little more.”

To check out more of Mr Moore’s striking photographs visit thelightsmith.com.
related.description: LARA hobby photographer Christopher Moore wants to reintroduce locals to the city they live in.

related.body:
Victorian Greens leader Greg Barber said it was important the 400,000 regional Victorians living along the line had access to fast and frequent train travel to places other than Melbourne.

“The Greens support a staged reintroduction of passenger services with existing stations reopened if possible and other new low-cost stations constructed where required,” Mr Barber said.

“We know that people want to travel between regional cities for work, education, health and recreation, so it isn’t enough for trains to only connect with Melbourne.”

However the party has not provided any of their own costings for the project, except to say that consultant and lobby group activist Noel Laidlaw completed an independent study which found reopening the line to a basic service would cost around $90 million. 

The state government Rail Revival Feasibility Study estimated the cost of a full reopening would be between $760-$935 million.

Mr Barber said the first stage should be to reopen the Geelong to Ballarat rail line, with new low-cost stations at Bannockburn and Meredith to provide a commuter service for those fast-growing communities.

They estimate a 65-minute moderate-speed service could be achieved with some new tracks, upgrades to level crossings and one passing loop.

Stage two would be to repair and rebuild the train line between Maryborough and Castlemaine and stage three would include upgrading to a faster and more regular service that could continue on existing tracks to Bendigo. 

“While we would love super-fast Goldfields trains, an affordable basic service would be preferable to none at all and still fast enough to compete with car travel,” Mr Barber said.

“V/Line buses are the only public transport for many towns along the line but they are unable to offer a viable commuter service.”

Mr Barber said freight trains still use sections of the track and could share some of the upgrade costs.

He said a return to train travel would encourage more people to move to regional Victoria and be more beneficial for residents than the $18 billion East-West toll road.

Community group Rail Revival Alliance has been lobbying the Government to reopen the line since last year.

About 200 people attended a rally at the now unused Carisbrook Station, about 150km north of Geelong, in December last year.

More than 1200 people braved wet and cold conditions to see Fevola pull on a Cheetah’s guernsey on Saturday and West president Simon Cavallo said the club would consider luring another marquee man.

“I won’t say no to anything,” Cavallo said.

“I’d like to leave our options open. He’s probably the biggest drawcard, I don’t think there’s any bigger than Fev.”

Rain put a dampener on the Cheetahs’ plans to lure thousands to West Oval for the EJ Whitten Foundation fundraiser.

“It could’ve been spectacular, but it was 11C and the showers came at one o’clock when everyone would’ve been decided whether or not to go,” Cavallo said.

“So it was a bit disappointing but we’ll definitely try something similar in the future.”

Fevola was spotted at Home House nightclub in the early hours of Saturday morning but Cavallo said the club was unfazed but his late night out.

“Fev’s been in the business a long time and he knows his capabilities and he has a bit of a rock star attitude,” Cavallo said.

“We would trust that he undertakes his actions knowing his capabilities. On the day he was completely fine, so we’ve got no problems with anything the night before as far as his performance was concerned.

“The delivery and conditions and the quality opponents that he played on made it difficult for him, so I’m not sure that if he went to bed at 8.30pm it would’ve made much of a difference.”

Fevola missed a club breakfast but Cavallo said the former AFL star was not required at the function.

“There’s a lot of rumours going around and I’m not sure what’s true but from 12 noon when he arrived, Fev was a complete professional,” Cavallo said.

“He was everything and more than we could’ve asked for. He signed close to 100 autographs and posed for an equal amount of photos with his fans. He was awesome.

“He was enthusiastic and positive and never said no to anyone. He gave his complete time and attention to everyone.”
related.description: GEELONG West has not ruled out bringing Brendan Fevola back into the fold in the future after what the club described as a successful one-off appearance.

The Geelong Magistrates’ Court heard yesterday Neil Hogg, who is on the sex offenders register for life, was spotted sitting opposite the primary school drinking a can of beer while children passed close by to exit the grounds on April 30.

Days later the 54-year-old was again seen in the area, this time talking to two five-year-old girls.

The police prosecutor told the court Hogg admitted to police his actions were “pretty dangerous”.

The court heard Hogg’s history of offending was well known and that a large number of people in Winchelsea are now fearful of their children’s safety.

Hogg’s lawyer Tim Fitzgerald said his client suffered from extremely low cognitive function and there were grave fears for his safety if jailed.

“It’s readily apparent that alcohol plays a significant contributing role. It’s a blight that’s been cast on Mr Hogg’s life,” he said.

Mr Fitzgerald said his client had previously been unable to complete any community service work handed down to him as part of his community corrections order due to two assaults in four months, one that left him with life-threatening head injuries.

In January, Hogg was flown to a Melbourne hospital after allegedly being assaulted with a shovel in Geelong West.

Mr Fitzgerald said, while Hogg was recovering in hospital, his house was set alight.

Magistrate Ron Saines said a suspended jail term was crucial in preventing repeat offending, but told Hogg he would head straight to prison if he failed to comply or follow treatments.

“This is a very serious matter, being drunk outside a school in Winchelsea after being sentenced many times for loitering and offences that make many people concerned about their children’s safety,” Mr Saines said.

“Were it not for the difficulties you have in understanding, with your disabilities, you’d go to jail for a long time.

“In circumstances where a guilty plea has been given at an early date, a jail sentence should not be imposed unless there is no other option.”

Mr Saines also imposed a revised two-year community corrections order that will see Hogg required to do 100 hours of work during 12 months, and undergo treatment for alcohol abuse.
related.description: A CONVICTED sex offender has been handed a two-month suspended jail term after he pleaded guilty to twice loitering while drunk near a Winchelsea primary school.

A new Yarra St pier would inject more than $61 million into Geelong’s economy and create 430 new local jobs, the business case found.

Geelong mayor Darryn Lyons launched the independent business case at the Royal Geelong Yacht Club.

He was joined by Portuguese cruise line Portuscale’s Oceania general manager Rosalea Ryan.

The pair had earlier signed a letter of intent to run cruises to Geelong if the city builds a new Yarra St pier.

Ms Ryan said her cruise ship company was looking to bring up to 12 cruise ship visits a year to Geelong.

‘‘We are looking at a mid-sized vessel and we are looking very much to work through regional sites,’’ she said.

‘‘We believe it’s a good size fit for our operation, the personality of a city such as Geelong is also an excellent match.

‘‘We are offering a smaller, more intimate, more personal type of experience for our passengers and we think that’s what people will experience when they first arrive in Geelong.’’

Ms Ryan said Portuscale’s vessels would also bunker in Geelong and the city would virtually be the company’s local headquarters.

Cr Lyons said the Yarra St pier was the top priority for Geelong. “Our CBD sits on a stunning north-facing bay — we have an enormous opportunity on our hands,” he said.

“The cruise ship industry is big business. In fact it’s the largest growing travel sector in the world. Australian cruise passenger numbers have risen by 500 per cent since 2002.

“But in order to capitalise on this opportunity we need a new pier that can accommodate cruise ships.

“Last year five cruise ships visited Geelong, this summer we have nine confirmed. And if we had a pier we could attract a further 19.”

related.body:
In 2020 how will our code look? I’ve gazed into a crystal ball and some things I liked and some things I didn’t.

What I do like is having the field cleared of everyone except players and umpires when the ball is in play.

At the moment the runners and waterboys are getting in the way. This year cutting the runners from two to one for each club has meant delivering coaches’ messages is a bit tougher. But there have still been incidents where runners are getting in the way of the play.

I think it’s just a matter of time before no one is allowed on the field except after a goal is kicked. It’ll declutter the field and that’s good for footy.

Another decluttering tool I think the AFL will have trialled is introducing zones. Former West Coast premiership coach John Worsfold would not have mentioned bringing in this critical game changer if his new colleagues on the AFL Rules Committee hadn’t given it serious consideration.

Coaches and fans are crying out that the game looks ugly with 36 players following the ball around without having the traditional backmen on forwards and wingmen sticking to their side of the ground.

I don’t think zoning will be implemented into the AFL but I do see it being trialled in preseason competitions and being used more and more at junior levels.

Another crucial change I believe will continue to be manipulated will be the number of interchange rotations. I see the cap being reduced to as low as 40 by season 2020.

These days players are fitter, stronger and have greater capacity to run out games and these attributes will be viewed so highly by clubs because they’ll need players to still be running at full pace in the dying moments of the fourth quarter.

I don’t see 10 rotations a quarter being a problem. When I was playing there were some games when players sat on the pine the whole game. It wasn’t a problem then and I can’t see it being a massive problem in the future.

One rule I do like, which incorporates the rotation figures, is the concussion rule. As research into this area of sports medicine continues to improve I think we may see more players wearing helmets. The experts are saying that at the moment wearing a helmet doesn’t decrease the likelihood of concussion, but with another six years of studies we may have different outcomes.

What I do know is more players, here in the AFL and over in the NFL, will have developed significant brain injuries from playing the sport with such intensity and getting knocked out numerous times. We are in the hands of the doctors with this one, but the more research that can be done, the better.

This week the AFL has cancelled any future plans for Sunday night football. Good. They’ve listened to the fans on this one. I think we’ll see the game played more on Thursday nights, and I’d love to see a return to the tradition 2.10pm start on a Saturday.

Engaging the fans will be the legacy of Gillon McLachlan’s legacy as chief executive. He’s started very well in his first six weeks in the job.

McLachlan will have to be really strong in his leadership as soccer will continue to increase in popularity in the country.

The efforts at this year’s World Cup have given the round ball game a significant boost and the FFA will have another big boost if Australia can win the Asian Cup next year.

AFL will have to look at the junior sports to ensure kids are still coming through the ranks because the dollars on offer for talented youngsters to play soccer overseas will be such a lure for them.

AFL salaries are nothing to be sneezed at, but if a kid has the chance to play for Manchester United or Hawthorn, it’d be a significant business decision for the young bloke.

And a couple of quirky predictions as we look to 2020. All the players were wearing black boots. Remember them?

It used to make news when a player, like the flamboyant Warwick Capper sported white boots. Wow, what a showman he was. Dermott Brereton loved to show off his white leather feet.

How things change, now you look out of place if you don’t have white ones, or blue ones, or yellow ones, or if you’re Bernie Vince you wear one pink boot and one blue boot.

I can foresee the players going “retro” and returning to the days of black.

Greater Western Sydney will have won back-to-back premierships, every player will have a tattoo and Dustin Fletcher will still be playing for Essendon.

You never know, I might be right on some of this. Time will tell.
related.description: AS the AFL gets ready to instigate a Charter to protect the fundamentals of our great game, I think it’s time we look to the future and make some predictions of where our game is headed.
related.standFirst: I HAVE looked into my crystal ball and I see the cap on interchange being reduced to as low as 40.

We know news stories, particularly breaking news, is the staple of our digital offering.

But now, with greater accessibility through our M-site, you might be looking for something else throughout the day.

Some suggestions include:

- A quick wrap-up of the news at the end of day;

- A regular, quirky odd spot for your afternoon break;

- More breaking national and world news sprinkled throughout the day; or,

related.body:
The mother, who did not want to be named to protect the reputation of her beautiful daughter, said she wanted to share their story in the hope that one person might think twice before trying the highly-addictive and potentially lethal substance.

The mother, who for three years has vacuumed dust from her daughter’s shoes where they sit unused by the front door, said people needed to be more aware of the fatal consequences of ice.

Her daughter, who regularly left notes around the house saying “I love you mummy”, was ultimately poisoned by drug manufacturers that laced their illegal potion with battery acid, arsenic, nail polish remover and nine other deadly chemicals. 

“Until you actually see your child dying and go to the funeral home and touch your freezing cold child you don’t realise what drugs can do,” she said.

“I had to watch my daughter dying all day because of that dirty, dirty stinking drug. It does kill people. People assume you can’t die from it but you can.”

This dedicated mother’s nightmare began three years ago when she received a phone call from her daughter asking to be picked up from a friend’s house because she was sick about 5am on a cold July morning.

“She was all hunched over and could barely speak,” the distraught mother said.

“When she got in the car that morning, she said: ‘Mummy I’ve used ice’.

“She started vomiting. She vomited all day. Her face had actually twisted, distorted.

“She lifted her little T-shirt and she said ... ‘Can you feel my chest, I think my heart is gone’.

“Then I heard her yelling at someone and I went in there and she’d called the ambulance herself so she knew then it wasn’t good.”

As the paramedics wheeled her out, she said: ‘Please I just want to go to sleep now. I need to sleep’.

That was the last time this mother saw her daughter alive.

The paramedics told her to wait 30 minutes before calling the hospital.

She did as she was told and when she made the call a male staff member had to end the conversation abruptly.

“I could hear her crying in the background, her little cry. He said: ‘I have to go, I have to do a procedure on your daughter’. They rang me back a couple of minutes later and said: ‘Can you come straight away, your daughter is unwell.’ That is when she would have died.

“The worst part about it was that because it was drugs, and she did tell the ambos that it was ice, she was shackled to the bed. My GP told me that the word ‘shackled’ was used so many times (in the autopsy) it upset her.”

If the aftermath of her daughter’s shocking death, this mother, flooded with grief, went on a crusade to try and find the people responsible for killing her daughter.

She knocked on doors and screamed at strangers, trying to track down the ones who had sold her daughter the deadly batch. 

“There was an hour where apparently they (the police) can’t determine who she saw or where she was but it was obviously someone in this area that she got the drugs from,” the Geelong mother said.

“I went around accusing, threatening. I was hell bent on finding out who, when, where and why but I was yelling at all the wrong people and they were missing her too.

“I don’t know what I would have done if I found out anyway. I think maybe it’s just the shock of it all and you live in hope of something ... and then one day you wake up and think there is no hope.”

In the Geelong home where the pair lived, there are constant reminders of a life taken away unexpectedly.

Although she visits her daughter in the cemetery every day, this mother has not had been able to summon the strength to pack up her things and admit that she is gone.

“I still don’t shut the curtains at night in her room because when the curtains were closed I knew she was home and she was safe.

“But why keep the curtains open? Why not shut them because you know she’s never going to come back. Why keep her toothbrush in the holder on the basin in the bathroom? It’s still sitting there. I haven’t moved it in three years.

“I washed her dressing gown and pyjamas that she had on that day and they’re still sitting there all folded and clean for her to put back on again but she won’t.

“I’d just love her back here for five minutes to tell her how much I love her.”

Despite the tears that flow freely as she talks about the day that will haunt her forever, this grieving mother said she wants her experience to be a catalyst for change.

She is pleased about the Geelong alliance between police, community groups and businesses who are trying to come up with new ways to beat ice in the community.

She thinks more should be done to educate teenagers in schools, by showing them graphic images of people who have died as a result of drugs.

If she could, she would line up all the chemicals listed in her daughter’s autopsy to make young people realise what could be in the next batch.

But despite the unprecedented action taken by the community alliance, this mother is still sceptical the ice problem will ever be solved.

She saw the grip drugs had on her daughter and knows that good people can get hooked all too easily.

She said the only hope was not to get involved in the first place.

“I drive through the city at night ... and I see them (the drug users) and some nights I just want to get out of the car and say it will be all right but I know that somewhere there’s going to be another mum and she’s going to go through hell,” she said.

“People will often look away and think ‘why should we care, they’re nothing, nobodies’. Not true. Most of the time these are people with problems and they do care, they care a lot, and they care maybe a bit too much sometimes.”

Among the many treasured items this mother clings to to remember her daughter is a baby blue sash, like something from a beauty pageant, that her daughter had made for her before she died.

She had gone to a local florist and had them print a personal message to her hero, her mum, to be given as a Mother’s Day gift.

When the sash was ready, this troubled girl did not have enough money to pay for it so she had to leave it at the store. 
When the staff found out she had died they presented one final gift to her heartbroken mother.

Three years on her mother still cries when she reads the words her daughter had printed on the sash: “Happy Mother’s Day. Thank you for being my best friend.”

A beautiful message from a beautiful girl who was killed by ice.

GEELONG TO HOST ICE FORUM

A PUBLIC forum about ice will be co-hosted by the Justice Department and Victoria Police at the Geelong Football Club from 6-8pm on July 14.

The forum will provide information about how methamphetamine substances work; the physical and psychological effects; the signs and symptoms of dependency, withdrawal and psychosis; how to engage with people who are affected by methamphetamines and treatment and support options.
related.description: A GEELONG mother whose daughter died alone and shackled to a hospital bed after taking one hit from a bad batch of ice has spoken out about her family’s endless grief at the hands of drugs.

In a major coup for the Blues who are knocking on the door of a double chance, Hollmer and Steven have agreed to join the GDFL club after returning from overseas.

It’s a bitter blow for the Dolphins, who were left reeling after a mass exodus of players following its 2013 senior premiership.

Many of Lorne’s stars, including Steve Oliver, Chris Giuricin, Joel Tipping and Boe Trickey, departed the CDFL club and joined former Dolphin coaches Drew Steven and Jason Langdon at Eastern Reserve.

Blues coach David Mensch said, pending clearances, Hollmer and Steven would bolster the side significantly.

“Tom’s a good player and Lewie’s 22-23 and he’s won a league medal in the CDFL. It’s pretty exciting for us,” Mensch said.

“We’re pushing for a top-three spot and hopefully that can happen. We play five or six of the top sides now, so it’s not an easy run but if we want to be around the mark we’ll have to earn it.”

Injuries have caused the Blues to restructure their side, with Mensch forced into the ruck in the absence of key talls Dan Hermans and Dan Wedding.

Winchelsea has also been without its first-choice midfield group of Andrew Leak (hip flexor), Ben Davis (knee) and Kane Bonner (shin splits) for a number of weeks.

Oliver was also absent against Thomson on Saturday, meaning the Blues were without its key quartet of on-ballers.

“We’ve had a shocking run,” Mensch said.

“We were after another ruckman and Lewie is a good fit. Dan (Wedding) has been good this year but he’s had injuries and Hermans has been riddled with injuries.

“It will take them (Hollmer and Steven) a few weeks to get back into it after being overseas but they give us a few options. We’ve got options galore now.”

Winchelsea lodged the clearances for both Hollmer and Steven last Thursday, just days before the July 1 cut-off.

“Once the clearance is lodged before July 1, it’s in the system and hopefully it can be done in the next couple of days,” Mensch said.
related.description: INJURY-ravaged Winchelesea is set to strengthen its credentials for a top-three finish, luring Lorne premiership duo Lewie Hollmer and Tom Steven.

related.body:
About 20 audience members had been selected to ask questions of a panel comprising Geelong mayor Darryn Lyons, G21 chief executive Elaine Carbines, Labor MP Richard Marles, Liberal MP Sarah Henderson and Greens Senator Richard Di Natale, but time constraints meant only about half of them were asked.

The most emotional questions came from audience members Michael Roach and Cathy Bond who raised the tragic death of Tamil asylum seeker Leo Seemanpillai who fatally set himself on fire in Geelong.

The rowdy 700-strong crowd was silent as they spoke about a man who was “terrified” of being returned to Sri Lanka, a country where he had been interrogated and tortured in the past, and where he feared it would happen again.

Ms Henderson said it was “a very dangerous exercise” to link Mr Seemanpillai’s death with federal policies and she had a surprising ally in Labor opponent Mr Marles.

“He had been suffering a mental illness,” Ms Henderson said. “Suicide is a horrible, dreadful thing and so often we can’t see what is about to happen.”

But Ms Bond said government policies had played a role in his death. “He knew what being returned to Sri Lanka meant for him,” Ms Bond said. “He spoke of nothing else but his terror of being returned.”

HENDERSON BLASTED IN SOCIAL MEDIA 

Senator Di Natale got a robust round of applause for insisting Australia’s hard line asylum seeker policy was teaching the next generation of kids to “harden their hearts and turn their back on people in need”.

He said the fact Mr Seemanpillai had donated his organs so other Australians could have a better life, demonstrated the contribution he wanted to make to this country.

“We’ve just got to realise that there is never, ever a reason to lock up young kids,” he said.

“We have to change what we’re doing. We can’t keep hurting people.”

Another questioner asked Cr Lyons why the city wanted to spend up to $2 million on Christmas decorations and light installations when there were people living “in their cars and under bridges”.

“Wouldn’t that be better spent on helping people?” the audience member asked.

But Cr Lyons was unapologetic, saying it had been years since the city spent money on anything celebratory.

“I think it is going to be a big sign of a beacon of hope,” he said. “It’s a very small price to pay to lift up our community.”

But in the end it was a surprising question from former federal Liberal candidate Mark Hoysted that received the biggest round of applause. He said he was “deeply ashamed” of the way the Liberal party was attacking people on welfare.

“It is a cornerstone of the philosophy of liberalism that the strong have a duty to protect the weak,” he said in the final question of the night. “The aged, the sick and the unemployed are not economic burdens. These are people who are our fellow Australians, who need our respect and our protection.”

However, the key theme that ran through the whole night, and the reason the show came to Geelong, was the demise of manufacturing and how Geelong would cope with large-scale job losses.

As host Tony Jones, the clear crowd favourite, said in his introduction: “It is the epicentre of manufacturing decline so what lessons can the rest of the country learn from Geelong?”

The first question of the night came from Ford worker Henry Fuller who said he was nervous about how, aged in his 50s, he was going to compete for jobs against younger workers.

“There has been a lot of talk about retraining but retraining to what?” he asked.

“Where are the jobs going to come from?”

Another Ford worker, Anthony Anderson, asked Ms Henderson what the Abbott Government was doing, and how much they were investing, to create new jobs for retrenched manufacturing workers.

“I know that I’m going to lose my job just like hundreds of others,” he said.

“Where is your Government actually going to create a job, especially in this town?”

Ms Henderson said the Federal Government had invested $15 million into the Geelong Region Innovation and Investment Fund and would launch a new initiative to give employers a $10,000 incentive to hire someone over 50 who has been on income support.

“Manufacturing has a very, very strong future but it won’t be traditional manufacturing,” she said.

“It’s sadly not going to be Alcoa, it’s not going to be making cars but in advanced manufacturing, we think there is a very, very bright future for Geelong.”

Ms Henderson said abolishing the carbon tax would take cost pressure off businesses and help grow the economy, in turn creating jobs.

Mr Marles said Geelong was facing a very difficult time economically and blamed the Abbott Government for letting the car industry die.

Ms Carbines said a one-stop shop was being set up at the Gordon Tafe to help manufacturing workers find job opportunities, access welfare payments or re-skill to ensure that no one was left behind.

Mr Di Natale said Geelong had the potential to become a hub for renewable energy.
related.description: IT WAS a lively, compassionate and at times angry crowd that packed the Geelong Performing Arts Centre to discuss the future of manufacturing, asylum seeker policy, welfare cuts and Christmas lights at the live television broadcast of the ABC’s Q&A.

Vail rolled the dice by pleading guilty to the forceful front-on contact charge, with his advocate Glenn Brown successfully arguing that contact to St Mary’s Callen Wade was accidental.

The tribunal was shown footage of Vail making contact to the side of Wade’s head with his body when both players were bent over contesting the ball last weekend.

“Zane had no intention to initiate contact, no intention to bump,” Brown told the tribunal, chaired by Phil Swindells.

“Both players made a determination to go and get the ball. (Wade) got there first, Zane was already committed to getting the ball.

“If you watch the video, Zane’s eyes were on the ball and at that point there was no way of avoiding contact. He went in sideways, to help avoid serious contact.

“We don’t accept that he had any intent, we don’t accept that he was reckless.

“I defy anyone to say he could have done anything else in that situation.”

Wade played out the match but left the field for about 15 minutes to be assessed following the second-quarter collision at St Mary’s Oval.

He rated the contact a “six to seven” out of 10.

Vail, who was suspended back in 2011 for two matches for front-on contact, was yellow-carded for the bump by reporting umpire David Maddock.

“I’m very happy to be able to play against Lara, I would have been disappointed if I got weeks,” Vail said post hearing.

“At the time, during the game, I was really disappointed with the call, being yellow-carded and reported.”

related.body:
55-year-old Sue Wilkins said she was sorry for mocking the language and facial features of an Asian woman on a Sydney to Newcastle train on Wednesday afternoon.

The incident was filmed by a passenger and posted on YouTube. The woman became angry at two young children when they didn’t give their seats up for her.

She then began to abuse other passengers, including a man who was sitting next to an Asian woman. “Who is this little jerk-off? He can only get a gook - he can’t even get a regular girlfriend. It is so sad,” she said, as passengers groaned in offence.

“Is it really that small that you can’t get an Aussie girl? Poor man. Look at this bogan, he has got a gook.”

After she caused a scene inside the carriage, police spoke to the woman when she alighted at Strathfield in Sydney’s west.

“There were police patrolling from a local area command,” police transport command assistant commissioner Max Mitchell told reporters.

“They were there for another matter, unaware of the full circumstances of this situation.

Police spoke to the woman but decided to let her “go about her journey”, Mr Mitchell said.

Mr Mitchell didn’t know why she was allowed to walk free but stressed the woman would be charged for her “abhorrent and unacceptable behaviour”.

“The person responsible will be prosecuted,” he said.

If found guilty of offensive behaviour, she faces a $500 fine.

“This person has committed offensive behaviour,” Mr Mitchell said.

“It is a crime that we will not tolerate, particularly in regards to the racial motivation behind this incident.”

The woman told ninemsn she had a rotten day and had been scammed out of $100,000 from a man she had met on a dating website.

Sydney Trains chief Howard Collins said he was “shocked” by the rant and the company would be working with police to investigate.

“I’m just amazed - we’ve got to stamp this out,” he said.

In April, Rebecca Blessington, 28, was charged after allegedly racially abusing two Asian women on a train from Town Hall to Bondi

Jade Marr boarded the train at Central Station when Ms Wilkins told her two children and two nephews, aged between four and 10, to get off the seats.

“I was in shock at the time. I’m probably more angry today that someone could be that low and attack a child or anyone else.

“Everyone took it seriously but it actually became quite comical, it was just ridiculous.”

“We were just thinking ‘what are you doing’? It was unbelievable.

“She called the police and her goal was to get my children removed from the train because they were sitting on a seat.

“We don’t catch the train very often so the kids were worried they had done the wrong thing. 

POLICE CHARGE WOMAN OVER RACISTS RANT 

RACIST RANT ON SYDNEY BUS CAUGHT ON CAMERA 

TAMARAMA SURF VICTIM WAS FATHER OF TWO 

THREE CHARGED OVER CROWN WITNESS KILLING 

“They were frightened that the police were coming to get them. I just kept telling them that they hadn’t done anything wrong and that this woman was not responding the way that normal people do.

“My nephew was really concerned about the words she was using and the way she spoke to the other woman.

“The kids just didn’t understand why someone would say that.”

Ms Wilkins was in apologetic mood this afternoon.

“I had a rotten day,’ she told Ninemsn . ‘I’ve been chasing work for quite some time now,” she said.

“It’s awful what I said to that woman, I do agree,” Ms Wilkins said.

Wilkins became enraged at some young children after they did not give into her demands for a seat on a morning Central Coast train.

She then started abusing passengers including an Asian woman and a man who stood up for her.

“Who is this little jerk off he can only get a gook, he can’t even get a regular girlfriend — it is so sad,” she said.

“Is it really that small that you can’t get an Aussie girl? Poor man. Look at this bogan he has got a gook — look at it. She probably thinks he is rich.”

The video was posted onto YouTube by user Kareem Abdul.

“On the Central coast & Newcastle line in peak hour during school holidays,” Abdul wrote.

“I started filming as the woman became aggressive toward some children (ages 12 and under) who refused to vacate their seats when she had demanded.

“This video begins just after she had started screaming expletives into the face of the upset kids and the mother of the children got up to stand in between the lady and her kids.

“The lady then assaulted the mother and a young dude who gave up his seat for her and now the lady is calling the police … Because the kids didn’t move?”
related.description: The woman who racially abused Sydney train passengers will be prosecuted despite police having initially let her go following the “unacceptable” spray.
related.standFirst: VIDEO: The 55-year-old woman filmed unleashing a racist tirade at an Asian commuter on a train to the Central Coast has apologised for her behaviour | Social media fights back against the racist hate
related.subtitle: Woman’s racist rant against Asian woman filmed on train from Central Coast to Sydney

Video shows that the man pulls out in front of the pack of bikies at which point they block the couple’s car in and furiously start shoving him around.

When they throw him on to the bonnet of the car his girlfriend gets out of the vehicle.

Just as things looked set to get worse, the man gets down on one knee and asks the stunned girl to marry him.

Not only that but these rough and tough bikers reveal a bouquet of flowers for the woman and start applauding.

The video was posted in Russia and while the couple has not been identified, their love story has clocked up more than 800,000 views.

Unconventional? Sure. But it is one wedding proposal this bride-to-be will never forget.

Rebecca Blessington, 28, was today charged with using offensive language and issued a field court attendance notice to appear at Downing Centre Local Court on May 9.

Nursing a young child in her arms, she allegedly yelled and threatened at least five women on a busy morning train between Town Hall and Bondi Junction.

The footage, allegedly filmed at about 8.30am on Tuesday April 8, shows a woman bouncing her toddler on her knee as she taunts other commuters.

One commuter filmed the entire outburst where the woman said to another passenger: “I’ll ****** hurt ya … So don’t underestimate me, ****.”

The woman said she was of Aboriginal descent before abusing two Asian women riding in the carriage.

“Youse aren’t citizens. You come in here and take our country ya *****. You know it too. And guess what mate — there’s a war comin’. A war between us and youse.”

“You know the ones that were here first? The black fellas, the Kooris, which I am. This is our country mate.”

One passenger stood up to the woman and warned that her threats were being taken seriously.

Blessington shouted in reply: “I do not care … You’re all scum!”

Another passenger pressed the train’s emergency button to alert security.

The footage was handed to the Police Transport Command and officers visited Blessington’s home at Merrylands West this morning.

Inquiries into the incident are continuing and police are urging anyone who witnessed it, or similar behaviour, to contact investigators.
related.description: POLICE have tracked down the woman whose shocking abusive and racist rant on a city train was filmed by a fellow passenger.

related.body:
The world’s most high-profile female spouses are at the centre of claims de Rossi spent a month in rehab dealing with alcohol and drug issues, stemming from ongoing issues in the pair’s relationship.

American reports have claimed the 41-year-old Aussie actor, who married DeGeneres in 2008, is believed to have spent a month in a rehab facility for drug and alcohol issues.

In a story which first appeared in the US magazine In Touch, de Rossi was said to have checked into the Passages Malibu centre in May.

Despite claims the rehab visit was a result of tense arguing between the pair — and de Rossi allegedly feeling “controlled” by DeGeneres — the famed talk show host was said to have visited her wife there every weekend.

They have since been photographed enjoying a romantic stroll together in New York and holidaying in Croatia. There is a 15 year age gap between the pair.

De Rossi, who starred in Ally McBeal, has previously spoken openly of her struggles with an eating disorder.

In her candid memoir written in 2010, which detailed her struggles with bulimia, de Rossi said “I swallowed my disillusionment in the form of cream sauces, pina coladas and pastries”.

Packer’s longtime mentor has flown to Europe with his family to escape the southern chill for a few weeks.

The touring party was headed first to Paris and then to Mediterranean waters to rendezvous with the casino magnate’s luxurious vessel.

Also enjoying Uncle Alan’s largesse is his niece Tonya Taylor and her three children and husband.

After joining Packer’s summer of fun, Jones and his party will fly on to London and then Glasgow for the Commonwealth Games which are underway July 23.

Meanwhile Packer will continue his traditional northern summer abroad - an annual event that sees him extend his now ­legendary hospitality to his closest friends.

A year ago Packer’s guests included Kerry Stokes, Karl Stefanovic and Lachlan and Sarah Murdoch though not wife Erica, who spent the 2013 summer season in LA in anticipation of the separation announcement that came soon after.

A year on and Packer’s ­now ex-wife Erica was among invited guests on this year’s roster — as were the couple’s three children, Indigo, Jackson and Emmanuelle.

Her visit came after Packer’s sometime girlfriend Miranda Kerr paid him a visit a fortnight ago.

It was heart-warming to see pictures of the family reunited in happy circumstances and Sydcon eagerly awaits the pictures of the Jones reunion.

Peters’s brother and Today Show host Karl Stefanovic has revealed that Peter has brought Sylivia home to the Sunshine State to meet mum.

Karl said Sylivia was a hit at the Stefanovic Sunday roast.

“She has been around a couple of times when Pete is home from London and everyone likes her,” Karl, recording for the show in Logan yesterday, said.

“She is a beautiful woman and super smart and most importantly, from Queensland.

“It is a big thing to cope with the in-laws, usually there is always a dodgy uncle but she has the crazy brother-in-law.

“It is early days and I don’t want to put pressure on it, I wish them all the best.”

Speaking from Sydney yesterday, Jeffreys laughed of suggestions she was a future Mrs Stefanovic.

Sylvia Jeffreys replaces Georgie Gardner on Today show 

Four weeks in to her new role, the on-air banter about her relationship has kept audiences amused. 

“It started on my second day,” she said.

“I find it is best to smile and ignore. I try and quickly deflect, that is my tactic with Karl.”

She said she knows the teasing from Karl comes from a good place.

“He is just having a laugh,” she said. “It all adds to the excitement of the show.”

Karl Stefanovic says sorry

related.body:
A laundress, she stood 5’2” and boasted a ruddy “pockpicktted complexion”, according to Convict Indents, the record kept by the British penal system to identify those sent Down Under for their sins.

But what stood Elizabeth apart was the tattoo she wore on her right hand — two double hearts pierced with arrows and surrounded by a wreath, the sort of marking you might expect to see on Ruby Rose.

Despite having the line “John Messenger I love” tattooed up her right arm and a blue ring on the forefinger of her left hand, once granted her ticket of leave in 1844 she went on to marry William Stevens, another convict in Dubbo in April, 1845.

The description column of the Convict Indents, available to view on Ancestry.com.au, contained information on the convict’s physical description, with a focus on tattoos, deformities or scars, native place, age and crime. Some later editions also contained Tickets of Leave, Pardons or Certificates of Freedom as well as details of any further crimes a convict committed in the colony.

They give a fascinating insight into the pre-photography appearances of the times and show the astonishing prevalence of body art.

In fact in 1831, of the 3000 convicts transported to New South Wales about 30 per cent of the men and 10 per cent of the women were recorded as having some form of inking 1.

Another mystery of the heart found in these records is the case of Thomas Hicken. A 21-year-old farm hand from Cheshire, Thomas was convicted to life transportation to NSW for the crime of sheep stealing in 1834.

Thomas is described in the Convict Indents as 5’10” with brown eyes and brown hair and the following tattoos: a man, “when this you see, remember me and bear me in your mind” on torso; a man and woman, flowerpot, two birds, “true love” on lower right arm, man standing on an anchor, fish, on upper left arm; bird on a branch, 1831, woman and basket, on lower left arm; anchor back of left hand, blue ring on fourth finger of same, scar outside left leg.

It seems that Thomas had a sweetheart who he’d left behind in England, however his marital status is listed in is indent as “single”. Was his de facto sweetheart the woman with a basket tattooed onto his left arm? Did they meet in 1831?

Not much else is known about Thomas, and he doesn’t appear in any records for the next 64 years. As was common in those days, family members in England who were looking for relatives abroad placed advertisements in newspapers or police gazettes in an attempt to find information about them.

It seems that someone with the same last name as Thomas, from his home town of Cheshire, was looking for him and placed a Missing Friends ad in an 1898 NSW Police Gazette: “Inquiry requested as to the whereabouts of Thomas Hicken or Higgin. Arrived in this Colony by the ship “Henry Porcher” in 1835.

Description on arrival: 21 years of age, 5’10”, sallow complexion, pockpitted, brown hair brown eyes; single; a farm servant; a native of Cheshire. Inquiries at the instance of William Thomas Hicken, 17 Regent St, Moulton, near Northwick, Cheshire”.

If still alive, Thomas would have been 84 by the time this advertisement was posted. Was this man looking for him possibly his illegitimate son, named after him by a lonely sweetheart left behind in England?

Interestingly, the tattoos listed in the indents often held different meanings in the 19th century, with popular tattoos such as an anchor not symbolising a career as a mariner but rather symbolising one’s faith or hope.

Some convicts, like 13-year-old William Robinson had only one or two tattoos: “five dots lower left arm, H back of left wrist”, with others such as 27-year-old William Martin adorned with strings of letters: “ ‘MBAMAGJMJMWNTM’ on right arm, ‘woman’, ‘WBABSBJBMNDM’ and ‘TM’ on left arm, ring on left third finger”.

Small groups of letters have been interpreted as possible initials of a loved one, with larger groups of letters maybe referring to a biblical phrase or political slogan of which the meaning is now lost.

Looking at the records, it appears the five dots are a consistent form of convict tattoo, among both men and women. Although we don’t have a definitive understanding for what these dots mean, Tasmanian professor and convict expert, Hamish Maxwell-Stewart, has a theory: “the five dots tattoo which persisted into the 1870s probably means ‘I have been inside’.

The four outer dots are thought to represent the corners of the cell and the central one the prisoner.”

Although we may not know what they meant, we do know that the edgy tattooed hipsters of today are simply following a trend as old as the colonies.

related.subtitle: Pierced hearts, anchors and flower pots: The history of convict tattoos

Perisher in the NSW Snowy Mountains contacted police about 10.50pm on Wednesday after the 25-year-old failed to show up for work. Searchers found his body about 11.30pm.

Queanbeyan Acting Inspector Graeme Bailey told AAP the man was found in an ungroomed area near Guthega Creek in the NSW Snowy Mountains.

It is believed his death was a tragic accident.

“We believe it was a tragic mishap, an investigation is under way,” Detective Inspector Shane Box of Queanbeyan police said.

BULLER TRAGEDY: Boy, 7, killed in freak accident 

Detective Inspector Box said the man was a staff member at the Perisher resort.

“This was a snowboarding accident,” he said.

Detective Inspector Box said the tragedy served as a warning to others to take proper safety precautions when snowboarding, such as carrying an EPIRB tracking device.

Police found the man’s body around 11.30pm on Wednesday, less than an hour after his employer contacted police after the man failed to show up for his rostered shift.

NSW Police say he had gone snowboarding earlier in the day and failed to return.

The man’s identity has not been released.

A post mortem examination will be conducted to determine exactly how he died.

“It’s obviously a very sad day for his family and the entire Perisher community; our condolences go out to the young man’s family and friends during this difficult time,” Perisher CEO Peter Brulisauer said today.

The tragic news comes at the same time a Narabeen man has told Fairfax Media of his miraculous rescue at Thredbo.

Mike Grace, 36, triggered an avalanche when he veered off course becoming trapped beneath almost 3m of snow unable to see or move with only a small space in front of his mouth for about an hour.

Mr Grace told Fairfax he screamed out to his childhood friend but went unheard. He said breathing slowly so that he didn’t run out of air probably saved him.

It’s the second death at an Australian snow resort in the past week.

A seven-year-old boy, Haadi Akhtar, died on June 26 after being buried by snow that came loose from his lodge at Mt Buller in Victoria.

He was found nearly two hours after he went missing, just 40 metres from where he was last seen.
related.description: THE body of a ski resort worker who did not return home from a snowboarding session was found in a wooded area without trails.

To the dismay of lady-fans, Bingle was spotted without her hunky Hollywood star boyfriend Sam Worthington.

Other celebrities were also at LK Boutique’s exclusive preview of the 2014 Rolex Baselworld novelties collection at Quay restaurant in Sydney last night, including Sandra Sully, Emma Lung and Gracie Otto. 

Bingle jetted into Australia after travelling through Europe with Worthington.

And it’s not the last time we will catch a glimpse of Bingle.

The buxom blonde model will pop in again in Sydney next week for a few hours’ work.

Bingle is expected to make an appearance at a Cotton On store for the VIP launch of the brand’s new The One range, of which she is the face.

In the same month she sold her Darling Point apartment, the 27-year-old has spent the last month vacationing in Italy, relaxing on the Island of Capri with Worthington and her friend Vicki Lee and also visiting Rome.

There’s no word whether Bingle’s Avatar star partner will join her on the brief visit, but at least the globetrotter will have a chance to visit her mum and do a load of laundry.

As Harris remained holed up in his Berkshire home yesterday after after his conviction this week on 12 counts of indecent assault on four girls from 1968 to 1986, lawyers in Australia and the UK are considering­ taking legal action to freeze his assets to stop him disposing of them ahead of any civil claims.

The moves follow his trial in London being told of an email written by his daughter Bindi in July 2012 in which she said she expected to be his sole heir and likened the windfall to winning the lottery.

While Harris, 84, and his wife Alwen jointly own a $9 million mansion in millionaires’ row in Bray, southern England, the bulk of his wealth from his 60-year career is held by two companies set up on the same day in January 2012.

RHEL Holdings Ltd controls Rolf Harris Enterprises Ltd, which was established back in 1963 and has been run by his Sydney-based brother Bruce Harris, 90.

Records filed in the UK last year reveal the company had more than $2 million in cash, $4,640,000 in assets, and liabilities of $872,000.

RHS Investments, a family trust set up to minimise tax, has a net worth of $12,700,000 and cash in the bank of $3 million, records state.

The new companies were set up nine months before Scotland Yard launched Operation Yewtree, which originally investigated the sexual depravities of well-known British entertainer Jimmy Savile but was later expanded to inquire into other alleged sex offenders, including Harris.

Law firm Slater and Gordon, which is representing more than 170 of Savile’s victims through its UK office, has been contacted by a number of women in both the UK and Australia who claim they were abused by Harris.

A High Court claim could be launched in the UK within weeks. Melbourne-based Sla-ter and Gordon senior public liability partner Barrie Woollacott yesterday said they were encouraging the women to contact police and were investigating their claims as they considered seeking orders freezing Harris’s assets.

He said while Rolf Harris Enterprises was registered in Australia, it may have no ­assets here: “In order to ensure that that wealth remains available for the victims rather than being locked up in trusts or transferred, it’s important proceedings commence quickly so a freeze on those assets can be ordered by the court.’’

NSW Police were not investigating allegations against Harris because they had not received any complaints, a spokesman said.

related.body:
Farah has lit the fuse for a potentially fiery State of Origin III dead rubber by declaring: “I’ve shown that he is not better than me.”

Farah even conceded he “never quite feels part of the (Australian) side” when representing the Kangaroos behind Smith.

The pair have engaged in some epic individual battles at both club and representative level over the past 12 years.

Smith has always been rated rugby league’s premier No. 9 — and the accolade frustrates Farah, who has current bragging rights after NSW’s series win.

“It hurts every time when people say he’s a better hooker than me,” Farah said.

“I’ve said it before — you might think I’m cocky — but I go out onto the field and don’t believe anyone is better than me.

“If you do that the battle is lost already. He has been regarded as the best in the game for a long time and has a mortgage on the Australian jumper and is captain of the country.

BRISBANE BEWARE, BLUE CREW IS COMING 

PRESSURE OFF AS BLUES EYE THREE-PEAT 

“For me it’s about proving myself every time I play against him.

“I’d like to think that not only this year but every time I’ve come up against him at club or at this (Origin) level, I’ve shown that he is not better than me.

“I still believe that. It doesn’t change if we’ve won or not. That’s my mindset, whether it’s him or anyone else.

“One thing he has been praised for is his calmness and consistency and it’s something I continue to work on. I believe in what I do and the way I prepare and play.”

Farah said he has been in career-best form recently in a sixth-placed Tigers team that was tipped to struggle this season.

“You don’t like hearing that [Smith is better],” Farah said.

“It has taken me a while to get back in this (Origin) arena. I was out of it for a couple of years.

“I think the last couple of years I’ve played the best footy I’ve played in my career. Definitely the most consistent footy.

“That’s something I was criticised for in the past — my flair and the options I took. I like to think my consistency has improved.”

Farah does concede though he will struggle to oust Smith as Kangaroos hooker.

CHAMBERS ASSAULT CLAIM ROCKS MAROONS 

Asked was there anything he could do to become Australia’s starting hooker, Farah said: “Probably not. Unless he gets an injury and I wouldn’t wish that upon him.

“It’s always pretty hard going into the Aussie camp knowing you are playing second fiddle waiting for your time. I never quite feel part of the side even though you are in the squad.

“That’s the way it is, that is something you have to deal with. I am lucky to have played for Australia. Some guys never get the chance and I am grateful for the chance I had but I am also realistic and know where I stand and I am fine with that.

“Some people didn’t even think I should have been in the last squad. Some d**khead journalist in Queensland — I’d love to see him for a couple of minutes on a footy field.”

NSW back-rower Ryan Hoffman spoke glowingly about Farah and Smith.

“Cam is the best player I have ever played with,” Hoffman said.

“I have been lucky enough to play with him for 13 years. He has had a lot of success. Robbie wouldn’t have had his success if he didn’t believe in his ability or believe in the type of player he is.

“Robbie’s confidence and the belief he has in himself rubs off on his teammates. That is why Robbie has been so good at the Tigers.”

related.body:
But from the beginning there was something special.

That ability to perform under pressure, an innate drive to win that cannot be taught or learned. All it took was the right guidance, the right people, the right opportunities. And one heck of a first serve.

Nick Kyrgios grew up in Canberra to Greek dad George and Malaysian mum Norlaila — a talented badminton player.

He spent weekends playing ball boy to his tennis-loving brother Christos, eight years his senior, before picking up a racquet of his own.

Only then was he able to demonstrate an uncanny knack for hitting a ball where the other player wasn’t, and lightning hand-eye co-ordination that made up for his early lack of agility.

Brent Larkham, head coach of the Australian Institute of Sport’s men’s tennis program, coached Kyrgios for two years until 2013 and followed his progress long before that.

“He has always had that fearless approach that he showed against Nadal,” Larkham said yesterday.

“He hits the ball big off both sides and he serves and returns extremely well, so it’s no surprise he’s done so well. It’s just a bit surprising that it happened so quickly.”

Larkham admitted his former student’s movement was “never really that good”, but improved once he entered the AIS and focused on fitness.

“When he came to the AIS program he had more physiotherapy and a lot more access to the gym and that really helped him,” he said.

“But he has always had this incredible self-belief — he’s had that from day one. He’s not scared of any occasion. It has always been the bigger the match, the bigger he plays, and that is a hard thing to teach.”

Such confidence can translate to cockiness, but other mentors of Kyrgios said his feet were firmly on the ground.

Tracey Lea, a pastoral care adviser at Daramalan College, where Kyrgios completed his HSC, said Kyrgios was “a very bright boy”, popular with students and respected by teachers: “He is a really nice guy — friendly, funny and was always very physically engaged.

“He didn’t ask for special treatment but I think all his peers recognised there was something pretty extraordinary about him.”

Mrs Lea said the loss of an uncle in a motorcycle accident while Kyrgios was in Year 11 “taught him about resilience and taught him that things can hurt you”.

“He’s not all just exuberance, confidence and bravado — there is a really decent young man there, and a kind and intelligent boy as well,” she said.

Such qualities make him the perfect target for sponsorship and endorsement opportunities, according to Central Queensland University sports management expert Dr Danya Hodgetts.

She said Kyrgios’s success at Wimbledon could translate to deals worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, rising to millions if he keeps winning the big games.

“The aim now is to capitalise on that success and leverage it as soon as possible to get sponsorships,” she said.

“Certainly, he’ll get a good burst for the next 12 or 24 months, depending on what contracts he signs, and then it is really up to him being able to continue to succeed on-court and build his brand.”

CHAMPIONS win big matches for a multitude of good reasons.

Sticking it to mum isn’t usually one of them.

That, however, is ­apparently what drove Nick Kyrgios to outclass the world’s No.1 early yesterday morning while most of Australia slept.

“I saw in an interview that my mum thought Rafa was too good for me,” the towering 19-year-old said in a post-match interview at Wimbledon.

“So that made me a little angry.”

He vowed to send an SMS smiley face to his mother, Norlaila, in response to her comment.

Despite the excitement of her son’s famous win, mum was still simply calling just like she saw it yesterday.

Speaking to 3AW, Mrs Kyrgios wasn’t getting too excited about her son’s chances in his quarter-final match against Canadian Milos Raonic.

“If he’s serving well he can get it,” she said.

“But if he’s not serving well, then no.”

And she had some motherly gems of advice for her youngest boy, who has rocketed from relative obscurity to the top echelon of his sport in just 18 months.

“You just have to treat people nice, be nice to everybody, show them respect,” she said.

Just goes to show: Mums aren’t always right ... but they usually are.

Experts say the young giant killer’s fearlessness could see him become the game’s next superstar.

related.body:
The Australian teenager, wearied from the physical and mental toll of upsetting world No 1 Rafael Nadal 24 hours earlier, has been railroaded out of the All England Club by huge-serving Milos Raonic.

THE END: EXHAUSTED, SORE AND NOTHING LEFT TO GIVE 

BIG FAN: ROGER RATES KID KYRGIOS 

UK HOPE: MURRAY KNOCKED OUT OF WIMBLEDON 

LEGEND: FEDERER MOVES CLOSER TO RECORD 

REPLAY ALL THE ACTION FROM OUR LIVE BLOG BELOW

The eighth seed preyed on tiring Kyrgios to advance 6-7 (4-7) 6-2 6-4 7-6 (7-4) to a semi-final meeting with seven-time champion Roger Federer.

Federer reached his 35th grand slam semi-final — and ninth at Wimbledon — with a 3-6 7-6 (7-5) 6-4 6-4 win over fellow Swiss Stan Wawrinka as Raonic banished Krygios.

Exhausted and frustrated at not being able to secure a last-four appointment with his idol Federer, Kyrgios leaves Wimbledon knowing that he has the game to return and eventually win it.

Supported by 2002 champion Lleyton Hewitt, Ken Rosewall and Tony Roche, Kyrgios clearly struggled to recover from ousting Nadal.

As disappointed as he was to lose to Raonic, who cannoned down 39 aces, Krygios has plenty of reasons for positives.

“Never did I think that I was ever going to make quarter-finals of Wimbledon and beat (Rafael) Nadal on centre court,” said Kyrgios after the match.

“It’s all happened pretty fast.

“I don’t think it’s completely sunk in yet, you know, the achievement. I’m just going to reflect on that the next couple days.”

Scheduled to contest Newport next week, the Canberran rises to a career-high mark of world No 66 and banks a prizemoney cheque of $432,000, almost doubling his career haul.

But Raonic, the first Canadian male to reach the semi-finals here, was a bridge too far.

The world No 9 was relieved and elated to have staved off Kyrgios.

“It hasn’t really sunk in,” he said post-match.

“To have that kind of win is pretty special.

“It’s another step forward, the goal is to be the No 1 player in the world and this is another step towards that goal.”

Attempting to become the first Wimbledon debutant to reach the semi-finals since David Nalbandian in 2002, Kyrgios lacked zip in the first set against Raonic.

But he showed plenty of class and resilience by winning, despite the Canadian having more — and better — opportunities.

A framed forehand in the tiebreak rewarded Kyrgios’s doggedness but it became obvious he was running on fumes.

Broken twice in the second set to allow Raonic to draw level, Kyrgios bounced back in the third set to claim an immediate break before leading 2-0.

A few minutes later, he was back on the ropes as Raonic rolled through five successive games.

Kyrgios’s fatigue was illustrated in the botched smash he dumped into the net as Raonic maintained focus and intensity to keep the young Australian at bay.

“I think it (the Nadal match) had a pretty big impact,” he said.

“I was struggling physically about halfway through the second set. I was feeling sore in a couple places.

“But I’m not going to take any credit away from him (Raonic) He served unbelievable.

“I thought I came out strong on his first return game. I made him earn that.

“All the other service games it looked like he was in such a rhythm that I just couldn’t do anything out there.”

The lanky right-hander methodically secured the third set, leaving Kyrgios with a huge task to reach the last four.

Kyrgios battled valiantly, regrouping to force a tiebreak.

But once there, he faltered leaving Raonic to cruise 6-1. There would be one final twist as Kyrgios saved three match points before Raonic hammered home a clinching ace.

Kyrgios bowed out to the acclaim of Novak Djokovic and Grigor Dimitrov.

“He’s a pretty exciting player to watch,” Dimitrov said. “Obviously he’s got a lot of skills and talent.”

Djokovic was similarly generous.

“Kyrgios just got into the mix in this tournament. He’s a 19-yearold, which is amazing.

“It’s good for tennis to see that, because we lacked a little bit of successful teenagers in the last 10 years or so.

“So we have these youngsters coming up, fearless on the court, hitting the ball, you know, not caring who is across the net.

“It’s good. You know, it gets more attention to new faces and to new wave of generation that is able to challenge the best and be contending for grand slam titles.”

Krygios stamped himself as a future champion with wins over Stephane Robert, Richard Gasquet, Jiri Vesely and Nadal.

related.body:
But Maroons enforcer Nate Myles hit back today in the build-up to Origin III, backing Chambers to mentally cope with what he says is the biggest test of the Queensland debutant’s career.

The Queensland camp is rallying around Chambers, who is under police investigation over the alleged assault of a patron at Brisbane’s Down Under Bar yesterday morning.

The Blues are watching the Chambers saga with interest, motivated by Meninga questioning NSW’s culture after halfback Mitchell Pearce was axed over a nightclub incident in the lead-up to Origin I.

HIT UP: MAROONS PREPARED TO FAIL 

ALLEGED SCUFFLE TARNISHES WILL’S DEBUT 

CHAMBERS DRAMA ‘STORM IN A TEACUP’: COYNE 

When asked in NSW camp today whether Meninga has egg on his face over that sentiment in light of the Chambers fallout, Bird didn’t hold back.

“I guess he probably does,” the NSW hardman said.

“NSW boys have been in their share of strife over the last couple of years .... off-field dramas.

“It’s nice to be tucked away in Coffs Harbour and not be a part of it.

“But it’s the nature of today’s society that the smallest thing is going to be exaggerated and everything from the past brought up.

“But I am sure it’s a storm in a teacup and glamourised for the media.”

Bird said the arrest of Blake Ferguson last year before game two in Brisbane for indecent assault was a distraction and said Queensland would experience a similar problem this week.

“I know our situation last year going into game two without ‘Fergo’ it did create quite a distraction to start the camp,” he said.

“You don’t want to talk about it or dwell on it, you just want to focus on football. You don’t need these dramas.”

No charges have yet been laid and Chambers will formally make his Origin debut this Wednesday night if Queensland police choose not to take action against the Maroons rookie.

Myles said Maroons players are supporting Chambers but concedes the 26-year-old is facing the ultimate test of character if cleared to play at Suncorp Stadium.

“I’ll throw it out there, this is another test for the man,” he said.

“If it wasn’t enough getting ready for his first (Origin) game, now it’s a test of getting ready with another thing over him.

“But Will is a great bloke and his footy has been doing enough to get him in the side. I know he will be alright, he just has to train hard and play better on the night.

“It’s not the first time we’ve had distractions in camp, as a team we need to keep doing what we are doing.

“None of the boys have been affected by it, to be honest we haven’t even spoken about it.

“We’ll see how it pans out but I think he’ll be fine.”

Myles, who was sacked by the Roosters in 2011 for breaching an alcohol ban, said some NRL players have stopped going out to avoid being a public target.

“I know a lot of blokes who are already on that bandwagon, they just play it safe and cross out the uncontrollables and do it that way,” he said.

“To their credit it works a bit better for them.

“There’s no excuses in this ... but for sure, there’s no doubt that sometimes people as an incentive will target someone (an NRL player).

“There is so much of a view and criticism of footy players and how they should act, but it goes both ways, there are people out there who can be as silly as footballers.

“Footy players aren’t the only ones who can act silly. It goes both ways and unfortunately it happens and you have to be careful with it.”

Peters’s brother and Today Show host Karl Stefanovic has revealed that Peter has brought Sylivia home to the Sunshine State to meet mum.

Karl said Sylivia was a hit at the Stefanovic Sunday roast.

“She has been around a couple of times when Pete is home from London and everyone likes her,” Karl, recording for the show in Logan yesterday, said.

“She is a beautiful woman and super smart and most importantly, from Queensland.

“It is a big thing to cope with the in-laws, usually there is always a dodgy uncle but she has the crazy brother-in-law.

“It is early days and I don’t want to put pressure on it, I wish them all the best.”

Speaking from Sydney yesterday, Jeffreys laughed of suggestions she was a future Mrs Stefanovic.

Sylvia Jeffreys replaces Georgie Gardner on Today show 

Four weeks in to her new role, the on-air banter about her relationship has kept audiences amused.

“It started on my second day,” she said.

“I find it is best to smile and ignore. I try and quickly deflect, that is my tactic with Karl.”

She said she knows the teasing from Karl comes from a good place.

“He is just having a laugh,” she said. “It all adds to the excitement of the show.”

Karl Stefanovic says sorry

related.body:
Mr Richell, 41, chief executive officer of Hachette Australia, was pulled out of the water and onto sand about 2pm.

Police suspect he was washed up shore and was found on rocks at Tamarama.

Hachette UK group chief executive officer Tim Hely Hutchinson confirmed Mr Richell’s death.

“With great sorrow, and in shock, we have to announce the death of our beloved friend and colleague, Matt Richell, CEO of Hachette Australia and Chairman of Hachette New Zealand, who was tragically killed in a surfing accident today,” he said.

“Our thoughts and most heartfelt condolences are with Matt’s wife Hannah, his family, his colleagues and many friends in publishing and more widely.”

Mr Richell and his wife Hannah are from Britain and were living in Balmain in Sydney’s inner west with their children aged six and three.

Paramedics performed CPR for an extended period of time before an ambulance helicopter arrived but sometime after he was declared dead.

“He suffered a head injury... it looks like a possible drowning.

“It was not treated as suspicious,” police said.

Investigations are continuing and a report will be prepared for the coroner.

A surfer said he saw people screaming down to the water pointing at a man who needed help.

“I looked at him and he was already struggling on his board,” he said.

“He was covered in scratches, he must have tried to jump off a rock.

Another witness expressed his outrage indicating there should have been a life saver watching.

“Why don’t they have someone down there,” he said.

“He separated from his board, his foot strap was loose and then he just went flying into the rocks.”

The man said the surfer was waving his hands in the air and then got pushed around by the current into the rocks.
related.byline: Sarah Crawford, Ben Pike, Tanya Smart and Shae McDonald
