related.body:
Filmed at the picturesque North Palm Beach, the show has stood the test of time to clock up its 6000th episode tonight at 7pm Channel 7).

To celebrate, here are the 10 biggest stars to come out of the show:

Guy Pearce may be one of Australia’s biggest stars, who’s been in everything from The Hurt Locker to Memento, but he was killed off after six weeks on Home and Away.

He played David Croft — A failed investor who arrived in Summer Bay in 1991 to patch things up with his sister, but ended up getting a crush on a younger woman.

While listening to a mix tape from his new love interest, he is hit by a car and is killed instantly. The distraught object of his affections then realises she’s carrying his baby.

Pearce’s impressive CV includes roles in Academy Award winning The Hurt Locker, Iron Man 3 and Prometheus.

Teenage runaway Angel Brooks may be remembered for her strong eyebrows, but if you browse the character’s history, you’ll see the plucky character played by Melissa George was no lightweight.

She became temporarily paralysed after a car crash, survived a seaplane crash, supported her baby as he was diagnosed with leukaemia, loses her husband to septicaemia and gave birth to her second child in a storm that cuts off all roads to the hospital.

It’s eyebrow-raising stuff to say the least.

George has gone on to appear in several US TV series including Alias, as well as the acclaimed Australian drama The Slap, and films ranging from Mulholland Drive to The Amityville Horror remake.

Before Australian acting great Heath Ledger played Batman bad boy The Joker, he was the resident rebel in Summer Bay.

Not only did he score a night in the back of a van with Sally Fletcher, he then tried to set her up for stealing the headmaster’s favourite record.

The prank, however was the beginning of the end as he was expelled from the school, and the series, soon after.

Ledger went on to deliver criticially acclaimed performances in Aussie films Two Hands and Candy and international blockbusters from Brokeback Mountain to The Dark Knight.

He tragically passed away in 2008, aged 28.

The fiery redhead arrives in Summer Bay as a foster child in 1994 along with her brother Curtis, but she is soon caught kissing him and it is revealed they’re not blood relatives.

After dating a drug dealer, she moves on to Angel’s husband, making a move on him while she’s supposed to be babysitting their child.

She then has a lesbian flirtation with an author that she scares away by writing a romantic short story about the two of them, however they reunite later and leave for Paris as a duo.

Post Summer Bay, Fisher has carved a niche in quirky comic film roles from The Wedding Crashers to Confessions of a Shopaholic, although recently proved she can still take a dramatic turn in The Great Gatsby. She is married to actor comedian Sacha Baron Cohen.

Long before Thor, Chris Hemsworth played the headmaster’s son Kim Hyde.

In his stint on the show from 2004 to 2007, he spent a fair amount of screen time with his shirt off — rescuing friends from the surf, joining swim squads, working out at the gym and having romantic trysts with girlfriends — including one steamy scene that followed a helicopter crash.

He also overdosed on ecstasy, was accused of sexual assault and ended up in a love triangle that saw him leaving his wife to be with his ex girlfriend.

Where is he now? Cutting a swathe through Hollywood in a string of leading man roles from Snow White and the Huntsman to The Avengers and of course, Thor.

As a wheelchair-bound love interest Julie Gibson, Naomi Watts had a short stint on Home and Away.

In one month, she had a romance thwarted by her overbearing brother Revhead, lost her father to a heart attack and left the Bay to study at university.

Now one of Hollywood’s leading dramatic actresses, Watts has starred everything from Tank Girl to King Kong and The Impossible.

The Americans know him as the sexy-but-stupid vampire hater on True Blood but for us Aussies, Ryan Kwanten will always be Vinnie Patterson.

The character arrived in Summer Bay on a jet ski in 1997 and broke a fair few hearts during his five-year stint including long-time character Sally Fletcher. He was a burger flipper by day and a stripper by night, but he got fired from his day job after wearing his burger apron to a stripping job.

After getting a full-body sunburn at a nudist beach, Sally applies lotion on his sensitive areas and discovers a lump. It turns out to be testicular cancer and he has surgery to have it removed.

He ends up in prison on fraud charges, and while Summer Bay things he died in a prison fire, he actually survived and was living in witness protection, where he dies, for real, in a farming accident.

While Kwanten has a huge fan base internationally thanks to True Blood, he has also starred in several films including Red Hill.

She may have played a super-attractive alien robot in Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen but her Home and Away role was as a shy wildling.

Her character Tasha Andrews appears on the beach in 2003 confused and disoriented, speaking only Latin. It is revealed she was raised by wacky survivalists and is reintegrated into society by way of the good folk at Summer Bay.

She finds love, gets married joins a cult and eventually, moves to Boston.

While most Australians choose a soapie, the Minogues most probably have VCRs of Home and Away and Neighbours. While Kylie was strutting around on Ramsay St, Dannii was living it up in Summer Bay.

Minogue played tomboy Emma Jackson, who was always getting into trouble sneaking alcohol, slamming doors and being an all-round spunky punk.

But the bad girl has a tragic back story of abuse at her stepfather’s hands after her father died, but grows up to reconcile with her mother. She leaves after about a year to become an air hostess on the Gold Coast.

Minogue’s post-soapie story has included stints as a pop star, TV presenter and judge on programs from Uk and Ireland’s Top Model to The X Factor.

Hollywood success story Simon Baker may be at ease cast alongside the likes of Anne Hathaway and Kevin Spacey but on Home and Away, he played a bit part.

In 1993 to 1994, Baker played James Healey but he’s also had roles on Heartbreak High and E Street.

Baker is now best known for his role as the star of US Tv series The Mentalist.

The wife of Australian cricket captain Michael Clarke joined the panel in selecting models, wearing swimwear, for the Spring/Summer David Jones launch later this month.

She told Confidential at the Docklands: “It wasn’t that long ago that I was on the other side of the fence, walking and being judged.

“It’s a great opportunity for emerging models to walk alongside Jessica Gomes and Montana Cox.

“I look for healthy models, a person full of energy and individuality and we’re such a multicultural society. It needs to be someone who will best represent the brand.”

Clarke sat alongside JETS designer Jessika Allen and David Jones stylist Kelvin Harries as over 300 models attended the casting. The David Jones launch will be held on July 30 in Sydney.

MICHAEL AND KYLY CLARKE GO UP MARKET 

SIX REASONS TO LOVE JESSICA GOMES 

Clarke, flanked by models Petra Mangos (blue bikini) and Adele McKeen (striped bikini), said she was continuing to develop her interest in fashion, strengthened by her first trip to New York in April.

“I loved that I could work and play at the same time,’’ she said.

“Seeing all the fashion trends, it’s one of the greatest things about globetrotting.”

Clarke is also busy revamping her new Sydney home after the couple recently moved into their multi-million dollar mansion.

related.body:
55-year-old Sue Wilkins said she was sorry for mocking the language and facial features of an Asian woman on a Sydney to Newcastle train on Wednesday afternoon.

The incident was filmed by a passenger and posted on YouTube. The woman became angry at two young children when they didn’t give their seats up for her.

She then began to abuse other passengers, including a man who was sitting next to an Asian woman. “Who is this little jerk-off? He can only get a gook - he can’t even get a regular girlfriend. It is so sad,” she said, as passengers groaned in offence.

“Is it really that small that you can’t get an Aussie girl? Poor man. Look at this bogan, he has got a gook.”

After she caused a scene inside the carriage, police spoke to the woman when she alighted at Strathfield in Sydney’s west.

“There were police patrolling from a local area command,” police transport command assistant commissioner Max Mitchell told reporters.

“They were there for another matter, unaware of the full circumstances of this situation.

Police spoke to the woman but decided to let her “go about her journey”, Mr Mitchell said.

Mr Mitchell didn’t know why she was allowed to walk free but stressed the woman would be charged for her “abhorrent and unacceptable behaviour”.

“The person responsible will be prosecuted,” he said.

If found guilty of offensive behaviour, she faces a $500 fine.

“This person has committed offensive behaviour,” Mr Mitchell said.

“It is a crime that we will not tolerate, particularly in regards to the racial motivation behind this incident.”

The woman told ninemsn she had a rotten day and had been scammed out of $100,000 from a man she had met on a dating website.

Sydney Trains chief Howard Collins said he was “shocked” by the rant and the company would be working with police to investigate.

“I’m just amazed - we’ve got to stamp this out,” he said.

In April, Rebecca Blessington, 28, was charged after allegedly racially abusing two Asian women on a train from Town Hall to Bondi

Jade Marr boarded the train at Central Station when Ms Wilkins told her two children and two nephews, aged between four and 10, to get off the seats.

“I was in shock at the time. I’m probably more angry today that someone could be that low and attack a child or anyone else.

“Everyone took it seriously but it actually became quite comical, it was just ridiculous.”

“We were just thinking ‘what are you doing’? It was unbelievable.

“She called the police and her goal was to get my children removed from the train because they were sitting on a seat.

“We don’t catch the train very often so the kids were worried they had done the wrong thing. 

POLICE CHARGE WOMAN OVER RACISTS RANT 

RACIST RANT ON SYDNEY BUS CAUGHT ON CAMERA 

TAMARAMA SURF VICTIM WAS FATHER OF TWO 

THREE CHARGED OVER CROWN WITNESS KILLING 

“They were frightened that the police were coming to get them. I just kept telling them that they hadn’t done anything wrong and that this woman was not responding the way that normal people do.

“My nephew was really concerned about the words she was using and the way she spoke to the other woman.

“The kids just didn’t understand why someone would say that.”

Ms Wilkins was in apologetic mood this afternoon.

“I had a rotten day,’ she told Ninemsn . ‘I’ve been chasing work for quite some time now,” she said.

“It’s awful what I said to that woman, I do agree,” Ms Wilkins said.

Wilkins became enraged at some young children after they did not give into her demands for a seat on a morning Central Coast train.

She then started abusing passengers including an Asian woman and a man who stood up for her.

“Who is this little jerk off he can only get a gook, he can’t even get a regular girlfriend — it is so sad,” she said.

“Is it really that small that you can’t get an Aussie girl? Poor man. Look at this bogan he has got a gook — look at it. She probably thinks he is rich.”

The video was posted onto YouTube by user Kareem Abdul.

“On the Central coast & Newcastle line in peak hour during school holidays,” Abdul wrote.

“I started filming as the woman became aggressive toward some children (ages 12 and under) who refused to vacate their seats when she had demanded.

“This video begins just after she had started screaming expletives into the face of the upset kids and the mother of the children got up to stand in between the lady and her kids.

“The lady then assaulted the mother and a young dude who gave up his seat for her and now the lady is calling the police … Because the kids didn’t move?”

related.body:
Rebecca Blessington, 28, was today charged with using offensive language and issued a field court attendance notice to appear at Downing Centre Local Court on May 9.

Nursing a young child in her arms, she allegedly yelled and threatened at least five women on a busy morning train between Town Hall and Bondi Junction.

The footage, allegedly filmed at about 8.30am on Tuesday April 8, shows a woman bouncing her toddler on her knee as she taunts other commuters.

One commuter filmed the entire outburst where the woman said to another passenger: “I’ll ****** hurt ya … So don’t underestimate me, ****.”

The woman said she was of Aboriginal descent before abusing two Asian women riding in the carriage.

“Youse aren’t citizens. You come in here and take our country ya *****. You know it too. And guess what mate — there’s a war comin’. A war between us and youse.”

“You know the ones that were here first? The black fellas, the Kooris, which I am. This is our country mate.”

One passenger stood up to the woman and warned that her threats were being taken seriously.

Blessington shouted in reply: “I do not care … You’re all scum!”

Another passenger pressed the train’s emergency button to alert security.

The footage was handed to the Police Transport Command and officers visited Blessington’s home at Merrylands West this morning.

Inquiries into the incident are continuing and police are urging anyone who witnessed it, or similar behaviour, to contact investigators.

The world’s most high-profile female spouses are at the centre of claims de Rossi spent a month in rehab dealing with alcohol and drug issues, stemming from ongoing issues in the pair’s relationship.

American reports have claimed the 41-year-old Aussie actor, who married DeGeneres in 2008, is believed to have spent a month in a rehab facility for drug and alcohol issues.

In a story which first appeared in the US magazine In Touch, de Rossi was said to have checked into the Passages Malibu centre in May.

Despite claims the rehab visit was a result of tense arguing between the pair — and de Rossi allegedly feeling “controlled” by DeGeneres — the famed talk show host was said to have visited her wife there every weekend.

They have since been photographed enjoying a romantic stroll together in New York and holidaying in Croatia. There is a 15 year age gap between the pair.

De Rossi, who starred in Ally McBeal, has previously spoken openly of her struggles with an eating disorder.

In her candid memoir written in 2010, which detailed her struggles with bulimia, de Rossi said “I swallowed my disillusionment in the form of cream sauces, pina coladas and pastries”.

Packer’s longtime mentor has flown to Europe with his family to escape the southern chill for a few weeks.

The touring party was headed first to Paris and then to Mediterranean waters to rendezvous with the casino magnate’s luxurious vessel.

Also enjoying Uncle Alan’s largesse is his niece Tonya Taylor and her three children and husband.

After joining Packer’s summer of fun, Jones and his party will fly on to London and then Glasgow for the Commonwealth Games which are underway July 23.

Meanwhile Packer will continue his traditional northern summer abroad - an annual event that sees him extend his now ­legendary hospitality to his closest friends.

A year ago Packer’s guests included Kerry Stokes, Karl Stefanovic and Lachlan and Sarah Murdoch though not wife Erica, who spent the 2013 summer season in LA in anticipation of the separation announcement that came soon after.

A year on and Packer’s ­now ex-wife Erica was among invited guests on this year’s roster — as were the couple’s three children, Indigo, Jackson and Emmanuelle.

Her visit came after Packer’s sometime girlfriend Miranda Kerr paid him a visit a fortnight ago.

It was heart-warming to see pictures of the family reunited in happy circumstances and Sydcon eagerly awaits the pictures of the Jones reunion.

As Harris remained holed up in his Berkshire home yesterday after after his conviction this week on 12 counts of indecent assault on four girls from 1968 to 1986, lawyers in Australia and the UK are considering­ taking legal action to freeze his assets to stop him disposing of them ahead of any civil claims.

The moves follow his trial in London being told of an email written by his daughter Bindi in July 2012 in which she said she expected to be his sole heir and likened the windfall to winning the lottery.

While Harris, 84, and his wife Alwen jointly own a $9 million mansion in millionaires’ row in Bray, southern England, the bulk of his wealth from his 60-year career is held by two companies set up on the same day in January 2012.

RHEL Holdings Ltd controls Rolf Harris Enterprises Ltd, which was established back in 1963 and has been run by his Sydney-based brother Bruce Harris, 90.

Records filed in the UK last year reveal the company had more than $2 million in cash, $4,640,000 in assets, and liabilities of $872,000.

RHS Investments, a family trust set up to minimise tax, has a net worth of $12,700,000 and cash in the bank of $3 million, records state.

The new companies were set up nine months before Scotland Yard launched Operation Yewtree, which originally investigated the sexual depravities of well-known British entertainer Jimmy Savile but was later expanded to inquire into other alleged sex offenders, including Harris.

Law firm Slater and Gordon, which is representing more than 170 of Savile’s victims through its UK office, has been contacted by a number of women in both the UK and Australia who claim they were abused by Harris.

A High Court claim could be launched in the UK within weeks. Melbourne-based Sla-ter and Gordon senior public liability partner Barrie Woollacott yesterday said they were encouraging the women to contact police and were investigating their claims as they considered seeking orders freezing Harris’s assets.

He said while Rolf Harris Enterprises was registered in Australia, it may have no ­assets here: “In order to ensure that that wealth remains available for the victims rather than being locked up in trusts or transferred, it’s important proceedings commence quickly so a freeze on those assets can be ordered by the court.’’

NSW Police were not investigating allegations against Harris because they had not received any complaints, a spokesman said.

Perisher in the NSW Snowy Mountains contacted police about 10.50pm on Wednesday after the 25-year-old failed to show up for work. Searchers found his body about 11.30pm.

Queanbeyan Acting Inspector Graeme Bailey told AAP the man was found in an ungroomed area near Guthega Creek in the NSW Snowy Mountains.

It is believed his death was a tragic accident.

“We believe it was a tragic mishap, an investigation is under way,” Detective Inspector Shane Box of Queanbeyan police said.

BULLER TRAGEDY: Boy, 7, killed in freak accident 

Detective Inspector Box said the man was a staff member at the Perisher resort.

“This was a snowboarding accident,” he said.

Detective Inspector Box said the tragedy served as a warning to others to take proper safety precautions when snowboarding, such as carrying an EPIRB tracking device.

Police found the man’s body around 11.30pm on Wednesday, less than an hour after his employer contacted police after the man failed to show up for his rostered shift.

NSW Police say he had gone snowboarding earlier in the day and failed to return.

The man’s identity has not been released.

A post mortem examination will be conducted to determine exactly how he died.

“It’s obviously a very sad day for his family and the entire Perisher community; our condolences go out to the young man’s family and friends during this difficult time,” Perisher CEO Peter Brulisauer said today.

The tragic news comes at the same time a Narabeen man has told Fairfax Media of his miraculous rescue at Thredbo.

Mike Grace, 36, triggered an avalanche when he veered off course becoming trapped beneath almost 3m of snow unable to see or move with only a small space in front of his mouth for about an hour.

Mr Grace told Fairfax he screamed out to his childhood friend but went unheard. He said breathing slowly so that he didn’t run out of air probably saved him.

It’s the second death at an Australian snow resort in the past week.

A seven-year-old boy, Haadi Akhtar, died on June 26 after being buried by snow that came loose from his lodge at Mt Buller in Victoria.

He was found nearly two hours after he went missing, just 40 metres from where he was last seen.

related.body:
Farah has lit the fuse for a potentially fiery State of Origin III dead rubber by declaring: “I’ve shown that he is not better than me.”

Farah even conceded he “never quite feels part of the (Australian) side” when representing the Kangaroos behind Smith.

The pair have engaged in some epic individual battles at both club and representative level over the past 12 years.

Smith has always been rated rugby league’s premier No. 9 — and the accolade frustrates Farah, who has current bragging rights after NSW’s series win.

“It hurts every time when people say he’s a better hooker than me,” Farah said.

“I’ve said it before — you might think I’m cocky — but I go out onto the field and don’t believe anyone is better than me.

“If you do that the battle is lost already. He has been regarded as the best in the game for a long time and has a mortgage on the Australian jumper and is captain of the country.

BRISBANE BEWARE, BLUE CREW IS COMING 

PRESSURE OFF AS BLUES EYE THREE-PEAT 

“For me it’s about proving myself every time I play against him.

“I’d like to think that not only this year but every time I’ve come up against him at club or at this (Origin) level, I’ve shown that he is not better than me.

“I still believe that. It doesn’t change if we’ve won or not. That’s my mindset, whether it’s him or anyone else.

“One thing he has been praised for is his calmness and consistency and it’s something I continue to work on. I believe in what I do and the way I prepare and play.”

Farah said he has been in career-best form recently in a sixth-placed Tigers team that was tipped to struggle this season.

“You don’t like hearing that [Smith is better],” Farah said.

“It has taken me a while to get back in this (Origin) arena. I was out of it for a couple of years.

“I think the last couple of years I’ve played the best footy I’ve played in my career. Definitely the most consistent footy.

“That’s something I was criticised for in the past — my flair and the options I took. I like to think my consistency has improved.”

Farah does concede though he will struggle to oust Smith as Kangaroos hooker.

CHAMBERS ASSAULT CLAIM ROCKS MAROONS 

Asked was there anything he could do to become Australia’s starting hooker, Farah said: “Probably not. Unless he gets an injury and I wouldn’t wish that upon him.

“It’s always pretty hard going into the Aussie camp knowing you are playing second fiddle waiting for your time. I never quite feel part of the side even though you are in the squad.

“That’s the way it is, that is something you have to deal with. I am lucky to have played for Australia. Some guys never get the chance and I am grateful for the chance I had but I am also realistic and know where I stand and I am fine with that.

“Some people didn’t even think I should have been in the last squad. Some d**khead journalist in Queensland — I’d love to see him for a couple of minutes on a footy field.”

NSW back-rower Ryan Hoffman spoke glowingly about Farah and Smith.

“Cam is the best player I have ever played with,” Hoffman said.

“I have been lucky enough to play with him for 13 years. He has had a lot of success. Robbie wouldn’t have had his success if he didn’t believe in his ability or believe in the type of player he is.

“Robbie’s confidence and the belief he has in himself rubs off on his teammates. That is why Robbie has been so good at the Tigers.”

related.body:
A laundress, she stood 5’2” and boasted a ruddy “pockpicktted complexion”, according to Convict Indents, the record kept by the British penal system to identify those sent Down Under for their sins.

But what stood Elizabeth apart was the tattoo she wore on her right hand — two double hearts pierced with arrows and surrounded by a wreath, the sort of marking you might expect to see on Ruby Rose.

Despite having the line “John Messenger I love” tattooed up her right arm and a blue ring on the forefinger of her left hand, once granted her ticket of leave in 1844 she went on to marry William Stevens, another convict in Dubbo in April, 1845.

The description column of the Convict Indents, available to view on Ancestry.com.au, contained information on the convict’s physical description, with a focus on tattoos, deformities or scars, native place, age and crime. Some later editions also contained Tickets of Leave, Pardons or Certificates of Freedom as well as details of any further crimes a convict committed in the colony.

They give a fascinating insight into the pre-photography appearances of the times and show the astonishing prevalence of body art.

In fact in 1831, of the 3000 convicts transported to New South Wales about 30 per cent of the men and 10 per cent of the women were recorded as having some form of inking 1.

Another mystery of the heart found in these records is the case of Thomas Hicken. A 21-year-old farm hand from Cheshire, Thomas was convicted to life transportation to NSW for the crime of sheep stealing in 1834.

Thomas is described in the Convict Indents as 5’10” with brown eyes and brown hair and the following tattoos: a man, “when this you see, remember me and bear me in your mind” on torso; a man and woman, flowerpot, two birds, “true love” on lower right arm, man standing on an anchor, fish, on upper left arm; bird on a branch, 1831, woman and basket, on lower left arm; anchor back of left hand, blue ring on fourth finger of same, scar outside left leg.

It seems that Thomas had a sweetheart who he’d left behind in England, however his marital status is listed in is indent as “single”. Was his de facto sweetheart the woman with a basket tattooed onto his left arm? Did they meet in 1831?

Not much else is known about Thomas, and he doesn’t appear in any records for the next 64 years. As was common in those days, family members in England who were looking for relatives abroad placed advertisements in newspapers or police gazettes in an attempt to find information about them.

It seems that someone with the same last name as Thomas, from his home town of Cheshire, was looking for him and placed a Missing Friends ad in an 1898 NSW Police Gazette: “Inquiry requested as to the whereabouts of Thomas Hicken or Higgin. Arrived in this Colony by the ship “Henry Porcher” in 1835.

Description on arrival: 21 years of age, 5’10”, sallow complexion, pockpitted, brown hair brown eyes; single; a farm servant; a native of Cheshire. Inquiries at the instance of William Thomas Hicken, 17 Regent St, Moulton, near Northwick, Cheshire”.

If still alive, Thomas would have been 84 by the time this advertisement was posted. Was this man looking for him possibly his illegitimate son, named after him by a lonely sweetheart left behind in England?

Interestingly, the tattoos listed in the indents often held different meanings in the 19th century, with popular tattoos such as an anchor not symbolising a career as a mariner but rather symbolising one’s faith or hope.

Some convicts, like 13-year-old William Robinson had only one or two tattoos: “five dots lower left arm, H back of left wrist”, with others such as 27-year-old William Martin adorned with strings of letters: “ ‘MBAMAGJMJMWNTM’ on right arm, ‘woman’, ‘WBABSBJBMNDM’ and ‘TM’ on left arm, ring on left third finger”.

Small groups of letters have been interpreted as possible initials of a loved one, with larger groups of letters maybe referring to a biblical phrase or political slogan of which the meaning is now lost.

Looking at the records, it appears the five dots are a consistent form of convict tattoo, among both men and women. Although we don’t have a definitive understanding for what these dots mean, Tasmanian professor and convict expert, Hamish Maxwell-Stewart, has a theory: “the five dots tattoo which persisted into the 1870s probably means ‘I have been inside’.

The four outer dots are thought to represent the corners of the cell and the central one the prisoner.”

Although we may not know what they meant, we do know that the edgy tattooed hipsters of today are simply following a trend as old as the colonies.

related.standFirst: OUR early convicts loved the sort of body art you would expect to see on modern day celebrities. And women were as likely to do it as men.
related.subtitle: Pierced hearts, anchors and flower pots: The history of convict tattoos

To the dismay of lady-fans, Bingle was spotted without her hunky Hollywood star boyfriend Sam Worthington.

Other celebrities were also at LK Boutique’s exclusive preview of the 2014 Rolex Baselworld novelties collection at Quay restaurant in Sydney last night, including Sandra Sully, Emma Lung and Gracie Otto. 

Bingle jetted into Australia after travelling through Europe with Worthington.

And it’s not the last time we will catch a glimpse of Bingle.

The buxom blonde model will pop in again in Sydney next week for a few hours’ work.

Bingle is expected to make an appearance at a Cotton On store for the VIP launch of the brand’s new The One range, of which she is the face.

In the same month she sold her Darling Point apartment, the 27-year-old has spent the last month vacationing in Italy, relaxing on the Island of Capri with Worthington and her friend Vicki Lee and also visiting Rome.

There’s no word whether Bingle’s Avatar star partner will join her on the brief visit, but at least the globetrotter will have a chance to visit her mum and do a load of laundry.

related.body:
But from the beginning there was something special.

That ability to perform under pressure, an innate drive to win that cannot be taught or learned. All it took was the right guidance, the right people, the right opportunities. And one heck of a first serve.

Nick Kyrgios grew up in Canberra to Greek dad George and Malaysian mum Norlaila — a talented badminton player.

He spent weekends playing ball boy to his tennis-loving brother Christos, eight years his senior, before picking up a racquet of his own.

Only then was he able to demonstrate an uncanny knack for hitting a ball where the other player wasn’t, and lightning hand-eye co-ordination that made up for his early lack of agility.

Brent Larkham, head coach of the Australian Institute of Sport’s men’s tennis program, coached Kyrgios for two years until 2013 and followed his progress long before that.

“He has always had that fearless approach that he showed against Nadal,” Larkham said yesterday.

“He hits the ball big off both sides and he serves and returns extremely well, so it’s no surprise he’s done so well. It’s just a bit surprising that it happened so quickly.”

Larkham admitted his former student’s movement was “never really that good”, but improved once he entered the AIS and focused on fitness.

“When he came to the AIS program he had more physiotherapy and a lot more access to the gym and that really helped him,” he said.

“But he has always had this incredible self-belief — he’s had that from day one. He’s not scared of any occasion. It has always been the bigger the match, the bigger he plays, and that is a hard thing to teach.”

Such confidence can translate to cockiness, but other mentors of Kyrgios said his feet were firmly on the ground.

Tracey Lea, a pastoral care adviser at Daramalan College, where Kyrgios completed his HSC, said Kyrgios was “a very bright boy”, popular with students and respected by teachers: “He is a really nice guy — friendly, funny and was always very physically engaged.

“He didn’t ask for special treatment but I think all his peers recognised there was something pretty extraordinary about him.”

Mrs Lea said the loss of an uncle in a motorcycle accident while Kyrgios was in Year 11 “taught him about resilience and taught him that things can hurt you”.

“He’s not all just exuberance, confidence and bravado — there is a really decent young man there, and a kind and intelligent boy as well,” she said.

Such qualities make him the perfect target for sponsorship and endorsement opportunities, according to Central Queensland University sports management expert Dr Danya Hodgetts.

She said Kyrgios’s success at Wimbledon could translate to deals worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, rising to millions if he keeps winning the big games.

“The aim now is to capitalise on that success and leverage it as soon as possible to get sponsorships,” she said.

“Certainly, he’ll get a good burst for the next 12 or 24 months, depending on what contracts he signs, and then it is really up to him being able to continue to succeed on-court and build his brand.”

CHAMPIONS win big matches for a multitude of good reasons.

Sticking it to mum isn’t usually one of them.

That, however, is ­apparently what drove Nick Kyrgios to outclass the world’s No.1 early yesterday morning while most of Australia slept.

“I saw in an interview that my mum thought Rafa was too good for me,” the towering 19-year-old said in a post-match interview at Wimbledon.

“So that made me a little angry.”

He vowed to send an SMS smiley face to his mother, Norlaila, in response to her comment.

Despite the excitement of her son’s famous win, mum was still simply calling just like she saw it yesterday.

Speaking to 3AW, Mrs Kyrgios wasn’t getting too excited about her son’s chances in his quarter-final match against Canadian Milos Raonic.

“If he’s serving well he can get it,” she said.

“But if he’s not serving well, then no.”

And she had some motherly gems of advice for her youngest boy, who has rocketed from relative obscurity to the top echelon of his sport in just 18 months.

“You just have to treat people nice, be nice to everybody, show them respect,” she said.

Just goes to show: Mums aren’t always right ... but they usually are.
related.description: AUSTRALIA’S Wimbledon wunderkind was a chubby boy chasing tennis balls not long ago — well fed, slow on his feet, perhaps a bit lazy.

Now, Nick Kyrgios is our latest Wimbledon wunderkid - a Greek-Australian god who served 37 aces to blast world No. 1 Rafael Nadal off the court. Experts say the young giant killer’s fearlessness could see him become the game’s next superstar.
related.subtitle: Nick Kyrgios: Ball boy to boy wonder as Wimbledon dream puts his name up in lights

Mr Richell, 41, chief executive officer of Hachette Australia, was pulled out of the water and onto sand about 2pm.

Police suspect he was washed up shore and was found on rocks at Tamarama.

Hachette UK group chief executive officer Tim Hely Hutchinson confirmed Mr Richell’s death.

“With great sorrow, and in shock, we have to announce the death of our beloved friend and colleague, Matt Richell, CEO of Hachette Australia and Chairman of Hachette New Zealand, who was tragically killed in a surfing accident today,” he said.

“Our thoughts and most heartfelt condolences are with Matt’s wife Hannah, his family, his colleagues and many friends in publishing and more widely.”

Mr Richell and his wife Hannah are from Britain and were living in Balmain in Sydney’s inner west with their children aged six and three.

Paramedics performed CPR for an extended period of time before an ambulance helicopter arrived but sometime after he was declared dead.

“He suffered a head injury... it looks like a possible drowning.

“It was not treated as suspicious,” police said.

Investigations are continuing and a report will be prepared for the coroner.

A surfer said he saw people screaming down to the water pointing at a man who needed help.

“I looked at him and he was already struggling on his board,” he said.

“He was covered in scratches, he must have tried to jump off a rock.

Another witness expressed his outrage indicating there should have been a life saver watching.

“Why don’t they have someone down there,” he said.

“He separated from his board, his foot strap was loose and then he just went flying into the rocks.”

The man said the surfer was waving his hands in the air and then got pushed around by the current into the rocks.
related.byline: Sarah Crawford, Ben Pike, Tanya Smart and Shae McDonald

related.body:
It’s estimated the scheduling will cost the code up to 100,000 in crowd figures in the final four rounds from stay-at-home fans at a time when attendance figures have just recovered from a disastrous start to the year.

Senior NRL officials don’t want anything to do with 7.45pm Thursday kick-offs but are legally obliged, under its contract with Channel Nine, to include five matches in the timeslot on the schedule every season for the next four years.

The Thursday nights schedule includes:

*Round 23 Rabbitohs v Broncos at ANZ Stadium;

*Round 24 Eels v Sea Eagles at Parramatta Stadium

*Round 25 Bulldogs v Rabbitohs at ANZ Stadium; and

*Round 26 Roosters v Rabbitohs at Allianz Stadium.

The TV deal was done by the previous administration before Dave Smith took over.

Fans voiced their outrage on social media on Tuesday afternoon over the Thursday night scheduling.

“More the reason to not be a member, impossible to get families to Nrl = clowns.” said David on Twitter.

“Once again made for television only — not made for the fans. Regional fans locked out of games due to travel, said Matt Roberts.

The club were not happy either.

Bulldogs CEO Raelene Castle said the club was disappointed with the scheduling of the Rabbitohs blockbuster in Round 25 on a Thursday night.

“On a Sunday afternoon we would have got 40 to 50,000,” she said.

“On a Thursday night it’s far more challenging and probably more like 30,000.

“I know we have a broadcaster that pays us a lot of money but the network would also prefer to have a product with full stadiums.”

Channel Nine boss David Gyngell was sticking to his guns last night when asked about the impact the scheduling had on fans and clubs.

“It gives fans an extra live game each week on free-to-air,” Gyngell said.

“And it gives the NRL a bigger build-up to the semi-finals.

“The clubs have got to remember they used to get grants of $4.5 million and they’re now getting $7 million from the money we and Fox Sports are paying them.

“The money they get from television is more than what they might lose in crowds.”

South Sydney played the Roosters on a Thursday night in round one to launch the season on a Thursday night and attracted only 27,000 fans on a school night.

As a result, round one crowds were down by 20 per cent.

Had it been played 24 hours later on the more traditional Friday night kick-off time at ANZ Stadium, officials believe they would have got 40,000 to the game.

Crowds have since recovered after 16 rounds to be level with last year’s figures.

The competition’s most overexposed team, the Broncos, have again drawn prime-time spots in five of the last six rounds.

The Eels too were disappointed at having their blockbuster against Manly in Round 24 scheduled on a Thursday night.

“While we do value our broadcast partners, it’s important that the interests of our 18,000 members are also considered in these decisions,” said CEO Scott Seward.

“Thursday night football can be difficult for families and this will obviously impact the crowd for such an important game.”
related.description: THE NRL has reluctantly given Channel Nine four Thursday night blockbuster games in the final rounds of the premiership, angering fans and costing the game millions of dollars in gate takings.
related.standFirst: THE NRL has reluctantly given Channel Nine four Thursday night blockbuster games in the final rounds, costing the game millions in gate takings.

related.body:
Adding weight to arguments the government’s controversial new bail laws are designed to relieve pressure on overflowing prisons, some jails have been forced to house three inmates in cells designed for two, with concerns there are not enough guards to safely handle the increase.

The revelation comes after Opposition Leader John Robertson ­accused the government of relaxing the bail laws to make room in jails.

Attorney-General Brad Hazzard has since ordered an urgent review of the laws. The Public Service Association’s prison officers branch has voted unanimously to refuse entry to new prisoners at jails where there government is trying to increase prisoner numbers.

The Bureau of Crime Statistics and Research warned this year that the prison population was at a record high of 10,917 and was expected to rise by another 17 per cent — to 12,500 inmates — by next March.

BOCSAR warned the explosion in the prison population was a “significant concern” and sources within government are spooked that a ­“crisis” is looming.

Prison Officers Vocational Branch chair Steve McMahon said prison ­officers were sick of being “human punching bags” and regularly had ­unsafe staffing levels.

“In some jails it’s not uncommon for 20 prison officers to be on duty to supervise more than 300 inmates,” Mr McMahon said.

A Corrective Services NSW spokeswoman said the “three-out” cells had been used for decades when there was a fluctuation in the prison population, and affected 80 cells across the system: “This means about 2 per cent of all inmates are housed in three-out cells. The use of three-out cells is a short-term measure. We are also planning for new accommodation buildings to be built at existing prisons and, in the longer term, building new prisons if and as required.”

In 2011 the state government closed three prisons that housed a total of 900 inmates.

Mr McMahon said prison officers did not have a safe working environment and would campaign for the same WorkCover provisions as police

related.body:
Hayne, 26, comes off contract after next year, and Parramatta management are desperately keen to kick-start negotiations early.

“If I wanted to go, I’d be long gone,” Hayne stressed.

Hayne spoke of a bright new era at Pirtek Stadium with a robust roster, flamboyant style and a rising coach in Brad Arthur.

“What he is building and the way he is coaching, I think he has a huge amount of talent as a coach,” Hayne said.

“He can read the game and reads the plays.

“For us, we want to make the finals. You look at the game on the weekend (versus Newcastle), we didn’t have a finals attitude and we should have wrapped that game up.

“If we had a better mentality and more experience we would have won. We went close, don’t get me wrong.

“We are definitely still in the hunt. We just need to find a bit of rhythm, that’s all we are lacking. We are a good team but not a great team at the moment.”

Parramatta has a big, fast and young football side.

With Arthur moulding the future, Parramatta is poised to yet again become a rugby league force.

“In the next couple of years when we can fix up our salary cap and start to buy marquee players, that will help as well,” Hayne said.

Asked was Parramatta about to sign Bulldogs centre Krisnan Inu, Hayne said: “I think there was (some talk about that).

“The last time I spoke to him, he was um-ing and ar-ing.”

Hayne is now back in camp with NSW and ready to star again in Origin III at Suncorp Stadum next Wednesday night.

The brilliant fullback was in tears after securing the historic series win in Sydney. They were television images that will forever be etched into Origin folklore.

“It was emotional and it was a long time coming,” Hayne said.

“It kind of caught up with me, especially seeing some of the older boys, Robbie, ‘Lukey’ (Lewis) and ‘Gal’ (Paul Gallen).

“To be apart of it was huge and special.”

Hayne denied this game should be referred to as a “dead rubber”.

“Everyone who has pulled on the jersey wants to win,” Hayne said.

Asked would Queensland come out fighting given their series failure, Hayne said: “You’d think so. I am sure they are going to want to win on their home ground.

“This game will be just as important as the first two. Origin is Origin, it wouldn’t matter whether we have been beaten 25 games in a row or won 25 games in a row.

“You want to win.”

Hayne has been simply stunning in this year’s series, particularly game one in Brisbane.

“I try and play my best every week and try and do my thing,” he said.

Maximillian Mazzilli, 33, is one of three men charged over the 2011 murder of Gemahl Maika, who was a Crown witness in a key drug trial.

Mazzilli was refused bail at Parramatta Local Court today.

Drug lord Luke “Fatboy” Sparos, who is currently serving time at Lithgow Jail, was been charged with murder this afternoon. He is appear at Lithgow Local Court today.

A 34-year-old Banksia woman was also charged with accessory before the fact to murder.

She is expected to appear before Parramatta Local Court today.

The court heard the Tweed Heads resident was on parole at the time of the alleged murder, has a history of interfering with witnesses and has an “unenviable” criminal record.

Mr Maika was killed in the driveway of his Glen Alpine home, in Sydney’s southwest, on April 6, 2012 shortly after returning from a TAFE night class.

The 38-year-old was a key witness in Operation Schoale, an investigation into a multi-million dollar Golden Gun drug syndicate believed to have imported more than 700kg of cocaine into Australia.

Homicide squad Commander Detective Superintendent Mick Willing said Mr Maika was offered witness protection before his murder but refused it.

A 29-year-old man from Peakhurst, and a 46-year-old man from Sydney were charged with accessory before the fact to murder.

They are expected to appear before the same court this afternoon.

A 34-year-old woman was arrested this morning at Campbelltown over the murder but is yet to be charged.

Police will allege Mazzilli was the shooter in Mr Maika’s alleged murder.

All three have been refused bail and are expected to appear in Parramatta Local Court on Thursday.

“Every single day people come forward and provide police with evidence,” Det Supt Willing said. “Every single day criminals give evidence against other criminals.

“We have a range of mechanisms to protect those people who come forward.

“Unfortunately in this case, Mr Maika declined all offers of assistance to him prior to his death.”

Three years of investigations led to the arrest of three men over the murder on Wednesday.

Det Supt Willing, commended Strike Force Hedgegrow detectives for their work and urged anyone with information to contact Crime Stoppers.

The investigation by Strike Force Hedgegrow continues and more arrests are expected, police said.

related.body:
It was a nice disguise.

Part of a wonderful veneer this humble Gerringong publican carried through four Parramatta premierships and 33 Tests for Australia.

And last night … well, the ‘Crow’ was at it again.

For when you think the greatest player in Parramatta Rugby League history — the elite Eel if you like — most opt immediately for Ray Price. Mr Perpetual Motion.

That bearded warrior who bled buckets, tackled himself unconscious and had a greater affinity for grease than even Olivia Newton John.

A hero whose bronzed image now stands guard outside Pirtek Stadium.

And if not Pricey, then surely you would pick halfback Peter Sterling. Or at a pinch, the mercurial Brett Kenny.

Maybe even Ken Thornett — that 1960s fullback they dubbed ‘The Mayor of Parramatta’ - for those whose memories stretch back far enough.

But then Cronin comes along and pips them all.

More unassuming than an Amish wardrobe, the bush hotelier was on Wednesday night crowned ‘Champion of Parramatta’ in a gala ceremony at The Star.

Here, truly, was a result equal parts surprising and apt.

Remembering that in Michael William Cronin, you have a footballer who represented Australia while still playing for Gerringong.

A centre who would eventually retire with not only more points than any Kangaroo, but anyone who ever played the game before him.

Cronin was strong. Evasive. A footballer back when the phrase meant plenty.

And ball skills? Here was a fella who could put you through the eye of a needle if required.

Famously commuting from his south coast hometown, the Crow would eventually play 10 years and 216 games for his beloved Eels.

Staying true despite rival offers — which allegedly included offers of a helicopter ride on game day by Manly — and a serious injury to his eye.

So, sure, by the end he had one peeper and a waddle.

For most rivals, it was still too much.

The 23-year-old, who jetted to Los Angeles with her shock-jock boyfriend Kyle Sandilands on the weekend, showed off her petite frame in a barely-there, skin-coloured two-piece on social media.

“Sun all day, errday,” she wrote on one Instagram picture, which was taken in a bathroom.

The model has been out and about in LA, sharing with her followers her travels, including her trip to the city’s famed Sunset Strip.

The US holidays comes after the couple travelled to Dubai for the Kyle and Jackie O show in May.

Anthony has been embroiled in a war of words with Sandiland’s ex-wife, Tamara Jaber, who is now based in LA.

In a wonderful rugby league family twist, Moses, 19, will make his NRL debut at the Tigers spiritual home, Leichhardt Oval, the same suburban venue where his uncle carved out a ball-playing reputation in the 1980s.

Whereas Elias brought cheek and creative flair out of dummy-half, Moses has played the majority of his junior football in the halves, starring in the Australian Schoolboys class of 2012 alongside fellow Tigers young gun Luke Brooks.

On Sunday against the table-topping Panthers, Moses is expected to get an opportunity playing fullback after James Tedesco suffered a broken knee cap last weekend, ruling him out for up to 12 weeks.

Fortuitously, Moses will get the perfect tutor to help him adapt to the intricacies of wearing the no.1 jumper in Tigers coach Mick Potter, who won two Dally M Medals playing fullback in 1984 and 1991.

When contacted by The Daily Telegraph, Potter said Moses had been training at fullback this week because the club was still awaiting a fitness report on Blake Austin, who sustained an ankle injury last weekend.

“We’ve got to see how Blake Austin is, he’s having a bit of trouble with his ankle,” Potter said.

“Mitchell’s on standby. He trained with the side the other day because Blake was sick and I’m waiting for the physio to give me a call.

“It could work out Mitchell does play but we will give Blake ample opportunity to recover.”

Moses was previously slated to make his NRL debut in round nine against premiers Sydney Roosters before being suspended for two weeks for making a homophobic slur in the under 20s State of Origin fixture.

The ascension of Moses to the NRL continues the strong family ties from the Balmain Tigers side which played in the 1988 and 1989 grand finals, where Wayne Pearce, Paul Sironen, Steve Roach, Garry Jack and Elias were all club icons.

Sironen’s son, Curtis, recently returned from a foot injury and has been earmarked as an NRL star of the future for the past couple of seasons, Pearce’s son Mitchell has played NRL since age 17 while Jack’s son Kieran is a star for the Sydney Swans in the AFL.

Moses, Brooks and Sironen were all products of the renowned rugby league nursery Holy Cross Ryde.

Video shows that the man pulls out in front of the pack of bikies at which point they block the couple’s car in and furiously start shoving him around.

When they throw him on to the bonnet of the car his girlfriend gets out of the vehicle.

Just as things looked set to get worse, the man gets down on one knee and asks the stunned girl to marry him.

Not only that but these rough and tough bikers reveal a bouquet of flowers for the woman and start applauding.

The video was posted in Russia and while the couple has not been identified, their love story has clocked up more than 800,000 views.

Unconventional? Sure. But it is one wedding proposal this bride-to-be will never forget.

Four major unions are threatening action over Bechtel’s demands that the workforce remain on a roster that means they work four weeks followed by one week off, a deal they agreed to in the previous enterprise agreement.

Unions are demanding a 3 and 1 roster and have won approval to go to a vote of workers for protected action. Bechtel’s offer has already been rejected twice by the workers.

Adding tension to the issue is that gas has already started to arrive at the island, piped from the Surat Basin, and one company, QGC, is scheduled to start exporting to Asia in December while others have another year.

Bechtel has fired back warning the workers of potential lock outs and stand downs of non-striking workers if unions take action.

KEEP READING TO FIND OUT HOW MUCH WORKERS EARN

More news... 
‘YOU KILLED YOUR WIFE, MR BADEN-CLAY?’ 
BIKER ‘ATTACK’ LEADS TO THE UNEXPECTED 
KARL RIBS SYLVIA OVER ROAST AND ROMANCE 

The affected workers are some of the best paid tradesman in Queensland with electricians earning $160,000 and labourers earning $135,000, but the toll of working away from home for four weeks straight of 10-hour days is telling and even the company admits it’s not for everyone, but that is also the reason they are highly paid.

It has also offered an average 13 per cent pay rise as part of the new enterprise agreement.

Bechtel has warned that its offer is only on the table until the end of July and that it will not buckle to demands.

“Bechtel can respond to those employees taking protected industrial action by taking action itself,’’ a note distributed to Curtis Island supervisors said.

“An example of this is that Bechtel can lock out employees who have taken protected industrial action. Such lock outs can be for an indefinite period.’’

It said it also had the right to stand down sections of the workforce who cannot be productively employed.

“These employees may not be the ones taking protected industrial action but nevertheless will lose money because of that action,” Bechtel said.

“It is business as usual at the projects. The existing agreement, though it expired on June 5, stays in place until it is terminated or replaced.

“The deal on the table is a fair and reasonable deal for all parties with many concessions won by the workforce, particularly in the current economic environment.

“These projects were planned to 4 and 1 rosters and non-local employees signed up to a 10-hour work day and that will not change for these projects.’’

The unions did not respond yesterday.

More news...

‘YOU KILLED YOUR WIFE, MR BADEN-CLAY?’

GERARD Baden-Clay has faced a barrage of prosecution accusations that he overpowered and probably smothered his wife Allison before dumping her body. Read more...

related.body:
After lining up for around 10 minutes I managed to squeeze into the last carriage, where I looked for an empty seat as I didn’t plan on standing for the entire trip to the end of the line. All the seats were taken, except one.

Three Aboriginal men were sitting in a four-berth seat by the door, where most people were crowded around. I hesitated for a second, to make sure nobody else was heading for the seat, and then walked through the standing passengers and asked if the seat was being used.

The men, having been sitting quietly, suddenly perked up and the man sitting next to the empty seat smiled and said, “No, you can sit here, please”. So I did.

To begin with, the men were quiet and respectful and didn’t talk or look at me. I could sense some discomfort so I made a comment about how cold it was. This was met with more smiles and nods of agreement.

VIDEO: Vile racist rant on Sydney train 

A minute or so later one of the men broke the ice by asking me what the time was, and when I thought the train would be leaving. Soon we were talking about all sorts of things.

We discussed the footy (they were supporting the wrong team), arguing about the cricket (you can’t go for the West Indies having just left Adelaide Oval), and laughing about netball — the oldest man’s wife loves it and we all agreed it is terrible.

We also discovered how many of the same places we had visited. They come from Alice Springs and I have travelled as far north as Pukatja and the surrounding towns. We discussed donkeys and camels and what I had been doing there — in 2005 I had travelled up with a rock band to take live music to the APY communities.

As the men reached their destination, they stood up and called out goodbyes and waved to the other passengers. The oldest man said ‘‘God bless you mob’’ before exiting the carriage. As the doors closed I waved one last time to the last guy saying, ‘‘See ya sis’’, and from behind me I heard the words, ‘‘Thank God”.

I thought for a second, decided to ignore the comment, and started to put in my headphones. Then I was tapped on the shoulder, and a comment was made along the lines of ‘‘Bet you’re relieved — those people really shouldn’t be allowed to drink!’’, followed by nervous giggling.

I turned to see a group of women sitting in the seats behind me, looking concerned and sympathetic. I removed the earphone, took a deep breath, and launched quietly into speech along the following lines:

“Excuse me! Those men were the friendliest, most polite people I have sat with on a train in years. I thoroughly enjoyed sitting with them and it completely sucks that when they got off, I was left sitting on a train amid a bunch of rude women, surrounded by an entire train full of white people who I am sure represent the very destruction of the traditional home of those men.

“Yet if anyone on the train had made the effort to speak to or even look at one of these blokes, they would have been treated with respect and friendliness.

“As for the alcohol you believed you could smell on them, yes, they have been at the football and had a couple of drinks, as did you obviously, but the alcohol you can smell is from me. I served hundreds of people today and am covered in beer and wine.

“Don’t you dare even think about responding to me right now, you disgust me and should be ashamed of yourselves”.

A small section of the carriage near us applauded quietly. One of the women cried, and the majority pretended they weren’t even on the train and had heard nothing. Maybe they didn’t. But they will now.

■ ■ ■ ■

My mother grew up along the South Australian section of The Ghan train line. My family has travelled extensively through the Outback on holidays as children and teenagers, and I was brought up to be aware of, respectful towards, interested in and involved with indigenous Australian culture.

I studied subjects relating to it at university. I understand, as much as I can being of British descent, what happened here and how the effects will be felt forever. But to be confronted with it first-hand in 2014 by people who an hour earlier were screaming together with these men in elation for Eddie Betts  was so hypocritical and disappointing.

I posted this story as a Facebook  status on Monday afternoon, and not 24 hours later it had received more than 9000 likes — 36 hours later it has more than doubled. The response has been overwhelming, and I have received so many messages of congratulations and thanks, from across the state, country and the world.

I am so glad the message has been received so positively by so many. However I am not looking for congratulations, as one woman has accused me of doing.

I merely did what I was raised to do, and stood up for what was right. I did what everybody should be doing.

I, like so many, hope to one day live in an Australia without division. We act like we have that, but the responses to my status have shown me that this still happens every day, often to the faces of the victims, and their children after them.

The education is there, the pathways are being paved, but so often we find that the minority is much louder. We see these stories of racism, often going unanswered. We hear about how it is ‘‘justified’’. We see responses to stories such as mine talking about how I must have run into the “good ones’’.

I just hope that by standing up and defending my new friends, and then sharing my story with others who may wish they had had the courage to do the same in a similar situation once, I can show people how much good it can do to convince yourself that you’re brave, just for 20 seconds.

This is not an acceptable way to live. Someone wrote to me this week: “Reconciliation is just a word unless we live it’’. And that does go both ways. I am not saying racism is one-sided. But somebody needs to be willing to start trying.

Why not you?

Brooke Skewes works in the hospitality industry and is a regular train commuter.
related.description: ON Sunday night following the Showdown in Adelaide, I finished work and headed to the train station. The platform was packed, the train carriages were filling up fast, and on most there was standing room only.
related.standFirst: IT doesn’t take much to spark up a conversation with someone of a different colour or race, but the reaction from those around you can sometimes be appalling.
related.subtitle: Brooke Skewes: Chance encounter with a friendly group of Aboriginal men on the train tells a story about us all

related.body:
The photo — which shows the first time Bethany Townsend, 23, dared to bare after being fitted with two colostomy bags — has now been viewed by an incredible nine million people.

Bethany, a makeup artist from Worcester in the UK, has been so overwhelmed by the response that she can finally acknowledge that the colostomy bags doesn’t define who she is.

“I didn’t expect this kind of reaction at all,” she said of the picture.

“When I first had the bags fitted I was devastated — the reaction to this photo has really helped me accept them.

“The photo has been seen by millions of people ... I’m just so glad that it’s brought about more awareness of Crohn’s disease, and it’s made me feel so much more confident.”

Bethany was fitted with her colostomy bags after battling with Crohn’s disease since the age of three. It is a condition that causes inflammation of the digestive system, affecting the sufferer’s ability to digest food, absorb nutrients and eliminate waste.

In extreme situations like Bethany’s, it becomes necessary to remove the damaged section of the intestine and bring the healthy part out as a stoma — known as a colostomy.

After almost dying when her bowel ruptured in 2010, Bethany woke from a life-saving operation to find she had been fitted with two colostomy bags.

“Growing up I’d had various surgeries to try and combat the Crohn’s,” said Townsend. “I’d go in and have sections of my intestine cut out, but I’d only be in remission for a couple of weeks before it came back again.

“Then, four years ago I woke up in the morning and couldn’t move because I was in so much agony. I had to break a glass on the floor to alert my mum who called on ambulance. When the paramedics came they lifted up my top to see that my surgery scar had split open. I was rushed to intensive care where they doctors told me family I would need more surgery as my intestines had become infected and inflamed again. I had no idea when I woke up that I would have the bags.

“When I first woke up and my mum told me about them I was just relieved as I’d thought I was going to die. When I came out of hospital and everything finally sunk in, I remember going upstairs into my bedroom and just bursting into tears.

“I’d known a colostomy bag might have been an option but it was always something that I had wanted to avoid. I had a really good cry that day, and since then I haven’t shed another tear — I’ve just got on with it I suppose.”

It was only after Townsend met and married her husband, Ian, 33, and jetted off to Mexico last Christmas that she finally felt ready to embrace the colostomy bags.

“When I met Ian I showed him my bags straight away, but he didn’t bat an eye lid — I actually felt like I was overreacting,” she said.

“He taught me that there was more to me than the bags and would always encourage me to show off my figure. I wasn’t sure but in Mexico I finally realised he was right, and decided to wear my bikini.

“At first I was nervous and worried that people would stare but it was fine. The staff at the hotel asked me about the bags on the last day of the holiday, but rather than being offended I was glad because it meant I could talk to them about Crohn’s and tell them what it is.

“I decided to get in touch with Crohn’s and Colitis UK Facebook group to see if they would let me post something on their page. I sent them the picture and my information, and it all blew up from there.”

Townsend still suffers from Crohn’s disease and hopes ones day for a cure, but for now she is considering getting back into modelling — a career she gave up on after she was fitted with the bags.

“I feel confident enough now to put myself out there and pursue modelling again,” she said.

“I did a little bit of work here and there before I had the colostomy bags, but once I had them fitted I thought that was the end of the dream. I’m looking forward to chasing my goals, and I know now that nothing can hold me back.

“I won’t let the Crohn’s control me anymore.”
related.description: A STUNNING brunette has become an internet sensation after bravely posting a bikini snap on Facebook that exposes her colostomy bags.
related.standFirst: SHE’S become a sensation after posting a bikini snap on Facebook, exposing the medical equipment she was once ashamed of.

related.body:
Brisbane obstetrician and former president of the Australian Medical Association Queensland Dr Gino Pecoraro says motherhood has become “filled with shame and guilt’’.

LIST: Wavell Heights’ Bowerbird cafe gets breastfeeding association green light 

SUPPORT: Bid to help isolated bottle-feeding mums 

He sees mothers and mothers-to-be every day who feel guilty about the choices they are making.

“I am all for removing the guilt from having babies,’’ he said. “We seem hell bent on making women feel guilty about everything to do with having children, leaving it too late, how they conceive, how the baby comes out and then how you feed it, how much time you spend with it.

“It is the most natural thing in life, central to all of us, so why do we keep beating women up about what they do?’’ he asked.

Dr Pecoraro, who is the AMA’s federal spokesman for obstetrics and gynaecology, said this was particularly true for women who chose an elective caesarean over a natural birth, or women who formula fed instead of breast fed their babies.

“The last thing that a sleep-deprived woman with a baby who won’t breastfeed needs is to be told she won’t get help with formula feeding and that her baby is missing out on the benefits of breastfeeding,’’ he said.

Once the children were older, returning to work also created an “obscene amount of guilt’’.

“There is this superwoman myth that women have to work and continue working until the baby is born, otherwise be worried other working mums will think less of them,’’ he said.

“You have to do what is right for you, not push yourself to exhaustion to keep up with other working mums.’’

Mother Angela Hedley, 36, was unable to breastfeed her children Harrison, 7, Jessica, 5, and Charlotte, 2, due to a lactose intolerance. She said she felt guilty when she couldn’t do “the natural thing’’.

“With Harry I was a first-time tired mum, it was very exhausting and I assumed I was going to be perfect at breastfeeding,’’ she said.

“I felt guilty buying tinned stuff when I had milk, but they slept better and all were healthy. Lots of people look at you when you are feeding them in public with bottles.’’
related.description: ONE of Brisbane’s leading obstetricians has called on mothers to stop shaming each other and making each other feel guilty about the way they are raising their child.

related.body:
The request, on top of calls for a top-up to their 15.4 per cent super and mandated 15-minute tea breaks morning and afternoon, comes as current enterprise agreements for Australian public servants expired on Monday.

The eight-page Australia Services Union document suggested staff should be able to finish work outside peak public transport times and should have additional breaks for private reasons.

“(We propose) limited access to flexitime for shift workers be provided to allow employees to take additional breaks that may be necessary for private purposes such as to move a car or to take a smoking break,” the document said.

ASU tax branch secretary Jeff Lapidos said the request to use flexitime was not specifically about smoking, although some people were heavy smokers and needed more than tea and lunch breaks.

“It may be that they have to go to the bank ... or have a bad nicotine habit,” he said.

He said if people had a disability such as addiction, then the Australian Tax Office needed to have an arrangement with staff.

Liberal Senator Cory Bernardi, who has railed against public service perks, told The Courier-Mail the ASU was “out of touch”.

Senator Cory Bernardi stands alone 

The document said many ATO employees ran out of paid personal leave because of long-term illness, forcing them to rely on social security benefits from Centrelink.

“Many are not eligible for this because their spouse works,” the document said, arguing for a “better safety net”.

“The ATO should insure itself against long-term illnesses that last longer than three months. This income protection should be for illnesses or injuries that are not eligible for workers compensation or other compensation schemes.”

It also argued staff should be able to be absent for 15 days’ personal leave without needing documentation. It wants it increased from eight days.

Senator Bernardi labelled the document “ridiculous”.

“There’s eight pages of demands but no acknowledgment of getting better value for taxpayers,” he said.

Cory Bernardi fires up online readers 

Department heads will sign more than 120 agreements across the public service but the new terms are subject to Government framework, which was released in March.

The Government will not agree to any pay increases unless there are clear productivity gains.

related.body:
They faced off, Gerard Baden-Clay and the man who wants him in jail.

It was Crown prosecutor Todd Fuller’s final assault, a torrent of accusations that finally revealed exactly what police believe happened to mother-of-three Allison Baden-Clay.

In his fourth and final day on the stand, Baden-Clay was forced to reject and deny as Mr Fuller accused him of smothering his wife and “unceremoniously’’ dumping her body in a creek before rushing home to his children.

“You killed your wife, Mr Baden-Clay,’’ the prosecutor said.

“You attacked her and the only way she could respond was to lash out and claw at your face and leave marks upon it. Probably as you smothered her. And took the life from her.’’

Baden-Clay denied the accusation.

Follow the trial of the year day-by-day here:

DAY 14: Drug in Allison had ‘unusual effects’ 

DAY 13: Allison’s journal ‘untrue’, says Baden-Clay 

DAY 12: Baden-Clay’s love triangle email trail 

DAY 11: Baden-Clay’s tears as he takes the stand 

DAY 10: How it unfolded as the Crown rests 

DAY 9: Plants on Allison found at her home 

DAY 8: Jurors inspect site where body found 

DAY 7: Neighbour’s explanation for scream 

DAY 6: Scratches not typical of razor 

DAY 5: Listen to triple-0 call to police 

DAY 4: Accused told lover to lie low 

DAY 3: Neighbours heard screams 

DAY 2: Daughter’s tape brings tears 

DAY 1: Photo shock in murder trial 

Mr Fuller told the court by April 19, 2012, the double-life Baden-Clay had been leading was about to come undone.

He said April 19 was when Baden-Clay discovered his wife and long-term lover Toni McHugh would be at the same real estate conference the following day.

“If those two women came together on the 20th, there was a real risk of a catastrophe,’’ Mr Fuller said.

“Your double life would be exposed.’’

Mr Fuller said Baden-Clay had promised Allison the affair was over when she had discovered his infidelity the previous September.

“Your wife had forgiven you once,’’ he said.

“You had no confidence she would forgive you again, did you?

“And if that came about, you’d be exposed to your family, to your friends, to your profession.

“The facade that was Gerard Baden-Clay will fall.’’

KEEP READING TO SEE THE PROSECUTOR’S DRAMATIC INTERROGATION

Mr Fuller said Baden-Clay had murdered his wife at their Brookfield home, either late on the night of the 19th or during the early hours of the following morning.

But he said the former real estate agent was back home by 1.48am — when he plugged his phone back into its charger.

“Perhaps she grabbed at your clothing? Is that why you had that injury under your right shoulder?’’ Mr Fuller said.

 Baden-Clay said he could not explain how he got the red bruising near his armpit.

“Perhaps her jumper came up as you tried to fight her off, up over her hands and up around her neck, or did that happen later as you moved her body and dumped her in the creek?’’ Mr Fuller said.

“You overpowered her pretty quickly, didn’t you?

Baden-Clay, often exasperated and sometimes angry during the barrage, rejected this. “I never overpowered her at all,’’ he said.

“I never did anything to physically harm my wife in any way, ever. So your supposition that then takes it further to suggest I did other things as well is absurd and I object to it. I can’t answer your question.’’

Mr Fuller said Allison’s hair came into contact with the blanket of fallen leaves in their back garden as he took her to the Captiva car.

He told Baden-Clay she had a minor injury, something that had caused her to bleed. He said when Baden-Clay put his wife’s body in the back of her car, with the rear seats folded flat to form a boot, her blood had run down the side. “It wasn’t enough to be noticed but enough to be found,’’ Mr Fuller said.

“You transported her to Kholo Creek and then dumped her underneath the bridge unceremoniously.

“Anxious to get back to your children.’’

The suggestion that Baden-Clay had abandoned his three daughters upset him.

“The suggestion that I would leave my children for any time in the middle of the night is absurd, let alone to do the dastardly things that you’re suggesting,’’ Baden-Clay said. It was then, Mr Fuller said, that Baden-Clay began covering his tracks.

He loaded toys into the back of his wife’s Captiva. He took his razor and used it to cut his face at the bottom of the scratch marks to “give some legitimacy’’ to the claim he would make again and again.

The claim he had made that morning and during his trial: the marks on his face were shaving cuts, done in a hurry. “You told … anybody who asked,’’ Mr Fuller said.

“And you kept up the facade of a concerned husband.’’ Baden-Clay denied all allegations.

The trial continues on Monday.

GERARD TELLS COURT OF MANY AFFAIRS

GERARD Baden-Clay has told a court he had ``many concurrent’’ affairs as he played down his long-term relationship with lover Toni McHugh.

Answering final questions in his murder trial, Baden-Clay yesterday for the first time alluded to the presence of more women in his life.

``It was purely about the physical aspect of that, that I went to those other women,’’ he said, under questioning from his defence barrister.

``Some of them over an extended period of time, admittedly. Many of them concurrent. But I felt like we’d put that behind us and moved on.’

The court had previously been told of Baden-Clay’s affairs with three women. One was with Ms McHugh, which lasted more than three years.

Another was with a woman at a real estate conference in Sydney, while he was with Ms McHugh.

And the third was from earlier in his marriage, long before Ms McHugh, he has testified previously.

Ms McHugh was more than just a fling, prosecutor Todd Fuller QC suggested to Baden-Clay yesterday.

``I suggest that you wanted to be with Toni McHugh,’’ Mr Fuller said.

Baden-Clay replied: That’s not correct.

``She offered things that you didn’t get from the wife that you no longer loved,’’ Mr Fuller said.

Baden-Clay replied: ``No, that’s not true’’. He insisted he still loved his wife.

``Allison and I had been through a period of about nine years where we had hardly had any physical intimacy at all,’’ he said.

``Yes there were a number of women that I went to for sex. Talked about some of them during that period.

``But Allison and I had recommenced our physical relationship and were rebuilding that.’’

Mr Fuller said Baden-Clay split from Ms McHugh in September 2011 after Allison discovered the affair, but went back to her three months later.

``I’d suggest to you that Toni McHugh offered you a different life and that you wanted to take that opportunity,’’ Mr Fuller said.

``That’s why you went back to her … because you realised you made the wrong choice in September 2011.

``That’s what the start of 2012 was all about: You and Toni McHugh planning how you were going to be living together.’’

Gerard insisted Ms McHugh was just another of his affairs. ``I’d had a number of infidelities over the years,’’ he said.

``The difference with Toni McHugh to the other women was that she worked together in the office with us. That made life a lot more challenging.’’

related.standFirst: GERARD Baden-Clay faces barrage of prosecution accusations that he overpowered and probably smothered his wife Allison before dumping her body.
related.subtitle: Prosecution launches tirade of accusations against Gerard Baden-Clay, on trial accused of murdering wife Allison

Peters’s brother and Today Show host Karl Stefanovic has revealed that Peter has brought Sylivia home to the Sunshine State to meet mum.

Karl said Sylivia was a hit at the Stefanovic Sunday roast.

“She has been around a couple of times when Pete is home from London and everyone likes her,” Karl, recording for the show in Logan yesterday, said.

“She is a beautiful woman and super smart and most importantly, from Queensland.

“It is a big thing to cope with the in-laws, usually there is always a dodgy uncle but she has the crazy brother-in-law.

“It is early days and I don’t want to put pressure on it, I wish them all the best.”

Speaking from Sydney yesterday, Jeffreys laughed of suggestions she was a future Mrs Stefanovic.

Sylvia Jeffreys replaces Georgie Gardner on Today show 

Four weeks in to her new role, the on-air banter about her relationship has kept audiences amused.

“It started on my second day,” she said.

“I find it is best to smile and ignore. I try and quickly deflect, that is my tactic with Karl.”

She said she knows the teasing from Karl comes from a good place.

“He is just having a laugh,” she said. “It all adds to the excitement of the show.”

Karl Stefanovic says sorry
