related.body:
The Advertiser understands Adelaide Oval staff who had intended to take leave over the mid-season AFL break have been told they will be required to work a major event on Friday, July 25, at Adelaide Oval.

A July clash is the perfect off-season preparation for European clubs and the Reds, who host Melbourne Victory on October 17 at Adelaide Oval.

Neither AFL clubs Adelaide or Port Adelaide play at Adelaide Oval in the last weekend of July.

Adelaide United’s former Barcelona youth coach Josep Gombau enjoys a bulging contact book from Argentine great Lionel Messi to the greats of Spain’s golden generation.

However, it is Gombau’s links with La Liga officials that stand to deliver a slice of overdue football heaven.

South Australia was outflanked by eastern states and Canberra who will host Tim Cahill’s Socceroos in Asian Cup fixtures through January 2015.

The Spanish government is using glamour La Liga clubs to spread its “culture and brand”.

This month’s exhibition game could lead to Adelaide’s possible inclusion in a Spanish-run LFP World Club summer tournament.

Malaga could also play against Perth Glory this month.

Luring one of the Spanish big three, Real Madrid, Barcelona or Atletico Madrid would be an outlandish coup.

However, high calibre outfits such Javi Gracia’s Malaga would pack a venue that has been restricted to cricket and AFL fixtures since the completion of a $535 million, tax-payer funded upgrade.

Malaga — supported by many English expats along the “coast of the sun” — boast the likes of former Bayern Munich and Manchester City striker Roque Santa Cruz, and Liverpool loan forward Luis Alberto on the books.

Gombau has spent the off-season in Catalonia where he met with La Liga officials and searched for players and expertise to bolster the Reds.

Landing La Liga opposition for the Reds in a one-off or ongoing arrangement would provide a massive boost at Hindmarsh and game in general.

Gombau is preparing for a busy pre-season, appointed to steer the A-League All-Stars against Italian powerhouse Juventus at ANZ Stadium on 10 August.

A La Liga side taking on the Reds adds lustre to an A-League that is set to welcome Spanish super star David Villa and England stalwart Frank Lampard at Melbourne City this season.

related.body:
Police arrested Kerri Lee Sansbury, 50, of Kilburn, when they attended an agreed meeting place for the phone handover last night.

It is alleged the Sansbury stole another woman’s phone from the counter of a gaming room of a Kilburn hotel about 9.30pm on Wednesday.

Shortly after, a friend of the victim started receiving text messages from the stolen phone demanding money for its return.

The victim contacted police, who then went to the exchange point and arrested Sansbury, who was allegedly in possession of the phone.

Sansbury appeared in the Holden Hill Magistrates Court today charged with one count of blackmail and one count of dishonestly taking property without consent.

She was granted bail to face court again in Adelaide later this month.
related.description: A WOMAN has been charged with blackmail after allegedly stealing a mobile phone then demanding money for its return.
related.standFirst: A WOMAN who stole a mobile phone from a pub pokie parlour before demanding a ransom from its owner for its return has walked into a police trap.

related.body:
When Love Comes to Town explored what happens when 17 single women tour regional Australia by bus to meet 20 eligible bachelors.

While all match-ups fizzled for the six lads from Barossa Valley, Kangaroo Island and Robe, they’ve been inundated with attention from girls who liked what they saw.

The experience has been “surreal” for Barossa winemaker and viticulturalist Josh Pfeiffer, 30, whose female fans contacted him on Facebook.

“I had quite a few girls get in touch with me ... I was surprised by the number that did,’ he said.

“I have no idea how many, but it was probably more than 50 ... it was pretty weird.”

Mr Pfeiffer, who is still single, said he would rather meet women face-to-face, adding they were welcome to “come up to Whistler Wines”.

Charlie Bainger, 30 of Robe, who has since landed himself “a really nice girl”, said his phone went “ballistic” after he appeared on the small screen.

“I run a surf school so my number is pretty readily available,” he said.

“I was getting messages on the phone and on Facebook from people saying ‘I’d love to catch up’ ... to the point I had to turn it off.”

Meanwhile, Kangaroo Island mechanic and farmer Thomas Oak, 31, had women travelling to meet him.

“I got the heads-up from the tourist information centre here that a couple of women were calling up about accommodation on the island and mentioned my name a couple of times,” he said.

One particularly keen lady turned up at his workshop, her bags at the ready.

“It was flattering and scary at the same time ... I’m just an island boy,” he said.

related.body:
Trengove is expected to miss between four and six weeks after having ankle surgery on Wednesday, while Carlile will miss up to three with a hamstring strain.

MORE: ALIPATE CARLILE OUT FOR TWO-TO-THREE WEEKS 

The absence of the key duo will severely test Port’s defence in the next month, including this Saturday’s game against Essendon at Adelaide Oval.

The Power are expected to promote Tom Clurey and Cameron O’Shea from the SANFL and will also regain the veteran leadership of Dom Cassisi in the back half.

“It will be a good test for our younger guys,” backline coach Matthew Nicks said.

“We’ve been talking about it all year, it’s been hard for that next tier (to get a game) because the team has been going so well ...

“It’s a really good opportunity and a really good test.”

Nicks said Port would rely on Tom Jonas to cover one of Essendon’s tall forwards after his job on Josh Jenkins in last week’s Showdown.

“He’ll really have to step up, he’ll have to take one of their key forwards,” said Nicks of Jonas.

“He can play on the bigs. He’s undersized, there’s no doubt about that, but he makes up for it with his competitiveness.”

The last time Port played without Carlile and Trengove in an AFL game was round 12, 2009. While the Power had a taste of playing without them in the preseason, their absence comes at an awkward time given the size of Bomber forwards Joe Daniher and Jake Carlisle.

“Carlisle is in good marking form and Daniher is going to be a superstar,” Nicks said.

But Port will also look to turn the match-ups in to a positive, using any advantage they have in speed and mobility to run off the Essendon forwards.

“When you play against a really tall forward line it’s a scary thought if the ball keeps coming in the air over and over,” Nicks said.

“But from a positive point of view, if you can get the ball on the ground you’ve got the ability to move it out quicker.”

Port defender Jasper Pittard said Carlile and Trengove would be missed but echoed Ken Hinkley’s message that the Power don’t rely on individuals.

“They’ve been rock solid for us all year,” Pittard said.

“But we’re not a personnel-based team — that’s the mantra Kenny drives.

“I’m not sure who the coaches will go for but Cam O’Shea and Tom Clurey are more than capable of playing the key position roles.”

related.body:
Adelaide turned the tables on a Port side that was supposed to be fitter, faster and harder in last Sunday’s clash at Adelaide Oval — regaining control of its September dream in the process.

The false dawns will be behind ninth-placed Adelaide with successive victories against the Giants at Spotless Stadium.

“Our heads are still above water, still in the race and only one game out of the eight so our destiny is in our own hands,” 259-game veteran Thompson told The Advertiser.

“It was the biggest win of the season so we have shown enough when we do get it together.

“Hopefully we can take a lot of confidence and self belief within the group that we are good enough and get the ball rolling.”

Port won contested possessions 154-128 in its March Showdown victory but Adelaide turned the tables with a 163-133 advantage on Sunday.

Thompson sees the green shoots of a Crows recovery as they target back-to-back wins for the first time since round six after a run of success against St Kilda, GWS and Western Bulldogs.

“We are getting better but are still patchy and that is what we need to get rid of. Our best footy is good enough. Against Port we played four quarters,” said Thompson, who kicked his 150th goal against the Power.

“It was a gutsy win. There is no doubt we were heavy underdogs, they sat top for a reason.

“When you have weight of numbers you will win more often than not.”

Thompson is in white hot form – gathering 34 touches, seven tackles and a goal against Port – only shaded by ruckman Sam Jacobs in Showdown medal voting.

Patrick Dangerfield’s 22 contested possessions and Rory Sloane’s nine influential tackles dismantled Port in a hand-to-hand midfield combat.

“They have a quality midfield and lot of guys who can roll through there but I thought our midfield was outstanding the way we pressured the ball, hunted the footy and balance around the contest was quite good,” said Thompson.

“It is always good when the big boy hits the scoreboard. Not only is he a very good ruckman off the hand but reads the play well for a big guy,” said Thompson of Jacobs, who also earnt 10 AFL coaches association votes.

“I am enjoying my footy, we have a great young group together.”

Brad Crouch and Matthew Wright also excelled against Port with Thompson sensing a solidification of the playing group ahead of the Giants clash.

Thompson predicted four-goal hero Eddie Betts’s second half of the season “will be even better” than the first and implored fans to keep the faith after what has been a bumpy ride.

“We do owe the supporters a big thank you and hope they do stick with us. We are trying to get off that rollercoaster and can hopefully string a few wins together,” said Thompson.

related.body:
In my 14-year career, he sits comfortably alongside the likes of Carlton’s Stephen Silvagni, Geelong’s Matthew Scarlett and West Coast’s Darren Glass as the hardest to beat.

Rutten might not receive the interstate kudos that the others enjoy but make no mistake, he is a top-notch defender.

“Truck’’ ranks alongside Ben Hart as the best two defenders the Adelaide Crows have ever produced.

They are completely different players but they are too good to split.

Hart was more versatile in that he was able to play on big-bodied key forwards like Tony Lockett, Jason Dunstall and Gary Ablett Snr but he was unique in that he could also quell elusive, smaller forwards like Phil Matera, Brad Johnson and Jeff Farmer.

While Rutten has made his name playing on the power forwards of the competition — Barry Hall, David Neitz, Matthew Richardson and Jonathan Brown to name a few — he has been one of the best lockdown defenders in the game.

After originally being ignored in the national draft, Rutten had to work hard for his chance at fulfilling his childhood dream of playing AFL.

Adelaide used its 40th pick at the 2002 rookie draft to select the man it later nicknamed Truck because of his size.

It is one of the best recruiting decisions it ever made.

Playing 225 games is no mean feat. And Rutten will hope to add a few more to his record before the year is out.

The Ben Rutten story is not only one of perseverance but also one of getting the very best out of yourself.

He has never been a track animal, joking at his retirement press conference that he has a large turning circle.

But this hasn’t mattered. The 190cm, 98kg Rutten turned himself from an immobile key forward into one of the most competitive and disciplined defenders in the game.

He became a genuine defender — not one of those pseudo, drop-off, uncontested defenders we see nowadays, who struggle to spoil when isolated one on one.

Rutten has thrived on taking on the opposition’s main man and beating him in a one-on-one contest, burying the incoming ball with a strong defensive fist.

Former coach Neil Craig’s defence-first game plan and Rutten was a match made in heaven. Between 2005 and 2007, Adelaide’s defence was a vault and nightmare to play against and Truck was the key.

He would lock down on the opposition’s best forward, Nathan Bock would attack from half-back and Nathan Bassett would drop off to air-assist as the third man in a marking contest.

Throw in Michael Doughty, Jason Torney, Graham Johncock and resting midfielders like Andrew McLeod, Tyson Edwards and Simon Goodwin and scoring was hard to come by.

Without ever seeing it first-hand I could tell Rutten was a diligent player who studied his opponent’s strengths and weaknesses because he was rarely beaten the same way twice in a row.

He was also smart, his positioning was second to none and he rarely lost sight of the moving ball and his opponent.

Defenders who lose sight of either one usually get cut up.

Rutten’s timing and ability to cut off the leading forward by cutting the angle has been brilliant and something that has assisted his game as father time has begun to catch up with him.

He has spoiled with both fists — preferred and non-preferred — which is something not always seen in today’s game. And his closing speed and first 10m out of the blocks has never been given enough credit.

As an opposition player, I was always confident of having Rutten covered for fitness, agility and speed. But exposing those perceived weaknesses wasn’t easy.

Trying to wrestle him out of position in a marking contest was even harder. Truck ensured he wouldn’t go down without a fight, no matter the scoreline.

No doubt his vocal leadership will also be missed in Adelaide’s defensive half when his career is over.

In the meantime, he can still be of value to the Crows — whether on the field or off it.

Adelaide’s young defenders Daniel Talia and Kyle Hartigan must pick his brain.

Absorbing as much defensive know-how in the next three months will be vital to their long term development before Rutten is lost to West Lakes.

The same goes for Taylor Walker and his fellow forwards. Gun defenders can teach you everything you need to know about what makes a great forward tick — how to move, where to lead and a few of the tricks about getting split on your opposition.

They have had a first-class seat in trailing the best key forwards in the game.

All you need to do is ask them two questions: What do you hate them doing and how do they do it?

Ben Rutten is without doubt an unheralded defensive star.

He will be sorely missed, but knowing what I do of this on-field warrior there will be a little candle still burning inside him waiting for one final fling on the big stage.

Enjoy retirement when it comes around. It was a pleasure playing against you.

Warren Tredrea is Port Adelaide’s 2004 premiership captain, a Channel 9 News sports presenter, Triple M Football commentator and Australian Football Hall of Fame member.

related.body:
Like the good burghers of Holdfast Bay, who are clutching their rosaries over whether to ban tattoo parlours and sex shops from Glenelg  in case they “ruin the family feel” of the place.

Never mind that no one actually seems to want to open up a sex shop in Glenelg, or that the one tattoo joint already on Jetty Rd doesn’t seem to hurt anyone.

No, according to Holdfast Bay councillors, Glenelg is Adelaide’s answer to Disneyland and must be protected from indecency at all costs.

“You don’t want these sort of things setting up because tourists won’t want to go there,” Cr Mikki Bouchee told The Guardian Messenger on Monday.

“It’s also in anticipation of brothels maybe becoming legalised. I don’t think we’ve got strong enough policies to stop this sort of shop from going ahead.”

And there we have it folks, the real heart of the issue.

Holdfast Bay’s sudden concern about “sex and sleaze infiltrating family-friendly areas” has nothing to do with tattoo parlours and adult shops, and everything to do with MP Steph Key’s fresh bid to decriminalise prostitution in this state.

As reported last week in The Advertiser, Ms Key is drafting her third attempt at decriminalising sex work in South Australia  after her last Bill was defeated by one vote in 2012.

She tried again in 2013 with an updated version of that Bill, but it was never heard because parliamentary sitting time ran out before the March election.

Thank goodness then that the clear-headed residents of Ashford voted Ms Key back in, giving her another chance to launch new legislation to decriminalise all forms of sex work including at home, in brothels, through escort services and on the street.

They obviously agreed with her plan and so, it seems, do readers of The Advertiser; a poll on last week’s story attracted 2225 votes, the majority of which — 76 per cent — were in favour of decriminalising sex work. Less than a quarter voted to keep prostitution illegal in SA.

Given this survey’s more than reasonable sample size, I’d say it’s a fair reflection of public sentiment on the matter. It’s not a feeling that’s just popped up overnight, either.

Queensland has had legal brothels since 1992, Victoria since 1994. New South Wales has been fully decriminalised since 1996. And yet here we are, with our dusty old laws — some of which date back to 1935 — dictating what people can and can’t do with their bodies and where.

The very fact that some of our legislation still refers to brothels as “bawdy houses” should be enough to convince us it is no longer effective in a modern world.

Currently SA sex workers can be charged with running a brothel for seeing a client in their home. Known sex workers can be, and have been, charged with loitering for just walking down the street. They don’t have access to WorkCover, and are seen as easy targets for assault and robbery because they’re less likely to report to police. It is also legal to discriminate against a current or former sex worker.

This is a clear human rights issue, and yet legislative change has been continually stymied for decades by so many of our elected leaders who confuse the discussion with irrelevant questions of morality, or who adopt a “not in my backyard” mentality — just like those at Holdfast Bay council appear to be doing.

Fretting about brothels “ruining the family feel” of an area, or worrying about how close they are to churches, is an old-fashioned attitude that stems from a lack of understanding of how the sex industry works.

In most cases such “brothels” are actually sex workers’ private homes, and guess what — they’re already quietly operating over the suburbs. Some are probably next to churches. You might even have one on your street. Bothered? Why should you be? I bet you didn’t even realise they were there.

It will be a scarlet-letter day when Ms Key’s Bill eventually passes. We must not allow outdated attitudes and moralistic hand-wringing by councils to render it useless.
related.description: ADELAIDE long ago shed its reputation as being the “city of churches”, but you’d never know it the way some of our elected leaders like to moralise about certain issues.
related.standFirst: SUDDEN concern about sex shops in Glenelg has nothing to do with keeping it family-friendly, and everything to do with a fresh bid to decriminalise prostitution in SA.
related.subtitle: Petra Starke: Fretting about brothels ruining the family feel of an area is an old-fashioned attitude

related.body:
As part of Channel 7’s live coverage of the Round 16 clash, the network is using a crowd noise meter to measure the decibel level.

Crowd noise has been a major talking point of the new stadium this season and last month the Power used a recording of a match-day crowd while training.

“It’s a pretty special sound,” midfielder Hamish Hartlett said.

“When we first run out and the crowd erupts it really inspires us to make sure we play well and even when things aren’t going so well the crowd can spur us on to get the momentum back in our favour.

“We rely on them a fair bit and we certainly gain plenty out of them making heaps of noise.

“In previous years we haven’t had heaps of people at our games so having 40 or 50,000 has made a fair bit of difference but I think the way the stadium is built it traps the sound in.”

Port’s biggest crowd at the Oval this year was in Round 10 when 52,233 — more than either Showdown attendance this season — packed the ground to see the Power play Hawthorn in a major endorsement of hosting Saturday night footy.

“I remember every time we kicked a goal or something significant happened, when the crowd erupted it was just incredible,” Hartlett said.

“That and the Geelong game were two that really stood out and the Showdown in Round 2.

“When the crowd is in full voice it’s quite difficult to hear anything else going on out on the field but we wouldn’t want it any other way to be honest.

“We’ve got to make sure we’re swivelling our head and taking in everything that’s going on around us.

“Making sure we keep track of what’s going on in the backline and forward line, just more awareness with our eyes.”

As for whether the Power is any chance of beating the Guinness World Record of 137.6 decibels set by NFL side the Seattle Seahawks’ crowd in 2013, Hartlett said it would take an absolute full house.

“It would take every seat to be filled and all the standing room to be full as well,” he said.

“We’re hoping for a huge crowd which would go a long way and then something special to happen like Chaddy’s (Wingard) mark against St Kilda to get the crowd up and about.”

related.body:
Federal Assistant Infrastructure Minister Jamie Briggs told The Advertiser that without seeing the changes the Federal Government could not grant its support.

The $896 million South Rd upgrade from Torrens Rd to the River Torrens relies on $448 million of Federal Government funding.

On Tuesday, State Infrastructure Minister Stephen Mullighan released the Project Assessment Report which revealed changes to the upgrade including leaving an electrical substation in place and stopping right turns on the Port Rd from South Rd.

“We (the Federal Government) haven’t seen the plan and weren’t told about the announcement,” Mr Briggs said.

“There are reasonable changes to what was originally planned. Because we haven’t seen it we can’t say if we support it and our money is contingent on our support.

“I expressed concern to the Minister (Mullighan). The national partnership agreement says when we are funding a project like this 50/50 (split between Federal and State funding) any plans need to be consulted with us and any announcement needs to be done in conjunction with us.

“I wouldn’t overstate there is any risk to the project but when we are committing taxpayer funding, especially of this size, we need to make sure we are getting value.”

Mr Briggs said he also had his office express the same concerns to the state infrastructure department to ensure this did not happen again.

“The Minister (Mullighan) explained it was a mix up so that’s what I have put it down to,” Mr Briggs said.

A key point of difference between both major parties during the Federal Election campaign last year was which end of South Rd to upgrade.

The Federal Liberal Party promised to upgrade Darlington, while Federal Labor was committed to the Torrens to Torrens project.

The issue continued to be fiercely debated following the election with the SA Labor Government continuing to pursue Torrens to Torrens despite the Federal Liberal Government’s commitment to Darlington until the Federal Budget revealed both projects would proceed.

When asked why the State Government did not consult the Federal Government on the changes to the Torrens to Torrens project, Mr Mullighan said the relevant Federal Department had provided input to the changes.

“It should be noted this is the next iteration of the project design; the design will be finalised once consultation on the Project Assessment Report is considered,” Mr Mullighan said.

“We have made Minister Briggs’s office aware of the opportunity to be involved in the announcement of the final project design.”
related.description: THE STATE Government has been warned over its decision to announce changes to the Torrens to Torrens project without Federal Government sign-off.
related.standFirst: THE STATE Government has been warned over its decision to announce changes to the Torrens to Torrens project without Federal Government sign-off.

related.body:
Mr Nowak on Wednesday declared himself bankrupt weeks after 114 creditors of his failed company Nova Real Estate claimed $6 million in compensation from him.

Nova RE liquidator Andrew Heard sought the compensation as damages from Mr Nowak for trading while being insolvent.

“In our investigations into the liquidation, we found him guilty of incurring debt at the time of being insolvent,” Mr Heard said.

A South Australian investor has filed a claim for $125,000, after investing her and her mum’s super into Mr Nowak’s entities.

“It’s a body blow. I feel gutted by this and the fact that he was taking our money to pay all his debts and at such a vulnerable time in our lives.

“He came in just after my dad passed away from lung cancer and me and my mum were in turmoil,” she said.

Co-director of Nova RE Dianne Westthorp is also facing a compensation claim from creditors and investors.

Peter Macks of Macks Advisory has been appointed trustee of Mr Nowak’s estate.

Mr Macks advised that investigations into the affairs of Mr Nowak are well underway, but believed any return to creditors is unlikely at this stage.

In the Statement of Affairs lodged with the trustee, Mr Nowak has listed 31 companies where he was or is a director and or shareholder.

“Unsecured creditors totals approximately $7 million substantially which includes a claim in his estate brought by the Liquidators of Nova Real Estate Pty Ltd of approximately $6 million.”

“Most of his wealth seems to be in his shareholding of the companies and all the properties that the companies own are currently sold or being sold at shortfalls,” he said.

Mr Nowak’s multimillion-dollar luxury Springfield home with 17 car spaces, a “batcave”, swimming pool and tennis court — bought by him for $4.26 million in 2012 — was sold by a major bank last month for $3.26 million.

In February, the Federal Court seized the assets and passports of Mr Nowak and his wife Betty Dawn Nowak pending an investigation by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission into the collapse of four entities linked to them.

That investigation is ongoing and likely to be completed before an early November ASIC court hearing.

O’Loughlins lawyer Michael Connelly said the law firm was still trying to get access to insurance paperwork on behalf of its 50 clients, but was still considering a number of options, including a class action.

A property search has revealed a number of properties, potentially worth millions, being held under the names of the other entities related to George and Betty Nowak, including Harralex Nominees and Harralex Homes.

Most investors have sunk money into different entities within Mr Nowak’s complex empire built around investment property proposals — not just the ones that have collapsed.

The Charterhill Group operated as a “one-stop shop”, providing advice to clients on the establishment of self-managed superannuation funds, rollover of existing super funds into an SMSF, sourcing and purchase of investment properties, property management, insurance and taxation.

Four known entities of Mr Nowak are believed to have collapsed — Nova Real Estate, Lending Solutions International, EJ Property Developments and Financial Wellness (EZ Residential) — and he has separately informed investors his rental guarantee company Australian Leasecorp has also stopped trading.
related.description: INVESTORS that lost their life savings in failed chartered accountant George John Nowak’s Charterhill Group businesses says they have received another body blow with him now filing for bankruptcy.

related.body:
Anton Martin Chicarella, 24, of Andrews Farm, appeared in the Adelaide Magistrates Court today by video link.

He has yet to plead to one basic count of causing serious harm by dangerous driving.

Court documents allege Chicarella was behind the wheel of a stolen V8 Commodore that caused Mr Milisits to fall outside his famed Mile End business, Cafe De Vili’s, in April .

He had allegedly met the car’s owner in the cafe car park for a test drive, only to snatch the keys and speed off after pushing the owner over.

Mr Milisits was taken to hospital and treated for minor injuries.

Last week, Chicarella asked the court to order a report so that their client could seek release on home detention bail .

Today Richard Talbot, for Chicarella, said his client was withdrawing that application.

“I had spoken to the woman who is the occupant of the address we had put down as suitable (for home detention bail) at Seaton,” he said.

“She had spoken to me, I had spoken to her, before we put the application in.

“In the meantime she’s apparently changed her mind and does not wish for my client to live with her.”

Mr Talbot said he had also approached Chicarella’s mother.

“She might have been a possible alternative, however for other reasons she’s not able to have him at her address either,” he said.

He asked his client be given leave to apply for bail at short notice should a suitable address be found.

The state’s chief magistrate, Judge Elizabeth Bolton, agreed and remanded Chicarella in custody to answer the charge at the end of this month.
related.description: THE man accused of running down iconic baker Vili Milisits has withdrawn his plea for bail because two women — including his mother — will not have him in their homes.

related.body:
The Power has identified the direct routes and the outside as the key dangers to the way Essendon plays when it is at its best, and will also apply a heavy tag on whoever turns out to be the Bombers’ most damaging midfielder.

Assistant coach Josh Carr, a premiership player with plenty of tricks in that area, said Kane Cornes would most likely be shuffled between playmakers such as Dyson Heppell, David Zaharakis, Brendan Goddard and Brent Stanton.

It comes as tagging has come back into fashion — provided the tagger can find his own ball - after some coaches and commentators read him his last rights during the time of rapid growth of interchange use.

“It’s up to us as a team — the whole team — to respond,’’ Carr said.

“They (Essedon) have played some really good football this year, were really against Geelong and their best is really good.

“We have to be on top of our game.’’

The tagging part will be one of constant evaluations.

Carr said there were a number of players that could get away from the Power.

The key was not to let too many of them get away on the outside.

“Sometimes there are players we pick out (to tag) during the week but you’ve also got to be prepared to make in-game adjustments,’’ Carr said.

“I think they move the ball very well, very sharply and very direct

“For us to be at our best we need to defend well.

“We know that Essendon’s very good at the uncontested footy and like to hold on to the ball. We’ve got to be ready for that.’’

Port will miss key defenders Jackson Trengove and Alipate Carlile to injury but is confident there is enough depth to cover for the club’s best two defenders, with Tom Clurey and Tom Jonas expected to fill the key posts.

“You expect somebody to come into the team and step up,’’ Carr said.

“And we’ll see how we come from here.

“It’s obviously a hit, but I think we’ve shown all year that, especially with the ankles, that we’ve had guys who have come in and played their roles.

“There’s not really much you can do about it. It’s bad luck; it’s football.

“There are 18 teams out there who have had their fair share of injuries.’’

Just after 7pm, police received a call about a man being found unconscious in the parklands on South Tce.

A group of men had been seen fighting a short time earlier.

The 44-year-old victim was taken to the Royal Adelaide Hospital with serious head injuries.

It was later determined the victim’s head injuries were the result of an existing medical condition.

However he had been assaulted and suffered minor leg injuries, police said.

Investigations are continuing and anyone with information is asked to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or online at sa.crimestoppers.com.au .

He then returned and denied it - changed his story to blame his erratic driving on a blackout - then cried when he was told there were witnesses.

An off-duty police officer had seen the alleged crash outside Dripstone School in Tiwi, Darwin, on Monday afternoon.

Duty Superintendent Louise Jorgensen said the 17-year-old boy was chased out of the school in his Ford Falcon by the caretaker.

READ: TOUGH LOVE FOR YOUTH OFFENDERS IN TERRITORY 

“Instead of leaving quietly he did another big burnout in the street outside colliding with an 82-year-old’s parked vehicle in Tiwi Gardens,” she said.

“He left the scene but returned a short time later and spoke to attending police.

“Initially, he denied the offence saying that he had fainted / blacked out at the time of his erratic driving.”

When the teenager was told his actions were witnessed by a number of persons in the area — including an off-duty police officer — he burst into tears and admitted the offences.

His car was impounded and he was issued with an infringement notice for doing burnouts and careless driving.

related.body:
The inmates cheered wildly and begged to have their photos taken while cooped up in medium security cages that are all overcrowded with humanity.

The trip began at the old Fannie Bay Gaol, which opened in 1884 and housed Darwin’s nastiest criminals until 1979.

Mr Elferink then took media to the new, delayed Darwin Correctional Precinct to highlight what he says is a change of philosophy in how prisons are run in the Territory.

The new facility, expected now to open in two months, will use state-of-the-art technology to monitor inmates as well as provide them with healthy eating choices and work experience. The new DCP will have a wood shop, metalworks and a bakery which will be used to train inmates for future careers in a variety of fields.

Mr Elferink says the inmates will produce manufactured products in fields that do not compete with private business in the Territory. It’s about getting them working and cutting down on repeat offenders.

“So that we use prisoners to develop a work ethic so that when they leave jail, they have something more than when they entered jail,” Mr Elferink said. “And often that’s just something to lose. We’ll make damn certain they have every opportunity to make something of themselves.”

The delayed $495 million prison will have enough beds for 1048 inmates, more than the 835 currently incarcerated in Berrimah. That prison was originally constructed in 1979 to hold 110.

DCP general manager Bill Carroll said despite the clean, bright complex, inmates would not have a soft ride.

“It’s all about regime. If prisoners don’t comply, if they don’t engage in education or programs to address their offending behaviour … then they won’t have the same opportunities as that of the prisoners who do,” he said.

“The regime here is quite strict and the prisoners will have to get used to it.”

Mr Elferink says it’s all part of the Government’s new working prisons policy.

“We have come a long way from the ‘rack and stack’ model of previous corrections facilities where prisoners are simply locked in their cells with little to no focus on rehabilitation,” he said.

Penalty clauses worked into the contract with construction consortium Sentinel means the Government will save $165,000 a day for every day they are not in the new building. That could work out to $10 million in savings over the next two months.

Or Territorians’ great affection for a local, unicameral legislature.

Territory Day which leads to cracker night, is an event that Territorians know is something the rest of Australia cannot be trusted with.

In Darwin the official, $300,000 fireworks were off Mindil Beach, and although they held focus for 20 minutes or so, the night really belonged to the random explosion in the hands of the public.

Darryl Hine, from Larrakeyah, said he’d been coming down near the Ski Club for “easy” 20 years and had kids of his own and was here with his folks and his mate and his folks.

And has anything changed?

“I don’t know, what can you print?

“Mate, this is the best thing our taxes get spent on,” he said.

“This is a little bit more quieter compared to the rest of the beaches.

“A little bit more safer. You go over the there you’ll get 4000 people sticking crackers in very direction.

“I just love the colours.”

Darryl’s mates chimes in that it’s about adrenalin and sticks a cracker in my hand.

“I’ll light, you throw it,” he said.

“Can you throw?”

“Where am I throwing it?

“That a-way.”

And like a grenade in my hand I did. It looked small. “Boom!”.

“It feels good, doesn’t it? That’s why we do it.”

I felt it through my body. It was about adrenalin.

But Darryl had a softer take on it.

“The whole town comes together mate,” he said.

“If you’re not on the beach, you’re in your yard setting off crackers. It brings the town and all the families out mate.

“This might be the only night of the year where no one’s sitting at home on their iPad or playing computer games. All the kids are out and about for a change.

“It will never end and I don’t want it to. No way in the world.”’

So you sit and wonder how many people $300,000 could feed?

And then someone retorts, “Yes, but it also fed a fair bit of Territory pride. You can’t put a price on that.”

Eager Territorians went and stocked up on things that go boom, bang and kapow to celebrate Territory Day.

NT Oriential Emporium worker Livia Loy said this year had been even busier than last.

“It’s been busy as, it’s definitely a lot more busy than last year, it’s flat out,” she said.

Ms Loy said she would not say exactly how many fireworks had been sold but it had been “heaps.”

The once-a-year day to light crackers was something she said was special.

“It’s something that Territorians can look forward to.”

Shopper Jason Holtham agreed.

Mr Holtham, from Humpty Doo, said he had bought $500 worth of fireworks.

“We got a bit of stuff, including two massive boxes,” he said.

“My mate got some big cakes, they shoot off in the air and look pretty.”

The born and bred Territorian said he couldn’t pick a favourite cracker.

“Anything that goes bang — I’ve grown up with cracker day and it’s kind of like Christmas and my birthday wrapped into one.”

related.body:
Another man called because his large, drunken wife fell asleep on him.

And a woman rang police in a panic because she missed her flight to Melbourne and didn’t know what else to do.

These are some of the more interesting calls with which the NT police Communications Unit must deal on a daily basis.

And Senior Sergeant Craig Laidler has asked Territorians to think carefully about calling triple-zero, especially on a busy day like Territory Day.

He said triple-zero is reserved for emergencies, and time-wasters can delay a genuine call from reaching help.

“A lot of calls are urgent requirements for emergency services because things do go wrong with fireworks sometimes and fire services have to attend,” he said.

“Triple-zero is used for serious and life-threatening calls, but a lot are noise complaints, dogs, noise, fireworks in general, people calling you to tell us fireworks are being set off and that they’ve had enough.”

READ: IDIOT 000 CALLERS CLOG EMERGENCY LINE IN BLACK OUT 

He said last Territory Day, the call centre got about 2200 calls – 1300 of which were between the legal fireworks time of 6pm and 11am. There will be 20 staff rostered on tonight.

He said grassfires, injuries, and dangerous situations warranted a triple-zero call.

“If there is six other people there with mobile phones it helps to discuss it with them to see who will call,” he said.

“We just ask people to consider the necessity of a call to emergency services.

“You would be amazed.”
And what about the aliens in the fridge?

“We discussed it with him and police attended because they were concerned with the state of his mental health,” Sen-Sgt Laidler said.

“We know not everyone is a fan of Territory Day, but we don’t need all these people to ring emergency services.”

“If a property is on fire, we need to know. But we get a lot of prank and abusive calls. They start amicably and then go into a tirade of abuse about police or firies.”

related.body:
He said it’s the same toil felt by most people in the emergency, corrections, defence, and medical professions before “going into battle”.

“Our job puts a lot of pressure on you, your family, your social life and your well-being,” he said on social media.

“Some will say: ‘harden-up’, and I accept that as it’s part of the job.

“Some of the sights I’ve seen, heard and smelt at crimes scenes, suicides, crashes and critical incidents will never leave me and I’m sure we weren’t designed to continually be subjected to these things.”

He said he wouldn’t lose sleep over jibes at police.

“We don’t always get it right but no matter the amount of training we are given it does not make you an expert on everything,” he said. “Each and every shift we attend­ to something completely different from anything we have been taught. I still learn something new each shift.

“The snide remarks – ‘I pay your wages’, the scoffing ‘look at those bludgers’ whilst trying to grab a quick coffee or a feed in-between jobs and the food – usually takeaway because you cannot get home to a lovely home-cooked meal – is water off a duck’s back these days.”

Mr Smith also said parents needed to be mindful in how they educated children about the position of police.

“I do object to the comments often said to kids: ‘if you don’t behave yourself, that policeman­ will take you to jail’, because we want to be a figure to which a child can go in time of need – not be frightened of,” he said.

He said it hit him as he went to work at the weekend and missed his son Sam’s 21st birthday party. “We chose our career paths,” he said. “I thought about all the things we miss out on due to our work, yeah I know it’s part of the job.

“I then pondered about the last quarter-century I have been involved with law enforcement­.

“Geez there’s been some great times, great memories and proud moments when I have achieved something good for society – putting a baddie before the courts, rescuing someone, etc.

“The most rewarding component being a simple thank you and a smile.

“Unfortunately, the bad memories and times far outweigh the good. I know that’s what we get paid for.”

He urged Territorians to think about the professions who work for their safety.

“Please have a safe night and weekend so the shift workers can have a little down time,” he said. “But most importantly – If I had my time over, I would do it all again.”
related.description: VETERAN  Territory cop Garry Smith has said the odd hours, horrific sights, and low public respect of police is tough, and that the bad times far outweigh the good.

related.body:
After years of dreaming about it while taking tourists on trips, and hours of rigorous training, the exercise science student has succeeded in fulfilling his dream.

Mr Macaskill-Hants completed the 12 sections of the trail in 61 hours and 32 minutes – the fastest ever recorded.

But it was no easy feat.

“It was as hard as I expected and yet I had no reference of how hard it would be – it was excruciating,” Mr Macaskill-Hants said.

“It’s a bit surreal – sort of one of those things, while you’re in it it’s so intense but then it’s over and it’s fleeting.”

The 223km have taken their toll on his body.

“I ruptured some ligaments in my foot on the second day,” Mr Macaskill-Hants said.

“The first day was really excruciating mentally.

“The second day was the biggest physical challenge, and the last day I was just gritting my teeth to finish it off.

“I went through some pretty dark places physically and mentally over the three days, its hard to believe it’s done.”

During estimates hearings, Treasurer Dave Tollner brought up the spectre of revisiting liquor licensing and pokies in remote indigenous communities with the Federal Government.

“You’ve got to wonder what thought process is happening in the CLP when they’re putting revenue raising ahead of community safety,” Labor Leader Delia Lawrie said.

“The Giles Government seems addicted to poker ­machine revenue and oblivious to the social harm.”

Mr Tollner says the issue comes down to freedom of choice and fundamental rights for people in current dry ­communities.

“Is Labor saying Aboriginal people should not have the same rights as everybody else?” Mr Tollner said yesterday in an email to the NT News.

READ: TERRITORIANS GAMBLE $611M ON POKIES IN 2013 

“That Aboriginal people should be banned from access to alcohol or gambling, or that drinking and gambling isn’t going on now?”

Mr Tollner said the Government is committed to trying to remove the barrier for so-called “social clubs” in remote communities. He added the endeavour is in response to people he says were “embarrassed” that their communities were shrinking as people flocked to other cities for grog.

“We think that social clubs on communities can reduce the number of people leaving communities and at the same time allow greater community responsibility of drinking,” he said.

Ms Lawrie says if the CLP plans to introduce pokies and pubs to bush communities, they should first complete a social impact assessment. But, she added, reports into the issue of gambling and drinking in remote communities already confirm the social ills.

“The sad reality is people spend beyond their means in the hope that they’re going to become big winners and there are so many devastating stories of the harm it’s done to families and especially children.”

The Government’s take from poker machines was more than $60 million in the Territory last year.

For the most part, police said Territorians were relatively well behaved.

TERRITORIAN CLACKERS UNCRACKERED

One Bees Creek man lost his hayshed and just about everything in it after it was burnt down by one of his last crackers.

“A chap was letting off one of his last ones for the night, and it went straight into his hayshed, igniting it,” Senior Sergeant Louise Jorgensen said.

“He managed to get a few things out — including fuel — before it was burnt down.

“He’s lost a lot of equipment.”

Sen-Sgt Jorgensen said there was only one report to police of any major injuries, and their call centre received only about 700 calls over the evening — down from about 2000 last year.

But there will always be irresponsible people — several received several reports of people throwing crackers at cars and buildings, and “generally not being safe”.

A 19-year-old woman in Nhulunbuy is the worst of the injured, suffering an injured ear after she was hit in the head by a rogue cracker.

An old boat was also lost to the cracker Gods in Stuart Park.

“A cracker landed in it, and it caught fire. It wasn’t a valuable boat — it was one on its way out.”

A woman has also injured her arm after falling out of her boat on Darwin Harbour.

She was rescued by water police.

CRACKER GALLERY

Sen-Sgt Jorgensen said all of these incidents seemed to be accidents.

“There didn’t seem to be anything malicious in any of them,” she said.

Darwin City Council had to clean up piles of rubbish left at popular fireworks spots yesterday morning.

The 22-year-old is the senior development officer for the Palmerston Girls Academy at Rosebery Middle School.

She is also captain of the Palmerston Magpies women’s senior side and also coaches their Youth Girls team.

But that’s not all.

She also finds time to study teaching.

Ms Jeffrey has been nominated for a Pride of Australia award as a Young Leader.

She said she felt lucky to have the relationship with the girls in the academy she does.

“We try to be aunties or big sisters, and guide them in right direction,” she said.

“I know some students have had much different experience from me, and to be there for them all the time, to be that constant mentor is special.”

Ms Jeffrey has been in a leadership position since her mid-teens, when she was a dance instructor in Nhulunbuy for primary, high school, and advanced dancers.

“I was 15 or 16 teaching girls in their mid-20s, it was good and I loved it.”

That experience has proved invaluable, leading her to a successful application within the Palmerston Girls Academy. “I’m lucky to be paid to do what I love,” she said.

In the decade since their inception, the Pride of Australia awards have honoured more than 550 Australians, shared more than 19,000 stories and unearthed extraordinary feats of courage and heroism.

To nominate someone for a Pride of Australia award, click here.

related.body:
Unfortunately, I had no time to go fishing.

I took the opportunity to write about barramundi’s field of vision and hunting patterns.

My theories are based on my experiences of catching 890 sea barramundis by land based around our urban shores since 2010.

Of course, you don’t have to agree with my thinking.

Barramundi have a super wide-angle vision therefore they can attack baits by changing direction of their bodies sideways.

A good sized barramundi is very cautious.

Barramundi will follow a lure and remain neither too close nor too distant from it while they decide if they want to eat it. But he/she sometimes finally gives up following a lure.

I think that barramundi may be short sighted.

The lateral line is a system of sense organs found in aquatic vertebrates, mainly fish, used to detect movement and vibration in the surrounding water. (Wikipedia)

Barramundi’s vision by itself probably is not brilliant but lateral line is a very, very good sensor to produce a very good reaction.

I think that they can sense a danger to them and the movement of bait fish even in muddy water using their lateral lines.

I think that barramundi can see more colours than snappers if the water is clear.

Barramundi’s bait hunting patterns are based on these above factors and maximise the barra’s advantage.

Barramundi try to catch popular and familiar bait to them at the time and place when it is easiest for them.

They are creatures of habit.

Check out Hiro’s blog: secretbarramundi.blogspot.com.au

related.body:
People who knew Scott Allen Millar had feared he might have tried to return.

Victorian police were searching for Millar, 42, after the naked and battered body of a woman aged about 30 was found in Melbourne’s Royal Botanic Gardens on Sunday morning.

It is believed the Chinese hospitality worker was walking to work early on Saturday when she was chased and then allegedly sexually and physically assaulted.

Joggers found her body later that morning.

READ: FAMILY TRAGEDY RULED MURDER-SUICIDE 

Millar was arrested in NSW yesterday afternoon following the release of security film.

A Darwin resident, who refused to be named for safety reasons, told the NT News: “He was in Darwin eight weeks ago. My daughter saw him sitting outside the cafe in Coles.

“He would have been heading back to the NT.

“He would know where to hide here, if he did it.”

Millar was a traveller in Darwin, and was regularly seen outside the city Woolworths.

It is understood he lived in Darwin for up to six years: in a disused oil storage tank at Doctors Gully; in a tree house under a lookout platform on The Esplanade; and in One Mile Dam community at Dinah Beach.

He was a talented didgeridoo-maker, and sold them to Didgeridoo Hut on the corner of the Stuart and Arnhem highways in Humpty Doo.

READ: EX-SERCO GUARD MATT VANKO GUILTY OF MURDER 

Co-owner Janice Mitchell was shocked when she heard news of the murder and the subsequent arrest.

“He made awesome didgeridoos,” she said.

She said Millar once lived at her house, in his bus.

The news of the alleged murder saddened her.

“I wouldn’t have seen it coming, but he had episodes of being a bit erratic,” she said.

“Something must have gone wrong. I don’t know what he was doing down in Melbourne.”

NT Police has confirmed it was never involved with the investigation.

related.body:
Darwin RSPCA shelter manager Anne Swarbrick said people should ensure they keep their pets safe during the cracker clatter and that all pets are microchipped.

“Many animals are terrified by firework displays,” she said.

“Some animals will try to escape and end up at shelters.”

The RSPCA recommendations include:

 Keeping animals locked inside in a safe place.

 Give them something to do, a bone or rawhide etc, that will keep them busy.

 Leave the TV or radio on to drown out the noise.

READ: WHERE TO SEE FIREWORKS THIS TERRITORY DAY 

The Australian Veterinary Association (AVA) recommended for pets that are normally kept outside including rabbits, guinea pigs, ferrets or birds to “bring their cages or hatches inside or into a garage.”

The AVA recommended horse owners should remain calm around their horses as they can sense unease in a person. They also suggest if a horse is known to react badly to loud noises to move them somewhere quiet.

For more information see rscpadarwin.org.au

related.body:
Mr Kemp died in Adelaide last Monday after an extended period of rehabilitation from strokes.

He had been the Master Builders Association Northern Territory executive director from 2008 until recently, having overseen its change from the Territory Construction Association.

MBANT acting executive director Dave Malone said Mr Kemp had been a great servant of the building industry.

“He was very well liked up here and he was a tireless worker for the construction industry,” he said.

Builder NT manager Richard Riedel said he had known Mr Kemp both through building and playing golf.

“He enjoyed very much helping people,” he said. “He was very passionate about the building industry and seeing things done right.

“He was someone who you could trust in and confide in. He was very genuine. And on the golf course he definitely had a great rapport with our social group.

“Such a passionate and likable man who assimilated into the Darwin community with great respect.

“Graham’s witty sense of humour and wayward golf shots will be happy memories.”

Mr Kemp was National Heart Foundation Northern Territory board vice-president from 2008 to 2014.

Board president Marcus Ilton said Mr Kemp was known for his wit as well as his work as a spokesman for the construction industry.

“He was very easy to work with. He made a great contribution to the board and was ­always helping the CEO and the national group as well.

“He was a major contributor to the Darwin community and to the Northern Territory community.”

In 2005 when the NT News asked Mr Kemp for his New Year’s resolution, it was in the same vein.

“To be able to hit a golf ball straight for 250m,” he said. “No that’s not a resolution – that’s a dream!’’

Colliers International Darwin principal Chris Hyland said Mr Kemp was well liked, respected and a tireless worker for the construction industry.

Chief Minister Adam Giles remembered a man who was “ deeply committed to making the Territory a better place”.

Born in Adelaide, Mr Kemp moved to Darwin in 1999 after working in the Housing Industry Association SA/NT branch in Adelaide. He came to Darwin to be the first manager of the new NT branch.

Mr Kemp joined the Board of Australia Day Council NT in 2006 and served for six years. He spent most of that time as the deputy chair.

Darwin Lord Mayor Katrina Fong Lim was the former executive director of the Australia Day Council NT and said Mr Kemp was a selfless volunteer.

“He was a wonderful man,” she said.

“He was caring he gave up lot to the community and was an outstanding committee member.”

Mr Kemp was the loving husband of Daniela (deceased) and Christine, as well as the ­father of Matthew and Andrew and father-in-law of Leah and Kerry.

He was also the stepfather of Sean, Justin and Danielle.

related.body:
Property analyst Terry Ryder, of hotspotting.com.au, predicts many investors will end up getting burnt once all proposed stock is built and they can’t find a tenant prepared to pay a decent rent.

Mr Ryder has produced a list of the top 10 markets to avoid and five markets to treat with caution – among which Darwin CBD was listed.

Half of the markets he advises against investing in are located in Queensland.

READ: PRICES DROP FOR FIRST TIME IN A YEAR 

Mr Ryder said the two current “danger situations’’ in the market are inner-city apartment markets and regional centres, where a rise in supply coincided with a drop in demand, as is the case in many mining areas.

In Darwin alone, there are 2038 existing units. A Census from 2011 reveals 409 units were completed in the past three years.

There are an additional 2242 units under way – 224 of those units are newly constructed, 745 under construction and 1273 have passed the first stage of obtaining a development application approval.

Real Estate Central director of projects Daniel Harris has dismissed Mr Ryder’s warnings, saying his predictions are a few years premature.

READ: CLP ANNOUNCES TWO NEW SUBURBS 

“In our projects office, we have actually found 2014 to be more buoyant than 2013,” Mr Harris said. “The Top End has some of the most severe existing housing shortfalls in the country – just ask anyone who’s searching for a rental property this time of year.”

He expects supply will catch up with demand eventually, but doesn’t see this happening any time soon.

“At our projects office, we deal with investors from all over the country and Darwin remains the preferred choice for Aussie investors chasing ‘yields’ and increasing the cashflow within their portfolio,” Mr Harris said. “They get the benefits of investing in a mining town with the stability offered by a capital city.”

Whether it happens sooner or later, Mr Ryder believes Darwin, along with Sydney and Canberra, is heading in the direction of having major surpluses of inner-city apartments, just like Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth do already.

related.body:
The drug – commonly known as ice – is wrecking lives across the Territory and causing havoc for police and health workers who have to frequently deal with violent addicts.

Detective Superintendent Peter Schiller, who runs the drug and organised crime squad, said the ice plague in the Top End began in about 2005.

“It’s like they’re taking zombie tablets,” Supt Schiller said.

“The people who use it have ­violent turns of behaviour, they’re irrational and the ­energy displayed is very ­destructive.

“You might hear about someone being beaten up on the street but you can guarantee the most damage is done inside the home.

“They steal from family but it’s the behaviour that is the real concern – a heroin addict will steal your telly but he won’t usually beat you up.”

READ: FOUR ARRESTED AFTER METH BUSGT 

Australian Medical Association NT president Dr Robert Parker said the drug is also affecting health workers who have to deal with users who frequently wind up in hospital.

“They often have psychotic episodes and require ongoing management,” Dr Parker said.

“These people are very sick and need a high level of ­observation.

“The level of aggressiveness and lack of insight means they are dangerous to themselves and to others.”

The drug sells for about $2000 a gram. Recently there have been a swag of high-profile cases, including involving outlaw motorcycle gangs, related to the drug. A Hells ­Angels bikie was busted this week with an alleged $250,000 worth of ice.

It seems to have found its way to the centre as well.

Alice Springs youth advocate Matty Day warned this week about a possible methamphetamine spike among young people in town, citing a recent string of break-ins.

READ: METH AND ECSTASY LAND MAN IN JAIL 

Families and users have also spoken out about the horrific impacts of the drug.

One woman told the NT News she knew of three people in Darwin who have become addicted in recent months.

“I’m talking successful people, with families, partners, kids, a house – the lot. They now stand to lose everything they’ve worked so hard for. It all means nothing once someone is addicted to ice,” she said.

“There is a serious ice epidemic in Darwin. Ice is in a league of its own.”

Health Minister Robyn Lambley said the department was “very conscious of the significant risks involved in the use of such dangerous recreational substances, both to the users and also to others in the community”.

“As the result of recent episodes, the Chief Health officer, spoke publicly and strongly of the several associated risks.”
related.byline: By ELLIE TURNER and KYLIE STEVENSON

Greg Devereaux scored 85 points aboard Napoleon Dynamite at Robbie Robbins Reserve on Saturday evening.

But his tally was not good enough to beat the 89 points scored by NSW rider Cliff Richardson in front of thousands of fans. Devereaux was one of three Territory riders, all of whom made it to the final championship round.

“Thanks Darwin fans and all sponsors for all your support,” Devereaux said on social media.

“A big congrats also to Darcey McBean and Benny Cole for also making it into the championship round and doing our hometown proud.”

Devereaux was just ahead of Jason Mara, from Cloncurry, Queensland, on 84.5 points, and fourth-placed Mitch Paton, from Nebo, Queensland on 81.5 points.

The next PBR round is the Cairns Invitational in Queensland on July 5.

related.body:
His opening serve in this fourth round clash at the All England Club rocketed straight down the middle, at 204km/h. He might well have been saying “g’day Rafa’’.

After three hours on the court and more than 37 aces later, having firmly established himself as The Next Big Thing with a shock defeat of the world number one he was saying “Cheerio Rafa’’ with a “juicy wiggle’’ dance celebration.

The scoreline was an incredible 7-6, 5-7, 7-6, 6-3 for Kyrgios to set up a quarter-final clash against Canadian Milos Raonic.

FIRSTS: Nick v Nadal by numbers

FAMILY: How mum’s negativity fired up Nick

PRIDE: Kyrgios kicks off Twitter storm with humble post

So emphatic was the performance, tennis legend John McEnroe remarked: “He’s acting to me like he can win the whole tournament. The last guy that I saw like that was Boris Becker.”

Kyrgios turned to his dad George wearing his akubra hat smiling broadly and his sister Halimah in tears in the players’ box and pumped his fist and danced on court to celebrate amid wild roars from the crowd.

“I think I was in a bit of a zone, I didn’t notice the crowd, it hasn’t sunk in,’’ he said, noting modestly, “I played some extraordinary tennis, I was struggling a bit on return, but I got a break in fourth.’’

Kyrgios stated the obvious remarking: “I served at a really good level all the way through the match.’’

Kyrgios said he had seen an interview given by his mum Norlaila back in Canberra where she had remarked Nadal would be too good for her boy.

“That made me angry, so I don’t know what she is thinking’’, he said smiling. Later when asked what he would say to his mum, he said he would send her a smiley text.

For the first time since 1982 someone from outside the world 100 had beaten a world number one.

Kyrgios started the big game with a ferocity that belied his 19 years, his wildcard status and his inexperience in the senior game. The crowd that filled centre court was initially unsure about this gangly Aussie upstart. How would he handle this pressure cooker atmosphere? As it turned out, the tougher and more critical the point, the more Kyrgios pulled out a blistering serve, a crosscourt backhand winner, or a line-hugging return. Midway during the second set Kyrgios pulled off an instinctive between the legs shot, that ended up being a winner.

Kyrgios said: “I think on the big stage, it’s something I thrive on, the atmosphere, the crowd. I just love it when at 5-3, I think it was in the fourth set, they erupted, the crowd. I just love that feeling. At that stage you just think about all the work you put in. You know if you believe in yourself. Especially with my serve, if I just go after it, hit the right spots, I’m going to have a pretty good shot to close out a match like that today.’’

From the start he had shocked Nadal and won over the polite crowd. “Aussie’’ yelled one British clipped accent in simple acknowledgment he was witnessing the rapid emergence of a genuine world class contender.

With his lackadaisical and relaxed manner — clearly undaunted by reputation of the man on the other side of the net — Kyrgios had quickly notched two game points and three set points in the first set. The speed of his play unsettled Nadal who likes his precise routine between points. But the sheer power generated by the 19-year-old saw him bring up an astounding victory.

“Nadal’s wishing Gasquet had put him away a couple of rounds ago, right now,’’ said McEnroe mid-match.

Nadal said he had created opportunities but wasn’t able to counter Kyrgios’ big serve. And as he started, Kyrgios closed the epic encounter with another ace.

“Congratulations to him. For me, the beach,’’ said Nadal.

Kyrgios will now look to the quarter-finals for his match up against the huge serving Canadian Milos Raonic.

“Have to do it all again tomorrow and I can’t wait! First @Wimbledon & I’m in the last 8 club!!’’, he tweeted later.

Having played Raonic at Roland Garros last month, Kyrgios, still buzzing from his sensational victory over the world number one Rafael Nadal, was asked about what he could expect when they play in the early hours of tomorrow morning.

“There’s going to be a lot of walking from side to side from his serve, and there’s going to be a lot of winners in the match," he said smiling.

Raonic is credited with the biggest serve in the game. At just 23 he is the youngest in the world top ten. But with Kyrgios also regularly firing down serves in excess of 130mph the match will be a peppered-fest of powered aces.

"It’s going to be hard to find rhythm," said Kyrgios. I’m just going to go out there and just go my return of serve. Holding serve is going to be important, being able to make inroads on the other person’s serves."

He admits to being scared of the more illustrious names he is now encountering. Raonic beat him in the first round of the French Open in straight sets.

"Definitely I’m scared, but I just go through my routine and I just play aggressive," he said of his strategy.

"You know, if they play too good on that point, then it’s too good.

"But I’m going to go after it and give myself the best chance to win the point."

Raonic, who like Kyrgios has been notching up in excess of 30 aces a match said his serve gives him a bit of freedom on the return.

The winner of the match will probably face the in-form Swiss legend Roger Federer in the semifinals.
related.description: AND it started with an ace. On Wimbledon centre court playing one of his heroes and the world number one Rafael Nadal, Nick Kyrgios arrived with his signature monster statement.
related.standFirst: AUSTRALIAN Nick Kyrgios has defeated Rafael Nadal in four sets on Wimbledon’s centre court.
related.subtitle: Nick Kyrgios stuns Wimbledon with win over Rafael Nadal

thumbnailImage.description: Wildcard Kyrgios stuns his hero Nadal
thumbnailImage.subtitle: f9da3d6c-0159-11e4-8fce-3dc9660cd2ac
thumbnailImage.title: Wildcard Kyrgios stuns his hero Nadal

related.title: Wildcard Kyrgios stuns his hero Nadal

related.body:
Every person in Wimbledon’s Centre Court applauded in awe.

Australian teenager Kyrgios’ audacious, between-the-legs winner in his historic fourth-round win over Rafael Nadal has gone viral on social media and is the talk of the tennis world.

With scores locked at 3-3 in the second set, 19-year-old Kyrgios played a shot most in his position would never dare try, let alone pull off.

WIN: Wildcard Kyrgios stuns his hero Nadal

FIRSTS: Nick v Nadal by numbers

PRIDE: Krygios kicks off Twitter frenzy with humble post

IN PICTURES: Kyrgios knocks Nadal out of Wimbledon

A powerful Nadal backhand was struck straight at the Australian, who duly opened his legs and clipped an outrageous effort just over the net for a winner.

Kyrgios had tried a few other “tweeners” in his previous matches at the All England Club this week.

This one, at a moment of tension against the world No. 1, stuck. Kyrgios raised his arms and circled for the crowd, as if to say “you’re welcome”.

Nadal, in no mood to admire, turned his back almost immediately. The shot has drawn comparisons with Roger Federer’s famous “tweener” at the 2009 US Open, considered by some as the greatest shot of all time.

In the context of the match, Kyrgios’ winner meant little.

He was 40-0 down at the time and went on to lose the game and the set.

However it was a perfect illustration of the fearless attitude that helped him pull off one of the biggest upsets in grand slam history.

It was one of a stack of spectacular winners for Kyrgios, who says his aggressive shot-making is more than a case of youthful exuberance.

“I love to entertain,” Kyrgios said.

“I think I’m always going to have a style of game that’s aggressive.

“To be able to play my best tennis, that’s how I’m going to have to play. I am going to have to play free, back myself under pressure.

“That’s going to give me the best chance to win matches.”

The teenage sensation said it was getting angry at his mum thinking he couldn’t beat the world number one that inspired his shock victory.

The 19-year-old, ranked 144 in the world, said he got all fired up by his Malaysian mother Norlaila thinking he had no chance against the two-time Wimbledon champion.

“I was reading a comment that she thought Rafa was too good for me. It actually made me a bit angry. You would think he’s in a whole other level compared to me. I just believed in myself that I could create some opportunities,’’ the Australian said.

Kyrgios, making his Wimbledon debut on a wildcard, downed 14-time Grand Slam winner Nadal 7-6 (7/5), 5-7, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 in an astonishing fourth round upset.

"I’m pretty happy. That’s the biggest win of my career, and that’s something I’m never going to forget. I’m going to draw so much confidence out of that no matter where I play now. To have that under my belt, it’s massive,’’ he said.

The wildcard performed a victory jig on the Centre Court, a dance move he called the "juicy wiggle’’.

The teenager did not have time to speak to his mum on the telephone but said: "I’ll just text her a smiley face.’’

"I’ve no girlfriend. My family have rotated from home. I get homesick pretty quickly if I don’t see them. I have my sister and my dad here at the moment. I think they’ve been good enough to come, visit me, make sure I’m okay.’’

Kyrgios next faces the huge-serving Canadian eighth seed Milos Raonic on Court One on Wednesday for a place in the semi-finals.

"I’m just a normal kid, 19-year-old. I play a lot of Xbox. I brought my Xbox with me. Never did I think a week ago I was going to make the quarter-finals of Wimbledon in my first appearance,’’ he said.

Kyrgios said appearing on the giant show courts did not faze him one bit.

"On the big stage, it’s something I thrive on: the atmosphere, the crowd. I just love it when at 5-3, I think it was in the fourth set, they erupted, the crowd. I just love that feeling,’’ he said.

"At that stage you just think about all the work you put in. You know if you believe in yourself. Especially with my serve, if I just go after it, hit the right spots, I’m going to have a pretty good shot to close out a match.’’

Three-time 1980s Wimbledon champion John McEnroe, himself a feisty youth in his heyday, reckons Kyrgios can win the whole tournament, but the Australian is trying not to get ahead of himself.

"I’m just going to stay grounded,’’ he said.

"Milos has probably got the best serve in the world. I’m just going to go out there and have fun again.

"I’m always going to have a style of game that’s aggressive, having an aggressive serve, really take control from the baseline. To be able to play my best tennis, that’s how I’m going to have to play.

"I am going to have to play free, back myself under pressure. That’s going to give me the best chance to win matches.

"There’s going to be a lot of walking from side to side from his serve, and there’s going to be a lot of winners in the match. It’s going to be hard to find rhythm. I’m just going to go out there and just go on my return of serve.’’

Kyrgios wants to draw on the fighting spirit of Australia’s Grand Slam winners as he makes what will now be a certain surge into the world’s top 100.

"You look at the Australian culture of what it was back when Lleyton Hewitt was a champion, Pat Rafter was a champion. They were such fearless competitors. I want to start bringing that back into the sport, especially for Australian tennis,’’ he said.

AFP/AAP
