related.body:
Running the length of his right arm from wrist to sleeve, fans were in awe of the supposed inking, saying the 19-year-old brought “swag in tennis to a whole new level”.

More: Kyrgios stuns with four-set Wimbeldon win over Rafael Nadal 

The “tatt”, which featured a tribal-looking pattern, appeared have given his dark skin a white hue underneath, leaving fans baffled about how it was done.

The tattoo that Kyrgios has is fkin awesome

— Daenerys Targaryen (@th4t_ginger) July 1, 2014 

Kind of obsessed with Kyrgios' tattoo pic.twitter.com/TIqP9LREL3

— Stacey Bartlett (@staceybartlett) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios brings swag in tennis to a whole new level with his arm tattoo

— Jack Carolan (@Jackobeanz) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios' arm tattoo is freaking me out! Why and how is it white?

— Beci Wood (@beciwood) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios's tattoo is sooo awesome! #LovinIt #Wimbeldon14

— Penny Clark (@PennyClark_23) July 1, 2014 

#wimbledon2014 kyrgios playing nadal....is that a tattoo on his right arm? pic.twitter.com/pKxT0h06Bn

— Terry Rideout (@TerrysTwit78) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios epic arm tattoo pic.twitter.com/irRs3ZarUg

— Technically Bryan (@technicallybry) July 1, 2014 

But for those wanting to mimic the look, it turns out it’s pretty easy to get “a Kyrgios” — the tatt is just a piece of tape.

Developed by an Australian Musculoskeletal Physiotherapist and made by Vanuatu-based Dynamic Tape, the product is a unique, strongly elastic tape for treating soft tissue sports injuries. 

The uniquely branded “Tattoo Tape” features a tribal tattoo design created by Norfolk Island and Tahitian artist, Tihoti, and is available in both black and beige.

The intricately-designed product was also worn by Tim Cahill during the World Cup to blend in with his own tattoos.

The Dynamic Tape website says the highly elastic tape is used to strongly assist or resist movement, facilitate or inhibit and offload tissue through full range of motion. The tape is applied to an injured muscle or tendon and as the muscle or joint lengthens, the tape is stretched to absorb load and reduce the work on the muscles. This results in decreased workload, demand on the muscle and improved tolerance to fatigue.

Managing Director of Dynamic Tape, Ryan Kendrick, told news.com.au he had no idea Kyrgios was using his Tribal Tape, but wasn’t surprised that people mistook the product for a real tattoo.

“When I have worn it myself people often ask to see my tattoo and I have had many of my patients recount funny stories like an 85-year-old great grandmother whose son was disgusted with her as he thought she had gone out and got some ink!” he said.

He said Ana Ivanovic and Sania Mirzer used the tan tattoo version of the product at the Australian Open earlier this year while Tommy Haas wore the black tattoo design. Serena Williams, Laura Robson and Kim Clijsters have also used the product.

Kendrick said the tattoo design came about because he was living on Norfolk Island when the tape was developed and wanted to reflect the heritage of the island and the South Pacific.

“The design was given to us by a very well known Polynesian artist and tattooist named Tihoti. Tihoti is Tahitian but his wife is a Norfolk Islander. Norfolk relies heavily on tourism and with the global financial crisis and high Australian Dollar, they were suffering so it was our way of spreading the word about Norfolk Island a little.”

Kinesio Australia Education Director, Clint Bridges, says while the tribal tape is not an official Kinesio product, the Kinesio taping method is regularly used on the tennis circuit.

“Novak Djokovic, Li Na and Serena Williams all use a beige form of the tape on court. At a base level, it’s used to try and change the way the muscle is firing. There are specific tensions for different tasks which changes the way the brain thinks that muscle is working.

“Certain tensions provide stimulus on the skin, which sends a message to the brain. The brain then reinterprets that message and sends instructions back to the muscle so it learns how to behave. There would be one tension for relaxation of the muscle if it’s tight and one for activation.”

Kendrick said the tape was released commercially in Australia in late 2010, followed by the UK and then North America in 2012. The tape was used by a number of athletes at the London 2012 games and is now available in 25 countries.

So there you have it, for all those out there wanting the Kyrgios tattoo, you’re in luck.

For just $15.10, you can buy five metres of the stuff.

Were you fooled by Kyrgios’ tattoo? Leave your comment below.

related.body:
Nick Kyrgios has delivered the most outstanding performance of his fledgling career to shock world No 1 Rafael Nadal to reach the Wimbledon quarter-finals.

In a performance that reverberated from the heart of the All England Club across the world, the 19-year-old from Canberra has pulled off one of the greatest upsets in tennis history.

‘TWEENER’: THE SHOT THAT STUNNED THE WORLD 

BOOM BOOM TIME: MCENROE, CASH BACK KYRGIOS TO WIN IT ALL 

SISTER ACT: FAMILY SO PROUD OF NICK 

BOILOVER: RAFA PRAISES CONQUEROR KYRGIOS 

SCROLL DOWN TO RELIVE ALL THE ACTION FROM OUR LIVE BLOG

His 7-6 (7-5) 5-7 7-6 (7-5) 6-3 triumph over 14-time grand slam champion Nadal is the first time a teenager has beaten a world No 1 at the majors since 2005.

Ironically, the last player to manage the feat was Nadal, who beat Roger Federer at the French Open.

Watched from the members’ pavilion by Australian greats Rod Laver and Neale Fraser, Kyrgios dissolved in emotion after putting dual Wimbledon champion Nadal to the sword on the most famous tennis court on the planet with a trademark forehand winner.

His father George and sister Halimah shed tears in the players’ box as the reality of triumph took hold.

Icily composed, the Australian prodigy blasted his way to career-defining victory with 37 aces in a truly astounding serving performance.

By the end of the match, Nadal — grand slam tennis’s ultimate warrior — was broken and baffled on losing to world No 144 Kyrgios.

No male world No 1 had fallen to a player ranked outside the top 100 since Russian Andrei Olhovskiy, then ranked 193rd, stunned Jim Courier at Wimbledon 21 years ago.

If most of the 15,000 spectators around centre court were startled, Kyrgious was not surprised at all.

“You’ve got to believe you can win the match and I did,” Kyrgios said.

“You’ve got to believe that you can win and that’s the way I approached it.

“I think I was in a bit of zone out there, I played some extradorindary tennis, I served at a really good level out there.”

Revealing he had been irked by his mother Nill’s comment that Nadal would be too good, Kyrgios said: “I don’t know what she was thinking.”

“The mind is buzzing, I’m just going to enjoy this, soak it up and not even think about my next match.”

Kyrgios will tonight face Canadian eighth seed Milos Raonic for a spot in Friday’s semi-finals.

Few would be prepared to write of the youngster who over the past week created a huge impression.

First-round victory over Frenchman Stephane Robert was followed by a herculean effort to save a Wimbledon record nine match points against Richard Gasquet before he edged past Czech Jiri Vesely.

Those excellent performances were eclipsed by 2hrs, 58mins of sheer excellence against Nadal.

Kyrgios’s only quandary post-match was how to celebrate.

He clasped his face in his hands, dropped his racquet and stared in disbelief at his support group, led by coaches Simon Rae, Aaron Kellett and Josh Eagle.

“I didn’t know what to do, there are so many emotions,” he said.

“I didn’t know whether to drop my racquet, to drop to my knees..

“It is unbelievable.”

Contesting only his 14th match at senior level, Kyrgios blazed his way past a grand slam immortal — only two weeks after losing in the first round of a Nottingham Challenge.

Since then, Kyrgios has won nine matches in a row — five at third-tier Challenger level and now four more at the grand temple of the sport — to stand on the brink of history.

Kyrgios would become the lowest-ranked player in Wimbledon history to win the tournament, surpassing world No 125 Goran Ivanisevic’s 2001 victory over Pat Rafter.

The teenager is guaranteed at least $432,000 and a rankings rise to world No 66 — only 18 months after he stood at No 828.

A large reason for Kyrgios’s transformation the fringes to world-beater is his vastly improved fitness.

Another is his omnipotent serve, which has delivered a tournament-high of 113 aces and only 14 double faults against elite company.

His delivery was unworldly against shell-shocked Nadal, who only briefly latched onto it.

Kyrgios conceded only 12 points on his first set for the match. That statistic is simply breathtaking — especially against nine-time French Open champion Nadal.

Faced with the most ferocious grand slam competitor in the world, Kyrgios did not lose a single first serve point, winning all 19 while gunning down 13 aces and thumping 22 clean winners.

And he was able to maintain momentum despite Nadal using every piece of his devastating artillery.

Impossibly laid back, Kyrgios seized the ascendancy by blasting drives past frustrated Nadal.

Unfazed at letting slip a set point on Nadal’s serve in the 12th game, Kyrgios romped through the tiebreak after surging to a 4-0 lead.

Maintaining incredible serving levels, the teenager produced the shot of the tournament midway through the second set, with a half-volley winner — played off a bare baseliner and between the legs.

In control, he will long rue a sloppy service game at 6-5.

Despite holding game points, he dropped serve for the first time in the match — and the set.

Nadal’s relief was palpable as the Spanish bull jabbed his fist in delight. It had taken him 95 minutes to create the first crack in Kyrgios’s arsenal.

No player in international tennis saps energy from opponent like Nadal. Impressively, Kyrgios continued to trade heavyweight blows with the world champion.

And when the tyro twice survived serving crisis deep in the third set before unleashing a monster forehand return Nadal could only push wide to lose the tiebreak, centre court erupted.

Krygios’s father George and sister Halimah jumped to their feet in jubilation as he grabbed the third set with classic stand-and-deliver missile.

More assured with every exchange, Kyrgios pressured Nadal into unforced forehand error in the fourth game of the fourth set as the prospect of miracle victory became reality.

Serving for the match, Kyrgios didn’t blink, sealing the issue with an ace.

related.body:
It was a piece of TV footage that didn’t show any form of abuse or even directly feature a victim, but it went to the heart of the 84-year-old’s credibility and in the moment it was shown in court, his fortunes were dramatically altered.

It was a turning point from which Harris’ case never truly recovered.

For days on the witness stand Harris had denied that he had indecently assaulted a then 14-year-old waitress at a celebrity sports contest in Cambridge in the 1970s for no other reason than he had never done the contest.

‘OMG I’M SO HAPPY’: Rolf’s victim Tonya Lee speaks out 

LINGERING FOREVER: The headlines that will haunt Rolf Harris 

CHILLING WORDS: Rolf Harris starred in Kids Can Say No! to sex abuse video 

ANOTHER VICTIM: Aussie woman claims rolf Harris assaulted her too 

Harris went further and said he had only ever done such a show in Florida in the US and had only been to the historic Cambridge city two years ago for the first time.

He was adamant, particularly about the latter point and mentioned it more than once, with his statements were widely reported.

It was then a member of the public tipped off authorities and they discovered not only was there such a celebrity sports event but it was a TV show called “Star Games”. Footage showed not only had Harris partaken but he captained the team and did a large televised painting at the event — all of which occurred at Cambridge.

The dramatic discovery of the 1978 TV footage disrupted the trial as the jury, which did not know then of the footage discovery, had to be retired to allow legal parties to argue for their respective inclusion and exclusion.

Defence lawyers knew its inclusion would go to the heart of their client’s credibility in the eyes of the jury since he was so sure on the stand of his evidence, with no-one at that point able to contradict.

His defence on that indictment — groping the 14-year-old on the buttocks in what she thought was about 1976 — revolved about his denial of the event and city. They tried unsuccessfully to have the footage blocked from inclusion on the grounds of fairness and prejudice and said their defence would have been different if the 1978 footage was known about.

Both prosecution and defence said it was not an ideal situation for either side but Justice Nigel Sweeney agreed while the case was at a sensitive stage he accepted the prosecution’s argument and allowed the footage to be shown.

Harris attempted to counter and said that he did not remember being on the program but accepted he was there but did not realise it was Cambridge and added no celebrities probably realised it was that city since they all just got bussed around the country and that was the nature of show business.

He repeatedly denied lying or tailoring his evidence to suit the evidence presented but the damage was done.

related.body:
Here’s how the world reacted.

THE MAN HIMSELF

Even Kyrgios was surprised at how well he played.

“I was in a bit of zone out there, I played some extraordinary tennis, I served at a really good level out there,” he said.

“I’m a normal kid like any 19-year-old who likes to play on his Xbox. The big stage is something I thrive on.

“Never did I think a week ago I was going to make the quarter-finals of Wimbledon in my first appearance.”

Have to do it all again tomorrow and I can't wait! First @Wimbledon & I'm in the last 8 club!! #HaveThat

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

Slowly sinking in. What an unreal day! Thanks to Simon, AK, Anne-Marie & @JohnMorris1982 for all their hard work. Massive team effort. #BOOM

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

HIS MUM

Kyrgios’ own mother didn’t think he could beat the world No. 1.

“My mum said in an interview she thought Rafa was too good ... that made me mad and spurred me on,” Kyrgios told the BBC.

MORE: The shot that stunned the world 

MORE: Giant killer Kyrgios takes out Nadal 

Nick Kyrgios’ quarter-final match against world No. 9 Canadian Milos Raonic will start after midnight tonight AEST. 

THE OPPONENT

The ever-gracious Rafael Nadal heaped praise on Kyrgios, conceding “he play better than me”.

“When you have an opponent that he decides to serve and to hit every ball very strong, you are in trouble,” Nadal said.

“I didn’t play really bad.”

Asked what the dual Wimbledon champion would be doing with his unexpected spare time, Nadal said: “Congratulations to him. For me, beach. For me, I going to go to the beach in Mallorca.”

THE LEGEND

John McEnroe came up with a massive call, saying, “We have found the next guy in the men’s game.”

“The last guy I saw like this was Boris Becker with no fear and believing that they can win this thing,” McEnroe said.

“You are watching someone who is going to be a big star in the future.”

Aussie Aussie Aussie Oi Oi Oi. @NickKyrgios the giant slayer! #wimbledon #believe pic.twitter.com/H8xt7lGRPh

— Pat Cash (@TheRealPatCash) July 1, 2014 

Nick Kyrgios- the Wonder from "Down Under" shocks #1 Nadal at Wimbledon. Welcome to the World Stage- YOUTH!! Great effort.

— Jimmy Connors (@JimmyConnors) July 1, 2014 

THE MEGASTAR AND A COUPLE OF PMs

Actor Hugh Jackman, Prime Minister Tony Abbott and former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser were among the famous Aussies to show their support for our newest star.

Aussie Aussie Aussie @NickKyrgios. Such composure and class! But hard off to @RafaelNadal ... one of the greatest of all time!

— Hugh Jackman (@RealHughJackman) July 1, 2014 

Extraordinary performance @NickKyrgios. Australia couldn't be prouder of you - what a win & what an amazing attitude! #Wimbledon2014

— Tony Abbott (@TonyAbbottMHR) July 1, 2014 

Wimbledon 2014: Nick Kyrgios defeats Rafael Nadal in four-set upset. Victory extraordinary, congratulations Kyrgios. http://t.co/F7DImcNLWm

— Malcolm Fraser (@MalcolmFraser12) July 1, 2014 

THE TWITTERATI

And this is how the rest of the world reacted...

Even though my TV show premiered tonight!!! I regretfully say this was by far the best thing on television. #Kyrgios pic.twitter.com/HhUockXJel

— Andy Lee (@andy_lee) July 1, 2014 

Now that was worth staying up for. @NickKyrgios take a bow. Remarkable play. #Wimbledon #aussiepride

— Steve Smith (@stevesmith49) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios is the 1st teenager to beat a world #1 at a Grand Slam since Nadal def Federer at 2005 French Open. Congrats Nick. Stunning effort.

— Darren Cahill (@darren_cahill) July 1, 2014 

Three weeks ago, Nick Kyrgios was losing in the first round of a Challenger event in Nottingham. To world 185 John-Patrick Smith. Meteor

— tomfordyce (@tomfordyce) July 1, 2014 

Nick #Kyrgios is the first player outside the top 100 to beat the world No.1 since Andrei Olhovsky v Jim Courier 1992 pic.twitter.com/veQynIAKlt

— BBC Tennis (@bbctennis) July 1, 2014 

‘He play better than me’: Rafael Nadal after losing his match against Aussie Nick Kyrgios. Photo: Scott Heavey/AELTC - Pool/Getty Images

related.title: World in shock over Aussie Nick

related.body:
Nick Kyrgios’ audacious between-the-legs winner against Rafael Nadal has made global headlines, with some news outlets describing it as the shot of the year.

MATCH REPORT: GIANT KILLER KYRGIOS BEATS NADAL 

BOOM BOOM TIME: MCENROE, CASH BACK KYRGIOS TO WIN IT ALL 

SISTER ACT: FAMILY SO PROUD OF NICK 

World applauds Kyrgios’ ‘shot of the year’

The “tweener” perfectly summed up Kyrgios’s approach at Wimbledon — fearless, fun and a finesse-to-firepower ratio to match it with the world’s elite.

Commentators including John McEnroe and Tim Henman described Kyrgios’ shot as “beyond belief” and the “shot of the year”. The world’s tennis media thought likewise.

Have to do it all again tomorrow and I can't wait! First @Wimbledon & I'm in the last 8 club!! #HaveThat

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

“Kyrgios played probably the shot of the year, let alone the shot of Wimbledon, as he nonchalantly knocked a return drop-shot through his legs for the point,” wrote Mike Singer of CBS Sports.

“It takes some kind of something to try that shot when you’re up a set, deadlocked in the second at three games each against the No. 1 player in the world.

“Kyrgios maintained his moxie to pull the stunning upset. It’s the first time Nadal has lost to a teenager since 2007.”

Slowly sinking in. What an unreal day! Thanks to Simon, AK, Anne-Marie & @JohnMorris1982 for all their hard work. Massive team effort. #BOOM

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

'I like to give the people a bit of a show' #nickkyrgios

— Paul McNamee (@PaulFMcNamee) July 1, 2014 

Sports Illustrated’s Courtney Nguyen concurred.

“The 19-year-old Australian wildcard grabbed headlines last week when he saved nine match points to rally from two-sets to love down to beat No. 14 Richard Gasquet for his first top-15 victory,” Nguyen wrote. “Now, he’ll grab some more after hitting an audacious front-side tweener in the second set against Nadal.

“The kid is a shot-maker.”

Chris Chase, writing for USA Today

, joked Kyrgios’ was “clearly cowed by his surroundings” when playing the between-the-legs shot on the biggest stage, against the biggest opponent in the biggest match of his career.

“Remember the name Nick Kyrgios,” Chase wrote. “The 19-year-old Australian has the necessary combination of skills, savvy, swag and serve to be a major player in the post-Federer/Nadal/Djokovic generation.

Aussie Aussie Aussie @NickKyrgios. Such composure and class! But hard off to @RafaelNadal ... one of the greatest of all time!

— Hugh Jackman (@RealHughJackman) July 1, 2014 

Incredible win @NickKyrgios Defeating world no.1 @RafaelNadal to move through to @Wimbledon #QuarterFinals Amazinggg!! #AussiePride

— Sally Fitzgibbons (@Sally_Fitz) July 1, 2014 

“On Tuesday, Kyrgios set foot on Centre Court for the first time to play the world No. 1 in Rafael Nadal. He was clearly cowed by his surroundings.

“Kyrgios won’t be 20 until next April. He was the youngest player in the men’s draw at Wimbledon and won three matches before taking the opening set against Nadal. Though he’s still a long way from contending at Slams, he’s a player to watch in the future, and not just when he goes through the legs.”

John Branch, writing for the New York Times, was similarly I pressed with Kyrgios’ outing, noting he had become the “lowest-ranked player to beat Nadal since No. 690 Joachim Johansson beat him in Stockholm in 2006.”

“Until the evening shadows fell on Centre Court Tuesday, the last time a teenager beat a No. 1 player at a Grand Slam event was at the 2005 French Open,” Branch wrote. “The winner was Rafael Nadal, over Roger Federer, a couple of days after Nadal’s 19th birthday.

Wildcard Nick Kyrgios just beat World No. 1 Nadal! Hats off. Well played champ.

— Virat Kohli (@imVkohli) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios is the 1st teenager to beat a world #1 at a Grand Slam since Nadal def Federer at 2005 French Open. Congrats Nick. Stunning effort.

— Darren Cahill (@darren_cahill) July 1, 2014 

“Nick Kyrgios, a 19-year-old wildcard entrant from Australia, joined Nadal by beating him in the fourth round of Wimbledon.

“All limbs and panache, Kyrgios battered Nadal with big serves, boundless reach and boyish enthusiasm. Ranked No. 144 in the world, but rising fast, Kyrgios looked immune to the pressure and fearless with his shots.”

Aussie Aussie Aussie Oi Oi Oi. @NickKyrgios the giant slayer! #wimbledon #believe pic.twitter.com/H8xt7lGRPh

— Pat Cash (@TheRealPatCash) July 1, 2014 

Nick Kyrgios- the Wonder from "Down Under" shocks #1 Nadal at Wimbledon. Welcome to the World Stage- YOUTH!! Great effort.

— Jimmy Connors (@JimmyConnors) July 1, 2014 

Just watching the 3rd set of @NickKyrgios V Rafa. What a effort by this young gun of aussie tennis, keep it going mate

— Scott Pendlebury (@SP_10) July 1, 2014 

I think it's now safe to change the tag line of #NKRising to #NKRisen ..@NickKyrgios

— Mahesh Bhupathi (@Maheshbhupathi) July 1, 2014 

The win by @NickKyrgios over Rafael Nadal. A bigger upset than Mark Philippoussis not finding his future wife on Age Of Love. Well done son.

— Ryan Fitzgerald (@FitzySA) July 1, 2014 

Well done to @NickKyrgios just woke up to the news. What a great effort to beat the world no1. #nowbringithome

— Anthony Watmough (@AnthonyWatmough) July 1, 2014 

Extraordinary performance @NickKyrgios. Australia couldn't be prouder of you - what a win & what an amazing attitude! #Wimbledon2014

— Tony Abbott (@TonyAbbottMHR) July 1, 2014 

Even though my TV show premiered tonight!!! I regretfully say this was by far the best thing on television. #Kyrgios pic.twitter.com/HhUockXJel

— Andy Lee (@andy_lee) July 1, 2014 

Now that was worth staying up for. @NickKyrgios take a bow. Remarkable play. #Wimbledon #aussiepride

— Steve Smith (@stevesmith49) July 1, 2014 

Nick kyrgios u r the man, awesome win

— Dane Tilse (@DaneTilse) July 1, 2014 

What a performance by @NickKyrgios Absolutely outstanding

— Laurie Fisher (@LordLaurie58) July 1, 2014

related.body:
It’s time to get on the bandwagon.

Kyrgios will face Canada’s world No. 9 in the early hours of tomorrow, and the likes of tennis legend John McEnroe are predicting an upset, saying the 19-year-old can go all the way and win the prestigious Wimbledon crown as a teenager.

Here are 10 things you didn’t know about Nick Kyrgios.

1. HOW TO PRONOUNCE HIS NAME

The “G” is silent. So “Kirr-ee-oss”. Not “Kurr-gee-oss”, like the spelling would suggest.

2. HIS BACKGROUND

Kyrgios is Aussie born. A Canberra boy. His father, George, was born in Greece and moved to Australia as a child. His mother, Norlaila, is Malaysian.

Kyrgios is the youngest of three kids. His brother is a lawyer and his sister an actor.

3. HE WAS A CHUBBY KID

Kyrgios’ mother, Norlaila, admits her boy ate too much as a child. He loved his food.

But he eventually stretched out into a lean 1.93m (6ft 4in), 77kg frame and lost the puppy fat.

MORE: The shot that stunned the world 

MORE: Legends, celebs in shock over Aussie Nick 

MORE: Why you don’t need to cheer for Tomic anymore 

4. THE HISTORY HE’S CREATED

With his 7-6 (7-5), 5-7 7-6 (7-5) 6-3 victory over Nadal — one of the greatest upsets in Wimbledon history — Kyrgios became the first teenager to defeat a world No. 1 at a grand slam since Nadal did it himself against Roger Federer in the 2005 French Open. An ominous sign.

The youngest man in the men’s draw, the 144th-ranked Kyrgios also became the first player ranked outside the top 100 to defeat a world No. 1 at a grand slam since Andrei Olhovsky defeated Jim Courier at Wimbledon in 1992.

Kyrgios is the youngest man to reach the last eight at Wimbledon since compatriot Bernard Tomic in 2011 and the first to reach the quarter-finals on debut since German Florian Mayer 10 years ago.

5. BASKETBALL BECKONED
Canberra is boasting right now about being the home of Australia’s hottest sporting stars. NBA star Patty Mills, the “next big thing” in basketball Dante Exum and Kyrgios are all products of the nation’s capital. Kyrgios was a hoops-mad kid as well, representing Australia in basketball as a young teen before making tennis his sole focus as a 14-year-old. He still loves the Boston Celtics.

6. THE MONEY GAME

Since turning pro in 2013, Kyrgios has played only 10 matches on ATP Tour. Of those, he has only won three and lost seven (going into Wimbledon).

This year, he’d won just one match on the pro tour — the Australian Open first round against Benjamin Becker, the namesake of the man Kyrgios has been compared to quite a bit today, Boris Becker.

What it all means is he’d won $A248,000 in his career up until Wimbledon. He will walk away from the All England Club with a minimum $A409,806 for reaching the quarter-finals. The Wimbledon champion takes home $A3.19 million.

7. HIS IDOLS

If Kyrgios can shock the world once more and defeat Raonic tonight, he is on track to meet the man he looked up to most as a child, Roger Federer, in the Wimbledon semi-finals. Another guy he really idolised as a youngster was Nadal.

Kyrgios first started playing tennis at six years old, in 2001. By that stage, Federer had already been a pro for three years.

8. HE LIKES RAP

Kyrgios is a Lil Wayne fan. And he was into Wu Tang as a kid. He also likes R’n’B artist Rihanna.

9. HE WAS A TOP JUNIOR

While top juniors don’t always make it big, Kyrgios was a junior world No. 1 and won the junior Australian Open in 2013, defeating countryman Thanasi Kokkinakis in the final.

10. HE LOVES A LAUGH

Proving he is not just a serious tennis robot, Kyrgios loves a comedy and is a big Family Guy fan.

related.body:
• An ugly barrage of texts sent from Tinder co-founder Justin Mateen to his fellow co-founder Whitney Wolfe have been published.

• Backpackers living in shipping containers had to be rescued from a fire in Sydney overnight.

• The first person to post the bubbling photo of Todd Carney has hit back at critics saying he was only trying to find out if the photo was fake.

• A rogue waiter who called his cafe customers “stupid” says that he was p****d off they got their order wrong.

10am 

That’s it for our live #RUSHHOUR news blog. You can get across the stories you need to know today below or go to news.com.au for the latest headlines.

9.55am 

The Sri Lankan military denies it has picked up a boatload of Tamil asylum seekers on their way to Australia, ABC reports.

The military says it has no plans to pick up the boat, which is believed to be carrying 150 people and has not be contactable since the weekend.

It may also have been intercepted by the Australian Navy or Customs.

9.45am 

Thousands of Game of Thrones fans lined up for hours yesterday for an exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art.

9.35am 

Air Chief Marshal Mark Binskin says an Australian Special Forces officer has died from a non-combat incident overnight.

9.20am 

Australia’s Chief of Defence is due to release details about an ‘incident in Afghanistan’ at 9.30am.

9.10am 

Yesterday was a special anniversary for a number of regions. Organisers say a record number of protesters took part in a pro-democracy rally in Hong Kong on July 1, to mark the date the city was handed back to China in 1997.

Meanwhile residents of the Northern Terrority celebrated their own anniversary, releasing fireworks to mark Territory Day, the day when the NT became an entity in its own right (which actually falls on January 1, 1911).

9am 

The US has been knocked out of the World Cup this morning after a thrilling game against Belgium. Catch up on all the action on our live blog. Also Argentina v Switzerland.

8.40am 

A rogue waiter who called his cafe customers “stupid” says that he was p****d off they got their order wrong.

Sydney woman Fung Dang was furious after receiving a bill that included an item for “stupid customers”, prompting a backlash against the Three Williams Cafe in Redfern.

Waiter Charles Oehlrich, 30, has told The Daily Telegraph that he never thought his comments would print on the bill.

“I take full responsibility. I’m the one that deserves to be fired and so I have been,” he said.

“She was really nice about it - that is the worst thing about it. They are not stupid people.”

8.30am 

The building industry is set to be rocked by an explosive video and claims of corruption, death threats and intimidation during royal commission hearings in Melbourne next week.

The Herald Sun understands witnesses will detail claims about senior figures in the Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union.

At least one witness due to give evidence has received death threats from people linked to the union.

8.20am 

Sydney train commuters face delays on the T1 Northern Line due to a broken down freight train at Beecroft.

Continue to allow extra travel time due to a freight train with a mechanical issue at Beecroft earlier.

— T1 Sydney Trains (@T1SydneyTrains) July 1, 2014 

8am 

The first person to post the bubbling photo of Todd Carney has hit back at critics saying he was only trying to find out if the photo was fake.

Mark Miler, who posts as @MarkRaider1 did not take the photo but is believed to be the first person to post it on Twitter.

Meanwhile Dragons player Josh Dugan, who engaged in a Twitter war with Miler last year, told Fairfax he wasn’t surprised that Miler was the first to post the photo.

R u ppl normal..URz r making out I took the pic and sent to the whole world..I found the pic and asked if it was real or fake ..simple

— Mark Miler (@MarkRaider1) June 30, 2014 

7.35am 

An ugly barrage of texts sent from Tinder co-founder Justin Mateen to his fellow co-founder Whitney Wolfe have been published as part of her sexual harassment case.

The texts revealed on Gawker reveal a relentless stream of abuse from Mateen after a failed romance with Wolfe. He calls her “heartless”, “fake” and responds to pleas from Wolfe to get back to work with his own warning: “if you threaten me I will bark back like a psycho”.

7.20am 

It was going to happen sooner or later. Sexy felon Jeremy Meeks has reportedly secured a modelling contract with LA based Blaze Models, according to TMZ.

The internet went crazy for Meeks after his mugshot was posted on Facebook and he now has an agent, Gina Rodriguez, a former porn star.

Now, if only he could get out of jail.

7.10am 

UPDATE: Looks like some of the people rescued from a major fire in a Sydney industrial area overnight were backpackers living in shipping containers.

7am 

Tens of thousands of mourners in Israel farewelled three teenagers killed in the West Bank, while vowing to hunt down the Hamas militants it holds responsible for their kidnap and murder.

Gilad Shaer and Naftali Frenkel, both 16, and 19-year-old Eyal Ifrach, were found in a field in the West Bank after going missing on June 12.

All three had been shot in a triple murder blamed on militants from the Islamist Hamas movement, Sky News reports.

6.25am 

Aussie teenager Nick Kyrgios has delivered one of the greatest upsets in tennis history, beating world No 1 Rafael Nadal at Wimbledon overnight.

The 19-year-old from Canberra pulled off a 7-6, 5-7, 7-6, 6-3 win to reach the Wimbledon quarterfinals. Click here for a recap of all the action.

6.10am 

The lover of an infamous prison gangster has disappeared amid grave concerns for her safety.

Tia Maria Jayne Landers has been missing since June 16. She was last seen when CCTV cameras recorded her walking into a petrol station on the Gateway Motorway at Nudgee in Brisbane’s north.

Ms Landers, 28, had been a no-show in an armed robbery and burglary trial a month earlier when the case against her partner, jailhouse “Angry Gang” member Wade Bartz, was dropped.

However, her disappearance is believed to be unrelated to Bartz.

6.05am 

About 70 firefighters battled a large fire in Sydney this morning.

The blaze in the inner west suburb of Alexandria spread to three buildings and firefighters had to rescue four people and evacuate 14 others.

Firefighters arrived at the industrial complex on Burrows Rd about 1.20am.

Motorists are advised to avoid the area but some traffic is now being allowed through Burrows Rd and Euston Rd between Campbell St and Sydney Park Rd.

Fire crews are still working to contain a blaze in an Alexandria industrial complex. Details @TheTodayShow. #9News pic.twitter.com/Nqji5vfIE4

— Nine News Sydney (@9NewsSyd) July 1, 2014 

6am 

Good morning, and welcome to our morning news coverage. We will be bringing you the best of what’s happening this morning, so you can get across the news quickly.

related.body:
After months of searching, Paul Fenech and his team have located the crème de la crème of boganism for 7mate’s reality show, Bogan Hunters, and the Apple Isle is certainly punching well above its weight.

After an exhaustive process of elimination, celebrity judges Angry Anderson, Jonesy, Miss Nude Australia, Tahir Bilgic, Jacko, Chris Franklin, Derek Boyer and Rob Shehadie have selected seven finalists to go through to next Tuesday’s Bogan Hunters Grand Final.

More: Do bogans know they’re bogans and other important questions

Fenech told news.com.au that only the purest of bogans made it through.

“When we started the series I thought it was a bit of a joke. But boganism is a culture. These guys are unashamedly bogans. They love it, they live it, they have a complete lack of any pretence. I reckon the bogan is the true Aussie battler of the new millennium.”

And while they are all unique in their embracement of the “culture”, they all have one thing in common. 

“It’s a mystery, the teeth of the bogan,” added Fenech, “a bit like the Bermuda Triangle. Could be too many Beam and Cokes, I don’t know. But I would say more than 50 per cent of bogans do have some pretty interesting teeth, that’s for sure. It could be a money thing. It costs a lot to get your teeth fixed.”

He says the finalists are defined by: “Mullets, thongs, ugg boots, flannelettes, tight jeans, a love of Oz rock, home done tattoos are important, a lack of pretence is very important, as is a willingness to be incredibly honest at all time.”

Australia, meet your finalists:

MEL: the kinky chick from Munno Para, South Australia 

Said to perfectly represent the “female of the bogan species”. She once stabbed her partner in the neck with a pair of scissors because he poked her too much in the arm.

ANDREW: the dad to eight kids to three different mothers from Bridgewater, Tasmania 

Has the name of his eight kids tattooed on his arms, all the girls on one arm and the boys on the other. “I can’t remember their dates of birth cos I’m always too smashed. That way if I go to Centrelink and they ask me, well I can say ‘here we go, here’s the date of birth” he said as he showed off the ink.

DARREN: the second worst driver in Tasmania, also from Bridgewater 

Has 52 charges of driving with no licence against his name and is proud of it. Has his own car graveyard full off abandoned wrecks. “What more do you want in life,” he said.

NANNA SHAZZA: the larger-than-life GILF from Victoria’s bogan epicentre, Nar Nar Goon 

Is the “odds on favourite” to win. Loves her Holdens, Collingwood football team and exposing her breasts. Enjoys drinking a goon sack of wine hung from a clothesline.

JUSTIN: the young chick magnet from St Helens, Tasmania 

Is the youngest bogan of the finalists. Sports a good array of tatts including an “Made in Australia” sign, a Southern Cross and the name of his son across his chest. Became a dad at 16 and is fiercely proud of his mullet which he describes as “nice and filthy”.

FORDY: the wild man from Rocky aka Western Australia’s most bogan suburb, Rockingham 

Can swear mid-word, loves a nudie run, Ned Kelly, a barbecue and has an esky of beers kept next to his bed. Attempted to eat the rubber remnants left on the ground after a burnout.

CLINT: the 50-something bogan “lifer” from George Town, Tasmania 

Judges said he “ticked so many bogan boxes”. Talked about his favourite sex position, doggie style, showed off his missus’ homemade tattoos and has an incredible collection of bogan friends. Lives in George Town which he describes as the “boganest place in the world”.

The Bogan Hunters Grand Final airs next Tuesday, July 8 at 9.30pm on 7mate. 

The finalists will have to prove themselves once and for all in a final showdown of bogan appearance, attitude and sex appeal, before “Australia’s Greatest Bogan” is crowned.

The winner will be awarded the Golden Thong Award and the Aussie Pride ‘straya ute with kegs in the back, which Paul Fenech describes as a “sick, hectic, off-the-hook prize.”

Local fashion icon, Wil Valor director Mark Ferguson, said the designs, which were revealed on the Gold Coast yesterday, missed the mark.

“It looks like they have tried too hard,” he said.

“They have tried to be out there and different, and it has not paid off.”

It is the team’s bright gold and green training swimwear, with a loud print that includes kangaroos, emus and a map of Australia, that Ferguson instantly disliked, calling it “busy”.

“I don’t like it at all,” Mr Ferguson said. “It is a really busy pattern, you don’t know where to look.

“If you are going to mix the patterns it should be smaller, and with the pattern finishing on the nipple line so they can fit the logos in, it looks half incomplete.

“It is very confusing to the eye.”

GALLERY: Australia’s Commonwealth Games uniform revealed. 

Strikingly similar to the swim uniform from the 1986 Edinburgh Games, it is almost a three-decade backstep in style.

Brisbane stylist Di Cant agreed the training gear was a bad choice.

“I think it is terribly obvious with kangaroos and the map of Australia,” she said. “I understand they wanted a print but it could have been more subtle.

“I think the girls will love wearing it and it will be comfortable, but those prints.”

What are your views on the swimwear designs? Leave your comments below

Both thought the green and black racewear was also a major fashion fail.

“My main issue is with the green and black suits and the emphasis on the crotch,” Ms Cant said.

“The shaping in the crotch and with the black leg, something is not quite flattering.

“It is drawing the eye to the wrong place, rather than to the athletic body and the overall look.”

The swimmers on the other hard were full of complements for the swimsuits.

“Yeah really happy, they’re basic and sort of the same as we’ve had for the last year or so,” freestyler Bronte Barratt said.

“The colours seem good, they’re majority green instead of majority black which is really good because that represents Australia.

“We have the gold cap as well so it will look great.”

related.body:
Baden-Clay has pleaded not guilty in the Supreme Court in Brisbane.

The 74th witness in the trial is forensic toxicologist Dr Michael Robertson.

He said he had been a forensic toxicologist for 20 years and had studied widely in his field.

Dr Robertson said he did a toxicological examination of the results obtained from Allison Baden-Clay.

He said the review was of Ms Baden-Clay’s post mortem results and the levels of a particular drugs, called sertraline.

“Sertaline is the active drug within the commercial or trade name medication Zoloft,” he said.

Dr Robertson said it was an anti-depressant and elevated levels of serotonin in the brain, or mood-elevating chemicals, to reduce depression.

He said sertraline was a Selective Serotonin Re-uptake Inhibitor (SSRI), which increased levels of serotonin in the brain.

He said the drug would be broken down and metabolised into desmethyl sertraline.

Dr Robertson said the levels of sertraline in the blood of Ms Baden-CLay was .59mg/kg and levels of desmethyl sertraline were at 3.3mg/kg.

He said there was also some detected in the stomach and liver, at 5mg/kg and desmethly sertraline of 31mg/kg.

Dr Robertson said it was unusual for levels to be above 0.05mg/kg in a person.

He said average numbers he expected in a living person taking sertraline was 0.03mg/kg.

He said Ms Baden-Clay’s levels were elevated.

He said elevated levels could be caused by the ingestion of a different amount of drug to the recommended therapeutic amount.

Dr Robertson said there were a number of side-effects for sertraline, including common adverse effects such as anxiety, agitation, confusion, thermo-regulation or an elevation of temperature, and even serotonin syndrome or toxicity.

“This is a well described adverse event that involves unusual behaviours,” he said.

He said serotonin effects varied from individual to individual.

Dr Robertson said serotonin syndrome occurred when levels were too high and started to affect other areas of the brain.

“When you get too much of this drug you can get situations again where more profound confusion might exist in a general way, increased agitation, unusual behaviours,” he said.

He said studies showed individuals who were taking “SSRIs” were more likely to experience suicidal ideation.

“The mechanism behind that is simply unclear… it usually happens when someone first starts to take medication or alters medication, those sort of things,” he said.

Dr Robertson agreed Allison would have likely developed a tolerance to the drug.

He said sertraline was usually reported as a multi-drug cause of death, rather than a drug alone.

He agreed the levels of serotonin in the blood were not consistent with an overdose causing death.

Prosecutor's heated questions: 'You killed your wife, Mr Baden-Clay?'

Follow the trial day by day as it unfolds:

DAY 13: Gerard says Allison's journal is 'untrue'

DAY 12: Baden-Clay’s love triangle email trail 

DAY 11: Baden-Clay’s tears as he takes the stand 

DAY 10: How it unfolded as the Crown rests 

DAY 9: Plants on Allison found at her home 

DAY 8: Jurors inspect site where body found 

DAY 7: Neighbour’s explanation for scream 

DAY 6: Scratches not typical of razor 

DAY 5: Listen to triple-0 call to police 

DAY 4: Accused told lover to lie low 

DAY 3: Neighbours heard screams 

DAY 2: Daughter’s tape brings tears 

DAY 1: Photo shock in murder trial

related.body:
Will this collection of hard, empirical evidence placate both the true believers and sceptics? Not likely.

Proving the existence of the Himalayan yeti, and its North American cousin Bigfoot, has been the objective of decades of amateur research.

Sightings of the hairy “ape men” abound, yet hard evidence proves elusive.

US GOVERNMENT MEMO: How to hunt Yetis 

Are they survivors of long-lost species, such as Homo Neanderthalensis or ancient Gigantopithecus apes? Are they embodiments of mythology, such as half-human were-bears?

There are plenty of books. There are plenty of documentaries.

But where’s the real scientific research?

Understandably, evidence-based science has largely avoided this arena where belief has a tendency to trump truth.

But: “Advocates frequently complain that they have been rejected by science,” a University of Oxford study points published in today’s edition of the Proceedings of The Royal Society “B”.

This conflicts with “the basic tenet that science neither rejects nor accepts anything without examining the evidence,” the researchers write.

So they did.

The team made up of Zoologists, geneticists and biologists from Britain, France, Germany, Switzerland and the United States have now carried out the first scientific publication report into the genetics of material attributed to “anomalous primates”.

Their findings?

WHAT DO YOU THINK? Have your say in the comments box, below.

Even in this modern age of high-definition smartphone videos and cameras, what few images do emerge are grainy, out-of-focus and leave much to the imagination. And smeared, oversizes footprints aren’t enough.

But over the years a few pieces have been presented as substantive signs of the sasquatch: Most commonly, hair.

GALLERY: Yeti fever — big, bad monsters 

Tufts of “sasquatch fluff” abound. There even examples of “yeti” scalps.

Hair contains DNA. DNA can be analysed and compared to known species to provide strong evidence of its origins.

“To introduce some clarity into this often murky field, we have carried out a systematic genetic survey of hair samples attributed to these creatures,” the researchers write.

To achieve this they set about gathering samples from museums and private collections all over the world — some 57 in all — and put them all to the test.

Macroscopic, microscopic and infra-red fluorescence methods were brought to bear: And that was just to eliminate the inevitable contamination presented by natural fibres (a nice way of saying forgeries).

The screening left 36 samples as being potentially “real”. These formed the basis of genetic analysis.

Individual strands were put in the blender and their DNA extracted and identified.

Here are the results:

— Six black bears

— Two polar bears

— One brown bear

— Four cows

— Four horses

— Four dogs

— Two raccoons

— One Malaysian tapir

— One deer

— One sheep

— One porcupine

— One human

— One serow

Serow what?

Don’t get too excited. It’s a goatlike antelope from Central Asia.

So, no Yetis.

But wait: There is wiggle room.

The above lists only 30 of the 36 samples.

“Seven samples failed to yield any DNA sequences despite multiple attempts,” the researchers argue.

Using different techniques, most of these were still linked to animals native to the Himalays. But there remains two “anomalies” where DNA and other techniques failed to provide even a hint.

“With the exception of these two samples, none of the submitted and analysed hairs samples returned a sequence that could not be matched with an extant mammalian species,” the researchers write.

“While it is important to bear in mind that absence of evidence is not evidence of absence and this survey cannot refute the existence of anomalous primates, neither has it found any evidence in support,” they conclude.

Clear sign of conspiracy? That’s up to you.

But the most intriguing aspect of the analysis may be that one of the polar bear samples belonged to a variety known only in Pleistocene fossils, not living examples. That puts it at between two million and 12,000 years old.

Immortal polar zombie/vampire bear, anyone?
related.description: THE evidence is in. The case is closed. As of today, we know what the yeti really is ... Or do we?
keywords: Proceedings of the Royal Society B
related.standFirst: THE first fully scientific study into the existence of the mythical yeti snow man is in, and it’s produced some startling results.
related.subtitle: Guess what they really are ... the first scientific study into evidence of yetis has been published

New York University student Gerry Shalam found that out the hard way after he and his mates were filmed leaving a popular Manhattan eatery after a long brunch.

Their antics got the internet talking.

Not only did Mr Shalam make a fool of himself, but he pretended to be someone he clearly wasn’t — and was caught out big time.

In a YouTube video posted yesterday, the student, who had just eaten at Pranna, is seen outside a dry cleaners on 28th Street with three friends, one of whom is being supported against a wall and appears to be drunk.

But Mr Shalam realises he is being filmed and approaches the cameraman, demanding he put his camera away because his dad is in real estate and owns half the city.

The man filming the footage then asks the pair to move off his property when Gerry launches into this tirade:

“This your property?,” he says as he goes to on to claim his name is Gerry Adjmi.

“My dad is in f***ing’ real estate, you’re gonna tell me this your property? My dad owns half of f***ing Manhattan.”

He also claims he also has both the police and Mayor Bill DeBlasio on his side. Oh and he’s apparently a lawyer too.

“You think a guy who does real estate doesn’t own the cops?”.

But if that isn’t bad enough; surprise, surprise it turns out Gerry Adjmi isn’t who he says he is at all.

Despite deleting all his social media accounts, US website The Smoking Gun  discovered he isn’t actually who he says he is.

As it turns out the drunken student is actually Gerry Shalam, a New Jersey man whose father Lou is a garment industry executive, and his mother Frieda an event co-ordinator and member of the Allenhurst Borough zoning and planning board.

The video, and his apparent claim to fame has attracted a raft of attention on social media with some people calling him a “terrible man child” while others called his behaviour disgusting.

#GerryShalam -BWAAAAAAA!

— Randall Ellis (@rketexas) July 1, 2014 

Gerry Shalam is actually a student of #NYU. No surprise that a self-indulgent capitalist is already attending there http://t.co/f7hV8U0Zse

— Donithan (@trollshevikism) July 1, 2014 

So looks like the drunken NYU students dad who owns half of Manhattan, doesn't actually own half of Manhattan. #gerryshalam

— Tom Strong-Grinsell (@TomSG_) July 1, 2014 

That terrible manchild who drunkenly proclaimed his father owns half of manhattan is from, of course, New Jersey: http://t.co/2KGm1Yk0QJ

— Olivia Nuzzi (@Olivianuzzi) July 1, 2014 

This whole Gerry Shalam thing is disgusting. I hope he gets expelled from NYU

— Storey (@storey_ofmylife) July 1, 2014 

And while Mr Shalam may be regretting his behaviour, at least he’s not quite as bad as the YouTube clip makes him out to be.

The 20-year-old co-founded a charitable organisation called Brothers Helping Others that helps low-income immigrant families in Asbury Park, New Jersey.

He is also not totally incorrect regarding the status of the Adjmi family who are indeed wealthy and also in real estate.

Today’s junk food is far more extreme. And with extreme junk food comes extreme names.

Yesterday, a Sydney cafe was forced to remove its signature dessert from the menu because it was called ‘diabetes’. While some critics thought the name offensive, there was no denying that the glorious stack of jam cronut, peanut butter ice cream, dulce de leche syrup and espresso coffee looked downright delicious.

This got us thinking about other extreme junk food treats around Australia, so we’ve gathered together the top 10.

10. Stoner’s Delight 2.0

What: Doughnut ice cream, peanut butter, raspberry jam, candied bacon, potato chips, mars bar slice, banana fritter

Where: Ms G’s, Potts Point, Sydney 

9. The Elvis Burger

What: Canadian bacon, ground beef patty, mayonnaise and gruyère cheese on a savory cronut with a side of think cut chips and tomato relish

Where: Brewtown Newtown, Sydney

8. Kinder Surprise on steroids

What: Chocolate, honeycomb and vanilla sphere, cardamom, saffron and ginger, passionfruit, mandarin

Where: Gastro Park, Potts Point, Sydney

7. Messina Wiener and Pluto Pup

What: Hot dog made completely from gelato. We’re not kidding. #messinawiener

Where: Gelato Messina

6. Deconstructed Neymar’s Bar

What: Milk chocolate gelato with bites of almond nougat, a chocolate flaked choc top coating and a warm caramel syringe.

Where: N2 Extreme Gelato, Melbourne

And while we’re at N2, check out this wacky creation...

5. Happy ‘lil Socceroos

What: Milk gelato with buttered sao crackers and vegemite. Wait, what?

Where: N2 Extreme Gelato, Melbourne

4. Croquembouche Verrine 

What: Caramel liquid, malted milk Panna cotta, lemon jam, almond Sable, crème patisserie Legere, jersey caramel crème, profiterole filled with crème patisserie

Where: Adriano Zumbo Patisserie 

3. Deep fried Golden Gaytime

What: Exactly what it sounds like. A Golden Gaytime ice cream, dipped in batter and deep fried in oil.

Where: Oxford Tavern, Petersham, Sydney 

2. ‘Piggy Face’ buns

What: Steamed sesame ‘piggy face' buns — a sweet Chinese dessert

Where: Chef’s Gallery 

1. Shake ‘n’ Fry

What: A fresh cinnamon doughnut filled with raspberry jam, topped with vanilla custard soft serve and served with a salted caramel popcorn milkshake.

Where: Gelato Messina, Darlinghurst, Sydney

Have we missed your favourite extreme fast food? Tell us in the comments below or join the conversation on Twitter @newscomauHQ | @gracekoelma

related.body:
Radical group ISIS (Islamic State of Iraq and Syria) last week seized control of every major border crossing between the two countries, as well as a number of towns and military bases in Iraq’s western province.

Just yesterday, ISIS announced the establishment of a “caliphate”, which is a system that sees a ‘caliph’ — ISIS leader Baghdadi — given absolute power and total ruling authority over Muslims.

The group’s spokesman Abu Mohammad al-Adnani described the caliphate as “the dream in all Muslims’ hearts” and “the hope of all jihadists” - but that means little to the thousands of people living in temporary displacement camps across the country because they were born into a different religion or ethnic group.

AP reported that the militant group’s surge of power and control across Iraq “has thrown the country into its deepest crisis since US troops withdrew in December 2011, and threatens to carve the nation in three along sectarian and ethnic lines.”

MORE: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi and ISIS explained

It is all too easy, from our safe houses here in Australia, to disassociate ourselves from a war happening halfway across the globe. We can get lost in the extremist claims populating mainstream and social media, and put the conflict down to something between men with covered faces, sporting guns.

But the reality of the situation is that terrified men, women and children have fled their homes across Iraq and Syria, streaming into temporary displacement camps rather than staying to submit to militant control.

The UN Refugee agency estimates that there are 1 million internally displaced people and 110,000 stateless people in Iraq alone, and the Red Crescent Society pegs over 80 per cent of them as women and young children.

The amazing pictures you will see below, captured by news photographers in the region, tell a story we will never be able to. Children in temporary displacement camps, children caught by roadside bombs, children scrambling to get food as they enter into the Ramadan period.

These are the faces of war.
related.description: THE current situation in Iraq and Syria is undeniably volatile, complicated and dangerous.
related.standFirst: THE terror group proudly publicises its brutal executions and atrocities. But there’s something about these images ISIS wishes we hadn’t seen.
related.subtitle: Faces of war: The reality facing children in Iraq and Syria

related.body:
“I almost didn’t get on the plane because of the fear, because of what we see in movies and in books,” Dr Fischer told News Corp Australia.

At least 759 confirmed or suspected cases of Ebola have been reported across Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone since March this year.

The death toll from the body-destroying virus now sits at 467, making this outbreak the deadliest on record according to the World Health Organisation.

Dr Fischer, a pulmonary diseases and critical care specialist from the University of North Carolina, has just returned from treating Ebola patients in Gueckedou, Guinea, near the border of Sierra Leone and Liberia.

WE NEED TO UNDERSTAND THIS DISEASE 

Although he describes the country as “incredibly beautiful”, he says the reality of the epidemic was incredibly confronting.

A lack of basic understanding, that sees families even eating with victims’ bodies in the same room during funeral ceremonies, combines with a dirth of resources to spread the germs.

“It’s an isolating despair that’s really difficult to swallow,” he says of watching people die from the blood-borne disease.

“In the US when people die they die with someone by their bedside.

“With Ebola you cannot see anyone, most of these people die in an isolation ward.”

Guinea has been hardest-hit by the outbreak, and according to the latest figures, some 413 cases and 303 deaths from haemorrhagic fever in the country are now believed to be due to Ebola.

Dr Fischer spent three weeks in Guinea working with doctors from Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) — a team he says he cannot praise highly enough — to treat Ebola patients.

He said his time in Guinea threw up numerous challenges, including the lack of hi-tech patient monitoring equipment and the lack of laboratory testing.

LOSING LITRES OF SWEAT

By far the biggest was wearing full rubber protection suits in 30C heat, with 90 per cent humidity.

Dressed in a pair of scrubs, gloves and rubber boots covered by a full tyvec suit and full-length apron, plus face mask, goggles and hood, Dr Fischer would spend up to two hours at a time treating patients in isolation.

“You would lose litres of sweat every time you went into the isolation ward. That was a huge challenge,” he said.

Initially the medic was on assignment with the World Health Organisation in Geneva — but when chiefs saw he spoke French and was a critical care doctor they sent him to Guinea.

“There’s a tremendous lack of understanding of this virus, not just in Guinea but around the world,” Dr Fischer says.

“That’s part of the reason the epidemic is ongoing. There a lack of understanding about how it is transmitted.”

Ebola virus is spread through the population through human-to-human contact with infected blood, bodily secretions, organs or other bodily fluids.

FAMILIES EAT WITH BODIES IN ROOM

Dr Fischer said funeral burial rites, where families wash the bodies of the dead and often eat with them in the same room, played a huge part in transmission of the virus.

He said often doctors and midwives treating patients at local clinics are carrying the virus and a lack of simple hygiene equipment, such as gloves and masks, aid the transmission.

The mortality rate among carriers is about 90 per cent.

“(People) have a fear of bringing their loved ones to seek treatment at the facilities because a high number of people don’t come back alive,” he said.

“They are trying to take care of them at home which means there is ongoing transmission of the virus and decreased chances of survival.

“I can understand the reticence to bring them in to a place were they’re more likely to die.”

In a series of poignant and oftentimes confronting emails home to North Carolina, where he lives with his wife and two sons, Dr Fischer described the daily challenges and the small rays of hope he experienced in Gueckedou.

“Today was a pretty tough day — one of the first two patients I admitted on May 30 died,” he wrote in one dispatch.

‘AS I FINISHED HE DIED’

“I walked into his room and he was on the floor half naked surrounded by bloody emesis and diarrhea. I put him back in bed, bathed him, and put fresh clothes on him and as I finished he died.”

“It’s pretty emotional to bathe a 27-year-old man who was incredibly strong and rendered completely helpless. His sister is next door and will likely die in the next hour.

“This is all in front of the other patients in the room, many of whom are family members or neighbours. The despair is suffocating. My computer is running out of batteries. Sorry, more to come.”

He also described the “miserable” case of an 18-year-old woman who was five months pregnant and had both Ebola and malaria. He helped deliver her stillborn baby after she began having contractions.

He said trying to save her from the disease was like “trying to put out a fire with squirt gun.”

“Part of writing the emails allowed my to share thing with my family that I probably wouldn’t have shared with them once I got home,” he told News Corp.

“It’s brutal. It’s tough.”

But amid the misery Dr Fischer said there was hope to contain the epidemic, despite the locations of the outbreak.

“One of the reasons is the location. Gueckedou is right on the border of Sierra Leone and Guinea. It’s tough to pick a worse place, virus and illness crosses borders easily,” he said.

“The resources and collaboration don’t follow as easily.”

He said MSF and the WHO were working together with officials from all three countries to improve treatment and prevention.

“It is absolutely controllable — it is not difficult to break the chain of transmission if you have the right resources and people are buying in and participating.”
related.description: WHAT began as a trip to Geneva to analyse technical documents landed US doctor William Fischer in a cement building in the middle of west Africa — where he witnessed the brutal reality of a rampant Ebola epidemic.
related.standFirst: IT is rampaging across borders in the deadliest outbreak on record. The reality for those infected his horrific. One man is trying to stop it.
related.subtitle: It is an isolating despair: Dr William Fischer speaks of horror in Guinea as Ebola outbreak spreads

related.body:
John Bieniewicz, 44, of Westland, Michigan, was unconscious and lying on the ground when police arrived, after he was allegedly punched in the head by a player who he’d just issued with a red card. He never regained consciousness.

US agencies are reporting that Bassel Abdul-Amir Saad, 36, of Dearborn, Mich, was charged with assault with intent to do great bodily harm.

Scott Herkes, a 39-year-old player in the match, said he was about 25 metres away from the action when he saw Bieniewicz punched by a player on the opposing team. He said the referee was looking down at the time and didn’t see the punch coming.

“It was terrifying,” Mr Herkes told US media. “I have never in my life seen something like this”.

Mr Herkes went on to say that Saad had been complaining about a call made by the referee prior to his alleged assault. There were reportedly around 30 players at the game and a handful of spectators, many of whom also witnessed the event.

Mr Bieniewicz worked as a medical assistant at a children’s hospital in Ann Arbor, Michigan, a small city near Detroit.

“I speak for all his friends when I say we are devastated. Crushed. Just a senseless way for a great guy to go out,” James Acho, Bieniewicz’s friend of 30 years, told the Detroit Free Press . “He deserved better.”

“He just absolutely lived it and loved [soccer],” Mr Acho added.

Mr Acho said Bieniewicz is being kept on a ventilator until his organs can be harvested and donated through an organisation called Gift of Life. He will leave behind a wife and two young sons.

Mr Saad is alleged to have fled the field after the incident and driven away. His attorney, Brian Berry, said his client cooperated with the police investigation and voluntarily turned himself in.

“Mr. Saad is presumed innocent unless and until a fact finder determines differently,” his legal team said in an email to the Detroit Free Press. “As tragic as this event is, we must keep open minds and listen and wait for all the facts of this case to unfold.”

related.body:
The 41-year-old actress sizzles on the cover of Esquire’s August 2014 issue in a high-cut swimsuit, and opened up to the magazine about getting naked on camera.

“It’s a first for me. But Jason [Segel] gets naked, too. It’s just a part of the role. So I did it. I mean you see everything,” she told the mag.

For a movie called Sex Tape, we’d be surprised if there wasn’t nudity, but her co-star is an old pro when it comes to baring it all on camera. Segel famously did a full-frontal scene for 2007’s Forgetting Sarah Marshall, a scene which made his mother cry and send out the following email: “I would like to inform you all that Jason has chosen to do full-frontal nudity, however, it is not gratuitous and is essential to the plot.”

But getting naked wasn’t all Diaz had to do for Sex Tape — there’s also a childbirth scene that sounds like it was a pretty intense experience to film.

“I found myself in a room in the middle of nowhere Massachusetts at 11:00 at night doing a childbirth scene, and everybody’s screaming at one another — Jason, the cameramen, the director,” she told Esquire.

“And me acting like I’m trying to push a basketball out of my vajoon. Crazy sh*t, right? And the thing is, I always take a moment to say, ‘We’re lucky. This is a great job. A fun job’.”

Sex Tape hits Australian cinemas on July 31, 2014.

This article originally appeared in The Huffington Post.

Edelsten has taken to social media the past week posting shots with a man who goes by the name of Red Ra on Facebook and Instagram.

He is as different as you can imagine to her ex-husband, Dr Geoffrey Edelsten.

On his social media profile it’s obvious that the musclebound Red is a competitive bodybuilder.

The pair have been on trips to the Great Ocean Rd and Tasmania together with Brynne’s beloved fur child, pooch Juddy.

Confidential approached Edelsten’s manager for more details about who exactly the man that goes by the name Red is, but didn’t hear back.

Edelsten perhaps hinted on Instagram last week that she had found new love, posting a cryptic picture.

“Sometimes you meet someone, and it’s so clear that the two of you, on some level, belong together,” the picture read.

It is no wonder Brynne was keen to find love again.

THE WEIRD ROMANCE OF BRYNNE AND GEOFFREY EDELSTEN 

MEET GABI GRECKO 

Her 71-year-old ex Geoffrey Edelsten certainly wasted no time in getting back in the saddle after he and Brynne officially called it quits earlier this year.

He has since hooked up with 25-year-old aspiring model and DJ Gabi Grecko.

Since arriving in Melbourne, the US-born glamour girl has wasted no time in letting her feelings be known about everything from Brynne, mental illness, and ‘corset training’.
related.byline: Luke Dennehy and Alice Coster Confidential

related.body:
His opening serve in this fourth round clash at the All England Club rocketed straight down the middle, at 204km/h. He might well have been saying “g’day Rafa’’.

After three hours on the court and more than 37 aces later, having firmly established himself as The Next Big Thing with a shock defeat of the world number one he was saying “Cheerio Rafa’’ with a “juicy wiggle’’ dance celebration.

The scoreline was an incredible 7-6, 5-7, 7-6, 6-3 for Kyrgios to set up a quarter-final clash against Canadian Milos Raonic.

FIRSTS: Nick v Nadal by numbers

FAMILY: How mum’s negativity fired up Nick

PRIDE: Kyrgios kicks off Twitter storm with humble post

So emphatic was the performance, tennis legend John McEnroe remarked: “He’s acting to me like he can win the whole tournament. The last guy that I saw like that was Boris Becker.”

Kyrgios turned to his dad George wearing his akubra hat smiling broadly and his sister Halimah in tears in the players’ box and pumped his fist and danced on court to celebrate amid wild roars from the crowd.

“I think I was in a bit of a zone, I didn’t notice the crowd, it hasn’t sunk in,’’ he said, noting modestly, “I played some extraordinary tennis, I was struggling a bit on return, but I got a break in fourth.’’

Kyrgios stated the obvious remarking: “I served at a really good level all the way through the match.’’

Kyrgios said he had seen an interview given by his mum Norlaila back in Canberra where she had remarked Nadal would be too good for her boy.

“That made me angry, so I don’t know what she is thinking’’, he said smiling. Later when asked what he would say to his mum, he said he would send her a smiley text.

For the first time since 1982 someone from outside the world 100 had beaten a world number one.

Kyrgios started the big game with a ferocity that belied his 19 years, his wildcard status and his inexperience in the senior game. The crowd that filled centre court was initially unsure about this gangly Aussie upstart. How would he handle this pressure cooker atmosphere? As it turned out, the tougher and more critical the point, the more Kyrgios pulled out a blistering serve, a crosscourt backhand winner, or a line-hugging return. Midway during the second set Kyrgios pulled off an instinctive between the legs shot, that ended up being a winner.

Kyrgios said: “I think on the big stage, it’s something I thrive on, the atmosphere, the crowd. I just love it when at 5-3, I think it was in the fourth set, they erupted, the crowd. I just love that feeling. At that stage you just think about all the work you put in. You know if you believe in yourself. Especially with my serve, if I just go after it, hit the right spots, I’m going to have a pretty good shot to close out a match like that today.’’

From the start he had shocked Nadal and won over the polite crowd. “Aussie’’ yelled one British clipped accent in simple acknowledgment he was witnessing the rapid emergence of a genuine world class contender.

With his lackadaisical and relaxed manner — clearly undaunted by reputation of the man on the other side of the net — Kyrgios had quickly notched two game points and three set points in the first set. The speed of his play unsettled Nadal who likes his precise routine between points. But the sheer power generated by the 19-year-old saw him bring up an astounding victory.

“Nadal’s wishing Gasquet had put him away a couple of rounds ago, right now,’’ said McEnroe mid-match.

Nadal said he had created opportunities but wasn’t able to counter Kyrgios’ big serve. And as he started, Kyrgios closed the epic encounter with another ace.

“Congratulations to him. For me, the beach,’’ said Nadal.

Kyrgios will now look to the quarter-finals for his match up against the huge serving Canadian Milos Raonic.

“Have to do it all again tomorrow and I can’t wait! First @Wimbledon & I’m in the last 8 club!!’’, he tweeted later.

Having played Raonic at Roland Garros last month, Kyrgios, still buzzing from his sensational victory over the world number one Rafael Nadal, was asked about what he could expect when they play in the early hours of tomorrow morning.

“There’s going to be a lot of walking from side to side from his serve, and there’s going to be a lot of winners in the match," he said smiling.

Raonic is credited with the biggest serve in the game. At just 23 he is the youngest in the world top ten. But with Kyrgios also regularly firing down serves in excess of 130mph the match will be a peppered-fest of powered aces.

"It’s going to be hard to find rhythm," said Kyrgios. I’m just going to go out there and just go my return of serve. Holding serve is going to be important, being able to make inroads on the other person’s serves."

He admits to being scared of the more illustrious names he is now encountering. Raonic beat him in the first round of the French Open in straight sets.

"Definitely I’m scared, but I just go through my routine and I just play aggressive," he said of his strategy.

"You know, if they play too good on that point, then it’s too good.

"But I’m going to go after it and give myself the best chance to win the point."

Raonic, who like Kyrgios has been notching up in excess of 30 aces a match said his serve gives him a bit of freedom on the return.

The winner of the match will probably face the in-form Swiss legend Roger Federer in the semifinals.
related.description: AND it started with an ace. On Wimbledon centre court playing one of his heroes and the world number one Rafael Nadal, Nick Kyrgios arrived with his signature monster statement.

related.subtitle: Nick Kyrgios stuns Wimbledon with win over Rafael Nadal
