related.body:
The Education Minister predicts parents will start a “revolution’’, demanding that children who are struggling with reading and writing be taught remedially through Direct Instruction or Explicit Instruction.

Mr Pyne’s comments came after the federal government kicked in $22 million for a rollout of the programs to remote-area schools in Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern ­Territory.

Funding the intensive teaching approach is part of Mr Pyne’s back-to-basics drive to shake up teaching methods and standards, as the government reviews the national curriculum.

DI, the focus of the Cape York pilot scheme, makes children sound out words in old-school style, led by a teacher who stands at the front of the classroom and works from a tightly scripted lesson plan.

Mr Pyne acknowledged there was likely to be resistance to the teaching method, “which has never been a favourite son or daughter of education departments’’ at the state level.

However, Mr Pyne said there was no indication of any such ­opposition at this point.

“I think a phonics-based, rob­ust curriculum in primary years should be the norm across all schools in Australia ... starting with those where we know that disadvantaged students — whether they are indigenous or non-indigenous — are struggling,’’ he told The Australian.

“The $22m, which I regard as a modest amount of money, is a start for Direct Instruction, but I think when parents discover the transformative impact ... on their struggling child’s learning ability there will be a revolution demanding that it be introduced beyond remote schools.’’

DI was championed on Cape York by indigenous leader Noel Pearson, who secured joint funding from the Queensland and federal government to pilot the Direct Instruction and Explicit Instruction methods in the townships of Aurukun, Coen, Hope Vale and at an indigenous college near Cairns.

Welcoming the funding of his organisation, Good to Great Schools Australia, to carry out the remote-area rollout in conjunction with the states, Mr Pearson said it would deliver effective instruction to every child. The not-for-profit entity would consult the states about their involvement in the rollout, Mr Pyne’s office said.

“There are no silver bullets for school reform, however international evidence shows there is a single keystone: effective instruction,’’ Mr Pearson said.

“The Australian education system routinely fails children from low socio-economic backgrounds, indigenous children and those in remote communities. As a developed country, we should not willingly accept that a child’s background determines their education success.’’

Cheryl Canon, the principal who introduced DI to the primary school in Mr Pearson’s home town of Hope Vale, said the approach had made a big difference. “It gets the kids to take responsibility for learning, to pay attention in class, get the lessons done, do the tests and pass them,’’ Ms Canon said. “They really participate.’’

Australian Institute for Teaching and School Learning chairman John Hattie said NAPLAN test results showed the 700 students involved in the Cape York trial had made one and a half times the literacy and numeracy gains of those in similar schools.

Critics insist that Direction Instruction and Explicit Instruction, a slightly more interactive form of teaching, straitjacket teachers and stifle innovation in the classroom.

Mr Pyne said an important element of DI was that children remained in their “ability level’’ until they mastered the course work, rather than being grouped by age and promoted each year to a higher grade. On Cape York, this meant that 12-year-olds who would normally be in year-7 classes were taught at year-3 level.

“With Direct Instruction, they catch up quickly and they will end up back at the age level appropriate to the year,’’ he said.

Asked whether the program would work in cities, Mr Pyne said: “Where there are areas of disadvantage that can be clearly identified and where Direct Instruction and Explicit Instruction would make the difference between a child succeeding or failing, then I have no qualms about them being introduced beyond remote schools.”

Mr Pyne said the government wouldn’t allow young people to leave school without being able to read and write. At present 20 per cent of year 3 students in remote schools failed to meet the national minimum standing in literacy skills, against just 4 per cent in metropolitan areas.

Townsville-based federal Liberal National Party MP Ewen Jones said Direct and Explicit Instruction had the potential to help any child with learning difficulties. “You don’t have to go to ... remote Queensland to find the problem,” Mr Jones said. “It’s happening right here in Townsville.’’
related.description: A CONTROVERSIAL literacy program trialled in Aboriginal communities on Cape York Peninsula is set to be adopted nationally as Christopher Pyne moves to have phonics-based teaching reintroduced to classrooms.
related.standFirst: A CONTROVERSIAL literacy program trialled in Aboriginal communities on Cape York Peninsula is set to be adopted nationally.

A CONTROVERSIAL literacy program trialled in Aboriginal communities on Cape York Peninsula is set to be adopted nationally as Christopher Pyne moves to have phonics-based teaching reintroduced to classrooms. 

The Education Minister predicts parents will start a “revolution’’, demanding that children who are struggling with reading and writing be taught remedially through Direct Instruction or Explicit Instruction.

related.body:
The Queensland Government yesterday announced that the $8.3 billion rebuild of Queensland from the horrific run of natural disasters in 2011/12 is complete.

That included $1.25 billion alone to repair damage done in North Queensland by category five Cyclone Yasi, which crossed the coast near Mission Beach in February 2011.

But if another super storm of the same ferocity rips through the region in the next few years, it could all be in vain.

Local Government, Community Recovery and Resilience Minister David Crisafulli yesterday admitted that “not enough” had been done in the rebuild to provide resistance against future acts of god.

Mr Crisafulli said another Category 5 juggernaut could rip apart all the work done in North Queensland.

“Indeed, that’s why we’ve got to rebuild better,” he said.

“You will never protect communities entirely, that’s for sure, but we can do a lot better than what we have, without question.”

A total of $1 billion was spent to repair North Queensland and another $0.8 billion for the Far North, with $1.25 billion of that specifically to repair damage from Yasi.

Mr Crisafulli wants the Queensland Betterment Fund, established after Cyclone Oswald last year, to be used in the future after cyclones to help prevent further devastation.

“My great thirst is to see the Betterment Fund … become business as usual,” he said.

“Yes, we spend a bit more up front, but long-term it saves you money and it saves you heartache. We haven’t done enough of it and we have got to continue to ramp up efforts.”

Cassowary Coast Mayor Bill Shannon backed Mr Crisafulli’s call for smarter repair work in the future.

“You don’t want to put a bridge in the same place, even if it is at the current (cyclone) standards, because it will get washed out again,” he said.

“You build it on another corner or you build it higher.”
related.description: IT is the $1.25 billion bandaid.
related.standFirst: Mr Crisafulli said another Category 5 juggernaut could rip apart all the work done in North Queensland.

related.body:
Armed police wearing bulletproof vests lined Dearness St and warned residents to remain indoors as they attempted to negotiate with the man.

Almost three tense hours ensued after emergency services swarmed the unit block and surrounds after police received a distressed call from a man about midday.

The man, 40, had also made distressed calls to family members, prompting concerns for his welfare.

Townsville Police Inspector Ian Haughton said police responded quickly, closing nearby streets to ensure public safety was maintained.

He said members of the man’s family had attended the unit after receiving­
the man’s distressed call, but were “not in any danger”.

Police negotiators were called to speak with the man, who finally surrendered peacefully. A firearm at the unit was not believed to have been loaded.

No one was injured and suburban streets surrounding the unit complex reopened about 2.30pm.

Insp Haughton said he was not aware of any threats made to paramedics.

“The person surrendered themselves to police and no one was injured. The person is receiving help for a possible mental illness,” Insp Haughton said.

“The message here is that there are probably one in five people in the community who, at some stage in life, are exposed to a mental episode.

“This, in this case, could be a rare occasion. The party involved will receive some help and treatment. It is not something that is rare in society.”

Insp Haughton said the Garbutt man was receiving help from mental health authorities.

No charges had been laid by police late yesterday, with investigations continuing.

Anyone seeking support or information about mental illness can contact Lifeline on 13 11 14
related.description: SUBURBAN streets were locked down and residents forced to stay indoors after an armed man barricaded himself inside a Garbutt unit yesterday.

related.body:
A spate of sightings of species almost never found in the city have been keeping snake catchers on their toes.

Three rare coastal taipans have been caught in recent days, including one at James Cook University and another on Riverway Drive.

Snake catchers have removed three other exotic snakes from the city, including a dwarf crowned snake, a species believed to have died out in Townsville.

Biologist Dr Greg Calvert said one reason for the increased sightings could be males on the hunt for a mate.

Warm winter days and rain could also be factors.

The coastal taipan is as deadly as the eastern brown, but is usually found in granite ranges such as Mt Stuart.

Two removed from neighbourhoods in recent days measured 2.15m and 1.9m. A third was sighted but could not be found for removal.

“I’ve seen more taipans in the last week than I have in the last three years,” Dr Calvert said. 

“It’s all happening and we’re pretty excited about it.”

Veteran snake catcher Brian West said he believed warmer winter days were behind the influx of snakes.

“This is my 15th year as a snake catcher and I’ve caught about 3000 snakes,” Mr West said. “Those (the taipans) were number 10 and 11. So removing two of them within three days is very unusual.”

Snake catcher Trish Prendergast said more snake catchers would help ease the workload, urging anyone interested to enrol in a course through info@snakehandler.com.au.
related.description: EXOTIC venomous snake species are slithering into Townsville neighbourhoods looking for a mate.

related.body:
All 135 cars in the Townsville fleet were in violation of new legislation rolled-out across yesterday Queensland for failing to have the automated meters running on time.

Queensland cab drivers were required by state law to have the meters installed and running by yesterday to apply correct tariffs and prevent confusion and overcharging.

Townsville Taxis IT manager Steve McBride said that CabCharge needed to download software to install the new meter functions yesterday.

But the Telstra glitch caused widespread havoc with EFTPOS and CabCharge services unavailable for large chunks of the day and the failure for new meter functions to be installed on time.

Telstra admitted it was at fault for the software malfunction.

“An overnight network upgrade caused an issue with the platform that supports the CabCharge service. This issue was resolved (yesterday) morning by 8.30am,” spokesman Steven Carey said.

“We understand that there may have been some short-term congestion issues after this time as a result of the taxis terminals reconnecting to the system.”

Mr McBride said he understood the problem was statewide, not just isolated to Townsville.

He said he hoped the Department of Transport and Main Roads (TMR) would be sympathetic to the reason why the cabs were unable to have the meters updated in time.

“It’s not the drivers’ fault,” he said.

But the Department of Transport and Main Roads said taxi companies had been given almost 12 months to install the software.

“These changes were announced in July last year, giving operators sufficient time to have the software installed and ready to go by July 1,” a statement read. “This time frame was determined through a consultative approach with the taxi industry, including meter suppliers.

“TMR is currently working with taxi drivers and operators to ensure they are following the new laws and are aware of the penalties that apply for noncompliance.”

The problem was resolved by mid-afternoon yesterday.

Mr McBride said the software was updated before 7pm, which is when the automated meter would have made its first changeover.
related.description: TOWNSVILLE Taxis could face penalties for failing to have new ­automated meters operating before the state deadline yesterday despite Telstra admitting a glitch in its system had caused the delays.
keywords: Department of Transport and Main Roads

related.body:
The homegrown talent will race in the V8 Ute category at the Townsville event, where he has competed in 2010, 2011 and 2013.

Edwards had a taste for life on tour in 2011 when he competed at the Clipsal 500, Sandown 500 and Gold Coast 600 – and now he wants more.

Two potential backers will be watching Edwards carry local expectations on his back this weekend, and if he puts in a strong performance the funding could come to make him a full-time V8 Ute driver.

“I want to give them a really good weekend,” Edwards said.

“I am looking at trying to take the next step ... finish the season that I am in now.

“I really want to take on Bathurst, which is an ultimate dream of mine.”

It is a major opportunity for Edwards, but the challenge laid before him in massive.

The 24-year-old – who goes by the moniker Local Lad – has not raced a V8 Ute in 12 months since he came 16th overall in last year’s Townsville 400.

Since then he has been forced to hone his skills on his home simulator and on go-karts with mates, tearing around his homemade track.

“I’ve had 12 months out of the car, but nothing has changed,” he said. “It still has three pedals, four wheels and a steering wheel.

“If I have a fantastic weekend I think I am going to be able to seal a bit of a deal.”

And he said those home races were anything but amateur, with his mates from speedway giving him a stern testing out in the go-karts.

“It’s about keeping your mind sharp,” he said. “They never do (make it easy), we’re always having to fix the karts.”

Edwards is hoping to get some last-minute backers for the Townsville 500.

He will at Townsville Kart Club from noon today, racing against fellow V8 drivers.
related.description: THIS weekend will be make or break for Townsville’s own Graham Edwards who hopes to take on the V8 Supercars tour for the rest of the year.

related.body:
Dr Charles Webb, an Adjunct Professor at Charles Sturt University and the chairman of the UN’s International Union for Conservation of Nature’s Specialist Crocodile Group, said that without a realistic management program, crocodile numbers would increase and the animals would start eating people.

Prof Webb, a co-owner of tourist farm Crocodylus Park in Darwin, said Queensland took a “highly conservationist” stance on crocodiles instead of being pragmatic and accepting that the animals were a serious threat to human life and could be sustainably managed.

“This might have something to do with Steve Irwin, who was too protectionist,” Prof Webb said.

“Steve didn’t like what was happening in the Northern Territory (with egg harvesting) and I don’t think he even knew that in Louisiana they harvest 40,000 alligators a year while still maintaining a healthy population of alligators.”

Prof Webb said NT had a healthy croc population despite “hundreds of thousands” of eggs having been harvested from nests in the wild.

“One way to commit suicide in the Territory is to jump off the Adelaide River bridge and start swimming,” he said.

“There is a 100 per cent chance you will be eaten by a crocodile. There are still a lot of crocodiles here.”

He said the catch-22 with the Queensland Government’s approach was that one day numbers would reach critical mass and people would be at risk.

“The thing with crocodiles is that no one wants them to be extinct, but no one wants to be eaten either,” Prof Webb said.

“As their numbers build up, they start eating people.”

Prof Webb said the Northern Territory model was working. He said the crocodile population had grown and stabilised and that industries such as tourism and egg harvesting had built up around it.

“ All of the crocodile farms in Queensland buy eggs from the Territory,” he said.

Prof Webb said there were “good people” working in Queensland’s Department of Environment but said the wrong decisions were being made.

“Queensland … needs to have a cold, hard look at what it is doing otherwise people will start taking care of them in other ways,” he said.

He said Queensland and harvesting eggs came up at a recent crocodile management conference in Louisiana.

“People there couldn’t believe Queensland was still making up its mind,” he said.

A spokesman for Queensland Environment Minister Andrew Powell said that under the state’s Crocodile Management Program there were no plans that included the harvesting of eggs in the wild.
related.description: ONE way to stop Queensland’s rising crocodile population from becoming a serious threat to human life is to start management programs such as egg harvesting in the wild.
related.standFirst: ONE way to stop Queensland’s rising crocodile population from becoming a serious threat to human life is to start management programs such as egg harvesting in the wild.

related.body:
The 6m vessel ran into trouble on Sunday morning, about 40 nautical miles northeast of the city, with water police receiving a distress call about 8.30am.

The vessel was disabled, adrift and taking on water when the search and rescue effort started.

A QantasLink flight from Moranbah to Townsville was diverted to help with the search and rescue effort.

Captain Andrew Shearer said he didn’t expect to be called on to help but he was glad to play a part in finding the stricken vessel.

“It was a great feeling knowing we played an important role in the search and rescue mission,” he said.

“When we spotted the small white boat it was in rough waters so if we took our eyes off it, we could have easily lost it.

“We kept orbiting the boat until the coast guard chopper came. The passengers on board were great and helped us spot the boat.”

Water Police officer-in-charge Sergeant Matthew Pegg said three adults and two children were rescued.

“They were bailing out the boat to try and keep it afloat,” he said.

“An EPIRB (Emergency Position-Indicating Radio Beacon) was set off and we then tasked out the rescue.

“The EMQ rescue chopper winched one of their crew down to check on them and then they waited for the coast guard to arrive.

“The people were transferred to the coast guard (boat) and the vessel was towed back into Townsville and they arrived about 4.30pm.”

Townsville Coast Guard administration officer John Andersen said the rescue was done in trying conditions.

“It was rough water out there and it was blowing about 25 knots,” he said. “The waves were about 2m to 3m high.

“It sounds as though it was an extremely difficult tow (back to Townsville). They had to change directions quite a bit.”

No one was injured.

Sgt Pegg said all boaties should check the conditions before heading out on the water.

“Every time there has been a southwesterly change come through there has been a search and rescue effort,” he said.
related.description: FIVE people were rescued after a QantasLink flight was diverted to aid in the search and rescue operation when a power boat was damaged and started taking in water off Townsville.
related.standFirst: FIVE people were rescued from the Coral Sea after their power boat suffered damage and started taking in water.

related.body:
And yesterday morning at 9am Cofco, owner of the Tully Mill, announced it was following suit. This is upheaval in the sugar industry, the likes of which has never been seen before. Deregulation was a mere hiccup compared to this.

MSF owns 500,000 tonnes of sugar which it is taking out of QSL’s marketing pot of gold. Tully Sugar has another 300,000 tonnes. Singaporean company Wilmar, which runs eight mills between Sarina and Ingham, announced back in April that it would be taking its two million-plus tonnes away from QSL in 2017 and would be marketing it on its own. Effectively QSL has lost more than three million tonnes of sugar to sell on the world market.

You could fit the sugar it will be left to market post-2017 inside a biscuit tin. Canegrowers Burdekin chairman Phil Marano told Talk of the North yesterday that growers would lose transparency and choice if Wilmar markets all of the Burdekin’s sugar. Marano said growers weren’t saying that it had to be QSL which marketed their sugar, but added that whoever did market it had to provide “choice” in the selling options and “transparency”.

He conceded Wilmar might “do a good job” but said all transparency would be lost. He said sugarcane growers would become “peasant farmers” and the Government should intervene.

A matter of choice

TULLY Sugar chairman Dick Camilleri is a farmer and, as his title indicates, a miller. Tully Sugar is owned by Asian company Cofco. He said growers have always had a choice of how they wanted to market with QSL and that this would continue with Cofco’s model.

To market, to market

DICK Camilleri made an interesting point about a lot of the farmer opposition to millers making the call to market the sugar they legally process and own. How it works is that the farmer grows the cane, but once it is harvested and then taken to the train siding to be hauled to the mill it becomes the property of the mill owner.

The tramlines and locos all belong to the mills. Dick’s theory about a lot of the opposition to what is happening is that it is coming from farmers who have never marketed their own sugar. They might be terrific farmers, but they have never taken any interest in the marketing of their own cane. It has always been handled by QSL. He says they can still do it this way after 2017 if that is what they want, or they can take more control of how their cane is marketed. He says the choice is theirs.

Where to from here

WHAT remains to be seen after 2017 is whether Wilmar, MSF and Cofco will form their own international sugar trading company. Or will each of them go it alone? There are other smaller independent millers in Queensland. All of them had until yesterday to decide if they would be pulling out of QSL in 2017.

In the meantime the Canegrowers organisation wants the Government to intervene. This isn’t something the Government is going to be keen to meddle in given that it invites foreign companies to set up business in Australia. Telling them afterwards that they can’t sell the product they make and own in their own factories will not go down well.

You’d have to think this is a case of stable doors left open and horses already bolted.

Write on, Megan

RICHMOND woman Megan Stafford, a journalism student at James Cook University has co-won a Journalism Student Walkley Award with Deacon University’s Kirrily Schwarz.

Megan won the award for a column she’s been doing in the North Queensland Register focusing on personalities. Judges said she was someone who had a “hunger” for chasing down stories. As part of her prize, Megan gets to spend eight weeks working with the Nine Network in Sydney and four weeks at the Walkley Foundation for Journalism.

Stick a cork in it

YOU can understand sometimes why people in the tourism/customer service industries can become so frustrated with their customers.

I was having dinner in a pub in Winton on Sunday night when a European woman ordered a glass of champagne. A glass of champagne in Winton? “Lady”, I felt like saying, “champagne isn’t exactly a big seller in Winton and no way if they have to open a bottle will you just get one glass. It’s the bottle or nothing”. The barman tried to explain he couldn’t just sell one glass, but she wasn’t having a bar of it. She turned on a scene and then continued to harass wait staff about her meal all during dinner. They were a patient lot. Anywhere else and they would have shown her the door.

Rest easy Andy

THE News of the World phone hacking trail in London is taking its toll even in Townsville. After hearing the outcome on his car radio, a bloke walked into his house after a day’s toil and said “I just heard that Rebekah Brooks got off, but Andy Toulson was found guilty.”

“No dear’, said his wife, “Andy Coulson was found guilty. Andy Toulson works here at the ABC.” “Ugh! Oh yeah, that’s right.” Nice to hear though that our own Andy Toulson is in the clear.

Beaut bloke, though

SO we say goodbye to Ron Boswell from the Senate. He was a good fighter for regional Australia. Bos is built like a brick outhouse and has a head that makes a cement mixer look sexy. Suffice to say, he’s no Brad Pitt.

He will always be remembered for his campaign slogan “he’s not pretty, but he’s pretty effective”. He also had a certain charm and innocence when it came to same-sex marriage. On the matter of lesbians being joined together in holy matrimony, the thing Bos was most concerned about was that if the lesbians had sons the boys would have no one to take them to the football. You have to like that one.

Doing it tough

THE Vision Splendid Outback Film Festival is on in Winton.

Out here like much of the inland it’s cold and as dry as the dingo’s proverbial. People like Marty and Sue Mitchell are moving cattle to wherever they can find grass, but the reality is you can drive the 214km from Hughenden to Winton and hardly see a beast. It’s bone dry. It looks like someone has picked the land up, turned it upside down, given it a good shake and emptied everything out.
related.description: MORE  petrol has been thrown on the fire raging in the Queensland sugar industry with the announcement that MSF Sugar with mills in Maryborough, Mulgrave, South Johnstone and Tableland is following the country’s biggest miller Wilmar and saying goodbye to Queensland Sugar in 2017.

related.body:
Morgan, 22, says he will not play in next Wednesday’s final Origin match at Suncorp Stadium, but his selection as Queensland’s 19th man appears to put him in line as a long-serving Maroons’ player.

Morgan got the nod ahead of other fullbacks such as Ben Barba and Anthony Milford, and his utility value — combined with a rugged frame and blistering pace — makes Morgan a prototype Origin player.

The Cowboys fullback joins other Townsville Brothers juniors Sam Thaiday and Aidan Guerra in Queensland camp on Sunday, but Morgan will still play for the Cowboys against the Dragons this Saturday.

“I wouldn’t have even considered it six months ago,” Morgan said of his Origin call-up.

“Coming back from Christmas I only had a few weeks with the group and I didn’t know if I’d get a trial game in, so I expecting to start the year in the Queensland Cup again.

“It is all a bit out of the blue, so it is hard to believe.”

Morgan has been part of Queensland’s emerging squad and won widespread respect this year following his surprise shift to fullback in place of Lachlan Coote (long-term knee injury), who was expected to fill the boots of former Cowboys’ custodian Matt Bowen.

Morgan has produced several big plays in both attack and defence this year, and his ability to deliver in almost all circumstances makes him arguably North Queensland’s most important attacking asset behind club co-captain Johnathan Thurston.

Cooper Cronk’s surprise call-up yesterday put Daly Cherry-Evans on Queensland’s bench, but there could be a possibility that if Cooper were to fail a fitness test Cherry Evans might start at No. 7, and Morgan would gain a promotion to Queensland’s interchange.

But Morgan firmly dismissed the hypothetical scenario.

“I’m not going to be playing Wednesday night, but being around the group and getting to experience what it’s all about is what I’m looking forward to,” he said.

“I think it will be weird when I actually get there.

“It’s a massive honour and I’m looking forward to next week when I get to be around everyone.”

Morgan got news of his call-up on Sunday night from Cowboys general manager of football Peter Parr, but is yet to speak with Maroons’ coach Mal Meninga.

Morgan is one of four players in Queensland’s Game III squad to have played junior football in Townsville, with former Kirwan State High School student Jacob Lillyman starting at prop.

“I don’t know a lot of the players but I’ve met a couple of them,” Morgan said.

“I’m looking forward to it and it should be a good week or so that I’m in there.”

Queensland: Billy Slater, Darius Boyd, Greg Inglis, Justin Hodges, Will Chambers, Johnathan Thurston, Cooper Cronk, Jacob Lillyman, Cameron Smith (capt), Nate Myles, Aidan Guerra, Sam Thaiday, Corey Parker.

Interchange: Daly Cherry-Evans, Ben Te’o, Matt Gillett, Dave Taylor.

Reserves: Josh McGuire, Michael Morgan.
related.description: EVEN Michael Morgan is shocked with his stunning turnaround from fringe first-grader to future State of Origin star.

related.body:
“These days homeowners just want to be able to go to work knowing their home is secure, they want their home to be maintained so they can lock up and leave if they go on holidays and they want to walk their dog or let their kids play in their street knowing that they’re safe,’’ Mr Torrisi said.

“Gated communities offer this level of security and maintenance without having to downsize to a unit plus their body corporate fees are often more reasonable and they still offer a great array of fully serviced facilities.’’

Mr Torrisi has listed a home at 46 Pebble Lane in the gated community of Royal Palms Estate at Kirwan, which backs on to the Willows Golf Course, and he has noticed an influx of buyers interested in living behind lock and key.

“I have had lots of interest in the location from young families, retirees and single parents seeking this easy way of life,’’ he said.

“There are about 100 properties in the estate so it is a large community but very tight with a real village feel.

“The on-site facilities, which include a Community Hall that features a lap pool, large deck, gym and function room complete with a fully equipped kitchen, are a massive drawcard.

“Plus the entire estate is immaculate with groundsmen maintaining all front yards and streetscapes.’’

And the current owners, Melissa and Matthew Burton, agree it’s a dream lifestyle that they’ve enjoyed for three years with 10-month-old daughter Macie in their four-bedroom, two-bathroom home, with double garage, open planned design and garden courtyard.

“My wife and I thought it would be a great place to move into as a young professional couple who don’t want to spend a lot of time doing maintenance work,” said Mr Burton, a sport and recreation co-ordinator for the Townsville City Council.

“I was travelling a fair bit and having a fully-fenced community made us feel safe.’’

“There are also many children who play around the area as Royal Palms Estate is actually very kid-friendly and great for young families because it’s close to schools and shops.”

“And if you love golf it’s a big bonus as you can drive your golf buggy from your house right on to the green.’’

The Pebble Lane property, listed for $379,000, is open for inspection tomorrow from 11.15-11.45am. For more details contact Mr Torrisi on 0407 636 259.

related.body:
Moga, 20, has been named in the centres of a reshuffled Cowboys team that also includes forwards Sam Hoare and Ben Spina on a five-man bench, which will be cut to four later this week.

The two Intrust Super Cup players are yet to play a National Rugby League game, but at least one is guaranteed to make his first-grade debut on Saturday against St George-Illawarra at Kogarah.

There is a possibility Spina and Hoare could both play, but Green is likely to keep Ethan Lowe and John Asiata on his bench.

Michael Morgan has moved to halfback in place of co-captain Johnathan Thurston, who has entered Queensland’s State of Origin camp, while Wright fills Morgan’s role at fullback.

There was hope that Ray Thompson would return from a hamstring injury, which could have kept Morgan at fullback, but Morgan said he was prepared for his return to No. 7.

“I had a little go at it this morning at training … it’s been in the back of my mind that I might have to that, so I’ll just do my best,” he said.

“I just have to get back into kicking and taking more of a role organising with talking without Johnno there, so I’ll see how I go.”

Ashton Sims is set to start at prop in place of James Tamou, who is in camp with New South Wales, while Scott Bolton retains his No. 8 spot from last weekend’s 20-18 win over South Sydney.

Injury has brought North Queensland’s playing stocks to breaking point, and Green is hopeful that Saturday’s clash — and next Wednesday’s Origin finale — does not bring any more injury woes.

“Hopefully the footy gods can be a little bit kinder to us,” he said.

“We get a bye in there (after Origin) which will be good, and we can freshen up and then finish with a run.”

Both Hoare and Spina will be desperate to make Green’s cut after spending the past few seasons playing for the Mackay Cutters and Northern Pride respectively.

Hoare is one of the biggest forwards in North Queensland’s first grade squad, and Spina is the son of inaugural Cowboys captain Laurie Spina.

The Spinas will become the first father-son combination to play first grade for the Cowboys if Ben suits up on Saturday.

“The challenge for us now is to put in another good performance,” Green said.
related.description: COWBOYS coach Paul Green will give at least two players their baptism of fire as Cowboys’ first-graders this weekend including new recruit Tautau Moga.

The owners of the Kwik Kopy business at 5 Fletcher St where they also house a design firm, 121 Creative, are looking for new housemates.

But the owners also still have 75sq m spare that they hope to sublease to a local small business.

“For a CBD-fringe tenancy in excellent condition, I think it’s a no-brainer if you need that sort of space,” Remax Excellence Commercial agent Gary Orford said.

“There’s a very reasonable kick-ass rate actually to attract a tenant: $9000 per annum.”

Kwik Kopy and 121 Creative owner and manager Hannah Leith said the space had until recently been leased by a small mining services firm. “It doesn’t have street frontage but it’s a great little space for somebody who’s looking for a smaller office,” she said.

“We’re here so it’s a well looked-after building with our two buildings already running out of it.

“There’s plenty of people around all the time, it’s very secure with good parking and all those sorts of things.

“There’s separate access for staffrooms.”

related.body:
Victorian couple Adam and Lisa nailed the perfect score for their work on the kitchen and guest room of their Queenslander style home, work that had Maddi reduced to tears.

“This is a dream kitchen, whoever did this, thank you,” she said. “This (guest bedroom is stunning. My mum will actually want to come and stay here, this is beautiful.

“I’m going to be so proud to have people over now.”

Lloyd was left speechless as he ran the rule over the two rooms and he knows guests will feel the same way.

“They’re not going to want to leave, we’re not going to be able to get anyone out of here,” he said.

Judge Wendy Moore has gone so far as to label Adam and Lisa the ‘dark horses’ of the competition after their stunning result put them five points ahead of any of their competitors on the leaderboard. “Lisa and I haven’t had the easiest run in the competition,” Adam says.

“We didn’t start the way that we wanted to. It has been a hard road so getting those tens was unbelievable.”

Adam and Lisa’s rise on House Rules mirrors that of underdogs Steve and Chantelle on The Block: Fans v Faves.

Steve and Chantelle started slowly and ended up winning a whopping $736,000 when they sold their Albert Park apartment for $2.47 million.

All of the couples on House Rules struggled in the Queensland heat as they renovated Maddi and Lloyd’s home.

Adam and Lisa faced the extra challenge of sleeping in the tent after getting low scores last week.

“I was absolutely blown away by your kitchen,” Moore told the couple.

“A beautiful, functional design. And then there’s the guest room – stunning work.

“What a massive turnaround last week.”

Lisa was shocked by the ­result. “Adam and I have been waiting for this feeling for a very long time in this com-­petition, and by gosh, it feels amazing,” she said.

Adam and Lisa had even more reason to smile when Tasmanian rivals Brooke and Grant copped a caning from the judges.

Their hessian ceiling in the master bedroom was said to look like a ‘camp site’.

South Australia’s Bomber and Mel also got hit hard for not sticking to the ‘laid back coastal’ rule for their entry, dining room, laundry and front deck.

Adam and Lisa finished with 30, Candy and Ryan 25, Carole and Russell 23, Brooke and Grant 19 and Bomber and Mel 18.

Brooke and Grant got a dose of karma when Adam and Lisa had to choose which team would be stuck in the tent this week.

The Victorians decided their Tassie rivals could camp out this week as teams renovate Bomber and Mel’s home. That was a decision that clearly pleased some of the other teams as well. “The karma bus has just come and it has parked in Tassie’s front lawn,” Ryan laughed. “All aboard”.

related.body:
Infrastructure Australia predicts northern Australia’s population to jump to 1.77 million people in 2031, up from 1.2 million in 2011, with most of the growth occurring in North Queensland. However, other estimates put Townsville’s population as potentially growing to more than 1 million in the future.

Townsville Enterprise chief executive David Kippin said the city should be ambitious in its planning goals to accommodate strong long-term growth.

“We should start planning for it because it’s really a matter of when, not if,” he said.

“Sydney and Brisbane are doing rearguard actions, in terms of infrastructure, because they never planned for the growth they ended up getting.

“We have a lot of available land (around Townsville) so we should be thinking of the best uses for it into the future and planning accordingly.”

Townsville Mayor Jenny Hill agreed the city could hit 1 million people.

“We are looking in the medium term for about 300,000 people,” she said. “You can plan for that now, but that’s not to say we won’t grow to 1 million people by the end of the century.

“That’s why when we talk about things like pipelines to the Burdekin (dam) and we have to plan for these things now.

“We need to ensure the city can grow in a sustainable way.”

Infrastructure Australia executive director of planning Stephen Alchin was more cautious with his growth forecasts for the region but estimated an almost 50 per cent increase in the next 17 years.

“Most of that growth is going to occur in North Queensland,” he said.

“The population in northern Australia might grow above that by somewhere between 100,000 to maybe a couple of hundred thousand in the period to 2031.

“I stress they’re draft figures but it’s important to give you some sense of the scale of that (predicted) change.

“The infrastructure debate, for us, is one of what’s the infrastructure needed to foster economic development?

“And the other is, what infrastructure is needed to support population growth?

“Maintenance of transport and water is a significant issue … and there are difficulties with cost recovery.”
related.description: TOWNSVILLE’S population could hit 1 million by the end of the century, while even the most conservative estimates are predicting North Queensland to grow by about half in 17 years.
related.standFirst: TOWNSVILLE could have 1 million residents by the end of the century.
related.subtitle: Townsville tipped to hit 1m people

Police confirmed the 53-year-old Ingham man took off from Ingham airport around 3.50pm on Saturday with plans to fly around the nearby island.

But the pilot allegedly then began experiencing engine trouble and told police he made an emergency landing at Little Ramsay Bay, before ­attempting to take off again.

Halifax Senior Constable Gavin Burnett said a bushwalker witnessed the accident and helped the pilot swim about 50m back to shore.

“The witness has seen the plane crash into the water and has gone down to the beach to check on the pilot, then he had to walk to find reception and raise the alarm,” he said.

Sen-Constable Burnett said the pilot boarded a nearby vessel, before another boat transported him back to Dungeness.

Sen-Constable Burnett said he was the aware the pilot had initiated a salvage operation on Sunday and the aircraft was recovered.

Recreational Aviation Australia president Michael Monck confirmed the pilot had to lodge an incident report within 48 hours of the crash.

“We don’t know the full set of circumstances or what led the pilot to take the action he did,” he said.

The addition of the promising 20-year-old (pictured) comes at a great time for the Cowboys as they try to fill the void left by Brent Tate’s potentially career-ending knee injury.

At home on the wing or in the centres, Moga joined his new teammates at Cowboys HQ for the first time yesterday and football manager Peter Parr spoke very highly of the mid-season recruit.

“With Tatey’s injury we are obviously looking to boost our depth in the outside backs. Tautau is an outstanding young man with extraordinary talent who should be a great fit for the Cowboys,” he said.

“Anyone who has seen him play comes away impressed with what he can do on the footy field.”

Moga has signed on until the end of the 2016 NRL season and the former Australian Schoolboys and Queensland Junior Origin rep will look to add to the 14 NRL matches he played for the Tricolours.

Likened to former league superstar Israel Folau, the hulking 198cm Brisbane product made his debut for the Roosters as an 18-year-old in 2012 before injuries and a lack of opportunity led to him negotiating an early release from his contract.

Parr said he was excited at the prospect of him linking with fellow young backs Curtis Rona and Matthew Wright.

“We’re very happy to not only have him join us for the next two seasons, but also the remainder of 2014 so he can get a head start on his career in North Queensland,” Parr said.

related.body:
On Friday night, Education Central, designed by Wilson Architects with Architects North, was again acknowledged at the Australian Institute of Architects National Architecture Awards.

The building won the Walter & Oliver Tunbridge Award for Building of the Year in the Public Architecture category.

Now just over a year-and-a-half old, the multi-million-dollar facility was built on the former site of the gym and squash courts in the middle of the busy Douglas campus.

Judges said they were impressed by how the architects and university teachers had worked together to come up with the design.

“James Cook University’s Education Central is the result of an intense reassessment by the architect and the University as to how contemporary students can learn,” the panel said in their decision.

“The resulting building and spaces are extraordinarily diverse and effective providing an enormously successful learning environment and a major contribution to the University’s urban landscape.”

It comes after the same building last month took out the Australian New Construction Major Facility category of the Council of Educational Facility Planners International in Adelaide after a unanimous decision from judges.

The design was previously named “Building of the Year” at the North Queensland Architectural Awards in March.

It will now compete in the national AIA awards, which will be held in November.

JCU’s College of Arts, Society and Education dean Professor Nola Alloway, said the award was a further reflection of extensive consultation and collaboration to determine how an upgrade could best improve student services and support contemporary methods of teaching and learning.

“The School staff worked with the architect to create innovative spaces with a view to optimising student engagement, motivation and learning outcomes,” he said.

The facility includes large-scale active learning spaces that support technology-enabled active learning (TEAL) areas.
related.description: JAMES Cook University’s state-of-the-art new education and student services building has received yet another award.

Ahead of Monday night’s unveiling of Maddi Carter and Lloyd Wright’s renovated Pallarenda home on House Rules, the 27-year-olds have revealed they initially thought they would be passed over for a metropolitan pair because of their regional roots.

‘‘  We were competing against all these Brisbane couples, so we’re stoked they came to Townsville, because it was a big ask as the logistics would have been so difficult with transporting equipment, flying up crew and sourcing supplies,’’ Maddi said.

However Channel 7 decided it was well worth the trouble of going outside the big smoke for these genetically blessed contestants, with the former swimsuit model and her well-built fiance securing Queensland’s only spot on the second season as the first regional, non-capital city couple to appear on the show and they have proven to be a popular choice.

‘‘ Everyone seems to like Maddi because she’s sweet and gets what she wants without being mean, and Lloyd because he’s got great muscles,’’ executive producer Maxine Gray said.

Maddi, the Cowboys community relations executive from Brisbane, and Lloyd, a Townsville Airport aviation firefighter from Cairns, are not actually born-and-bred locals after relocating here two years ago however their relaxed, laid-back attitudes on our screens have ensured they have been embraced as our own.

‘‘ With our home transformation finally airing we’ve really noticed what a great local following we have – everywhere we go we are holding babies and getting photos,’’ Maddi said.

‘‘ I think we’ve showcased Townsville really well and put it on the map as a beautiful little gem where you can have a tropical lifestyle on a budget and it will be our forever home.’’

This week the other contestants were salivating over Maddi and Lloyd’s four-bedroom, one-bathroom 701sq m 1950s reno just a stone’s throw from the beach, a property they bought in April 2013 for $372,000.

‘‘ Some of them were so in love with the prime location and good house prices in Townsville that they actually looked at property to buy when they were up here,’’ Lloyd said.

However the pair’s bargain buy has not been without its share of problems on the show – with rot and mould, leaky taps, uneven floors, an almost unusable kitchen and outdated bathroom providing challenges for their competition.

But viewers have to wait until 7.30pm on Monday to find out whether or not the Pallarenda pair got the ‘‘ beachy entertainer’’ of their dreams, though they did reveal that it is a ‘‘ massive transformation that will blow everyone away’’.

Maddi and Lloyd are currently in third place on 21 points and are still in contention to win the series, which would see them become mortgage free.
related.description: THEY are the ridiculously photogenic Townsville-based couple who reality television producers were willing to break the rules for to ensure they would light up our screens.
related.standFirst: House Rules contestants Maddi and Lloyd have been embraced as Townsville locals because of their laidback attitutes, despite moving here only two years ago.
related.subtitle: House Rules Townsville contestants shine national spotlight on city

related.body:
Does this adage hold true?

Let’s look at the most recent Labor government. The Rudd Government inherited a $20 billion surplus, but left office with a $30 billion deficit (albeit while dealing with the GFC).

Largely because of this perceived profligacy, Labor was booted out of power after just two terms.

The Abbott Government was then elected, in large part, to bring the budget back to surplus.

But the government is caught up in a number social issues no one seems to care about. The Racial Discrimination Act, Knights and Dames and school chaplains are the furthest things from the mind of the average Australian, yet they seem to be front and centre in Tony Abbott’s.

Meanwhile in Queensland, the Newman Government’s controversial crackdown on bikies and its ongoing war with the judiciary detracts from its good budget stories.

The two governments’ focus on non-economic issues has coincided with a fall in the polls.

The Abbott Government’s current slide in the polls began in April this year – immediately after the restoration of the Knights and Dames royal titles and its attempt to weaken the Racial Discrimination Act.

So what would happen if a Labor government didn’t spend money like it was going out of style?

And how would the Coalition fare if it didn’t act like that annoying, offensive, out-of-touch relative at a family get-to-together? Well, we only need to look at recent history.

The Hawke and Keating Labor governments enacted some of the most important economic reforms this country has seen – such as floating the dollar and lowering tariffs – and returned the budget to surplus after the recession of the early 1980s.

It was this economic success that enabled the government to continue supporting the most vulnerable in society without people thinking it was spending like, well, a Labor government.

Alternatively, if a Coalition government could effectively manage the economy without getting sidetracked on conservative social issues – like the Howard Government did for most of the time – then they would no doubt be duly rewarded at the ballot box.

Abbott and Newman need to quickly realise they weren’t elected to foist their worldview on the public.

Unless they do, people won’t be able to stand them any longer ... and they will elect a government they probably can’t afford.
related.description: I ONCE heard a saying about Australian politics: We keep Labor until we can’t afford them anymore, and we keep the Coalition until we can’t stand them anymore.
related.standFirst: I ONCE heard a saying about Australian politics: We keep Labor until we can’t afford them anymore, and we keep the Coalition until we can’t stand them anymore.
related.subtitle: Coalition social policy surplus to need

Bree Elizabeth Benyon, a former V8 Grid Girl and Bikini Babe finalist, supplied four ecstasy pills to Ashley Craperi and tried to source another five tablets for him.

Benyon’s barrister, Greg Lynham, told Townsville District Court yesterday that his client had already been punished after local media reports about her charges.

“The courts long recognise that public humiliation and shame is always a factor that’s relative to the sentencing process,” he said.

“As a consequence of the behaviour that brings her to court today, already she’s suffered embarrassment and humiliation due to her conduct being exposed as broadly as it has been as a consequence of the article in the .”

Benyon, 24, gained further notoriety in the past month after an image of her bound and gagged appeared on a relative’s ute tray.

She pleaded guilty to two counts of supplying dangerous drugs. Judge Stuart Durward SC fined her a total of $1000 and did not record a conviction.

“I accept you’re not a user of drugs but rather you were used by a drug user to facilitate the drugs to him in a way that’s now landed you in a lot of trouble,” he said.

Benyon told Craperi she would come to his salon after he texted her, asking “can you get those lollies for the weekend?”.

In one message intercepted by police, Benyon told him that it would cost “30 for a haircut”.

Mr Lynham pointed out that on both occasions Craperi had contacted his client to ask for ecstasy.

Crown prosecutor Chris Moore admitted the offences were low level, but were still serious.

“The courts cannot fail to be aware of the scourge of dangerous drugs, particularly by … people who might labour under the misconception they do not risk serious harm to themselves by using those drugs,” he said.

Mr Moore said Benyon did not agree to an interview with police when they searched her home, but pleaded guilty at an early occasion.
related.description: A TOWNSVILLE model who supplied ecstasy to her hairdresser has been fined after claiming she had been publicly humiliated since pleading guilty.
related.standFirst: A TOWNSVILLE model who supplied ecstasy to her hairdresser has been fined, after saying she had been publicly humiliated since pleading guilty.
related.subtitle: Bikini model fined for supplying ecstasy

related.body:
The photo — which shows the first time Bethany Townsend, 23, dared to bare after being fitted with two colostomy bags — has now been viewed by an incredible nine million people.

Bethany, a makeup artist from Worcester in the UK, has been so overwhelmed by the response that she can finally acknowledge that the colostomy bags doesn’t define who she is.

“I didn’t expect this kind of reaction at all,” she said of the picture.

“When I first had the bags fitted I was devastated — the reaction to this photo has really helped me accept them.

“The photo has been seen by millions of people ... I’m just so glad that it’s brought about more awareness of Crohn’s disease, and it’s made me feel so much more confident.”

Bethany was fitted with her colostomy bags after battling with Crohn’s disease since the age of three. It is a condition that causes inflammation of the digestive system, affecting the sufferer’s ability to digest food, absorb nutrients and eliminate waste.

In extreme situations like Bethany’s, it becomes necessary to remove the damaged section of the intestine and bring the healthy part out as a stoma — known as a colostomy.

After almost dying when her bowel ruptured in 2010, Bethany woke from a life-saving operation to find she had been fitted with two colostomy bags.

“Growing up I’d had various surgeries to try and combat the Crohn’s,” said Townsend. “I’d go in and have sections of my intestine cut out, but I’d only be in remission for a couple of weeks before it came back again.

“Then, four years ago I woke up in the morning and couldn’t move because I was in so much agony. I had to break a glass on the floor to alert my mum who called on ambulance. When the paramedics came they lifted up my top to see that my surgery scar had split open. I was rushed to intensive care where they doctors told me family I would need more surgery as my intestines had become infected and inflamed again. I had no idea when I woke up that I would have the bags.

“When I first woke up and my mum told me about them I was just relieved as I’d thought I was going to die. When I came out of hospital and everything finally sunk in, I remember going upstairs into my bedroom and just bursting into tears.

“I’d known a colostomy bag might have been an option but it was always something that I had wanted to avoid. I had a really good cry that day, and since then I haven’t shed another tear — I’ve just got on with it I suppose.”

It was only after Townsend met and married her husband, Ian, 33, and jetted off to Mexico last Christmas that she finally felt ready to embrace the colostomy bags.

“When I met Ian I showed him my bags straight away, but he didn’t bat an eye lid — I actually felt like I was overreacting,” she said.

“He taught me that there was more to me than the bags and would always encourage me to show off my figure. I wasn’t sure but in Mexico I finally realised he was right, and decided to wear my bikini.

“At first I was nervous and worried that people would stare but it was fine. The staff at the hotel asked me about the bags on the last day of the holiday, but rather than being offended I was glad because it meant I could talk to them about Crohn’s and tell them what it is.

“I decided to get in touch with Crohn’s and Colitis UK Facebook group to see if they would let me post something on their page. I sent them the picture and my information, and it all blew up from there.”

Townsend still suffers from Crohn’s disease and hopes ones day for a cure, but for now she is considering getting back into modelling — a career she gave up on after she was fitted with the bags.

“I feel confident enough now to put myself out there and pursue modelling again,” she said.

“I did a little bit of work here and there before I had the colostomy bags, but once I had them fitted I thought that was the end of the dream. I’m looking forward to chasing my goals, and I know now that nothing can hold me back.

“I won’t let the Crohn’s control me anymore.”
related.description: A STUNNING brunette has become an internet sensation after bravely posting a bikini snap on Facebook that exposes her colostomy bags.

related.body:
Running the length of his right arm from wrist to sleeve, fans were in awe of the supposed inking, saying the 19-year-old brought “swag in tennis to a whole new level”.

More: Kyrgios stuns with four-set Wimbeldon win over Rafael Nadal 

The “tatt”, which featured a tribal-looking pattern, appeared have given his dark skin a white hue underneath, leaving fans baffled about how it was done.

The tattoo that Kyrgios has is fkin awesome

— Daenerys Targaryen (@th4t_ginger) July 1, 2014 

Kind of obsessed with Kyrgios' tattoo pic.twitter.com/TIqP9LREL3

— Stacey Bartlett (@staceybartlett) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios brings swag in tennis to a whole new level with his arm tattoo

— Jack Carolan (@Jackobeanz) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios' arm tattoo is freaking me out! Why and how is it white?

— Beci Wood (@beciwood) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios's tattoo is sooo awesome! #LovinIt #Wimbeldon14

— Penny Clark (@PennyClark_23) July 1, 2014 

#wimbledon2014 kyrgios playing nadal....is that a tattoo on his right arm? pic.twitter.com/pKxT0h06Bn

— Terry Rideout (@TerrysTwit78) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios epic arm tattoo pic.twitter.com/irRs3ZarUg

— Technically Bryan (@technicallybry) July 1, 2014 

But for those wanting to mimic the look, it turns out it’s pretty easy to get “a Kyrgios” — the tatt is just a piece of tape.

Developed by an Australian Musculoskeletal Physiotherapist and made by Vanuatu-based Dynamic Tape, the product is a unique, strongly elastic tape for treating soft tissue sports injuries. 

The uniquely branded “Tattoo Tape” features a tribal tattoo design created by Norfolk Island and Tahitian artist, Tihoti, and is available in both black and beige.

The intricately-designed product was also worn by Tim Cahill during the World Cup to blend in with his own tattoos.

The Dynamic Tape website says the highly elastic tape is used to strongly assist or resist movement, facilitate or inhibit and offload tissue through full range of motion. The tape is applied to an injured muscle or tendon and as the muscle or joint lengthens, the tape is stretched to absorb load and reduce the work on the muscles. This results in decreased workload, demand on the muscle and improved tolerance to fatigue.

Managing Director of Dynamic Tape, Ryan Kendrick, told news.com.au he had no idea Kyrgios was using his Tribal Tape, but wasn’t surprised that people mistook the product for a real tattoo.

“When I have worn it myself people often ask to see my tattoo and I have had many of my patients recount funny stories like an 85-year-old great grandmother whose son was disgusted with her as he thought she had gone out and got some ink!” he said.

He said Ana Ivanovic and Sania Mirzer used the tan tattoo version of the product at the Australian Open earlier this year while Tommy Haas wore the black tattoo design. Serena Williams, Laura Robson and Kim Clijsters have also used the product.

Kendrick said the tattoo design came about because he was living on Norfolk Island when the tape was developed and wanted to reflect the heritage of the island and the South Pacific.

“The design was given to us by a very well known Polynesian artist and tattooist named Tihoti. Tihoti is Tahitian but his wife is a Norfolk Islander. Norfolk relies heavily on tourism and with the global financial crisis and high Australian Dollar, they were suffering so it was our way of spreading the word about Norfolk Island a little.”

Kinesio Australia Education Director, Clint Bridges, says while the tribal tape is not an official Kinesio product, the Kinesio taping method is regularly used on the tennis circuit.

“Novak Djokovic, Li Na and Serena Williams all use a beige form of the tape on court. At a base level, it’s used to try and change the way the muscle is firing. There are specific tensions for different tasks which changes the way the brain thinks that muscle is working.

“Certain tensions provide stimulus on the skin, which sends a message to the brain. The brain then reinterprets that message and sends instructions back to the muscle so it learns how to behave. There would be one tension for relaxation of the muscle if it’s tight and one for activation.”

Kendrick said the tape was released commercially in Australia in late 2010, followed by the UK and then North America in 2012. The tape was used by a number of athletes at the London 2012 games and is now available in 25 countries.

So there you have it, for all those out there wanting the Kyrgios tattoo, you’re in luck.

For just $15.10, you can buy five metres of the stuff.

Were you fooled by Kyrgios’ tattoo? Leave your comment below.

related.body:
Here’s how the world reacted.

THE MAN HIMSELF

Even Kyrgios was surprised at how well he played.

“I was in a bit of zone out there, I played some extraordinary tennis, I served at a really good level out there,” he said.

“I’m a normal kid like any 19-year-old who likes to play on his Xbox. The big stage is something I thrive on.

“Never did I think a week ago I was going to make the quarter-finals of Wimbledon in my first appearance.”

Have to do it all again tomorrow and I can't wait! First @Wimbledon & I'm in the last 8 club!! #HaveThat

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

Slowly sinking in. What an unreal day! Thanks to Simon, AK, Anne-Marie & @JohnMorris1982 for all their hard work. Massive team effort. #BOOM

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

HIS MUM

Kyrgios’ own mother didn’t think he could beat the world No. 1.

“My mum said in an interview she thought Rafa was too good ... that made me mad and spurred me on,” Kyrgios told the BBC.

MORE: The shot that stunned the world 

MORE: Giant killer Kyrgios takes out Nadal 

Nick Kyrgios’ quarter-final match against world No. 9 Canadian Milos Raonic will start after midnight tonight AEST. 

THE OPPONENT

The ever-gracious Rafael Nadal heaped praise on Kyrgios, conceding “he play better than me”.

“When you have an opponent that he decides to serve and to hit every ball very strong, you are in trouble,” Nadal said.

“I didn’t play really bad.”

Asked what the dual Wimbledon champion would be doing with his unexpected spare time, Nadal said: “Congratulations to him. For me, beach. For me, I going to go to the beach in Mallorca.”

THE LEGEND

John McEnroe came up with a massive call, saying, “We have found the next guy in the men’s game.”

“The last guy I saw like this was Boris Becker with no fear and believing that they can win this thing,” McEnroe said.

“You are watching someone who is going to be a big star in the future.”

Aussie Aussie Aussie Oi Oi Oi. @NickKyrgios the giant slayer! #wimbledon #believe pic.twitter.com/H8xt7lGRPh

— Pat Cash (@TheRealPatCash) July 1, 2014 

Nick Kyrgios- the Wonder from "Down Under" shocks #1 Nadal at Wimbledon. Welcome to the World Stage- YOUTH!! Great effort.

— Jimmy Connors (@JimmyConnors) July 1, 2014 

THE MEGASTAR AND A COUPLE OF PMs

Actor Hugh Jackman, Prime Minister Tony Abbott and former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser were among the famous Aussies to show their support for our newest star.

Aussie Aussie Aussie @NickKyrgios. Such composure and class! But hard off to @RafaelNadal ... one of the greatest of all time!

— Hugh Jackman (@RealHughJackman) July 1, 2014 

Extraordinary performance @NickKyrgios. Australia couldn't be prouder of you - what a win & what an amazing attitude! #Wimbledon2014

— Tony Abbott (@TonyAbbottMHR) July 1, 2014 

Wimbledon 2014: Nick Kyrgios defeats Rafael Nadal in four-set upset. Victory extraordinary, congratulations Kyrgios. http://t.co/F7DImcNLWm

— Malcolm Fraser (@MalcolmFraser12) July 1, 2014 

THE TWITTERATI

And this is how the rest of the world reacted...

Even though my TV show premiered tonight!!! I regretfully say this was by far the best thing on television. #Kyrgios pic.twitter.com/HhUockXJel

— Andy Lee (@andy_lee) July 1, 2014 

Now that was worth staying up for. @NickKyrgios take a bow. Remarkable play. #Wimbledon #aussiepride

— Steve Smith (@stevesmith49) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios is the 1st teenager to beat a world #1 at a Grand Slam since Nadal def Federer at 2005 French Open. Congrats Nick. Stunning effort.

— Darren Cahill (@darren_cahill) July 1, 2014 

Three weeks ago, Nick Kyrgios was losing in the first round of a Challenger event in Nottingham. To world 185 John-Patrick Smith. Meteor

— tomfordyce (@tomfordyce) July 1, 2014 

Nick #Kyrgios is the first player outside the top 100 to beat the world No.1 since Andrei Olhovsky v Jim Courier 1992 pic.twitter.com/veQynIAKlt

— BBC Tennis (@bbctennis) July 1, 2014 

‘He play better than me’: Rafael Nadal after losing his match against Aussie Nick Kyrgios. Photo: Scott Heavey/AELTC - Pool/Getty Images

related.title: World in shock over Aussie Nick

related.body:
It’s time to get on the bandwagon.

Kyrgios will face Canada’s world No. 9 in the early hours of tomorrow, and the likes of tennis legend John McEnroe are predicting an upset, saying the 19-year-old can go all the way and win the prestigious Wimbledon crown as a teenager.

Here are 10 things you didn’t know about Nick Kyrgios.

1. HOW TO PRONOUNCE HIS NAME

The “G” is silent. So “Kirr-ee-oss”. Not “Kurr-gee-oss”, like the spelling would suggest.

2. HIS BACKGROUND

Kyrgios is Aussie born. A Canberra boy. His father, George, was born in Greece and moved to Australia as a child. His mother, Norlaila, is Malaysian.

Kyrgios is the youngest of three kids. His brother is a lawyer and his sister an actor.

3. HE WAS A CHUBBY KID

Kyrgios’ mother, Norlaila, admits her boy ate too much as a child. He loved his food.

But he eventually stretched out into a lean 1.93m (6ft 4in), 77kg frame and lost the puppy fat.

MORE: The shot that stunned the world 

MORE: Legends, celebs in shock over Aussie Nick 

MORE: Why you don’t need to cheer for Tomic anymore 

4. THE HISTORY HE’S CREATED

With his 7-6 (7-5), 5-7 7-6 (7-5) 6-3 victory over Nadal — one of the greatest upsets in Wimbledon history — Kyrgios became the first teenager to defeat a world No. 1 at a grand slam since Nadal did it himself against Roger Federer in the 2005 French Open. An ominous sign.

The youngest man in the men’s draw, the 144th-ranked Kyrgios also became the first player ranked outside the top 100 to defeat a world No. 1 at a grand slam since Andrei Olhovsky defeated Jim Courier at Wimbledon in 1992.

Kyrgios is the youngest man to reach the last eight at Wimbledon since compatriot Bernard Tomic in 2011 and the first to reach the quarter-finals on debut since German Florian Mayer 10 years ago.

5. BASKETBALL BECKONED
Canberra is boasting right now about being the home of Australia’s hottest sporting stars. NBA star Patty Mills, the “next big thing” in basketball Dante Exum and Kyrgios are all products of the nation’s capital. Kyrgios was a hoops-mad kid as well, representing Australia in basketball as a young teen before making tennis his sole focus as a 14-year-old. He still loves the Boston Celtics.

6. THE MONEY GAME

Since turning pro in 2013, Kyrgios has played only 10 matches on ATP Tour. Of those, he has only won three and lost seven (going into Wimbledon).

This year, he’d won just one match on the pro tour — the Australian Open first round against Benjamin Becker, the namesake of the man Kyrgios has been compared to quite a bit today, Boris Becker.

What it all means is he’d won $A248,000 in his career up until Wimbledon. He will walk away from the All England Club with a minimum $A409,806 for reaching the quarter-finals. The Wimbledon champion takes home $A3.19 million.

7. HIS IDOLS

If Kyrgios can shock the world once more and defeat Raonic tonight, he is on track to meet the man he looked up to most as a child, Roger Federer, in the Wimbledon semi-finals. Another guy he really idolised as a youngster was Nadal.

Kyrgios first started playing tennis at six years old, in 2001. By that stage, Federer had already been a pro for three years.

8. HE LIKES RAP

Kyrgios is a Lil Wayne fan. And he was into Wu Tang as a kid. He also likes R’n’B artist Rihanna.

9. HE WAS A TOP JUNIOR

While top juniors don’t always make it big, Kyrgios was a junior world No. 1 and won the junior Australian Open in 2013, defeating countryman Thanasi Kokkinakis in the final.

10. HE LOVES A LAUGH

Proving he is not just a serious tennis robot, Kyrgios loves a comedy and is a big Family Guy fan.

related.body:
• An ugly barrage of texts sent from Tinder co-founder Justin Mateen to his fellow co-founder Whitney Wolfe have been published.

• Backpackers living in shipping containers had to be rescued from a fire in Sydney overnight.

• The first person to post the bubbling photo of Todd Carney has hit back at critics saying he was only trying to find out if the photo was fake.

• A rogue waiter who called his cafe customers “stupid” says that he was p****d off they got their order wrong.

10am 

That’s it for our live #RUSHHOUR news blog. You can get across the stories you need to know today below or go to news.com.au for the latest headlines.

9.55am 

The Sri Lankan military denies it has picked up a boatload of Tamil asylum seekers on their way to Australia, ABC reports.

The military says it has no plans to pick up the boat, which is believed to be carrying 150 people and has not be contactable since the weekend.

It may also have been intercepted by the Australian Navy or Customs.

9.45am 

Thousands of Game of Thrones fans lined up for hours yesterday for an exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art.

9.35am 

Air Chief Marshal Mark Binskin says an Australian Special Forces officer has died from a non-combat incident overnight.

9.20am 

Australia’s Chief of Defence is due to release details about an ‘incident in Afghanistan’ at 9.30am.

9.10am 

Yesterday was a special anniversary for a number of regions. Organisers say a record number of protesters took part in a pro-democracy rally in Hong Kong on July 1, to mark the date the city was handed back to China in 1997.

Meanwhile residents of the Northern Terrority celebrated their own anniversary, releasing fireworks to mark Territory Day, the day when the NT became an entity in its own right (which actually falls on January 1, 1911).

9am 

The US has been knocked out of the World Cup this morning after a thrilling game against Belgium. Catch up on all the action on our live blog. Also Argentina v Switzerland.

8.40am 

A rogue waiter who called his cafe customers “stupid” says that he was p****d off they got their order wrong.

Sydney woman Fung Dang was furious after receiving a bill that included an item for “stupid customers”, prompting a backlash against the Three Williams Cafe in Redfern.

Waiter Charles Oehlrich, 30, has told The Daily Telegraph that he never thought his comments would print on the bill.

“I take full responsibility. I’m the one that deserves to be fired and so I have been,” he said.

“She was really nice about it - that is the worst thing about it. They are not stupid people.”

8.30am 

The building industry is set to be rocked by an explosive video and claims of corruption, death threats and intimidation during royal commission hearings in Melbourne next week.

The Herald Sun understands witnesses will detail claims about senior figures in the Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union.

At least one witness due to give evidence has received death threats from people linked to the union.

8.20am 

Sydney train commuters face delays on the T1 Northern Line due to a broken down freight train at Beecroft.

Continue to allow extra travel time due to a freight train with a mechanical issue at Beecroft earlier.

— T1 Sydney Trains (@T1SydneyTrains) July 1, 2014 

8am 

The first person to post the bubbling photo of Todd Carney has hit back at critics saying he was only trying to find out if the photo was fake.

Mark Miler, who posts as @MarkRaider1 did not take the photo but is believed to be the first person to post it on Twitter.

Meanwhile Dragons player Josh Dugan, who engaged in a Twitter war with Miler last year, told Fairfax he wasn’t surprised that Miler was the first to post the photo.

R u ppl normal..URz r making out I took the pic and sent to the whole world..I found the pic and asked if it was real or fake ..simple

— Mark Miler (@MarkRaider1) June 30, 2014 

7.35am 

An ugly barrage of texts sent from Tinder co-founder Justin Mateen to his fellow co-founder Whitney Wolfe have been published as part of her sexual harassment case.

The texts revealed on Gawker reveal a relentless stream of abuse from Mateen after a failed romance with Wolfe. He calls her “heartless”, “fake” and responds to pleas from Wolfe to get back to work with his own warning: “if you threaten me I will bark back like a psycho”.

7.20am 

It was going to happen sooner or later. Sexy felon Jeremy Meeks has reportedly secured a modelling contract with LA based Blaze Models, according to TMZ.

The internet went crazy for Meeks after his mugshot was posted on Facebook and he now has an agent, Gina Rodriguez, a former porn star.

Now, if only he could get out of jail.

7.10am 

UPDATE: Looks like some of the people rescued from a major fire in a Sydney industrial area overnight were backpackers living in shipping containers.

7am 

Tens of thousands of mourners in Israel farewelled three teenagers killed in the West Bank, while vowing to hunt down the Hamas militants it holds responsible for their kidnap and murder.

Gilad Shaer and Naftali Frenkel, both 16, and 19-year-old Eyal Ifrach, were found in a field in the West Bank after going missing on June 12.

All three had been shot in a triple murder blamed on militants from the Islamist Hamas movement, Sky News reports.

6.25am 

Aussie teenager Nick Kyrgios has delivered one of the greatest upsets in tennis history, beating world No 1 Rafael Nadal at Wimbledon overnight.

The 19-year-old from Canberra pulled off a 7-6, 5-7, 7-6, 6-3 win to reach the Wimbledon quarterfinals. Click here for a recap of all the action.

6.10am 

The lover of an infamous prison gangster has disappeared amid grave concerns for her safety.

Tia Maria Jayne Landers has been missing since June 16. She was last seen when CCTV cameras recorded her walking into a petrol station on the Gateway Motorway at Nudgee in Brisbane’s north.

Ms Landers, 28, had been a no-show in an armed robbery and burglary trial a month earlier when the case against her partner, jailhouse “Angry Gang” member Wade Bartz, was dropped.

However, her disappearance is believed to be unrelated to Bartz.

6.05am 

About 70 firefighters battled a large fire in Sydney this morning.

The blaze in the inner west suburb of Alexandria spread to three buildings and firefighters had to rescue four people and evacuate 14 others.

Firefighters arrived at the industrial complex on Burrows Rd about 1.20am.

Motorists are advised to avoid the area but some traffic is now being allowed through Burrows Rd and Euston Rd between Campbell St and Sydney Park Rd.

Fire crews are still working to contain a blaze in an Alexandria industrial complex. Details @TheTodayShow. #9News pic.twitter.com/Nqji5vfIE4

— Nine News Sydney (@9NewsSyd) July 1, 2014 

6am 

Good morning, and welcome to our morning news coverage. We will be bringing you the best of what’s happening this morning, so you can get across the news quickly.
