related.body:
After months of searching, Paul Fenech and his team have located the crème de la crème of boganism for 7mate’s reality show, Bogan Hunters, and the Apple Isle is certainly punching well above its weight.

After an exhaustive process of elimination, celebrity judges Angry Anderson, Jonesy, Miss Nude Australia, Tahir Bilgic, Jacko, Chris Franklin, Derek Boyer and Rob Shehadie have selected seven finalists to go through to next Tuesday’s Bogan Hunters Grand Final.

More: Do bogans know they’re bogans and other important questions

Fenech told news.com.au that only the purest of bogans made it through.

“When we started the series I thought it was a bit of a joke. But boganism is a culture. These guys are unashamedly bogans. They love it, they live it, they have a complete lack of any pretence. I reckon the bogan is the true Aussie battler of the new millennium.”

And while they are all unique in their embracement of the “culture”, they all have one thing in common. 

“It’s a mystery, the teeth of the bogan,” added Fenech, “a bit like the Bermuda Triangle. Could be too many Beam and Cokes, I don’t know. But I would say more than 50 per cent of bogans do have some pretty interesting teeth, that’s for sure. It could be a money thing. It costs a lot to get your teeth fixed.”

He says the finalists are defined by: “Mullets, thongs, ugg boots, flannelettes, tight jeans, a love of Oz rock, home done tattoos are important, a lack of pretence is very important, as is a willingness to be incredibly honest at all time.”

Australia, meet your finalists:

MEL: the kinky chick from Munno Para, South Australia 

Said to perfectly represent the “female of the bogan species”. She once stabbed her partner in the neck with a pair of scissors because he poked her too much in the arm.

ANDREW: the dad to eight kids to three different mothers from Bridgewater, Tasmania 

Has the name of his eight kids tattooed on his arms, all the girls on one arm and the boys on the other. “I can’t remember their dates of birth cos I’m always too smashed. That way if I go to Centrelink and they ask me, well I can say ‘here we go, here’s the date of birth” he said as he showed off the ink.

DARREN: the second worst driver in Tasmania, also from Bridgewater 

Has 52 charges of driving with no licence against his name and is proud of it. Has his own car graveyard full off abandoned wrecks. “What more do you want in life,” he said.

NANNA SHAZZA: the larger-than-life GILF from Victoria’s bogan epicentre, Nar Nar Goon 

Is the “odds on favourite” to win. Loves her Holdens, Collingwood football team and exposing her breasts. Enjoys drinking a goon sack of wine hung from a clothesline.

JUSTIN: the young chick magnet from St Helens, Tasmania 

Is the youngest bogan of the finalists. Sports a good array of tatts including an “Made in Australia” sign, a Southern Cross and the name of his son across his chest. Became a dad at 16 and is fiercely proud of his mullet which he describes as “nice and filthy”.

FORDY: the wild man from Rocky aka Western Australia’s most bogan suburb, Rockingham 

Can swear mid-word, loves a nudie run, Ned Kelly, a barbecue and has an esky of beers kept next to his bed. Attempted to eat the rubber remnants left on the ground after a burnout.

CLINT: the 50-something bogan “lifer” from George Town, Tasmania 

Judges said he “ticked so many bogan boxes”. Talked about his favourite sex position, doggie style, showed off his missus’ homemade tattoos and has an incredible collection of bogan friends. Lives in George Town which he describes as the “boganest place in the world”.

The Bogan Hunters Grand Final airs next Tuesday, July 8 at 9.30pm on 7mate. 

The finalists will have to prove themselves once and for all in a final showdown of bogan appearance, attitude and sex appeal, before “Australia’s Greatest Bogan” is crowned.

The winner will be awarded the Golden Thong Award and the Aussie Pride ‘straya ute with kegs in the back, which Paul Fenech describes as a “sick, hectic, off-the-hook prize.”

related.body:
Today’s junk food is far more extreme. And with extreme junk food comes extreme names.

Yesterday, a Sydney cafe was forced to remove its signature dessert from the menu because it was called ‘diabetes’. While some critics thought the name offensive, there was no denying that the glorious stack of jam cronut, peanut butter ice cream, dulce de leche syrup and espresso coffee looked downright delicious.

This got us thinking about other extreme junk food treats around Australia, so we’ve gathered together the top 10.

10. Stoner’s Delight 2.0

What: Doughnut ice cream, peanut butter, raspberry jam, candied bacon, potato chips, mars bar slice, banana fritter

Where: Ms G’s, Potts Point, Sydney 

9. The Elvis Burger

What: Canadian bacon, ground beef patty, mayonnaise and gruyère cheese on a savory cronut with a side of think cut chips and tomato relish

Where: Brewtown Newtown, Sydney

8. Kinder Surprise on steroids

What: Chocolate, honeycomb and vanilla sphere, cardamom, saffron and ginger, passionfruit, mandarin

Where: Gastro Park, Potts Point, Sydney

7. Messina Wiener and Pluto Pup

What: Hot dog made completely from gelato. We’re not kidding. #messinawiener

Where: Gelato Messina

6. Deconstructed Neymar’s Bar

What: Milk chocolate gelato with bites of almond nougat, a chocolate flaked choc top coating and a warm caramel syringe.

Where: N2 Extreme Gelato, Melbourne

And while we’re at N2, check out this wacky creation...

5. Happy ‘lil Socceroos

What: Milk gelato with buttered sao crackers and vegemite. Wait, what?

Where: N2 Extreme Gelato, Melbourne

4. Croquembouche Verrine 

What: Caramel liquid, malted milk Panna cotta, lemon jam, almond Sable, crème patisserie Legere, jersey caramel crème, profiterole filled with crème patisserie

Where: Adriano Zumbo Patisserie 

3. Deep fried Golden Gaytime

What: Exactly what it sounds like. A Golden Gaytime ice cream, dipped in batter and deep fried in oil.

Where: Oxford Tavern, Petersham, Sydney 

2. ‘Piggy Face’ buns

What: Steamed sesame ‘piggy face' buns — a sweet Chinese dessert

Where: Chef’s Gallery 

1. Shake ‘n’ Fry

What: A fresh cinnamon doughnut filled with raspberry jam, topped with vanilla custard soft serve and served with a salted caramel popcorn milkshake.

Where: Gelato Messina, Darlinghurst, Sydney

Have we missed your favourite extreme fast food? Tell us in the comments below or join the conversation on Twitter @newscomauHQ | @gracekoelma

related.body:
New York University student Gerry Shalam found that out the hard way after he and his mates were filmed leaving a popular Manhattan eatery after a long brunch.

Their antics got the internet talking.

Not only did Mr Shalam make a fool of himself, but he pretended to be someone he clearly wasn’t — and was caught out big time.

In a YouTube video posted yesterday, the student, who had just eaten at Pranna, is seen outside a dry cleaners on 28th Street with three friends, one of whom is being supported against a wall and appears to be drunk.

But Mr Shalam realises he is being filmed and approaches the cameraman, demanding he put his camera away because his dad is in real estate and owns half the city.

The man filming the footage then asks the pair to move off his property when Gerry launches into this tirade:

“This your property?,” he says as he goes to on to claim his name is Gerry Adjmi.

“My dad is in f***ing’ real estate, you’re gonna tell me this your property? My dad owns half of f***ing Manhattan.”

He also claims he also has both the police and Mayor Bill DeBlasio on his side. Oh and he’s apparently a lawyer too.

“You think a guy who does real estate doesn’t own the cops?”.

But if that isn’t bad enough; surprise, surprise it turns out Gerry Adjmi isn’t who he says he is at all.

Despite deleting all his social media accounts, US website The Smoking Gun  discovered he isn’t actually who he says he is.

As it turns out the drunken student is actually Gerry Shalam, a New Jersey man whose father Lou is a garment industry executive, and his mother Frieda an event co-ordinator and member of the Allenhurst Borough zoning and planning board.

The video, and his apparent claim to fame has attracted a raft of attention on social media with some people calling him a “terrible man child” while others called his behaviour disgusting.

#GerryShalam -BWAAAAAAA!

— Randall Ellis (@rketexas) July 1, 2014 

Gerry Shalam is actually a student of #NYU. No surprise that a self-indulgent capitalist is already attending there http://t.co/f7hV8U0Zse

— Donithan (@trollshevikism) July 1, 2014 

So looks like the drunken NYU students dad who owns half of Manhattan, doesn't actually own half of Manhattan. #gerryshalam

— Tom Strong-Grinsell (@TomSG_) July 1, 2014 

That terrible manchild who drunkenly proclaimed his father owns half of manhattan is from, of course, New Jersey: http://t.co/2KGm1Yk0QJ

— Olivia Nuzzi (@Olivianuzzi) July 1, 2014 

This whole Gerry Shalam thing is disgusting. I hope he gets expelled from NYU

— Storey (@storey_ofmylife) July 1, 2014 

And while Mr Shalam may be regretting his behaviour, at least he’s not quite as bad as the YouTube clip makes him out to be.

The 20-year-old co-founded a charitable organisation called Brothers Helping Others that helps low-income immigrant families in Asbury Park, New Jersey.

He is also not totally incorrect regarding the status of the Adjmi family who are indeed wealthy and also in real estate.
related.description: HERE’S the first lesson of the internet — what goes on stays there forever and if you’re going to act like a drunken fool, then this is what happens.

related.body:
Radical group ISIS (Islamic State of Iraq and Syria) last week seized control of every major border crossing between the two countries, as well as a number of towns and military bases in Iraq’s western province.

Just yesterday, ISIS announced the establishment of a “caliphate”, which is a system that sees a ‘caliph’ — ISIS leader Baghdadi — given absolute power and total ruling authority over Muslims.

The group’s spokesman Abu Mohammad al-Adnani described the caliphate as “the dream in all Muslims’ hearts” and “the hope of all jihadists” - but that means little to the thousands of people living in temporary displacement camps across the country because they were born into a different religion or ethnic group.

AP reported that the militant group’s surge of power and control across Iraq “has thrown the country into its deepest crisis since US troops withdrew in December 2011, and threatens to carve the nation in three along sectarian and ethnic lines.”

MORE: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi and ISIS explained

It is all too easy, from our safe houses here in Australia, to disassociate ourselves from a war happening halfway across the globe. We can get lost in the extremist claims populating mainstream and social media, and put the conflict down to something between men with covered faces, sporting guns.

But the reality of the situation is that terrified men, women and children have fled their homes across Iraq and Syria, streaming into temporary displacement camps rather than staying to submit to militant control.

The UN Refugee agency estimates that there are 1 million internally displaced people and 110,000 stateless people in Iraq alone, and the Red Crescent Society pegs over 80 per cent of them as women and young children.

The amazing pictures you will see below, captured by news photographers in the region, tell a story we will never be able to. Children in temporary displacement camps, children caught by roadside bombs, children scrambling to get food as they enter into the Ramadan period.

These are the faces of war.
related.description: THE current situation in Iraq and Syria is undeniably volatile, complicated and dangerous.
related.standFirst: THE terror group proudly publicises its brutal executions and atrocities. But there’s something about these images ISIS wishes we hadn’t seen.
related.subtitle: Faces of war: The reality facing children in Iraq and Syria

related.body:
John Bieniewicz, 44, of Westland, Michigan, was unconscious and lying on the ground when police arrived, after he was allegedly punched in the head by a player who he’d just issued with a red card. He never regained consciousness.

US agencies are reporting that Bassel Abdul-Amir Saad, 36, of Dearborn, Mich, was charged with assault with intent to do great bodily harm.

Scott Herkes, a 39-year-old player in the match, said he was about 25 metres away from the action when he saw Bieniewicz punched by a player on the opposing team. He said the referee was looking down at the time and didn’t see the punch coming.

“It was terrifying,” Mr Herkes told US media. “I have never in my life seen something like this”.

Mr Herkes went on to say that Saad had been complaining about a call made by the referee prior to his alleged assault. There were reportedly around 30 players at the game and a handful of spectators, many of whom also witnessed the event.

Mr Bieniewicz worked as a medical assistant at a children’s hospital in Ann Arbor, Michigan, a small city near Detroit.

“I speak for all his friends when I say we are devastated. Crushed. Just a senseless way for a great guy to go out,” James Acho, Bieniewicz’s friend of 30 years, told the Detroit Free Press . “He deserved better.”

“He just absolutely lived it and loved [soccer],” Mr Acho added.

Mr Acho said Bieniewicz is being kept on a ventilator until his organs can be harvested and donated through an organisation called Gift of Life. He will leave behind a wife and two young sons.

Mr Saad is alleged to have fled the field after the incident and driven away. His attorney, Brian Berry, said his client cooperated with the police investigation and voluntarily turned himself in.

“Mr. Saad is presumed innocent unless and until a fact finder determines differently,” his legal team said in an email to the Detroit Free Press. “As tragic as this event is, we must keep open minds and listen and wait for all the facts of this case to unfold.”

related.body:
We’ve had one result so far this morning:

• Argentina 1 Switzerland 0. Angel Di Maria’s winner in the dying minutes of extra time saved Argentina from the prospect of a penalty shootout.

• Belgium 2 USA 1. A pulsating period of extra time saw Belgium progress to the quarterfinals, with Kevin De Bruyne and Romelu Lukaku scoring the crucial goals.

Scroll down to the bottom of the page to relive our blow-by-blow coverage of Belgium v USA.

LINK: All the quarterfinal match-ups 

9:45am - OUCH! JERMAINE JONES’ EPIC FALCON

We can hardly complain about a lack of goals at this World Cup ... but there has been an outrageous shortage of quality falcons.

Jermaine Jones took a step towards changing that this morning, when he copped a ball to the face against Belgium.

9:30am - AMERICANS RESPOND TO THEIR WORLD CUP DEFEAT

Yeah but at least we have nukes

— David Pierce (@piercedavid) July 1, 2014 

9:15am — BELGIAN PLAYER VOMITS ON THE FIELD

Jan Vertonghen was clearly exhausted after 90 minutes of end-to-end action against the USA. As his team prepared for extra time, Vertonghen was shown throwing up on camera.

You certainly can’t fault the man’s commitment.

Don’t watch this video if you have a delicate stomach.

9:00am — WHO’S PLAYING WHO IN THE QUARTERFINALS?

We’ve finished the round of 16 now, and the World Cup quarterfinals will be played on Saturday and Sunday morning (AEST). Here are all the match-ups.

France v Germany, 2am Saturday

Brazil v Colombia, 6am Saturday

Argentina v Belgium, 2am Sunday

Netherlands v Costa Rica, 6am Sunday

8:30am — END OF EXTRA TIME ... BELGIUM 2 USA 1

In my somewhat humble opinion, that was the most exciting game of the World Cup so far, even though it was scoreless after 90 minutes.

Belgium scored twice in the first half of extra time, with goals from Kevin De Bruyne and Romelu Lukaku. The American dream was fading. Then the USA pulled one back at the start of the second half.

There were several excellent chances to equalise, but the USA couldn’t break through again, so Belgium will go through to play Argentina in the quarterfinals.

Ultimately, the Americans will look back on a golden opportunity to win the game in the 92nd minute, just before the end of regular time. The ball fell to Chris Wondolowski seven yards out from goal, but he sliced it wide.

In all fairness, Belgium was the better side for the vast majority of this match, and would have won easily if not for the heroics of American goalkeeper Tim Howard, who racked up the highest tally of saves by any goalkeeper at a World Cup since 1966.

MATCH REPORT: Belgium v USA 

8:20am — THE USA GETS ONE BACK!

Oh hang on. Maybe this isn’t over! The USA’s teenage substitute, Green, has volleyed the ball past Courtois to make the score 2-1. Now his team has just over 10 minutes to score another and force the game into a penalty shootout.

8:10am — LUKAKU KILLS THE AMERICAN DREAM

That must be it. Romelu Lukaku, having played a key role in Belgium’s first goal, has latched onto a through ball and fired it into the net.

Tim Howard has tallied 15 saves so far — that’s the most by any goalkeeper at a World Cup since 1966 — but there was nothing he could have done about that.

8:00am — BELGIUM SCORES!

Well, that didn’t take long. Just like Germany did yesterday, Belgium has scored almost immediately in extra time, despite failing to find the net during 90 minutes of regular time.

Romelu Lukaku surged down the right touchline, then sent the ball infield. The American defenders got there first, but couldn’t clear it, and Kevin de Bruyne pounced. That makes it 1-0.

7:55am — FULL TIME ... BELGIUM 0 USA 0

Chris Wondolowski missed a golden chance to win the game for the USA deep in stoppage time. The ball looped to his feet seven yards out from goal. He was unmarked. Wondolowski just had to slot it into the net to earn his team a place in the quarterfinals ... but he sliced it horribly.

So, the game has (somehow) finished scoreless, and we’re going to extra time.

Belgium has had 30 shots on goal, compared to the USA’s five. No prizes for guessing who’s the favourite.

7:40am — HOW GOOD IS TIM HOWARD?

With 10 minutes left, the USA is clinging to this 0-0 scoreline ... just. There have been several brilliant, desperate blocks from the American defenders, but the man of the match so far is undoubtedly goalkeeper Tim Howard.

The man is a beast between the posts. That is all.

7:30am — LIVERPOOL PLAYERS EXPECT SUAREZ TO LEAVE

Luis Suarez’s teammates at Liverpool believe the Uruguayan striker has played his last game for the club.

Suarez was sent home from the World Cup in disgrace and banned from football for months after biting Italian defender Giorgio Chiellini. Reds officials are reportedly nervous about the reception he would get in the Premier League once that ban expires.

So, they are poised to sell Suarez to Barcelona, in a move that would echo his sale from Ajax to Liveprool in 2011 — he was in the middle of a seven game ban for biting PSV Eindhoven’s Otman Bakkal at the time.

7:05am — XHERDAN SHAQIRI IS THE SADDEST MAN ALIVE

Switzerland’s best player, Xherdan Shaqiri, really lost his composure after that heartbreaking extra time loss to Argentina. You have to feel for the guy.

6:50am — USA AND BELGIUM SCORELESS AT HALF TIME

We needed this game. Particularly after the borefest between Argentina and Switzerland earlier today.

Belgium and the USA don’t seem to have much interest in defence. I mean, the last ditch stuff has been fantastic, and the American goalkeeper, Tim Howard, has pulled off some great saves, but the ball is flowing from end to end with ridiculous ease.

I’m not complaining, mind you. The match is scoreless at half time, but I can’t imagine it will stay that way for long.

6:40am — NEYMAR TO PLAY AGAINST COLOMBIA

Brazil’s star forward Neymar will be fit to play in his nation’s World Cup quarterfinal against Colombia, despite picking up thigh and knee injuries against Chile, AP reports.

The Brazilian football confederation says team doctor Jose Luiz Runco checked Neymar when the squad returned to its training camp, and the superstar is not in doubt for Saturday morning’s match.

MORE: The full report on Neymar’s fitness 

6:25am — A BAD OMEN FOR THE USA

This game between Belgium and the USA is the last round of 16 tie. So far, every match in the round has been won by the team that topped its pool.

Brazil, the Netherlands, Colombia, Costa Rica, France, Argentina and Germany have all advanced to the quarterfinals. All of them beat sides that came second in the group stage.

Belgium finished on top of Group H, and the USA was the runner-up to Germany in Group G, so if the pattern continues, Belgium will go through here.

6:05am — ARGENTINA 1 SWITZERLAND 0

Angel Di Maria’s winner in the dying minutes of extra time saved Argentina from the prospect of a penalty shootout against the stubborn Swiss.

After 118 minutes of frustration reminiscent of Argentina’s pool match against Iran, Lionel Messi picked out Di Maria, who slotted the ball into the net with his left foot.

Switzerland nearly grabbed an equaliser at the death when Blerim Dzemaili’s header cannoned off the foot of the post, and he pushed the rebound wide.

It was a cruel result for the Swiss, but they gave their coach Ottmar Hitzfeld, who is quitting football, a memorable swan song. Hitzfeld had learned of his brother’s death before the match.

MATCH REPORT: Argentina v Switzerland 

LIVE UPDATES

related.body:
Depending on your worldview, the film is either really, really romantic or really, really depressing - but did you know star Rachel McAdams nailed her role from the get-go?

McAdams’ first taped audition for the role of headstrong, lovestruck Allie Hamilton has, in the ensuing years, racked up hundreds of thousands of views on YouTube — when you watch it, you’ll see why they couldn’t cast anyone else in the part:

Throw in The Gosling and you’ve got yourself a hit. 

Here are some of the other most memorable celebrity audition tapes:

While Johansson wasn’t successful with this audition — she lost out to Kirsten Dunst for the 1995 family film — it still provides a rare, small glimpse at her life as a child actor, some six years before her breakout role as a surly teen in the 2001 cult classic Ghost World.

THIS KID. Barely 10 years old, actor Henry Thomas’ audition for the role of Elliott Taylor is absolutely heartbreaking. Tears welling in his eyes, the young actor pleads that his extraterrestrial friend not be taken away by the government. In the final seconds of the audition tape, Steven Spielberg can be heard off camera saying the immortal words: “OK kid, you got the job.”

OK, we don’t speak French and there are no subtitles on this clip. But check out Tautou’s adorably wide-eyed performance and try telling us there was anyone else who could’ve played Amelie so perfectly.

The audition tape as webcam confessional? Nailed it, Stone.

Steve Carell’s first go at inept weatherman Brick Tamland is positively deranged: the poor guy goes as red as a tomato during this two-minute skit with Will Ferrell. Absolutely hilarious.

Seth Rogen’s reputation as Hollywood’s most lovable stoner dates right back to his first audition for Freaks & Geeks, when he was still a teenager. One quibble: Rogen keeps a straight face through his very funny monologue. Where’s that bear-like laugh, Seth!

Page had a few big movies under her belt at this point - Hard Candy and X Men among them - but Juno remains her most memorable role, and it’s not hard to see why: she plays the acerbic, fast-talking teen to perfection, even in this early screen test.

Twenty years on, check out the audition that landed a then-13-year-old Portman her first film role, in the 1994 movie Leon: The Professional. 

As Lea Michele tells it in the clip above, her first Glee audition went “terribly”. Girl, please. As you can see, she had them eating out of the palm of her hand — she was Rachel Berry, even stopping to chastise the auditioners for laughing in the wrong places during her performance.

Umm, Megan Fox is very pretty. She looks very pretty in this audition. And that’s all we’re going to say about that. *sips tea*

*Special mention must also go to Rose Byrne’s spectacularly foul-mouthed audition for Get Him to the Greek, surely one of the funniest (and filthiest) comedy auditions of recent years. Language warning on that link, obviously.
related.description: HOLLYWOOD romance weepie The Notebook celebrated its 10th anniversary the other day.
related.standFirst: HOW did Emma Stone get her big break? And was Seth Rogen always such a funny guy? We’ve unearthed the early audition tapes of huge Hollywood stars.

related.body:
The annual or midyear performance review can range from a quick chat to a structured meeting, and is often your chance to speak up on everything from pay rises to promotions.

Pragmatic Thinking co-founder and behavioural scientist Darren Hill said despite their frequency, the process if often dreaded mainly because it’s so poorly handled by managers and staff.

“The general reaction is that if they’re not disliked, they’re loathed,” he said. “People see them as a necessary evil and at worst their least liked part of job. Most managers detest the process as well.”

But with no way around them, here’s his tips on how to avoid the most common mistakes people make at their performance reviews:

Mistake # 1 — Leaving everything up to the boss

Mr Hill said a major faux-pas most managers make is leaving all performance-related feedback, pay rises and talk of promotions until the annual review and lumping them all in together in a chat designed to cover everything but actually covering nothing well.

Instead, the best reviews occur when both parties are invested in the conversation.

“Instead of sitting back and hating the process, jump in and take control of your end. Look at this hour of your manger’s time as an opportunity to discuss your career and some key projects. Start the process by turning up well prepared and with a proactive intent; you’ll get much better results if you do.”

How you attack it depends on how your company handles the process. If it’s designed to talk about working conditions and pay — tell them what you want. Your manager can’t help you if they don’t know. It’s also a good way of ensuring your goals are in writing if your boss happens to move on.

But while it’s tempting to blurt out everything you want at once, Mr Hill said it’s actually better for employees to separate conversations about pay and working conditions from the review entirely and schedule another meeting to discuss these things.

“I actually think it’s a bad strategy to ask for a pay rise at a performance review. You really should be putting that into a secondary request rather than just lumping it in as a process otherwise the really important stuff can get lost in the process,” he said.

Mistake # 2 — Whining about everything 

Mr Hill said when it comes to making things happen, “attitude trumps policy every single time.”

Having a professional attitude with clear goals can mean the difference between getting what you want and not. There’s no sense sulking, getting angry or dwelling on the past.

“The most cumbersome performance review can turn into a worthwhile discussion, yet the most transparent, fair system can quickly turn into WWIII if the parties decide war is inevitable. Approaching the process in the right energy state; you’ll be amazed at what a different conversation might occur,” he said.

Mistake # 3 — Getting bogged down in the detail

Reviews are all about the big picture — don’t get bogged down in detail over who should empty the dishwasher and what time exactly you sent that email.

Mr Hill said given you might only get the chance to sit down with your boss once or twice a year, keep things focused on the wider context.

Mistake # 4 — Focusing on the negatives

Bring me solutions, not problems, is a common business mantra for good reason. Mr Hill said most managers will tell you one of their biggest bugbears is employees who bring problems to the table.

“Sure, this is a good time to bring up things that aren’t working or are holding you back in your work, but rather than dump them on your boss, give them your ideas on fixing the problems at the same time. Again, this isn’t just a process for your boss alone, the best performance reviews are when responsibility is shared.”

Mistake # 5 — Assuming you’re on the same page 

Bad lines of communication are an unfortunate reality for plenty of businesses. If you’re laying out a new strategy in your review make sure you’re clear on what success looks like. That way, you won’t go off on a tangent and waste your time.

“Generally [mistakes happen] because we assumed understanding rather than checked. Especially on the big stuff — big projects and strategy — we need to reflect our approach back to the boss to ensure it’s in keeping with what they had in mind. It’ll save you a lot of time and effort if you do.”

What about the managers? 

Mr Hill said all the managers out there should take note the biggest mistake they can make is focusing on the past rather than the future. Treat it like a ‘preview’ rather than a ‘review’ he said — no one wants to be graded like a school report card.

“Most performance reviews make people happy or sad but actually don’t make them any better at their job. That’s the major issue — they should be previews rather than reviews”

The other common mistake made by managers is falling into the “lazy trap” of giving feedback only at review time.

“In high performing cultures feedback is a daily process. When people are doing things well immediacy in feedback is really important whether it’s positive or negative. Either way the closer to the event the feedback is attached the more effective the behaviour modification is.”

Is there a workplace issue you want to know more about? Email Victoria.Craw@news.com.au
related.description: IF YOUR workplace is like hundreds of others around the country — it’s that dreaded time again.
related.standFirst: THE middle of the year means that dreaded chat with your boss. But if you want pay rises and promotions it’s best to avoid these rookie mistakes.
related.subtitle: Pragmatic Thinking’s Darren Hill gives tips on how to nail your performance review

related.body:
Following his conviction on 12 counts of indecent assul this week, the 84-year-old also had his BAFTA Fellowship annulled and stands to lose a string of other honours including his OBE, handed to him by the Queen.

The once much-loved entertainer was inducted into the ARIA Hall of Fame in 2008.

Harris joins an ignoble list of celebrities who’ve had their honours received and then taken away over the years. Turns out it’s not all that common:

R&B pop duo Milli Vanilli

In 1990, pop duo Milli Vanilli (a.k.a Fabrice Morvan and Rob Pilatus) ­won the Grammy Award for Best New Artist for their album Girl You Know It’s True. It was later revealed that the only roles the pair had played in the creation of the hit album were appearing on the cover and lip-synching along to studio musicians in the video.

The duo was stripped of the award and eventually disappeared from the spotlight.

Miley Cyrus

Miley Cyrus was nominated for Best Song Written for a Soundtrack at the Grammys in 2009. The nod was for her hit song The Climb from Hannah Montana: The Movie, but she was disqualified just days after being nominated because the song was not originally penned for the film.

The Climb, while performed by a then-17-year-old Cyrus, was actually written by Jon Mabe and Jessi Alexander, who shopped the number around to other country music artists before it landed in Cyrus’s movie.

Alone Yet Not Alone

Small budget Christian movie Alone Yet Not Alone made headlines earlier this year when it was nominated for an Oscar for Best Song and later disqualified.

The film, which will be released on June 13, had the nomination yanked by the Motion Picture Academy after it discovered composer Bruce Broughton violated the rules by emailing voters and asking them to give it a listen.

Rihanna

Now, this one is awkward. Chris Brown won a total of five awards at the BET Awards in 2011 but one was accidentally awarded to ex-girlfriend Rihanna.

Luckily, RiRi wasn’t present to accept the award and Drake accepted it on her behalf. At the end of the show, host Kevin Hart announced that Brown had actually won the award.

Kelsey Martinovich

When Kelsey Martinovich was crowned Australia’s Next Top Model, it was a live-TV stuff-up of the highest order.

The trouble with Kelsey’s win, you might remember, is that host Sarah Murdoch had actually named the wrong girl. It was the other beautiful finalist, Amanda Ware, who’d earned the title.

“I feel sick,” Murdoch said upon realising the gaffe.

While Martinovich’s reign only lasted a few fleeting moments, at least the cringiness of the situation made us feel like we were enduring it in slow motion.
related.description: THE inevitable has been confirmed for disgraced entertainer Rolf Harris, who was officially stripped of his ARIA Hall of Fame induction on Tuesday.

related.body:
The fourth Transformers movie hit cinemas last week and has been killing it at the box office, raking in over $300 million worldwide so far.

That’s not bad for a film that’s been described by one critic as “excruciating a movie as is likely to be experienced by anyone, anywhere”.

Think that review’s harsh? Wait till you read these. As a community service, we present to you the most damning reviews ofMichael Bay’s Transformers: Age of Extinction:

“The urine you discharge during the inevitable pi** break is guaranteed to flow better than any dialogue in this near three-hour movie.” Digital Spy.

“If I could ask (Michael) Bay one question, it would be: Why can’t you make a better movie? At the end, I wished I could make a citizen’s arrest for assault with intent to bore to death.” Boston Herald.

“Bay has said that this film will kick off a second trilogy of Transformers movies — and I think he’s serious. That means there will be (at least) two more of these things. God help us all.” Entertainment Weekly

“Even by the low IQ standards of the three previous Transformers films, Transformers: Age of Extinction is grave and exceptionally stupid, with a plot as bewildering and incoherent as a caffeinated 5-year-old’s explanation of the multiverse theory.” The Blade.

“This tepid fourth instalment is actually an improvement over 2011’s ridiculous Dark of the Moon entry. But that’s like saying the flu is better than pneumonia.” Us Weekly.

“Sitting through Transformers: Age of Extinction is like binge-watching the death of the human spirit. It is a crushing and relentless experience, one where even the comedic relief bits are nihilistically hateful.” Badass Digest

“Transformers: Age of Extinction also has appalling dialogue (“My face is a warrant!” says James Nesbitt lookalike Titus Welliver as an FBI agent); exploitative and deplorable representations of women; ridiculous, hard to follow and un-self-aware action sequences; very little humour (unless you count the guffaws) and racial stereotyping. In other words, it’s a Michael Bay movie.” Film Ink.

So how does director Michael Bay feel about these shocking reviews?

“They love to hate, and I don’t care; let them hate,” Bay said to MTV .

“They’re still going to see the movie! I think it’s good to get a little tension. Very good.”

But the question remains, if the reviews are SO bad, why is it that so many people are paying money to go and see it?

According to Polygon’s  Chris Plante, it’s because Transformers movies are “arguably, universally loved”.

“Some people watch Transformers to reconnect with their childhood, others because it’s a familiar action series that they associate with ‘things we do in the summertime’ and others — and this is on a subconscious level — take pleasure in watching a world like ours, but in which the lines between good and evil are clear, and good triumphs all,” Plante said.

If you’ve seen Transformers: Age of Extinction let us know what you thought of it in the comments section below.
related.description: IT’S THE movie that everyone’s talking about, but for all of the wrong reasons.
related.standFirst: REVIEWERS have described the latest  movie as “tepid”, “like having the flu” and “incoherent”. These are the best reviews of the most popular movie in our box office.
related.subtitle: ‘Transformers: Age of Extinction’ is a box office success but critics hate it

In a one-hour special, Rolf Harris: Dark Star, which aired Tuesday night on Seven News, Melissa Doyle, together with Europe correspondent Hugh Whitfeld detailed the rise and fall of Harris — from national treasure to international disgrace.

Australian woman Nina Bekker claims she was attacked by Harris at age 14 during a chance encounter in the late 1970s.

“Rolf Harris hasn’t just groomed his victims. He has groomed their families and he has groomed the whole community by creating a character who’s innocent. An affable gentleman,” Bekker, now 50, tells Seven reporter David Richardson.

“That’s what happens. Rolf Harris has become a master of impressions.”

Richardson asked Ms Bekker: “So he’s groomed the world?”

Bekker responded: “Absolutely. Yep. You suckers! That’s what he’s done. He’s groomed the world.”

Ms Bekker’s exclusive interview with Seven comes as the veteran entertainer was yesterday found guilty of sexually assaulting four teenage school girls over an almost 20-year period with a jury unanimously declaring him guilty on all charges.

Ms Bekker recounted the alleged assault in terrifying detail, saying she was staying with her family at the Glenview Motel on Sydney’s north shore when Harris entered the dining room with In The Wild presenter Harry Butler, whom she recognised and was keen to interview for a school project.

“I thought ‘what an unreal opportunity to get to interview Harry Butler’ ... and I thought ‘woo hoo, top marks for this’,” she said on air last night.

“Harry Butler agreed to allow me to interview him and at 14 even though I didn’t really know who he was, that was a pretty cool opportunity. So I left the restaurant with Harry Butler to do an interview and Rolf Harris followed us.

“As soon as we were in the lift Rolf Harris started to touch me. He was basically getting his fingers and tickling my ribs and pinching my bottom and I was very uncomfortable with that.”

Ms Bekker claimed that as they stepped out of the lift Harris only got more brazen, following her to her room.

“As I was walking along he had his tummy placed against me and he had reached around my shoulders and he has his hands over my breast. And he was saying like a kind of poem which basically referred to my breasts as ripe plums.

“And then he was saying ‘oh give Rolfy a cuddle. Rolfy deserves a cuddle, give Rolfy a hug’.”

The then-teenager told Richardson that she was eventually able to flee the room and conduct her interview with Butler, who had no idea what was going on.

Richardson asked: “Looking back now, do you believe you were the first?”

Bekker responded: “Absolutely not. His actions were so fluid and quick. He had such a limited time and he just went straight into it and he was absolutely rehearsed ... he’s rehearsed and rehearsed and rehearsed.”

Bekker, who went on to become a youth worker, claimed she tried to lodge a complaint with police in 1984 which went nowhere, resulting in her going “off the rails”.

“Self-hatred, doubts, anger, anger, years and years of anger. I’m still angry ... an angry person,” she said, adding that until this week she hadn’t even told her daughter of the attack.

“You can’t take away what he’s done. There’s no correcting it. I’m 50. This happened when I was 14. There’s no way to fix that. I don’t have a second chance at this. I never had a second chance.”

Harris will be sentenced at the end of this week.
related.description: SEVEN women gave evidence as witnesses of groping incidents involving Rolf Harris during his sex abuse trial. But there is one victim who has never spoken publicly of her ordeal, until now.
related.standFirst: AN Australian woman who claims she was attacked by Rolf Harris in the late 1970s has spoken out about the ordeal for the first time.

related.body:
She appeared to be disoriented, weakly pushing volleys into the net from a metre away, missing practise strokes and failing to pick up tennis balls that bounced her way.

When the warm-up ended, Williams was examined in her seat by medical staff, who checked her blood pressure. The delay was so long that one of her opponents, Kristina Barrois, asked the umpire whether she could warm up again.

The match eventually started, but Williams was still struggling. In the third game, she was broken to love after serving four double-faults. One of the best servers in the history of women’s tennis hit balls that bounced before reaching the net.

With the score at 0-40 in that game, umpire Kader Nouni climbed down from his chair and asked Williams whether she would able to continue. One point later, she walked to the side of the court holding hands with her doubles partner (and sister) Venus, ready to end the match.

“Ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, Miss Williams has to retire,” Nouni announced to the crowd. Williams wiped away tears as she trudged towards the exit.

According to the referee’s office, Williams’ withdrawal was due to a viral illness.

“I am heartbroken I’m not able to continue in the tournament,” she said in a statement afterwards. “I thought I could rally this morning because I really wanted to compete, but this bug just got the best of me.”

Venus Williams confirmed her sister was sick.

“Unfortunately, Serena has been feeling unwell for the past few days and she just couldn’t play to her potential today,” she said. “I’m really proud of her for trying because we just love playing doubles together.”

Venus and Serena have won 13 Grand Slam doubles titles as a pair, including five at Wimbledon. In singles, 32-year-old Serena is the world number one, and has claimed 17 major championships.

“We were all looking forward to a great match. From the bottom of my heart, I thank all of the fans for their cheers and understanding,” she said. “I look forward to returning to Wimbledon next year.”

related.body:
The Today Show in the USA released its first of three reports last week exposing the dirty truth about what germs are lurking on planes and in airports.

Taking three different flights across the country, each on a different major airline, their team gathered samples from various stages of the journey including check-in, armrests and toilets with some concerning results.

The first shock — security screening.

Tests of two bins used to collect shoes, bags and other personal belongings that go through the x-ray machine revealed the presence of dangerous bacteria. One bin was found to have foecal matter at levels high enough to make people sick.

Dr. Robert Glatter, an emergency doctor at New York’s Lenox Hill Hospital told the show: “We’re talking about skin or soft-tissue infections, which can potentially lead to overwhelming infections in your bloodstream”.

But that’s just the beginning.

Once on the plane, the germ situation isn’t any more comforting. Crumbs on the aisle floors and mysterious stains on the seats had the team questioning how thorough the cleaners were between flights.

The most shocking find was the levels of bacteria found on the tray tables. Covered in germs, one flight attendant recalled seeing them being used as change tables for babies nappies.

While all the armrests came back negative, tests on the seat belts were filthy including one that showed the presence of “human bacteroides”.

“These are bacteria that live in our gut and our intestines. These are dangerous bacteria that cause serious infections”, said Glatter.

Another study conducted by Auburn University found that harmful and potentially deadly bacteria like MRSA and E. coli survive for days on arm rests, toilet flush handles, tray tables, window shades, seats and seat pockets.

So how can you prevent picking up one of these dreaded bugs on a plane?

Carry sanitiser and wipe down your tray table before use, wash your hands frequently, don’t walk barefoot on the carpet and check the back seat pocket before use for any nasty leftovers from the previous flight.
related.description: IF YOU thought using the bathrooms on a plane was a tad risky, you’ll be shocked at these latest findings.

related.body:
They meet in bushland or on a beach, out of sight of passers-by, under cover of darkness, to place their bets.

Then, they cheer as two dogs, specifically bred to fight, tear each other apart until one of them dies.

This is the brutal reality of Australia’s underground dog fighting rings.

Evidence of these clandestine clubs usually evades police and animal welfare advocates, but a new, barbaric club has been exposed overnight.

The Newcastle Herald reports that a highly organised dog-fighting ring is operating in the Hunter Valley, with up to 50 members attending and gambling thousands of dollars on matches every few months.

Participants use generators to power lights and set up temporary fencing to create a fighting ring in remote bush locations around Oyster Cove, near Anna Bay.

“Most of the time they will break it up with a whip or a big stick, but I have seen dogs fight to the death,” an insider told the Herald. 

‘‘Big money changes hands and the dogs belong to the people who bring them.”

But the Australian representative of the international Anti-DogFighting Campaign says this is not an isolated incident, and she knows of other hot spots for the illegal blood sport on the outskirts of Brisbane and Melbourne.

The Queensland woman, who asked for her name not to be published, said some clubs were more vicious than others, and that they ranged from regulated matches that are treated like a sport to barbaric street brawls where the animals fight to the death.

“There are the street fighters that will meet up at any random place, they will have the fight then walk off,” she said.

She described one fight that occurred in a coastal town north of Brisbane on Anzac Day last year where club members were told the location of the fight via text message 30 minutes before the event. They met on a beach where the dogs fought to the death, with the carcass of the losing animal thrown into the ocean.

“They are very, very brutal,” she said.

On the other end of the spectrum are the more organised groups, whose members call themselves “gentlemen fighters”.

“The gentlemen fighters look after their dogs, as such. They’re well-fed, kennelled, they always have water. When you can see there’s a loser, the fight stops,” the campaigner said.

“They see it as a sport, as such — but I see no difference.”

She said ring leaders used long, flat “break sticks” to pry open dogs’ jaws, they trained the dogs on treadmills, and administered steroids to the animals to pump them up for fights. Owners also conduct their own surgery to patch up their injured fighters, to evade the suspicion of vets.

American Staffordshire terriers are popular breeds to use in dog fights, as are agile pitbulls.

“They’re the most loving dogs. All they want to do is please,” the campaigner said.

The RSPCA website says there are “many” dog fighting rings across the country.

“These (rings) are often associated with gambling activities and other illegal practices, such as drug dealing and firearms,” the site states. “Dogs … are often specifically bred for fighting and are trained to be extremely aggressive towards other dogs.”

RSPCA Victoria told news.com.au that it had received reports of dog fighting in Melbourne.

“Dog fighting is most often linked with organised crime and, as an underground activity, it is difficult to locate and investigate,” inspectorate manager Allie Jalbert said.

“As such, complaints to RSPCA Victoria regarding dog fighting have been minimal and investigations have not resulted in sufficient evidence to substantiate cruelty charges in recent years.”

The Queenland anti-dog-fighting campaigner asked for anonymity in this story so she could continue to gather evidence against participants.

She tracks their activities by befriending people on Facebook, and then shares what information she gathers with the RSPCA. She said she had passed on names of suspected dog fighters in the Hunter Valley previously.

She also tracks dog fighters in the US.

“My evidence has been responsible for a few busts,” she said.

A police spokesman said the Port Stephens Local Area Command, which looks after Oyster Cove, had not received any reports of dog fighting in the area, either formally or anecdotally.

An RSCPA NSW spokesman for the area said he was not aware of any dog fighting, but said he would investigate the Oyster Cove report.

“We hear the odd rumour but we’ve never been able to get any evidence,” he said.

He encouraged those who may have any details about it to inform the RSCPA through its website.

Do you know more? Email james.law@news.com.au

related.body:
Davao City Mayor Rodrigo Duterte, who has been dubbed the real-life Punisher, has received local adoration and international condemnation for using vigilante methods to tackle crime.

For the uninitiated, The Punisher is a comic book and movie character who wages a one-man war against the mob, using murder, kidnapping, extortion and torture to crush criminal elements.

Mr Duterte, who was elected for his seventh term last year, earnt the “Punisher” reputation by encouraging the killing of criminals without first finding them guilty in court.

Over the past 26 years, the crime fighting mayor has turned Davao City from the murder capital of The Philippines to what tourism organisations now spruik as “the most peaceful city in southeast Asia”.

The mayor has long been linked to the so-called Davao Death Squad, a vigilante outfit responsible for the execution of drug traffickers, petty criminals, gang members and other lawless elements. More than 700 people went missing between 2005 and 2008, presumed killed by the squad.

Mr Duterte has never publicly endorsed the squad’s behaviours, but his public comments about cleaning up the streets appear to condone its violent activities.

“If you are doing an illegal activity in my city, if you are a criminal or part of a syndicate that preys on the innocent people of the city, for as long as I am the mayor, you are a legitimate target of assassination,” Mr Duterte said in 2009.

In a 2012 press conference, Mr Duterte offered a $120,000 reward for whoever could bring him the decapitated head of an alleged gang leader, the Daily Mail reports. He offered an extra $24,000 if the head could be brought in a bag of ice, “so it won’t smell so bad”.

His war against rice smugglers raised eyebrows internationally in February when he told a Senate committee that he would “gladly kill” an accused smuggler.

“I want smuggling of rice in my city stopped,” he said at an earlier press conference. “But if you still do not stop your smuggling activities, I will kill you.”

He has also issued a shoot-to-kill order against any lawless elements in Davao City and instructed security forces to shoot any looters after Typhoon Haiyan hit last year.

Davao is the world’s largest city in terms of land area, with a population over 1.5 million, but international database numbeo.com has named it the world’s “fourth safest place”.

Despite this, human rights advocates, including Amnesty, have slammed Mr Duterte’s take-no-prisoners response to the city’s crime.

Commission on Human Rights chairwoman Loretta Ann Rosales said Mr Duterte’s threats were “sending the wrong signals that invite vigilantism”, according to Rappler.

“Simply put, ordering law enforcement officers to ‘shoot to kill’ suspects, or threatening smugglers to leave your area out of their operations or ‘I will kill you’, is no way for a local chief executive to lead,” she said.

But Mr Duterte has always been unapologetic about his methods.

“I admit I am 100 per cent terrorist but I am terrorising only the drug pushers, kidnappers, hold-up gangs and other criminals,” he said on TV in 2003. “Kidnappers, drug pushers from other places, I dare you to come over here so that I can finish you off.”

Thousands of residents staged a mobilization here in Davao City to urge Mayor Rodrigo Duterte to run for president. pic.twitter.com/oyzgdAuKsj

— karlos manlupig (@karlosmanlupig) March 29, 2014 

Now, there is a legion of supporters who are keen to see Mr Duterte become the country’s next president.

In March, thousands turned up to Davao City’s Rizal Park to push him to run to replace President Benigno Aquino III, who steps down in 2016, Rappler reports.

The Pilipinas 2016 Duterte Movement has collected more than four million signatures and leader Mar Masanguid has described him as an “iron-fisted leader with heart”.

Mr Duterte has always rejected suggestions that he run for president, but that has not stopped this grassroots movement.
related.description: A NOTORIOUS mayor who has taken law enforcement into his own hands is being urged to run for president of the Philippines.
related.standFirst: HE’S the badass mayor who used vigilante justice to turn his city from the murder capital into one of the region’s safest. Now his supporters want him to become president.
related.subtitle: The Philippines’ real-life Punisher, Davao City Mayor Rodrigo Duterte, urged to run for president

The winning ticket, which is yet to be claimed, was sold at Princess Road News and Lotto, Balga, in Perth’s north-east.

Lotterywest is still waiting to hear from WA’s newest multi-millionaire.

It is the fourth Division 1 Lotto win in just three days and was the nation’s only Division One winner.

Lotterywest spokesperson Pina Compagnone said last night’s win follows a run of Division 1 Lotto wins in WA.

Two of these prizes, each worth $1.2 million, were from last weekend’s Saturday Lotto Superdraw and another $1 million win from Monday night’s Lotto draw.

“This is an incredible result for WA and we are delighted that we have added another local player to our Division 1 winners’ tally which has now reached 40 for the year,” she said.

Ms Compagnone said the $10 million win was the second largest in WA for the year after a couple from Perth’s southern suburbs collected a $15 million OZ Lotto prize in April.

A further 40,270 other WA players collected an OZ Lotto prize last night in the draw’s other Divisions.

Lotterywest encourages all players who may have purchased a ticket in the draw to check them as soon as possible for the winning numbers 10, 19, 44, 20, 15, 1 and 11.

Lotto winners are not the only ones who benefited from OZ Lotto’s jackpot run, with Lotterywest raising millions to support the WA community from the draws.

Local groups to benefit from Lotterywest funding include the WADJAK Northside Aboriginal community Group located in Balga. The group received a $14,865 Lotterywest Grant last year to help with the development of a resource centre for community members living in Perth’s northern suburbs.

WA players will have another chance to win big in Lotto tonight with Double Win Day.

Double Win Day will mean prizes across all Divisions in Wednesday Lotto (Draw 3361) will be doubled with a potential Division 1 winner taking home a topped up $2 million! Make sure to purchase your tickets by 6pm today to be in it to win it.

Tickets are available from Lotterywest retailers across WA, online and on mobile devices via Play Online at www.lotterywest.wa.gov.au

Lotterywest’s Spirit of Our Community

related.body:
Her legs are crippled by arthritis, her back is poor, her hearing not what it used to be but the Welsh sculptress has shuffled into the room to be helped into the same front row seat almost every day for seven weeks.

One can only imagine what has been going through her mind as day after day, week after week, the secret life of her husband Rolf Harris was laid bare in the most graphic of detail.

Nothing was sacred: from the size of his penis, to sexual affairs and his long-held and sick desire for little girls in bikinis.

And with the guilty verdict, Welsh sculptress Alwen Hughes joined an unenviable wives club, the unwitting spouses of shamed sex offender husbands.

VICTIMS HAPPY: Tonya Lee “excited” as Rolf’s brother “badgers” witness 

JURY NOT TOLD: The other harassment claims against Rolf Harris 

ROLF HARRIS: How the predator was treated in the UK press 

Even after his questioning by police Alwen remained steadfast by his side, similar to Robyn Gardiner, the celebrity agent wife of Aussie TV star Robert Hughes of Hey Dad! fame, who stood by her man even after he was charged with sexually abusing four girls over a 20-year period.

Gardiner didn’t attend court in May when the 65-year-old was sentenced to six years jail, but that was not, her lawyer said, because she no longer supported him, but to avoid the media.

“We knew it was going to be a difficult day and we didn’t want her to be under any more stress,” lawyer Greg Walsh said of Gardiner. “We appreciated members of the media would perceive it as being a lack of support for Robert but that was not the case.”

Gardiner and Hughes appear to be standing beside their husbands even after they are found guilty.

Not so the wife of British celebrity publicist Max Clifford, 71. His wife of four years Jo divorced him in a hearing lasting less than two minutes after he was jailed this year for eight years for indecent assault of four women.

In the divorce proceedings when asked about the grounds for divorce she declared “unreasonable behaviour” and said it affected her health.

“I suffered from stress and heart palpitations and saw a specialist,” she declared.
related.description: SITTING diligently in the front row of Room 2 at Southwark Crown Court, Alwen Hughes has been a pillar of support.
related.standFirst: AFTER a guilty verdict, Alwen Hughes has now joined an unenviable wives club – the unwitting spouses of shamed sex offender husbands.
related.subtitle: Rolf Harris’s wife Alwen Hughes joins unenviable wives club

related.body:
Here’s how the world reacted.

THE MAN HIMSELF

Even Kyrgios was surprised at how well he played.

“I was in a bit of zone out there, I played some extraordinary tennis, I served at a really good level out there,” he said.

“I’m a normal kid like any 19-year-old who likes to play on his Xbox. The big stage is something I thrive on.

“Never did I think a week ago I was going to make the quarter-finals of Wimbledon in my first appearance.”

Have to do it all again tomorrow and I can't wait! First @Wimbledon & I'm in the last 8 club!! #HaveThat

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

Slowly sinking in. What an unreal day! Thanks to Simon, AK, Anne-Marie & @JohnMorris1982 for all their hard work. Massive team effort. #BOOM

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

HIS MUM

Kyrgios’ own mother didn’t think he could beat the world No. 1.

“My mum said in an interview she thought Rafa was too good ... that made me mad and spurred me on,” Kyrgios told the BBC.

MORE: The shot that stunned the world 

MORE: Giant killer Kyrgios takes out Nadal 

Nick Kyrgios’ quarter-final match against world No. 9 Canadian Milos Raonic will start after midnight tonight AEST. 

THE OPPONENT

The ever-gracious Rafael Nadal heaped praise on Kyrgios, conceding “he play better than me”.

“When you have an opponent that he decides to serve and to hit every ball very strong, you are in trouble,” Nadal said.

“I didn’t play really bad.”

Asked what the dual Wimbledon champion would be doing with his unexpected spare time, Nadal said: “Congratulations to him. For me, beach. For me, I going to go to the beach in Mallorca.”

THE LEGEND

John McEnroe came up with a massive call, saying, “We have found the next guy in the men’s game.”

“The last guy I saw like this was Boris Becker with no fear and believing that they can win this thing,” McEnroe said.

“You are watching someone who is going to be a big star in the future.”

Aussie Aussie Aussie Oi Oi Oi. @NickKyrgios the giant slayer! #wimbledon #believe pic.twitter.com/H8xt7lGRPh

— Pat Cash (@TheRealPatCash) July 1, 2014 

Nick Kyrgios- the Wonder from "Down Under" shocks #1 Nadal at Wimbledon. Welcome to the World Stage- YOUTH!! Great effort.

— Jimmy Connors (@JimmyConnors) July 1, 2014 

THE MEGASTAR AND A COUPLE OF PMs

Actor Hugh Jackman, Prime Minister Tony Abbott and former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser were among the famous Aussies to show their support for our newest star.

Aussie Aussie Aussie @NickKyrgios. Such composure and class! But hard off to @RafaelNadal ... one of the greatest of all time!

— Hugh Jackman (@RealHughJackman) July 1, 2014 

Extraordinary performance @NickKyrgios. Australia couldn't be prouder of you - what a win & what an amazing attitude! #Wimbledon2014

— Tony Abbott (@TonyAbbottMHR) July 1, 2014 

Wimbledon 2014: Nick Kyrgios defeats Rafael Nadal in four-set upset. Victory extraordinary, congratulations Kyrgios. http://t.co/F7DImcNLWm

— Malcolm Fraser (@MalcolmFraser12) July 1, 2014 

THE TWITTERATI

And this is how the rest of the world reacted...

Even though my TV show premiered tonight!!! I regretfully say this was by far the best thing on television. #Kyrgios pic.twitter.com/HhUockXJel

— Andy Lee (@andy_lee) July 1, 2014 

Now that was worth staying up for. @NickKyrgios take a bow. Remarkable play. #Wimbledon #aussiepride

— Steve Smith (@stevesmith49) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios is the 1st teenager to beat a world #1 at a Grand Slam since Nadal def Federer at 2005 French Open. Congrats Nick. Stunning effort.

— Darren Cahill (@darren_cahill) July 1, 2014 

Three weeks ago, Nick Kyrgios was losing in the first round of a Challenger event in Nottingham. To world 185 John-Patrick Smith. Meteor

— tomfordyce (@tomfordyce) July 1, 2014 

Nick #Kyrgios is the first player outside the top 100 to beat the world No.1 since Andrei Olhovsky v Jim Courier 1992 pic.twitter.com/veQynIAKlt

— BBC Tennis (@bbctennis) July 1, 2014

related.title: World in shock over Aussie Nick

related.body:
Nick Kyrgios’ audacious between-the-legs winner against Rafael Nadal has made global headlines, with some news outlets describing it as the shot of the year.

MATCH REPORT: GIANT KILLER KYRGIOS BEATS NADAL 

BOOM BOOM TIME: MCENROE, CASH BACK KYRGIOS TO WIN IT ALL 

SISTER ACT: FAMILY SO PROUD OF NICK 

World applauds Kyrgios’ ‘shot of the year’

The “tweener” perfectly summed up Kyrgios’s approach at Wimbledon — fearless, fun and a finesse-to-firepower ratio to match it with the world’s elite.

Commentators including John McEnroe and Tim Henman described Kyrgios’ shot as “beyond belief” and the “shot of the year”. The world’s tennis media thought likewise.

Have to do it all again tomorrow and I can't wait! First @Wimbledon & I'm in the last 8 club!! #HaveThat

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

“Kyrgios played probably the shot of the year, let alone the shot of Wimbledon, as he nonchalantly knocked a return drop-shot through his legs for the point,” wrote Mike Singer of CBS Sports.

“It takes some kind of something to try that shot when you’re up a set, deadlocked in the second at three games each against the No. 1 player in the world.

“Kyrgios maintained his moxie to pull the stunning upset. It’s the first time Nadal has lost to a teenager since 2007.”

Slowly sinking in. What an unreal day! Thanks to Simon, AK, Anne-Marie & @JohnMorris1982 for all their hard work. Massive team effort. #BOOM

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

'I like to give the people a bit of a show' #nickkyrgios

— Paul McNamee (@PaulFMcNamee) July 1, 2014 

Sports Illustrated’s Courtney Nguyen concurred.

“The 19-year-old Australian wildcard grabbed headlines last week when he saved nine match points to rally from two-sets to love down to beat No. 14 Richard Gasquet for his first top-15 victory,” Nguyen wrote. “Now, he’ll grab some more after hitting an audacious front-side tweener in the second set against Nadal.

“The kid is a shot-maker.”

Chris Chase, writing for USA Today

, joked Kyrgios’ was “clearly cowed by his surroundings” when playing the between-the-legs shot on the biggest stage, against the biggest opponent in the biggest match of his career.

“Remember the name Nick Kyrgios,” Chase wrote. “The 19-year-old Australian has the necessary combination of skills, savvy, swag and serve to be a major player in the post-Federer/Nadal/Djokovic generation.

Aussie Aussie Aussie @NickKyrgios. Such composure and class! But hard off to @RafaelNadal ... one of the greatest of all time!

— Hugh Jackman (@RealHughJackman) July 1, 2014 

Incredible win @NickKyrgios Defeating world no.1 @RafaelNadal to move through to @Wimbledon #QuarterFinals Amazinggg!! #AussiePride

— Sally Fitzgibbons (@Sally_Fitz) July 1, 2014 

“On Tuesday, Kyrgios set foot on Centre Court for the first time to play the world No. 1 in Rafael Nadal. He was clearly cowed by his surroundings.

“Kyrgios won’t be 20 until next April. He was the youngest player in the men’s draw at Wimbledon and won three matches before taking the opening set against Nadal. Though he’s still a long way from contending at Slams, he’s a player to watch in the future, and not just when he goes through the legs.”

John Branch, writing for the New York Times, was similarly I pressed with Kyrgios’ outing, noting he had become the “lowest-ranked player to beat Nadal since No. 690 Joachim Johansson beat him in Stockholm in 2006.”

“Until the evening shadows fell on Centre Court Tuesday, the last time a teenager beat a No. 1 player at a Grand Slam event was at the 2005 French Open,” Branch wrote. “The winner was Rafael Nadal, over Roger Federer, a couple of days after Nadal’s 19th birthday.

Wildcard Nick Kyrgios just beat World No. 1 Nadal! Hats off. Well played champ.

— Virat Kohli (@imVkohli) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios is the 1st teenager to beat a world #1 at a Grand Slam since Nadal def Federer at 2005 French Open. Congrats Nick. Stunning effort.

— Darren Cahill (@darren_cahill) July 1, 2014 

“Nick Kyrgios, a 19-year-old wildcard entrant from Australia, joined Nadal by beating him in the fourth round of Wimbledon.

“All limbs and panache, Kyrgios battered Nadal with big serves, boundless reach and boyish enthusiasm. Ranked No. 144 in the world, but rising fast, Kyrgios looked immune to the pressure and fearless with his shots.”

Aussie Aussie Aussie Oi Oi Oi. @NickKyrgios the giant slayer! #wimbledon #believe pic.twitter.com/H8xt7lGRPh

— Pat Cash (@TheRealPatCash) July 1, 2014 

Nick Kyrgios- the Wonder from "Down Under" shocks #1 Nadal at Wimbledon. Welcome to the World Stage- YOUTH!! Great effort.

— Jimmy Connors (@JimmyConnors) July 1, 2014 

Just watching the 3rd set of @NickKyrgios V Rafa. What a effort by this young gun of aussie tennis, keep it going mate

— Scott Pendlebury (@SP_10) July 1, 2014 

I think it's now safe to change the tag line of #NKRising to #NKRisen ..@NickKyrgios

— Mahesh Bhupathi (@Maheshbhupathi) July 1, 2014 

The win by @NickKyrgios over Rafael Nadal. A bigger upset than Mark Philippoussis not finding his future wife on Age Of Love. Well done son.

— Ryan Fitzgerald (@FitzySA) July 1, 2014 

Well done to @NickKyrgios just woke up to the news. What a great effort to beat the world no1. #nowbringithome

— Anthony Watmough (@AnthonyWatmough) July 1, 2014 

Extraordinary performance @NickKyrgios. Australia couldn't be prouder of you - what a win & what an amazing attitude! #Wimbledon2014

— Tony Abbott (@TonyAbbottMHR) July 1, 2014 

Even though my TV show premiered tonight!!! I regretfully say this was by far the best thing on television. #Kyrgios pic.twitter.com/HhUockXJel

— Andy Lee (@andy_lee) July 1, 2014 

Now that was worth staying up for. @NickKyrgios take a bow. Remarkable play. #Wimbledon #aussiepride

— Steve Smith (@stevesmith49) July 1, 2014 

Nick kyrgios u r the man, awesome win

— Dane Tilse (@DaneTilse) July 1, 2014 

What a performance by @NickKyrgios Absolutely outstanding

— Laurie Fisher (@LordLaurie58) July 1, 2014

related.body:
New York University student Gerry Shalam found that out the hard way after he and his mates were filmed leaving a popular Manhattan eatery after a long brunch.

Their antics got the internet talking.

Not only did Mr Shalam make a fool of himself, but he pretended to be someone he clearly wasn’t — and was caught out big time.

In a YouTube video posted yesterday, the student, who had just eaten at Pranna, is seen outside a dry cleaners on 28th Street with three friends, one of whom is being supported against a wall and appears to be drunk.

But Mr Shalam realises he is being filmed and approaches the cameraman, demanding he put his camera away because his dad is in real estate and owns half the city.

The man filming the footage then asks the pair to move off his property when Gerry launches into this tirade:

“This your property?,” he says as he goes to on to claim his name is Gerry Adjmi.

“My dad is in f***ing’ real estate, you’re gonna tell me this your property? My dad owns half of f***ing Manhattan.”

He also claims he also has both the police and Mayor Bill DeBlasio on his side. Oh and he’s apparently a lawyer too.

“You think a guy who does real estate doesn’t own the cops?”.

But if that isn’t bad enough; surprise, surprise it turns out Gerry Adjmi isn’t who he says he is at all.

Despite deleting all his social media accounts, US website The Smoking Gun  discovered he isn’t actually who he says he is.

As it turns out the drunken student is actually Gerry Shalam, a New Jersey man whose father Lou is a garment industry executive, and his mother Frieda an event co-ordinator and member of the Allenhurst Borough zoning and planning board.

The video, and his apparent claim to fame has attracted a raft of attention on social media with some people calling him a “terrible man child” while others called his behaviour disgusting.

#GerryShalam -BWAAAAAAA!

— Randall Ellis (@rketexas) July 1, 2014 

Gerry Shalam is actually a student of #NYU. No surprise that a self-indulgent capitalist is already attending there http://t.co/f7hV8U0Zse

— Donithan (@trollshevikism) July 1, 2014 

So looks like the drunken NYU students dad who owns half of Manhattan, doesn't actually own half of Manhattan. #gerryshalam

— Tom Strong-Grinsell (@TomSG_) July 1, 2014 

That terrible manchild who drunkenly proclaimed his father owns half of manhattan is from, of course, New Jersey: http://t.co/2KGm1Yk0QJ

— Olivia Nuzzi (@Olivianuzzi) July 1, 2014 

This whole Gerry Shalam thing is disgusting. I hope he gets expelled from NYU

— Storey (@storey_ofmylife) July 1, 2014 

And while Mr Shalam may be regretting his behaviour, at least he’s not quite as bad as the YouTube clip makes him out to be.

The 20-year-old co-founded a charitable organisation called Brothers Helping Others that helps low-income immigrant families in Asbury Park, New Jersey.

He is also not totally incorrect regarding the status of the Adjmi family who are indeed wealthy and also in real estate.
related.description: HERE’S the first lesson of the internet — what goes on stays there forever and if you’re going to act like a drunken fool, then this is what happens.
related.standFirst: HERE’S the first lesson of the internet — what goes on stays there forever, so it’s best not to act like New York’s biggest jerk.
related.subtitle: New York student Gerry Shalam becomes the talk of the internet after embarrassing himself in viral video

related.body:
The front crossed the South West coast overnight, dumping heavy rain across much of the South West of the state, with a top fall of 52mm at Payndale near Donnybrook.

Most centres in the region received between 30mm-50mm.

Jarrahwood had 51mm, Acton Park, 43mm, Capel 41mm, Busselton 37mm and Manjimup 32mm.

Perth recorded 18mm after heavy rain started falling at about 8.20am.

Falls were even heavier in southern and coastal suburbs, with Jandakot reaching 40mm, Garden Island 22mm, and Dwellingup, 97km south of Perth, 27mm, Champion Lakes 21mm, Swanbourne 20mm and Mandurah 12mm. Lancelin, north of Perth has had 20mm

A thick blanket of showers settled over the city from early today, promising more rain before it eases off this afternoon.

Some rain has already reached agricultural areas, with Wandering in the Great Southern recording 8mm and Katanning 4mm.

In the Central Wheatbelt, Badgingarra and Geraldton have both recorded 9mm.

The downpour made driving conditions horrendous with a spate of minor crashes causing problems across the city traffic grid.

TRAFFIC: Check our traffic site 

A multiple-car pile-up on Marmion Avenue, southbound in Tamala Park in Perth’s far north, caused severe problems just after 8am, but has since been cleared.

More recently, a truck breakdown on Beeliar Drive, eastbound, at the Kwinana Freeway intersection is causing delays.

A band of heavy showers was visible on the Bureau of Meteorology radar, with the most severe downpour having moved over the city by about 9am and heading inland.

However further showers are clearly visible and are expected to continue through the morning.

Perth can expect a wet day, with rain clearing later in the afternoon and a maximum of 20C.

The Bureau tipped between 15mm and 25mm for the city and some showers are forecast for the rest of the week and heading into the weekend.

THE WEEK AHEAD

Min 10C

Showers.

Monday

Min 10C

Max 18C

Showers.

Max 17C

Possible shower.

related.body:
Here’s how the world reacted.

THE MAN HIMSELF

Even Kyrgios was surprised at how well he played.

“I was in a bit of zone out there, I played some extraordinary tennis, I served at a really good level out there,” he said.

“I’m a normal kid like any 19-year-old who likes to play on his Xbox. The big stage is something I thrive on.

“Never did I think a week ago I was going to make the quarter-finals of Wimbledon in my first appearance.”

Have to do it all again tomorrow and I can't wait! First @Wimbledon & I'm in the last 8 club!! #HaveThat

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

Slowly sinking in. What an unreal day! Thanks to Simon, AK, Anne-Marie & @JohnMorris1982 for all their hard work. Massive team effort. #BOOM

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

HIS MUM

Kyrgios’ own mother didn’t think he could beat the world No. 1.

“My mum said in an interview she thought Rafa was too good ... that made me mad and spurred me on,” Kyrgios told the BBC.

MORE: The shot that stunned the world 

MORE: Giant killer Kyrgios takes out Nadal 

Nick Kyrgios’ quarter-final match against world No. 9 Canadian Milos Raonic will start after midnight tonight AEST. 

THE OPPONENT

The ever-gracious Rafael Nadal heaped praise on Kyrgios, conceding “he play better than me”.

“When you have an opponent that he decides to serve and to hit every ball very strong, you are in trouble,” Nadal said.

“I didn’t play really bad.”

Asked what the dual Wimbledon champion would be doing with his unexpected spare time, Nadal said: “Congratulations to him. For me, beach. For me, I going to go to the beach in Mallorca.”

THE LEGEND

John McEnroe came up with a massive call, saying, “We have found the next guy in the men’s game.”

“The last guy I saw like this was Boris Becker with no fear and believing that they can win this thing,” McEnroe said.

“You are watching someone who is going to be a big star in the future.”

Aussie Aussie Aussie Oi Oi Oi. @NickKyrgios the giant slayer! #wimbledon #believe pic.twitter.com/H8xt7lGRPh

— Pat Cash (@TheRealPatCash) July 1, 2014 

Nick Kyrgios- the Wonder from "Down Under" shocks #1 Nadal at Wimbledon. Welcome to the World Stage- YOUTH!! Great effort.

— Jimmy Connors (@JimmyConnors) July 1, 2014 

THE MEGASTAR AND A COUPLE OF PMs

Actor Hugh Jackman, Prime Minister Tony Abbott and former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser were among the famous Aussies to show their support for our newest star.

Aussie Aussie Aussie @NickKyrgios. Such composure and class! But hard off to @RafaelNadal ... one of the greatest of all time!

— Hugh Jackman (@RealHughJackman) July 1, 2014 

Extraordinary performance @NickKyrgios. Australia couldn't be prouder of you - what a win & what an amazing attitude! #Wimbledon2014

Wimbledon 2014: Nick Kyrgios defeats Rafael Nadal in four-set upset. Victory extraordinary, congratulations Kyrgios. http://t.co/F7DImcNLWm

And this is how the rest of the world reacted...

Even though my TV show premiered tonight!!! I regretfully say this was by far the best thing on television. #Kyrgios pic.twitter.com/HhUockXJel

— Andy Lee (@andy_lee) July 1, 2014 

Now that was worth staying up for. @NickKyrgios take a bow. Remarkable play. #Wimbledon #aussiepride

— Steve Smith (@stevesmith49) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios is the 1st teenager to beat a world #1 at a Grand Slam since Nadal def Federer at 2005 French Open. Congrats Nick. Stunning effort.

— Darren Cahill (@darren_cahill) July 1, 2014 

Three weeks ago, Nick Kyrgios was losing in the first round of a Challenger event in Nottingham. To world 185 John-Patrick Smith. Meteor

Nick #Kyrgios is the first player outside the top 100 to beat the world No.1 since Andrei Olhovsky v Jim Courier 1992 pic.twitter.com/veQynIAKlt
