related.body:
Nick Kyrgios has delivered the most outstanding performance of his fledgling career to shock world No 1 Rafael Nadal to reach the Wimbledon quarter-finals.

In a performance that reverberated from the heart of the All England Club across the world, the 19-year-old from Canberra has pulled off one of the greatest upsets in tennis history.

‘TWEENER’: THE SHOT THAT STUNNED THE WORLD 

BOOM BOOM TIME: MCENROE, CASH BACK KYRGIOS TO WIN IT ALL 

SISTER ACT: FAMILY SO PROUD OF NICK 

BOILOVER: RAFA PRAISES CONQUEROR KYRGIOS 

SCROLL DOWN TO RELIVE ALL THE ACTION FROM OUR LIVE BLOG

His 7-6 (7-5) 5-7 7-6 (7-5) 6-3 triumph over 14-time grand slam champion Nadal is the first time a teenager has beaten a world No 1 at the majors since 2005.

Ironically, the last player to manage the feat was Nadal, who beat Roger Federer at the French Open.

Watched from the members’ pavilion by Australian greats Rod Laver and Neale Fraser, Kyrgios dissolved in emotion after putting dual Wimbledon champion Nadal to the sword on the most famous tennis court on the planet with a trademark forehand winner.

His father George and sister Halimah shed tears in the players’ box as the reality of triumph took hold.

Icily composed, the Australian prodigy blasted his way to career-defining victory with 37 aces in a truly astounding serving performance.

By the end of the match, Nadal — grand slam tennis’s ultimate warrior — was broken and baffled on losing to world No 144 Kyrgios.

No male world No 1 had fallen to a player ranked outside the top 100 since Russian Andrei Olhovskiy, then ranked 193rd, stunned Jim Courier at Wimbledon 21 years ago.

If most of the 15,000 spectators around centre court were startled, Kyrgious was not surprised at all.

“You’ve got to believe you can win the match and I did,” Kyrgios said.

“You’ve got to believe that you can win and that’s the way I approached it.

“I think I was in a bit of zone out there, I played some extradorindary tennis, I served at a really good level out there.”

Revealing he had been irked by his mother Nill’s comment that Nadal would be too good, Kyrgios said: “I don’t know what she was thinking.”

“The mind is buzzing, I’m just going to enjoy this, soak it up and not even think about my next match.”

Kyrgios will tonight face Canadian eighth seed Milos Raonic for a spot in Friday’s semi-finals.

Few would be prepared to write of the youngster who over the past week created a huge impression.

First-round victory over Frenchman Stephane Robert was followed by a herculean effort to save a Wimbledon record nine match points against Richard Gasquet before he edged past Czech Jiri Vesely.

Those excellent performances were eclipsed by 2hrs, 58mins of sheer excellence against Nadal.

Kyrgios’s only quandary post-match was how to celebrate.

He clasped his face in his hands, dropped his racquet and stared in disbelief at his support group, led by coaches Simon Rae, Aaron Kellett and Josh Eagle.

“I didn’t know what to do, there are so many emotions,” he said.

“I didn’t know whether to drop my racquet, to drop to my knees..

“It is unbelievable.”

Contesting only his 14th match at senior level, Kyrgios blazed his way past a grand slam immortal — only two weeks after losing in the first round of a Nottingham Challenge.

Since then, Kyrgios has won nine matches in a row — five at third-tier Challenger level and now four more at the grand temple of the sport — to stand on the brink of history.

Kyrgios would become the lowest-ranked player in Wimbledon history to win the tournament, surpassing world No 125 Goran Ivanisevic’s 2001 victory over Pat Rafter.

The teenager is guaranteed at least $432,000 and a rankings rise to world No 66 — only 18 months after he stood at No 828.

A large reason for Kyrgios’s transformation the fringes to world-beater is his vastly improved fitness.

Another is his omnipotent serve, which has delivered a tournament-high of 113 aces and only 14 double faults against elite company.

His delivery was unworldly against shell-shocked Nadal, who only briefly latched onto it.

Kyrgios conceded only 12 points on his first set for the match. That statistic is simply breathtaking — especially against nine-time French Open champion Nadal.

Faced with the most ferocious grand slam competitor in the world, Kyrgios did not lose a single first serve point, winning all 19 while gunning down 13 aces and thumping 22 clean winners.

And he was able to maintain momentum despite Nadal using every piece of his devastating artillery.

Impossibly laid back, Kyrgios seized the ascendancy by blasting drives past frustrated Nadal.

Unfazed at letting slip a set point on Nadal’s serve in the 12th game, Kyrgios romped through the tiebreak after surging to a 4-0 lead.

Maintaining incredible serving levels, the teenager produced the shot of the tournament midway through the second set, with a half-volley winner — played off a bare baseliner and between the legs.

In control, he will long rue a sloppy service game at 6-5.

Despite holding game points, he dropped serve for the first time in the match — and the set.

Nadal’s relief was palpable as the Spanish bull jabbed his fist in delight. It had taken him 95 minutes to create the first crack in Kyrgios’s arsenal.

No player in international tennis saps energy from opponent like Nadal. Impressively, Kyrgios continued to trade heavyweight blows with the world champion.

And when the tyro twice survived serving crisis deep in the third set before unleashing a monster forehand return Nadal could only push wide to lose the tiebreak, centre court erupted.

Krygios’s father George and sister Halimah jumped to their feet in jubilation as he grabbed the third set with classic stand-and-deliver missile.

More assured with every exchange, Kyrgios pressured Nadal into unforced forehand error in the fourth game of the fourth set as the prospect of miracle victory became reality.

Serving for the match, Kyrgios didn’t blink, sealing the issue with an ace.

related.body:
Justice John Middleton told the court today a decision on whether the players would be joined to the proceedings would be made on Friday. A consequence of the move could be that their names are disclosed at some stage during the trial.

Lawyers for the AFL Players’ Association, which is representing the 34 players, have until 10.15am on Friday to decide whether to join voluntarily or face the prospect of being included at the orders of the court. The players’ legal team is headed by David Grace QC.

“As Mr Grace QC made clear in court this morning, the players’ key concern is their anonymity,” AFLPA acting CEO Ian Prendergast said.

“Despite speculation as to which players have received show-cause notices, the 34 players have not been named, and nor should they. The players do not believe that the action taken by the club and James Hird — the involvement in which they resisted — should change this.”

Justice Middleton today ruled a tranche of secret ASADA documents about the joint investigation and its agreements with the AFL must be released to Essendon’s lawyers.

The swathe of documents would include ASADA’s interim report and any document between the AFL and ASADA related to the drafting and publication of the interim report. Hird’s legal team was given the green light to subpoena the AFL and its integrity chief Brett Clothier to supply them with some documents it received and sent to ASADA.

But the main argument was if the players themselves would be forced to join the proceedings and then publicly outed.

David Grace QC acting for the players said they would suffer “irreparable reputational harm” if their identities were disclosed.

He said the players would not join the club and its coach James Hird in its action against ASADA joint investigation unless their anonymity could be guaranteed.

Mr Grace said he would seek suppression orders for the player if they were named as parties in the case.

Justice Middleton did not rule out forcing the players to join the action as respondents and said while he understood the difficult position they were in, “hard decisions” would have to be made.

Justice Middleton said the issue of joining players would be resolved on Friday.

He also flagged that Essendon and Hird’s lawyers should be provided with the documents ASADA chief Ben McDevitt used to make his decision to issue the show-cause notices.

Daniel Star acting for ASADA revealed to the court there were 45,000 documents which could be relevant to the court action under discovery. He said the agency would provide a full defence to Essendon’s lawyers by July 9.

The direction hearing will continue on Friday.

Earlier, lawyers for 34 former and current Bombers issued with doping show-cause notices met players yesterday to discuss the move.

“We are working through a process with the players to determine whether they (the players) are willing to be joined as a party to the proceedings,” AFL Players’ Association acting chief Ian Prendergast told the Herald Sun last night.

“It is still being considered by the legal team. While we weren’t interested in being joined to the action initially, we understand any decision made by the Federal Court will impact on the interests of players.”

The move came as suspended Bombers coach James Hird yesterday declared players and officials were robbed of the right to stay silent during interviews with AFL and Australian Sports Anti-Doping Authority investigators.

In documents lodged with the Federal Court, Hird claimed the Bombers should have been afforded “the common law right against self-incrimination”.

Instead, Hird says, players and officials were “under threat of censure and sanction” from the AFL if they did not “answer every question asked”.

New details of the legal challenges mounted against ASADA by Essendon and Hird were revealed in documents lodged by both camps ahead of today’s Federal Court hearing.

The Bombers, Hird and ASADA will return to court at 10.15am to finalise which documents must be made available to parties and whether the players will join.

Federal Court Justice John Middleton could also be asked to rule on an application by Hird for AFL integrity boss Brett Clothier to provide documents and give evidence in the witness box.

A statement of claim lodged by Hird yesterday included the allegation that ASADA provided draft versions of its interim report to the AFL before it was completed.

The report was used by the AFL Commission as the basis for the heaviest penalties in football history slapped on the Bombers on August 27 last year.

“On dates known to the respondent, ASADA provided drafts or versions of the Interim Report or parts thereof to the AFL,” the Hird statement alleges.

Hird’s statement claims that his legal team raised concerns about the validity of the AFL-ASADA investigation at the start of his interview at Etihad Stadium on April 16 last year.

It includes an exchange between Hird’s former legal counsel Tony Nolan SC and AFL investigator Abraham Haddad.

Nolan: “Now, gentlemen, we don’t want to enter into any debate as to the legal arguments today as to the nature of the joint investigation as distinct from two separate investigations. We’ll put that debate to the side for a later time, if necessary.”

Haddad: “Okay. That’s good.”

Nolan: “We understand that’s what you say.”

Hird is studying in France and will return to Melbourne on July 28. His 12-month suspension from Essendon expires on August 25.

The Tiger, who turned 23 last week, was caught speeding along the Peninsula Link Freeway at Moorooduc on December 7 last year.

Police alleged Martin was travelling 105kmh in the 100kmh zone near the Mornington-Tyabb Rd Bridge.

The tough midfielder did not show up at the Melbourne Magistrates Court today for the hearing and was fined without conviction in his absence.

Martin, who is thought to be on about $480,000 a year, has one month to pay the fine.

related.body:
And that seems to have been the template for a proven formula in this town. Organise a photograph with an AFL footballer and a woman in skimpy clothes and you have yourself a spot in the newspaper to promote your latest product/cause/event.

It could be anything from flavoured milk to ballet, but the formula has been used over and over again through the years.

So this week Retrogram has delved into the vault to find a few classic examples. If you can think of any we’ve missed, post a comment below or get in contact through Twitter at @_warwickgreen  and we’ll publish a selection next week.

1. DERMIE AND MILK

Victoria’s ailing dairy industry found a way to turn around its fortunes in the 1970s when it came up with the Big M concept. And a huge part of its marketing was “Big M Girls’’. How else was up-and-coming Hawks star Dermott Brereton going to manage to drink his carton of Big Chocolate back in 1983?

2. LETHAL AND MORE MILK

And without the help of Big M, Hawthorn skipper Leigh Matthews clearly would have struggled with this enormous football-shaped cake in 1982.

3. KB AND TEA 

The question is, did Kevin Bartlett take milk in his tea? Here he is pictured at Punt Rd Oval in 1980, getting a little help to promote Richmond’s sponsor, Tetley, and its upcoming Tetley Tea Party.

4. KOUTA, ANGE AND TOY CARS

Carlton pair Anthony Koutoufides and Ange Christou took time from pre-season training in 1999 to hop on to a Harley-Davidson with Hot Wheels representative Bianca Ross. Something to do with Hot Wheels sponsoring the V8 Supercar Showdown at the Australian Grand Prix apparently.

5. RHYCE SHAW AND FAST CARS

And while we’re on the Formula 1 and grid girls theme, then-Collingwood footballer Rhyce Shaw found himself at Fed Square in 2004. What else would you do but volunteer to have your head shaved by Fosters and Gillette GP reps Ana, Mieke and Katie and then hop into the cockpit of an FI car? Thumbs up, Rhyce.

6. SAM AND LACE

When Geelong ruckman Sam Newman wanted to display the Cats’ snappy lace-up guernsey in 1973, he enlisted the help of a model. Just so that we could compare it to the conventional woollen number, you understand.

7. NICK RIEWOLDT AND BEER

A decade ago the young Saints forward posed in this photo with VB Girls Julia Tink and Elisha Missen to help promote the Great Aussie Legends Evening at the Esplanade Hotel in St Kilda. What that actually involved was beer tasting with more than 650 publicans. Tough gig.

8. LLOYDY AND MUSICAL THEATRE

Also in 2004, Essendon’s Matthew Lloyd took time out from the forward line to join the chorus line. The photo at the top of this page was a cross promotion, with dancers from the musical comedy The Producers giving their show a kick along, while at the same time sporting the colours of the teams playing in that year’s finals series.

9. KEKA AND BOOTS

Long before he became a “lambassador’’, North Melbourne star Sam Kekovich was turning his attention to flogging products. Back in 1969 Keka enlisted the help of HSV7 ballet girls Joan Brockenshire and Heather Warnecke, presumably to promote the new range of locally made White Diamond football boots, famously worn by the likes of Peter Huddson, Ian Stewart and Ted Whitten.

10. ST KILDA AND … NOT SURE REALLY

No. Not a clue, to be honest. The year was 1982 and for some reason St Kilda footballers Darryl Hewitt (26 career games) and Wayne Slattery (11) were out on the Moorabbin turf with a wheelbarrow, in which sat a bikini-clad, high-heeled model. Unless the Saints had just signed a sponsorship deal with a wheelbarrow manufacturer, it’s hard to know how this photograph ever came to be.

RETROGRAM RECALL

FROM Countryfootyscores on Twitter: How rural for the Retrogram country footy list? Leigh Matthews qualifies because Chelsea is in the Mornington Peninsula Football League.

RETROGRAM SAYS: Fair suggestion, but I can’t have it. Chelsea is metro for mine. If you call it rural you have to say that St Kilda (which is further down the line at Seaford) is a country footy club.

FROM Tigerbob on Twitter: What about Graham Arthur and Fred Swift from Sandhurst?

RETROGRAM SAYS: Both outstanding players, who captained their clubs (Hawthorn and Richmond respectively) to premierships in the 1960s, but I couldn’t squeeze them in.

related.body:
1. HAWTHORN

44pts 147.9%

R16: North Melbourne (Etihad) W

R17: Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) W

R18: Sydney (MCG) W

R19: Western Bulldogs (Aurora) W

R20: Melbourne (MCG) W

R21: Fremantle (Patersons) L

R22: Geelong (MCG) W

R23: Collingwood (MCG) W

Matt says: This Hawthorn side just does not know how to lose despite everything that has been thrown at it. Remarkably remains in the box seat to claim top spot and now gets its coach and potentially one of its best players (Sam Mitchell) back. Still to play five of the teams currently in the top eight plus Adelaide away, but would only likely not start favourite in one of those games (Fremantle at Patersons).

2. PORT ADELAIDE

44pts 141.9%

R16: Essendon (Adelaide Oval) W

R17: Richmond (Etihad) W

R18: Melbourne (Adelaide Oval) W

R19: Collingwood (MCG) L

R20: Sydney (Adelaide Oval) L

R21: Gold Coast (Metricon) W

R22: Carlton (Adelaide Oval) W

R23: Fremantle (Patersons) L

Matt says: Could have almost locked up the minor premiership with a win over Sydney three weeks ago, now a top two spot is looking anything but secure after losses to the Swans and Adelaide. Securing a home qualifying final has to be the goal. From there, can you imagine what a preliminary final at a packed Adelaide Oval would be like?

RE-LIVE THE CHAT AND HAVE YOUR SAY BELOW

3. SYDNEY

44pts 137.9%

R16: West Coast (Patersons) W

R17: Carlton (SCG) W

R18: Hawthorn (MCG) L

R19: Essendon (SCG) W

R20: Port Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) W

R21: St Kilda (SCG) W

R22: Western Bulldogs (Etihad) W

R23: Richmond (ANZ) W

Matt says: Premiership favourites with Hawthorn and deservedly so based on its last two and a half months. Still, Sydney is no certainty to finish top two given the draws of Hawthorn, Port Adelaide and Fremantle. Luckily for the Swans, they play the Hawks and Power on the run home so they can shape their own destiny. Unluckily though they have to play them both away. Could it be that we’re still talking about that costly Round 1 loss to GWS come the end of the season?

4. FREMANTLE

40pts 132%

R16: Melbourne (TIO) W

R17: GWS (Patersons) W

R18: St Kilda (Etihad) W

R19: Carlton (Patersons) W

R20: Geelong (Simonds) L

R21: Hawthorn (Patersons) W

R22: Brisbane Lions (Gabba) W

R23: Port Adelaide (Patersons) W

Matt says: The derby win for an undermanned Fremantle was massive because it doesn’t play another side currently in the top eight until Round 20, by which stage it could have virtually locked up the double chance. Clashes with Geelong (away), Hawthorn and Port Adelaide (home) in the last month will determine the top two fate of last year’s runner-up.

5. GEELONG

40pts 106.8%

R16: Western Bulldogs (Simonds) W

R17: Melbourne (MCG) W

R18: GWS (Spotless) W

R19: North Melbourne (Etihad) L

R20: Fremantle (Simonds) W

R21: Carlton (Etihad) W

R22: Hawthorn (MCG) L

R23: Brisbane Lions (Simonds) W

Matt says: Great draw to come, one that is rated as one of the easiest by Champion Data. But Geelong’s loss to Gold Coast a couple of weeks ago puts it well and truly on the back foot in terms of taking a spot in the top four. The Cats will have to win at least one, if not two, of their games against North Melbourne (Etihad), Fremantle (Simonds) an Hawthorn (MCG) to have any realistic hope of securing the double chance.

6. COLLINGWOOD

36pts 114.1%

R16: Gold Coast (Metricon) L

R17: Essendon (MCG) W

R18: Adelaide (MCG) W

R19: Port Adelaide (MCG) W

R20: West Coast (Patersons) W

R21: Brisbane Lions (MCG) W

R22: GWS (Spotless) W

R23: Hawthorn (MCG) L

Matt says: Popular consensus suggests Collingwood’s top four hopes were shot the minute it dropped the game it shouldn’t have against the Western Bulldogs. Given the draw ahead, the Magpies are probably just a rung below those sides anyway. May already be sizing up a week one elimination final at the MCG against any one of North Melbourne, Geelong or Gold Coast by virtue of finishing between fifth and seventh.

7. NORTH MELBOURNE

32pts 110%

R16: Hawthorn (Etihad) L

R17: St Kilda (Blundstone) W

R18: Carlton (Etihad) W

R19: Geelong (Etihad) W

R20: GWS (Startrack) W

R21: Western Bulldogs (Etihad) W

R22: Adelaide (Blundstone) W

R23: Melbourne (Etihad) W

Matt says: North Melbourne has, according to Champion Data, the easiest run home of any team in the AFL. The question though is does that rating take in to account the inconsistencies of the Kangaroos? Hawthorn and Geelong stick out as the only two really difficult games left for Brad Scott’s men, who are still every chance of pushing further up the ladder despite the weekend’s shock loss to the Brisbane Lions.

8. GOLD COAST

32pts 101.2%

R16: Collingwood (Metricon) W

R17: Western Bulldogs (Cazaly’s) W

R18: Brisbane Lions (Gabba) W

R19: St Kilda (Metricon) W

R20: Carlton (Etihad) W

R21: Port Adelaide (Metricon) L

R22: Essendon (Etihad) L

R23: West Coast (Metricon) W

Matt says: Gold Coast is surely now headed for its first finals series after a historic win against Geelong a fortnight ago. Given the expectations around the Suns now, they should be favourites in home games against Collingwood, St Kilda and West Coast and away games against the Western Bulldogs (Cairns), Brisbane Lions (Gabba) and Carlton (Etihad). Wins in five of those games, maybe even four depending on percentage, should be enough to clinch a September berth.

9. ADELAIDE

28pts 105%

R16: GWS (Spotless) W

R17: Hawthorn (Adelaide Oval) L

R18: Collingwood (MCG) L

R19: West Coast (Adelaide Oval) W

R20: Brisbane Lions (Gabba) W

R21: Richmond (Adelaide Oval) W

R22: North Melbourne (Blundstone) L

R23: St Kilda (Adelaide Oval) W

Matt says: A shock win in the Showdown on the weekend puts Adelaide back in the hunt to make the eight. The Crows have now won seven of their past 11 games and should make that eight from 12 against Greater Western Sydney this week, which could catapult it — for a week at least — in to eighth. But from there it gets hard. Hawthorn (home) and Collingwood (away) are challenging games while Gold Coast takes on the Western Bulldogs and Brisbane Lions, while North Melbourne in Tassie also lies in waiting down the track. Can’t afford any slip-ups.

10. ESSENDON

28pts 104.9%

R16: Port Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

R17: Collingwood (MCG) L

R18: Western Bulldogs (Etihad) W

R19: Sydney (SCG) L

R20: Richmond (MCG) W

R21: West Coast (Etihad) W

R22: Gold Coast (Etihad) W

R23: Carlton (MCG) W

Matt says: Unfortunately, like last year, the great unknown about Essendon is not so much its fixture but how it will fare in terms of the ongoing supplements saga. All things being even, and if the Bombers are performing to their optimum, then the draw presents the club with a chance to make the finals despite it being rated as the toughest run home of any side. But, like Adelaide, the Bombers can’t afford any more slip-ups ahead of the Round 22 clash with Gold Coast. An upset victory over either Port Adelaide (away) this week or Collingwood next week would be a big help.

11. WEST COAST

24pts 110.6%

R16: Sydney (Patersons) L

R17: Brisbane Lions (Gabba) L

R18: Richmond (Patersons) W

R19: Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

R20: Collingwood (Patersons) L

R21: Essendon (Etihad) L

R22: Melbourne (Patersons) W

R23: Gold Coast (Metricon) L

Matt says: Couldn’t do what Adelaide did — win a game against the odds against its cross-town rivals. Big percentage remains a factor, but realistically now West Coast’s hopes of making the finals are gone. The Eagles have, after all, only won three games since winning their first three matches of the season.

12. WESTERN BULLDOGS

20pts 82.4%

R16: Geelong (Simonds) L

R17: Gold Coast (Cazaly’s) L

R18: Essendon (Etihad) L

R19: Hawthorn (Aurora) L

R20: St Kilda (Etihad) W

R21: North Melbourne (Etihad) L

R22: Sydney (Etihad) L

R23: GWS (Etihad) W

Matt says: Great win against Melbourne on the weekend. Beyond that though, only the most ardent of Western Bulldogs fans would argue it should start favourite in any game other than those against St Kilda and perhaps Greater Western Sydney.

13. RICHMOND

16pts 96.5%

R16: Brisbane Lions (MCG) W

R17: Port Adelaide (Etihad) L

R18: West Coast (Patersons) L

R19: GWS (MCG) W

R20: Essendon (MCG) L

R21: Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

R22: St Kilda (MCG) W

R23: Sydney (ANZ) L

Matt says: Finally Richmond has a bit of breathing space between itself and the wooden spoon. The draw actually doesn’t look too bad for the Tigers. A few wins against the likes of Brisbane Lions (MCG), Greater Western Sydney (MCG) and St Kilda (MCG) again may paper over some of the cracks, but at least they will put smiles on the faces of a few fans ahead of a long, hot summer.

14. CARLTON

16pts 87.1%

R16: St Kilda (Etihad) W

R17: Sydney (SCG) L

R18: North Melbourne (Etihad) L

R19: Fremantle (Patersons) L

R20: Gold Coast (Etihad) L

R21: Geelong (Etihad) L

R22: Port Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

R23: Essendon (MCG) L

Matt says: Shaping as being the season of ‘What ifs?’ for Carlton given close losses to Richmond (12 points), Greater Western Sydney (eight), Brisbane Lions (seven), Geelong (five), GWS (eight) and Collingwood (15). Finals chances were officially extinguished, if they weren’t already, with the loss to the Giants two weeks back.

15. MELBOURNE

16pts 78.1%

R16: Fremantle (TIO) L

R17: Geelong (MCG) L

R18: Port Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

R19: Brisbane Lions (Etihad) W

R20: Hawthorn (MCG) L

R21: GWS (MCG) L

R22: West Coast (Patersons) L

R23: North Melbourne (Etihad) L

Matt says: For the first time since 2007 Melbourne has beaten each of Essendon, Carlton and Richmond in a season. The form the Demons have displayed this year suggested they would take a top eight scalp at some stage, but perhaps the team is showing signs of tiring in the last couple of weeks.

16. GREATER WESTERN SYDNEY

16pts 77%

R16: Adelaide (Spotless) L

R17: Fremantle (Patersons) L

R18: Geelong (Spotless) L

R19: Richmond (MCG) L

R20: North Melbourne (Startrack) L

R21: Melbourne (MCG) W

R22: Collingwood (Spotless) L

R23: Western Bulldogs (Etihad) L

Matt says: You can’t sit here now and say with any confidence that Greater Western Sydney should start favourite in any of its remaining games. But you also know that the Giants will win again, at least once, somewhere, because their kids are just too good not to. Games against Melbourne and the Western Bulldogs in the last three rounds will be interesting tests.

17. BRISBANE LIONS

16pts 62%

R16: Richmond (MCG) L

R17: West Coast (Gabba) W

R18: Gold Coast (Gabba) L

R19: Melbourne (Etihad) L

R20: Adelaide (Gabba) L

R21: Collingwood (MCG) L

R22: Fremantle (Gabba) L

R23: Geelong (Simonds) L

Matt says: Gabba form — loss to GWS aside — has been relatively good this year. Game at home against West Coast and potentially trips to Victoria to play Richmond and Melbourne present the most realistic opportunities to avoid the wooden spoon.

18. ST KILDA

12pts 59.6%

R16: Carlton (Etihad) L

R17: North Melbourne (Blundstone) L

R18: Fremantle (Etihad) L

R19: Gold Coast (Metricon) L

R20: Western Bulldogs (Etihad) L

R21: Sydney (SCG) L

R22: Richmond (MCG) L

R23: Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

Matt says: The warm favourites to win the wooden spoon now after the Brisbane Lions’ win on the weekend. No one thought it would end this way after St Kilda won three of its first four games, but the draw does look bleak from here.

MATT WINDLEY’S PREDICTED LADDER

1. Hawthorn 18-4

2. Sydney 18-4

3. Fremantle 17-5

4. Port Adelaide 16-6

5. Geelong 16-6

6. Collingwood 15-7

7. North Melbourne 15-7

8. Gold Coast 14-8

----------------

9. Adelaide 12-10

10. Essendon 12-10

11. West Coast 8-12

12. Richmond 7-15

13. Western Bulldogs 7-15

14. Carlton 5-17

15. Melbourne 5-17

16. GWS 5-17

17. Brisbane Lions 5-17

18. St Kilda 3-19

WHICH WOULD MEAN ...

Finals, week one

First qualifying final: Hawthorn v Port Adelaide, MCG

Second qualifying final: Sydney v Fremantle, ANZ Stadium/SCG

First elimination final: Geelong v Gold Coast, Etihad Stadium/Simonds Stadium

Second elimination final: Collingwood v North Melbourne, MCG

related.body:
Nick Kyrgios’ audacious between-the-legs winner against Rafael Nadal has made global headlines, with some news outlets describing it as the shot of the year.

MATCH REPORT: GIANT KILLER KYRGIOS BEATS NADAL 

BOOM BOOM TIME: MCENROE, CASH BACK KYRGIOS TO WIN IT ALL 

SISTER ACT: FAMILY SO PROUD OF NICK 

World applauds Kyrgios’ ‘shot of the year’

The “tweener” perfectly summed up Kyrgios’s approach at Wimbledon — fearless, fun and a finesse-to-firepower ratio to match it with the world’s elite.

Commentators including John McEnroe and Tim Henman described Kyrgios’ shot as “beyond belief” and the “shot of the year”. The world’s tennis media thought likewise.

Have to do it all again tomorrow and I can't wait! First @Wimbledon & I'm in the last 8 club!! #HaveThat

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

“Kyrgios played probably the shot of the year, let alone the shot of Wimbledon, as he nonchalantly knocked a return drop-shot through his legs for the point,” wrote Mike Singer of CBS Sports.

“It takes some kind of something to try that shot when you’re up a set, deadlocked in the second at three games each against the No. 1 player in the world.

“Kyrgios maintained his moxie to pull the stunning upset. It’s the first time Nadal has lost to a teenager since 2007.”

Slowly sinking in. What an unreal day! Thanks to Simon, AK, Anne-Marie & @JohnMorris1982 for all their hard work. Massive team effort. #BOOM

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

'I like to give the people a bit of a show' #nickkyrgios

— Paul McNamee (@PaulFMcNamee) July 1, 2014 

Sports Illustrated’s Courtney Nguyen concurred.

“The 19-year-old Australian wildcard grabbed headlines last week when he saved nine match points to rally from two-sets to love down to beat No. 14 Richard Gasquet for his first top-15 victory,” Nguyen wrote. “Now, he’ll grab some more after hitting an audacious front-side tweener in the second set against Nadal.

“The kid is a shot-maker.”

Chris Chase, writing for USA Today

, joked Kyrgios’ was “clearly cowed by his surroundings” when playing the between-the-legs shot on the biggest stage, against the biggest opponent in the biggest match of his career.

“Remember the name Nick Kyrgios,” Chase wrote. “The 19-year-old Australian has the necessary combination of skills, savvy, swag and serve to be a major player in the post-Federer/Nadal/Djokovic generation.

Aussie Aussie Aussie @NickKyrgios. Such composure and class! But hard off to @RafaelNadal ... one of the greatest of all time!

— Hugh Jackman (@RealHughJackman) July 1, 2014 

Incredible win @NickKyrgios Defeating world no.1 @RafaelNadal to move through to @Wimbledon #QuarterFinals Amazinggg!! #AussiePride

— Sally Fitzgibbons (@Sally_Fitz) July 1, 2014 

“On Tuesday, Kyrgios set foot on Centre Court for the first time to play the world No. 1 in Rafael Nadal. He was clearly cowed by his surroundings.

“Kyrgios won’t be 20 until next April. He was the youngest player in the men’s draw at Wimbledon and won three matches before taking the opening set against Nadal. Though he’s still a long way from contending at Slams, he’s a player to watch in the future, and not just when he goes through the legs.”

John Branch, writing for the New York Times, was similarly I pressed with Kyrgios’ outing, noting he had become the “lowest-ranked player to beat Nadal since No. 690 Joachim Johansson beat him in Stockholm in 2006.”

“Until the evening shadows fell on Centre Court Tuesday, the last time a teenager beat a No. 1 player at a Grand Slam event was at the 2005 French Open,” Branch wrote. “The winner was Rafael Nadal, over Roger Federer, a couple of days after Nadal’s 19th birthday.

Wildcard Nick Kyrgios just beat World No. 1 Nadal! Hats off. Well played champ.

— Virat Kohli (@imVkohli) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios is the 1st teenager to beat a world #1 at a Grand Slam since Nadal def Federer at 2005 French Open. Congrats Nick. Stunning effort.

— Darren Cahill (@darren_cahill) July 1, 2014 

“Nick Kyrgios, a 19-year-old wildcard entrant from Australia, joined Nadal by beating him in the fourth round of Wimbledon.

“All limbs and panache, Kyrgios battered Nadal with big serves, boundless reach and boyish enthusiasm. Ranked No. 144 in the world, but rising fast, Kyrgios looked immune to the pressure and fearless with his shots.”

Aussie Aussie Aussie Oi Oi Oi. @NickKyrgios the giant slayer! #wimbledon #believe pic.twitter.com/H8xt7lGRPh

— Pat Cash (@TheRealPatCash) July 1, 2014 

Nick Kyrgios- the Wonder from "Down Under" shocks #1 Nadal at Wimbledon. Welcome to the World Stage- YOUTH!! Great effort.

— Jimmy Connors (@JimmyConnors) July 1, 2014 

Just watching the 3rd set of @NickKyrgios V Rafa. What a effort by this young gun of aussie tennis, keep it going mate

— Scott Pendlebury (@SP_10) July 1, 2014 

I think it's now safe to change the tag line of #NKRising to #NKRisen ..@NickKyrgios

— Mahesh Bhupathi (@Maheshbhupathi) July 1, 2014 

The win by @NickKyrgios over Rafael Nadal. A bigger upset than Mark Philippoussis not finding his future wife on Age Of Love. Well done son.

— Ryan Fitzgerald (@FitzySA) July 1, 2014 

Well done to @NickKyrgios just woke up to the news. What a great effort to beat the world no1. #nowbringithome

— Anthony Watmough (@AnthonyWatmough) July 1, 2014 

Extraordinary performance @NickKyrgios. Australia couldn't be prouder of you - what a win & what an amazing attitude! #Wimbledon2014

— Tony Abbott (@TonyAbbottMHR) July 1, 2014 

Even though my TV show premiered tonight!!! I regretfully say this was by far the best thing on television. #Kyrgios pic.twitter.com/HhUockXJel

— Andy Lee (@andy_lee) July 1, 2014 

Now that was worth staying up for. @NickKyrgios take a bow. Remarkable play. #Wimbledon #aussiepride

— Steve Smith (@stevesmith49) July 1, 2014 

Nick kyrgios u r the man, awesome win

— Dane Tilse (@DaneTilse) July 1, 2014 

What a performance by @NickKyrgios Absolutely outstanding

— Laurie Fisher (@LordLaurie58) July 1, 2014

related.body:
Pusic told Confidential that the pressure on the show was “ridiculous,” but not the reason for the pair ultimately deciding too call it quits.

“I think we knew that going into the competition that we had doubts about our relationship,’’ he said.

“We don’t blame the show for not being together.

“There were other weaknesses in the competition.

“Even though we came out of the show not together, we loved the experience.

“I don’t look at it as a bad thing at all, it’s just the way the cookie crumbles.”

The pressure cooker environment of the show also caused conflict between the couples.

In a raging fight during tonight’s episode, Pusic and Stuart accused Perth couple Carol and Russell Bramston of sabotage after a dispute over a wall.

“We agreed at the start of the week what was happening with the wall and it was crucial to have the time,’’ Pusic said.

“Then with two-and-a-half days to go, Russell and Carol said what we agreed to, we were not going to do that anymore. We felt like we were sabotaged.”

Pusic said at the time the tension was crazy.

“Candy was very upset, she took off and I didn’t think she was going to come back,” he said.

“She didn’t think it was fair. I was stuck to pick up the pieces there for a while.

“I was on site trying to redesign a room in a day and half and deal with the missus who wanted to go home.”

The couple was interviewed in recent months by News Corp and spoke about their relationship, wedding plans and their experience on the show, giving no hint of their separation.

related.body:
Ms Lau, a 32-year-old from Hong Kong who is formally known as Yuk Ling Lau, was allegedly brutally murdered and raped in Kings Domain on Saturday morning.

Mr Miller, a Californian-born man who has been living on Melbourne’s streets for at least two months, stared straight ahead as he was formally remanded in custody to reappear on October 24.

He has been charged with one count of murder and two counts of rape.

Dressed in a green long-sleeved T-shirt, he looked bewildered during the short hearing and yawned several times.

Legal aid lawyer Sarah Pratt said Mr Miller had been diagnosed with drug-induced psychosis in the past and was suffering a mouth infection.

“It’s his first time in custody,” Ms Pratt said.

A police application to retain a forensic sample was granted.

Friends yesterday described Ms Lau as a “beautiful lovely person” who would be sorely missed.

Family members are now on their way to Melbourne to identify her body.

Mr Miller was extradited back to Melbourne from Batemans Bay late yesterday afternoon.

He looked down throughout the brief hearing at Batemans Bay courthouse yesterday, with magistrate Doug Dick granting a warrant by Victorian detectives.

A makeshift shrine has appeared in Kings Domain near where Ms Lau died. It has drawn people who did not know the dead woman but were deeply affected by her plight.

A cyclist on her way to work left a card that read: “We are so sorry for the sadness and loss that your family is experiencing. Our city grieves with you and for you. I’m so sorry.”

The woman, who also did not know the victim, said it was time Melbourne united and stood up to the violence plaguing the city.

“I think the message that’s coming to us is we’re not safe on the way to work, on the way home from work, out cycling or going for a run,” she said.

“It’s time as women, and men, we stand up and say no to this violence.”

Another woman touched by the death wiped away tears as she left a note addressed to the victim.

“Dear unknown girl,” she wrote. “I’m sorry you had to lose your life in an unknown country at the hands of an evil mad man.

“I hope you managed to have some fun in your young life and lots of love.

“Although I didn’t know you, I will think of you everyday as I pass this spot.”

Ms Lau’s employer at a city chocolate shop said she had worked there since May 2012.

“She worked in our kitchen as a valued member of our pastry team. She will be terribly missed here.

“She was a wonderful person and a beautiful friend and colleague.

“We offer our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends and all our thoughts are with them.

He added: “She was a beautiful, lovely person and will be sorely missed.”

A friend who was laying flowers near the crime scene in Kings Domain told the Herald Sun: “I really liked her smile. She had a beautiful smile. I will never forget it.”

The friend, who did not want to be named, attended the same church as Ms Lau.

Mr Miller was nabbed at 3.30pm on Monday while he was sleeping on rocks in an idyllic coastal town more than 500km away from Melbourne.

He was spotted by off-duty police officers at Snug Cove, Eden, in southern NSW.

Detective Inspector John Potter said the attack on Miss Lau was particularly violent.

She was assaulted sexual and physically, he said.

Insp Potter said some of the woman’s family had been contacted in China and that they were to fly to Melbourne to formally identify her.

Insp Potter urged women not to walk alone, especially in the dark, and to travel by public transport or taxi where possible.

The Herald Sun understands witnesses will detail claims about senior figures in the Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union.

At least one witness due to give evidence has received death threats from people linked to the union.

The Herald Sun understands footage of a senior Victorian CFMEU official intimidating a builder will be revealed at the hearings.

Links between the official, the union and an underworld figure will also be aired.

It is understood the whistleblower in the video was warned his business may be threatened if he released it.

Sources say he was approached by a person linked to the CFMEU.

He was told that the underworld figure would be able to smooth the way for his projects if he agreed to withhold the information.

Several building industry sources have confirmed the existence of the videos.

The union is preparing a media strategy to limit the damage of the exposure.

It comes after another whistleblower was stabbed in his driveway after he claimed earlier this year that a union official was given a free roof for his home in exchange for industrial peace.

The whistleblower, Andrew Zaf, was hit with a piece of wood and stabbed in the arm and leg in March, according to a police report.

Claims of bikie infiltration at Victoria’s desalination plant are also expected to be heard.

A separate source with knowledge of witness statements confirmed that the outlaw motorcycle gangs were a significant presence on the site.

The hearings are set down for three days from Monday.

stephen.drill@news.com.au

related.body:
Ms Greenaway, who represented dog owners Shannon Holt and partner Evan Jeremiejczyk, said she had been shocked by the council’s stance.

“I deal with councils all over Australia and none of them have been like Frankston,” she said.

Ms Greenaway accused the council of ignoring reports in favour of the dogs.

“They (council) have been provided with an expert report that is very favourable on the dogs’ temperaments,” she said.

“Their next-door neighbours have given favourable statements.”

Ms Greenaway said Ms Holt and Mr Jeremiejczyk’s lives had been destroyed by the ordeal involving the dogs.

DEATH ROW DOG OWNERS QUIETLY CONFIDENT 

Ms Holt said she is “numb” over the impending demise of her beloved dogs.

Ms Holt, who repeatedly broke down in tears during an interview with the Leader, said she had been financially and emotionally exhausted by the battle to save the dogs.

“They are going to kill my dogs. There’s nothing I can do about it. I have lost everything,” a distraught Ms Holt said.

“It’s hit us hard (financially). We are struggling. They (council) have too much power and too much money.”

Frankston Council announced it would push ahead with plans to euthanase the dogs, Charlie and Sharni, owned by Ms Holt and Evan Jeremiejczyk, by the end of this week.

In a statement, the council said it would “humanely destroy the dogs” following a review and “based on the risk they pose to the safety of other animals and people”.

Ms Holt accused the council of being manipulative in its dealings regarding the dogs.

“They were never going to give me my dogs back,” she said.

“There’s nowhere to turn.”

Ms Holt said funds from an anonymous donor had already been soaked up in legal fees and neither she nor partner Evan Jeremiejczyk had the money for a Supreme Court challenge to the council’s decision.

Mayor Darrel Taylor said the decision to euthanase the dogs had been difficult for all involved.

But he added: “We have no tolerance for dogs not responsibly managed by their owners.”

Council chief executive Dennis Hovenden said the decision was based on ensuring the safety of residents and their animals — a priority for the council.

“The decision was based on the nature and impact of the attack on the cat last year, and on the risk of further attack on an animal or a person should the dogs be released.

“The mayor and councillors are fully supportive of the decision, saying that they have little tolerance for dogs who are not responsibly managed by their owners.”

Outraged supporters of Mr Jeremiejczyk and Ms Holt have voiced their anger on the council’s Facebook page.

Debra Talbot wrote: “The people of Victoria request that you intervene and stop your employees from murdering two dogs that have been wrongly accused of killing a cat.

“No witnesses ... you cannot kill on assumptions.”

HAS THE COUNCIL MADE THE RIGHT DECISION? JOIN THE DEBATE BELOW

Jessie Cran added: “Why on earth is your council so hellbent on killing two dogs which pose no risk to the community ... what good is having a secure yard for your dogs if your dogs are dead?”

Cindy Battles posted photographs of the dogs, adding: “The whole family will never forget what you do ... these are not just dogs — don’t you get that? They are part of a family.”

The dogs were impounded after they escaped the couple’s Frankston property on November 8 and killed a cat.

They were due to be put down in March, but Mr Jeremiejczyk and Ms Holt won an 11th-hour reprieve when an anonymous donor provided financial support to help them launch a Supreme Court appeal.

The donor stepped in after Mr Jeremiejczyk and Ms Holt, along with supporters, chanted “save our dogs” during an impassioned demonstration outside Frankston Council offices.

The Supreme Court appeal was subsequently put on hold after the council agreed on a review.

Ms Holt has previously spoken of her devotion to Charlie, a male mastiff cross, and Sharni, a sharpei female cross, and what they mean to her family.

“I can’t believe my dogs would viciously kill a cat. I know they would not,’’ she said.

“I feel like I have lost my children … I am at the end of my tether.’’

The 24-year-old mother of two has set up a Facebook group “Please Save My Beloved Dogs’’ outlining her situation.

Ms Holt and Mr Jeremiejczyk pleaded guilty to a range of charges including having a dog at large and dog attack serious injury causing death at the magistrates court in February.

Mayor Darrel Taylor previously told the Leader that the decision to euthanase the dogs had not been taken lightly.

Ms Holt told the Leader earlier this year that she and Mr Jeremiejczyk had already spent $20,000 in pound and legal fees as they fought to save the dogs.

More to come

related.body:
The photo — which shows the first time Bethany Townsend, 23, dared to bare after being fitted with two colostomy bags — has now been viewed by an incredible nine million people.

Bethany, a makeup artist from Worcester in the UK, has been so overwhelmed by the response that she can finally acknowledge that the colostomy bags doesn’t define who she is.

“I didn’t expect this kind of reaction at all,” she said of the picture.

“When I first had the bags fitted I was devastated — the reaction to this photo has really helped me accept them.

“The photo has been seen by millions of people ... I’m just so glad that it’s brought about more awareness of Crohn’s disease, and it’s made me feel so much more confident.”

Bethany was fitted with her colostomy bags after battling with Crohn’s disease since the age of three. It is a condition that causes inflammation of the digestive system, affecting the sufferer’s ability to digest food, absorb nutrients and eliminate waste.

In extreme situations like Bethany’s, it becomes necessary to remove the damaged section of the intestine and bring the healthy part out as a stoma — known as a colostomy.

After almost dying when her bowel ruptured in 2010, Bethany woke from a life-saving operation to find she had been fitted with two colostomy bags.

“Growing up I’d had various surgeries to try and combat the Crohn’s,” said Townsend. “I’d go in and have sections of my intestine cut out, but I’d only be in remission for a couple of weeks before it came back again.

“Then, four years ago I woke up in the morning and couldn’t move because I was in so much agony. I had to break a glass on the floor to alert my mum who called on ambulance. When the paramedics came they lifted up my top to see that my surgery scar had split open. I was rushed to intensive care where they doctors told me family I would need more surgery as my intestines had become infected and inflamed again. I had no idea when I woke up that I would have the bags.

“When I first woke up and my mum told me about them I was just relieved as I’d thought I was going to die. When I came out of hospital and everything finally sunk in, I remember going upstairs into my bedroom and just bursting into tears.

“I’d known a colostomy bag might have been an option but it was always something that I had wanted to avoid. I had a really good cry that day, and since then I haven’t shed another tear — I’ve just got on with it I suppose.”

It was only after Townsend met and married her husband, Ian, 33, and jetted off to Mexico last Christmas that she finally felt ready to embrace the colostomy bags.

“When I met Ian I showed him my bags straight away, but he didn’t bat an eye lid — I actually felt like I was overreacting,” she said.

“He taught me that there was more to me than the bags and would always encourage me to show off my figure. I wasn’t sure but in Mexico I finally realised he was right, and decided to wear my bikini.

“At first I was nervous and worried that people would stare but it was fine. The staff at the hotel asked me about the bags on the last day of the holiday, but rather than being offended I was glad because it meant I could talk to them about Crohn’s and tell them what it is.

“I decided to get in touch with Crohn’s and Colitis UK Facebook group to see if they would let me post something on their page. I sent them the picture and my information, and it all blew up from there.”

Townsend still suffers from Crohn’s disease and hopes ones day for a cure, but for now she is considering getting back into modelling — a career she gave up on after she was fitted with the bags.

“I feel confident enough now to put myself out there and pursue modelling again,” she said.

“I did a little bit of work here and there before I had the colostomy bags, but once I had them fitted I thought that was the end of the dream. I’m looking forward to chasing my goals, and I know now that nothing can hold me back.

“I won’t let the Crohn’s control me anymore.”

related.body:
It’s time to get on the bandwagon.

Kyrgios will face Canada’s world No. 9 in the early hours of tomorrow, and the likes of tennis legend John McEnroe are predicting an upset, saying the 19-year-old can go all the way and win the prestigious Wimbledon crown as a teenager.

Here are 10 things you didn’t know about Nick Kyrgios.

1. HOW TO PRONOUNCE HIS NAME

The “G” is silent. So “Kirr-ee-oss”. Not “Kurr-gee-oss”, like the spelling would suggest.

2. HIS BACKGROUND

Kyrgios is Aussie born. A Canberra boy. His father, George, was born in Greece and moved to Australia as a child. His mother, Norlaila, is Malaysian.

Kyrgios is the youngest of three kids. His brother is a lawyer and his sister an actor.

3. HE WAS A CHUBBY KID

Kyrgios’ mother, Norlaila, admits her boy ate too much as a child. He loved his food.

But he eventually stretched out into a lean 1.93m (6ft 4in), 77kg frame and lost the puppy fat.

MORE: The shot that stunned the world 

MORE: Legends, celebs in shock over Aussie Nick 

MORE: Why you don’t need to cheer for Tomic anymore 

4. THE HISTORY HE’S CREATED

With his 7-6 (7-5), 5-7 7-6 (7-5) 6-3 victory over Nadal — one of the greatest upsets in Wimbledon history — Kyrgios became the first teenager to defeat a world No. 1 at a grand slam since Nadal did it himself against Roger Federer in the 2005 French Open. An ominous sign.

The youngest man in the men’s draw, the 144th-ranked Kyrgios also became the first player ranked outside the top 100 to defeat a world No. 1 at a grand slam since Andrei Olhovsky defeated Jim Courier at Wimbledon in 1992.

Kyrgios is the youngest man to reach the last eight at Wimbledon since compatriot Bernard Tomic in 2011 and the first to reach the quarter-finals on debut since German Florian Mayer 10 years ago.

5. BASKETBALL BECKONED
Canberra is boasting right now about being the home of Australia’s hottest sporting stars. NBA star Patty Mills, the “next big thing” in basketball Dante Exum and Kyrgios are all products of the nation’s capital. Kyrgios was a hoops-mad kid as well, representing Australia in basketball as a young teen before making tennis his sole focus as a 14-year-old. He still loves the Boston Celtics.

6. THE MONEY GAME

Since turning pro in 2013, Kyrgios has played only 10 matches on ATP Tour. Of those, he has only won three and lost seven (going into Wimbledon).

This year, he’d won just one match on the pro tour — the Australian Open first round against Benjamin Becker, the namesake of the man Kyrgios has been compared to quite a bit today, Boris Becker.

What it all means is he’d won $A248,000 in his career up until Wimbledon. He will walk away from the All England Club with a minimum $A409,806 for reaching the quarter-finals. The Wimbledon champion takes home $A3.19 million.

7. HIS IDOLS

If Kyrgios can shock the world once more and defeat Raonic tonight, he is on track to meet the man he looked up to most as a child, Roger Federer, in the Wimbledon semi-finals. Another guy he really idolised as a youngster was Nadal.

Kyrgios first started playing tennis at six years old, in 2001. By that stage, Federer had already been a pro for three years.

8. HE LIKES RAP

Kyrgios is a Lil Wayne fan. And he was into Wu Tang as a kid. He also likes R’n’B artist Rihanna.

9. HE WAS A TOP JUNIOR

While top juniors don’t always make it big, Kyrgios was a junior world No. 1 and won the junior Australian Open in 2013, defeating countryman Thanasi Kokkinakis in the final.

10. HE LOVES A LAUGH

Proving he is not just a serious tennis robot, Kyrgios loves a comedy and is a big Family Guy fan.

Four majors each to champion forwards Matthew Lloyd and Brendon Fevola and two from comedian Dave Hughes was the difference in the 0.15.6 (96) to 2.10.10 (88) result.

#ejwhittengame @karlstefanovic Not even close mate! @EJLegendsGame @TheTodayShow @AngoveWine @9NewsMelb #triedhard pic.twitter.com/POjCaRtDkH

— Stephen (@stephen_harman) July 1, 2014 

The All-Stars started the better side kicking the opening two goals through captain-coach Shane Crawford and a super goal to Hawthorn premiership player Michael Osborne.

Great to be part of the victorious Big V at #ejwhittengame. Thanks for kind feedback. Just happy to get 4pts. #2kicks2goals #100%efficiency

— Dave Hughes (@DHughesy) July 1, 2014 

great nite at @EJLegendsGame ! great cause and great support! well done 2 all involved ! bit sore 2day running messages - 3 votes 4 that !

— Warwick Capper (@WarwickCapper39) July 2, 2014 

Fevola ignited the Vics with a miraculous soccer-style volley goal midway through the second quarter to give his side a narrow halftime lead, despite the efforts of Darwin-based goalkicking machine Abbey Holmes.

WHAT A GAME!! Who was your best on ground? #EJLegendsGame pic.twitter.com/GXmaBUmgtT

— EJWhittenLegendsGame (@EJLegendsGame) July 1, 2014 

Holmes bounced back from a heavy tackle by boxer Sam Soliman to kick three first-half goals.

The third quarter started in controversy with former Sun and Hawk Campbell Brown striking former teammate Osborne high.

#ejwhittengame FEVOLA goes one-handed @EJLegendsGame @EtihadStadiumAU @sportsbetcomau @BrendanFevola25 #fevola #fev pic.twitter.com/2sUnwCMXo6

— Stephen (@stephen_harman) July 1, 2014 

However, Osborne bounced back to take a spectacular mark over Brown in the final term.

The All-Stars had a chance to win the game in the dying minutes, when Today host Karl Stefanovic found space deep in the forward line, but Jeff Farmer’s pass sailed over his head.

The ALL-STAR selfie led by @SCrawf9 #ejwhittengame @EJLegendsGame @heraldsunsport @EtihadStadiumAU @WWOS9 #crawf pic.twitter.com/g7qEY5Ebco

— Stephen (@stephen_harman) July 1, 2014 

A strong mark and goal from Hughes — who had spent time on Holmes at full-back but found himself in the goalsquare with minutes to play — was the difference and brought the 25,000-crowd to its feet.

Stafanovic blamed poor delivery from the All-Stars midfielders for his inability to steal the win and joked after the siren that captain-coach Shane Crawford should be sacked after the loss. But Crawford said today the fact that no one was seriously injured counted as a win.

He said his pre-game instructions were to avoid tackling and any defensive pressure.

Now in its 18th year the Legends game has raised more than $1.3 million in aid of prostate cancer research.

#ejwhittengame Brown hits Osborne hard @EJLegendsGame @EtihadStadiumAU @heraldsunsport pic.twitter.com/GKuFAKqkY4

— Stephen (@stephen_harman) July 1, 2014 

#ejwhittengame Holmes was a crowd favourite @EJLegendsGame @EtihadStadiumAU @RayWhiteGroup @MelbourneHilton #allstars pic.twitter.com/gWkCCPk0Cw

— Stephen (@stephen_harman) July 1, 2014 

.@samkingsoliman shapes up at the end of the game #boxing #legend #ejwhittengame @EJLegendsGame @sportsbetcomau pic.twitter.com/09e4hLiThl

— Stephen (@stephen_harman) July 1, 2014

related.body:
Matchmaker Blue Label Life has been ordered to refund Sofia Baltatzidis her membership fee after a representative failed to show at a Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal hearing yesterday.

The Malvern businesswoman joined the service in January 2011 hoping to snare an “intelligent, caring, down-to-earth, genuine” partner.

“It’s hard to meet intelligent people. Every time you go on the RSVP website all they talk about is star signs and footy,” Ms Baltatzidis told the Herald Sun.

Ms Baltatzidis claimed a consultant insisted on introducing her to a primary school teacher despite her objection that he wasn’t suitable for her.

“When I called him he was unappealing and completely negative about his experience with Blue Label Life,” she claimed.

“He had no personality, no humour, no spark. He was a bit of a boring sod.”

She claimed she never heard from a second candidate and a phone introduction to another man proved unsuitable as he lived in Jan Juc and was a “weirdo”.

The consultant described the men as “wonderful, successful” and “genuine gentlemen” who were excited to meet Ms Baltatzidis.

Ms Baltatzidis said Blue Label Life sent her two more profiles of men it said were “extremely compatible” with her in July 2011 despite her demands for a refund, which the agency refused.

Blue Label Life claims all matches are “scientifically compatible” and hand-picked from an “extensive and elite pool of members”.

Director Samantha Jayne said she wasn’t notified of the VCAT hearing and a review of the order has since been recommended.

Ms Jayne said Ms Baltatzidis was given numerous opportunities to meet with suitable candidates.

“Between July 2011 and December 2011 I personally tried to engage with Ms Baltatzidis and to work out a way forward or a resolution to her issue, but Ms Baltatzidis’ behaviour and what we felt at the time were unreasonable demands made it impossible for a resolution to be found,” she told the Herald Sun.

angus.thompson@news.com.au

related.body:
Running the length of his right arm from wrist to sleeve, fans were in awe of the supposed inking, saying the 19-year-old brought “swag in tennis to a whole new level”.

More: Kyrgios stuns with four-set Wimbeldon win over Rafael Nadal 

The “tatt”, which featured a tribal-looking pattern, appeared have given his dark skin a white hue underneath, leaving fans baffled about how it was done.

The tattoo that Kyrgios has is fkin awesome

— Daenerys Targaryen (@th4t_ginger) July 1, 2014 

Kind of obsessed with Kyrgios' tattoo pic.twitter.com/TIqP9LREL3

— Stacey Bartlett (@staceybartlett) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios brings swag in tennis to a whole new level with his arm tattoo

— Jack Carolan (@Jackobeanz) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios' arm tattoo is freaking me out! Why and how is it white?

— Beci Wood (@beciwood) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios's tattoo is sooo awesome! #LovinIt #Wimbeldon14

— Penny Clark (@PennyClark_23) July 1, 2014 

#wimbledon2014 kyrgios playing nadal....is that a tattoo on his right arm? pic.twitter.com/pKxT0h06Bn

— Terry Rideout (@TerrysTwit78) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios epic arm tattoo pic.twitter.com/irRs3ZarUg

— Technically Bryan (@technicallybry) July 1, 2014 

But for those wanting to mimic the look, it turns out it’s pretty easy to get “a Kyrgios” — the tatt is just a piece of tape.

Developed by an Australian Musculoskeletal Physiotherapist and made by Vanuatu-based Dynamic Tape, the product is a unique, strongly elastic tape for treating soft tissue sports injuries. 

The uniquely branded “Tattoo Tape” features a tribal tattoo design created by Norfolk Island and Tahitian artist, Tihoti, and is available in both black and beige.

The intricately-designed product was also worn by Tim Cahill during the World Cup to blend in with his own tattoos.

The Dynamic Tape website says the highly elastic tape is used to strongly assist or resist movement, facilitate or inhibit and offload tissue through full range of motion. The tape is applied to an injured muscle or tendon and as the muscle or joint lengthens, the tape is stretched to absorb load and reduce the work on the muscles. This results in decreased workload, demand on the muscle and improved tolerance to fatigue.

Managing Director of Dynamic Tape, Ryan Kendrick, told news.com.au he had no idea Kyrgios was using his Tribal Tape, but wasn’t surprised that people mistook the product for a real tattoo.

“When I have worn it myself people often ask to see my tattoo and I have had many of my patients recount funny stories like an 85-year-old great grandmother whose son was disgusted with her as he thought she had gone out and got some ink!” he said.

He said Ana Ivanovic and Sania Mirzer used the tan tattoo version of the product at the Australian Open earlier this year while Tommy Haas wore the black tattoo design. Serena Williams, Laura Robson and Kim Clijsters have also used the product.

Kendrick said the tattoo design came about because he was living on Norfolk Island when the tape was developed and wanted to reflect the heritage of the island and the South Pacific.

“The design was given to us by a very well known Polynesian artist and tattooist named Tihoti. Tihoti is Tahitian but his wife is a Norfolk Islander. Norfolk relies heavily on tourism and with the global financial crisis and high Australian Dollar, they were suffering so it was our way of spreading the word about Norfolk Island a little.”

Kinesio Australia Education Director, Clint Bridges, says while the tribal tape is not an official Kinesio product, the Kinesio taping method is regularly used on the tennis circuit.

“Novak Djokovic, Li Na and Serena Williams all use a beige form of the tape on court. At a base level, it’s used to try and change the way the muscle is firing. There are specific tensions for different tasks which changes the way the brain thinks that muscle is working.

“Certain tensions provide stimulus on the skin, which sends a message to the brain. The brain then reinterprets that message and sends instructions back to the muscle so it learns how to behave. There would be one tension for relaxation of the muscle if it’s tight and one for activation.”

Kendrick said the tape was released commercially in Australia in late 2010, followed by the UK and then North America in 2012. The tape was used by a number of athletes at the London 2012 games and is now available in 25 countries.

So there you have it, for all those out there wanting the Kyrgios tattoo, you’re in luck.

For just $15.10, you can buy five metres of the stuff.

Were you fooled by Kyrgios’ tattoo? Leave your comment below.

related.body:
As her family prepare to fly to Australia to be with their daughter, it can be revealed Ms Lau was walking to a dessert shop where she did the early morning shift when the unthinkable began to unfold.

Video footage from the cameras of high-end residential complex The Melburnian, which capture St Kilda Rd, show a woman running from a man before dawn on Saturday morning.

The confrontation on the street before Ms Lau was chased down is still unknown.

It will be the police case Ms Lau was confronted by accused man Scott Allen Miller as he walked home from a night at Bourke St hotel The Carlton after he was ejected about 5am.

What is known is Ms Lau was a devout Baptist Christian who was enjoying life in Melbourne. Although it is believed she had no family in Melbourne, Ms Lau, a Chinese national, had made industry friends here, particularly at the William Angliss Institute.

But those who placed cards and flowers at the site of her death were mainly from her church, who remembered Ms Lau for her faith and her smile.

Fellow colleagues of Renea Lau said she was a “beautiful, lovely person” who will be sorely missed.

“It is with deep sadness that we can confirm Renea Lau was an employee here,” Steven Kearney, her employer, said.

“She’s been with us since May 2012. She worked in our kitchen as a valued member of our pastry team. She will be terribly missed here.

“She was a wonderful person and a beautiful friend and colleague.

“We offer our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends and all our thoughts are with them.

He added: “She was a beautiful, lovely person and will be sorely missed. It is a difficult time for us and we do not wish to comment further.”

In contrast, the riches to rags story of Mr Miller had led him to Melbourne’s Janet Lady Clarke rotunda, opposite the tan track.

He had fallen on hard times since running a nightclub in the 1990s and reportedly until a couple of months ago was living in a shed on a property in Darwin and making didgeridoos.

It will be alleged their paths met for the first and only time as they walked along the tree-lined St Kilda Rd - one of Melbourne’s busiest streets.

The cameras capture Ms Lau running towards Kings Domain. Hours later a jogger would find her battered body near the Victoria Police Memorial.

Homicide investigators had the awful task of informing Ms Lau’s siblings of her death, who in turn told her parents.

Her alleged attacker was apprehended after a three-day manhunt sleeping on rocks in the southern NSW coastal town of Eden.

Mr Miller’s extradition to Victoria was granted by a Batemans Bay magistrate and he was flown to Melbourne for questioning at the St Kilda Road Police Complex today.

Mr Miller will appear in court tomorrow after he is remanded at the Melbourne Custody Centre.

Friends and complete strangers returned to the scene of Ms Lau’s murder today.

Despite not knowing the dead woman, a local resident who wished only to be known as Rod was so touched by her death that he laid a bunch of yellow flowers just metres from where her body was found before holding a minute’s silence.

“It’s terrible. I really feel sorry for her parents,” he said.

“It shouldn’t have happened here. It’s a beautiful spot.”

A cyclist on her way to work left a card that read: “We are so sorry for the sadness and loss that your family is experiencing.

“Our city grieves with you and for you. I’m so sorry.”

The woman, who also did not know the victim, said it was time Melbourne united and stood up to the violence plaguing the city.

“I think the message that’s coming to us is we’re not safe on the way to work, on the way home from work, out cycling or going for a run,” she said.

“It’s time as women, and men, we stand up and say no to this violence.”

Another woman touched by the death wiped away tears as she left a note addressed to the victim.

“Dear unknown girl,” she wrote. “I’m sorry you had to lose your life in an unknown country at the hands of an evil mad man.

“When WILL men stop killing women? Why was he not in an institution?

“I hope you managed to have some fun in your young life and lots of love.

“Although I didn’t know you, I will think of you everyday as I pass this spot.”
related.byline: Jon Kaila, Christopher Gillett, Rebekah Cavanagh

related.body:
Nothing that could taint the London jurors could be published in the UK until the verdict – meaning an internet blackout for some of the most shocking claims of all against the once-beloved entertainer.

Damning claims never heard by the jury were made during pre-trial argument, including that Harris downloaded child porn, cruised dirty sites with names like ‘Youngest Teen Porn’ and attempted to erase his browsing history.

GUILTY: Court rules Harris sexually assaulted teen girls 

VERDICT: Harris brought down by bizarre letters 

‘PREDATORY’: What the jury didn’t hear 

HARRIS’ DAUGHTER: I had him on a pedestal 

The jury was also banned from hearing from other witnesses who painted a picture of Harris as a lecherous old man, with a judge ruling their evidence prejudicial.

And they certainly didn’t get to read about long-standing rumours within Australian entertainment circles that Harris had abused young women.

Shocking allegations emerged during the pre-trial arguments that Harris had attempted to erase pornographic images of young girls from his computer in 2012.

Prosecutor Sasha Wass, QC, told the court that Harris, 84, had searched websites with names like Russian Virgins, My Little Nieces and Youngest Teen Porn, searching for images of underage girls.

Ms Wass said she would not describe the images due to their graphic nature.

The images were on galleries involving “very young people in various levels of forbidden poses”, and were believed to have been of girls under the age of 13.

Harris’s lawyers argued the images were the result of accidental downloads.

HUMILIATED: Rolf’s reputation savaged by trial 

PROSECUTION: Harris called a sinister pervert 

ADMISSIONS: Harris admits to ‘affair’ 

WITNESS CLAIM: Rolf just ‘love to hug’ 

The pre-trial hearing was told that 328 images of adult pornography also existed, and other suspect images could have been pictures of “models” aged 18.

One file called “watch my girlfriend” featured two girls with a teddy bear in the foreground while another deleted file, later retrieved, featured just a girl’s genitals.

Another was of a boy and girl in a pose that he allegedly downloaded and deleted four times

Ms Wass said Harris returned “over and over” to some of the images, including some of underdeveloped girls wearing nothing but socks.

She said Harris’ diary had handwriting detailing how to erase files from the browser history.

Ms Wass said an admission to seeking help to delete images led to the conclusion that he had not downloaded them by accident, and knew some were illegal.

“If it was an accident it appears it was one he had a number of times,” she said.

She conceded the ages of the girls shown was unknown but they appeared to be Ukrainian or another eastern European country known to traffic girls - and their ages would be hard to prove.

Ms Wass urged the Judge to let the jury decide if the underdeveloped bodies meant they were young.

Harris was not required to enter a plea on four charges relating to downloading indecent images of children, and the charges were not dealt with as part of his trial on 12 charges of indecently assaulting girls and a young woman between 1968 and 1986.

During the pre-trial hearing, Judge Nigel Sweeney also ruled that most of the prosecution’s “bad character” witnesses – other people who made allegations of lecherous behaviour - were admissible.

The hearing was delayed at one point when a member of the public tweeted three pages of evidence not meant for publication.

After being informed of the breach, Judge Sweeney called a halt to proceedings and asked the offender to own up – but nobody did.

The suspect tweeter was reported to have been a member of a child abuse activist group.

The trial hit other delays, including one caused by a missing box of evidence.

When contradictory old film footage surfaced that placed him in Cambridge — an area where he said he’d never been at the time – Harris’ lawyers tried to have it kept from the jury.

It was Thames Television footage of a 1978 celebrity sport game show starring Harris – and one of Harris’s accusers alleged she was waitress at the event, when she was 13 or 14.

A person following the case in the local media tipped the prosecution off about the footage, and in the jury’s absence the prosecutor urged the judge to admit the tape as evidence.

Harris’s lawyers unsuccessfully objected to the new evidence, claiming it would unfairly prejudice his case and he had a “less than perfect” memory, despite having been adamant in his evidence that he had not been there.

related.body:
Here’s how the world reacted.

THE MAN HIMSELF

Even Kyrgios was surprised at how well he played.

“I was in a bit of zone out there, I played some extraordinary tennis, I served at a really good level out there,” he said.

“I’m a normal kid like any 19-year-old who likes to play on his Xbox. The big stage is something I thrive on.

“Never did I think a week ago I was going to make the quarter-finals of Wimbledon in my first appearance.”

Have to do it all again tomorrow and I can't wait! First @Wimbledon & I'm in the last 8 club!! #HaveThat

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

Slowly sinking in. What an unreal day! Thanks to Simon, AK, Anne-Marie & @JohnMorris1982 for all their hard work. Massive team effort. #BOOM

— Nicholas Kyrgios (@NickKyrgios) July 1, 2014 

HIS MUM

Kyrgios’ own mother didn’t think he could beat the world No. 1.

“My mum said in an interview she thought Rafa was too good ... that made me mad and spurred me on,” Kyrgios told the BBC.

MORE: The shot that stunned the world 

MORE: Giant killer Kyrgios takes out Nadal 

Nick Kyrgios’ quarter-final match against world No. 9 Canadian Milos Raonic will start after midnight tonight AEST. 

THE OPPONENT

The ever-gracious Rafael Nadal heaped praise on Kyrgios, conceding “he play better than me”.

“When you have an opponent that he decides to serve and to hit every ball very strong, you are in trouble,” Nadal said.

“I didn’t play really bad.”

Asked what the dual Wimbledon champion would be doing with his unexpected spare time, Nadal said: “Congratulations to him. For me, beach. For me, I going to go to the beach in Mallorca.”

THE LEGEND

John McEnroe came up with a massive call, saying, “We have found the next guy in the men’s game.”

“The last guy I saw like this was Boris Becker with no fear and believing that they can win this thing,” McEnroe said.

“You are watching someone who is going to be a big star in the future.”

Aussie Aussie Aussie Oi Oi Oi. @NickKyrgios the giant slayer! #wimbledon #believe pic.twitter.com/H8xt7lGRPh

— Pat Cash (@TheRealPatCash) July 1, 2014 

Nick Kyrgios- the Wonder from "Down Under" shocks #1 Nadal at Wimbledon. Welcome to the World Stage- YOUTH!! Great effort.

— Jimmy Connors (@JimmyConnors) July 1, 2014 

THE MEGASTAR AND A COUPLE OF PMs

Actor Hugh Jackman, Prime Minister Tony Abbott and former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser were among the famous Aussies to show their support for our newest star.

Aussie Aussie Aussie @NickKyrgios. Such composure and class! But hard off to @RafaelNadal ... one of the greatest of all time!

— Hugh Jackman (@RealHughJackman) July 1, 2014 

Extraordinary performance @NickKyrgios. Australia couldn't be prouder of you - what a win & what an amazing attitude! #Wimbledon2014

— Tony Abbott (@TonyAbbottMHR) July 1, 2014 

Wimbledon 2014: Nick Kyrgios defeats Rafael Nadal in four-set upset. Victory extraordinary, congratulations Kyrgios. http://t.co/F7DImcNLWm

— Malcolm Fraser (@MalcolmFraser12) July 1, 2014 

THE TWITTERATI

And this is how the rest of the world reacted...

Even though my TV show premiered tonight!!! I regretfully say this was by far the best thing on television. #Kyrgios pic.twitter.com/HhUockXJel

— Andy Lee (@andy_lee) July 1, 2014 

Now that was worth staying up for. @NickKyrgios take a bow. Remarkable play. #Wimbledon #aussiepride

— Steve Smith (@stevesmith49) July 1, 2014 

Kyrgios is the 1st teenager to beat a world #1 at a Grand Slam since Nadal def Federer at 2005 French Open. Congrats Nick. Stunning effort.

— Darren Cahill (@darren_cahill) July 1, 2014 

Three weeks ago, Nick Kyrgios was losing in the first round of a Challenger event in Nottingham. To world 185 John-Patrick Smith. Meteor

— tomfordyce (@tomfordyce) July 1, 2014 

Nick #Kyrgios is the first player outside the top 100 to beat the world No.1 since Andrei Olhovsky v Jim Courier 1992 pic.twitter.com/veQynIAKlt

— BBC Tennis (@bbctennis) July 1, 2014 

‘He play better than me’: Rafael Nadal after losing his match against Aussie Nick Kyrgios. Photo: Scott Heavey/AELTC - Pool/Getty Images
