related.body:
Little phoned AFL chief executive Gillon McLachlan at 9.30am after details of Dr Peter Harcourt’s address to a Zurich anti-doping conference were revealed.

“The AFL are not in any doubt about how we feel,” Little said.

“We’ve either got a doctor who is running his own agenda, or we’ve got an organisation which gave the approval (for him to speak) when they shouldn’t have.

“We now need to get the background behind why Dr Harcourt said what he said. Does he know information that we don’t?

“That needs to happen somewhat urgently I would have thought.”

Asked if Harcourt’s position was untenable, Little said: “I think if he acted above and beyond the brief that he had to speak at this international conference then he requires to be sanctioned. What that sanction is I’m not going to speculate about that.

“If he was exceeding his authority we have a problem with him. If he was doing what the AFL had signed off on, then we have a problem with the AFL.

“So we are not quite sure where that sits.”

EARLIER today, the AFL Players’ Association has condemned comments from the league’s chief medical officer suggesting “broad acceptance” by Essendon players of the club’s supplements program.

The AFL has sensationally revealed it sent specimens from Essendon players to Germany during 2012 — months before the club “self-reported” to the league and ASADA.

A video emerged yesterday where AFL chief medical officer Dr Harcourt stated that the AFL had caught “wind” that the Bombers were using exotic drugs.

In the video Dr Harcourt says “most athletes of the team were involved — so there was quite broad acceptance by the players of this program even though it involved quite unusual practices and hundreds of injections.”

ROBBO: AFL’S ACTIONS HARD TO FATHOM 

ESSENDON PLAYER IDENTITIES MAY BE REVEALED 

However the AFLPA hit back on Thursday morning, with acting CEO Ian Prendergast saying players didn’t expect to be subjected to such experimental substances. The players union says it will seek further information from the AFL regarding Dr Harcourt’s comments.

“We disagree with Dr Harcourt’s suggestion that players passively accepted the use of supplements and did not ‘jack up and say what the hell is going on’,” Prendergast said.

“As has been made abundantly clear on many occasions, players took an active role in ensuring that the substances they were to be administered were compliant with the WADA Code and were provided with written guarantees from the club to that effect. This is hardly what we would call ‘passive acceptance’.”

Harcourt’s explosive claims were made in an address to an anti-doping conference in Zurich last November and seized on by lawyers for suspended Essendon coach James Hird in the Federal Court today.

The revelations raise fresh questions about what was known and suspected within the AFL about Essendon’s 2012 drugs regime.

“We did have some wind of this during the course of the year — it was 2012,” Harcourt said in his address.

“And so we did arrange through ASADA to have a number of specimens of these players sent to the Cologne laboratory rather than the Sydney laboratory — but nothing came out of it.

“Most athletes of the team were involved — so there was quite broad acceptance by the players of this program even though it involved quite unusual practices and hundreds of injections.

“It was shocking the extent to which experimental drugs were given to young athletes.

“It highlighted the craziness or madness of certain individuals in the support staff who really didn’t come to grips with what they were doing.”

Harcourt also made the stunning claim in the video that “35-odd” Essendon players were being monitored for “potential hormonal issues or cancers”.

Prendergast was also critical of the AFL chief medical officer to speak publicly about any potential health issues.

“We also believe Dr Harcourt’s comments with regards to potential health consequences are unhelpful and have the potential to create unnecessary stress and anxiety for players and their families,” the acting AFLPA boss said.

“As has been reported, the Players’ Association has been working with the AFL and the club to implement a health protocol to monitor players’ health going forward.

“However, to publicly speculate on any potential health issues in the absence of any evidence is premature and inappropriate.

“We are seeking further information from the AFL in regards to Dr Harcourt’s comments.”

Six months after the video, show-cause notices would be issued to 34 former and current Essendon players by the Australian Sports Anti-Doping Authority.

VIDEO REVEALS WHY AFL TEAMED UP WITH ASADA 

“One thing that we have to deal with, and this is the sobering element, my job now is to work out a program to monitor the players for the next five to 10 years because they were given such exotic substances — many of them growth factors — which means that we are looking at potential hormonal issues or cancers,” Harcourt said.

“So now we have to go through a process of looking after this 35-odd players just to make sure that nothing really nasty happened to them from this crazy activity that individuals allowed to occur at the club.”

He told the conference Essendon’s governance in 2012 was “shocking” and that Bombers players did not “jack up” and protest against the drugs program.

“There was shocking corporate governance over the team … club officials who were blind to their accountability and (there was) fan syndrome — so the leadership within the club were ex-players who were icons of the game,” he said.

“And I think this intimidated a number of management staff. Basically we think there was a degree of fan syndrome in accepting the leadership knew what they were doing.

“Athletes passively accepted the use — this shocked us. Players did not jack up and say ‘what the hell is going on?’.

“There was probable use of performance enhancing drugs … there was clear risk of use.”

He explained why the AFL booted Essendon from last year’s finals before ASADA had finalised its case against the players.

“We had to deal with the team in the context of the competition,” Harcourt said.

HIRD MAKES EXPLOSIVE CLAIM AGAINST ASADA 

“We pushed for there to be some resolution about that in around about July/August because our finals are in September.

“There was an urgency within the league ... which was an issue we had to confront with ASADA who were focused on building there anti-doping cases which take longer.

“So in a sense we have separated those two issues, so that we can address the issues of the team, but keep the option open of dealing with the individuals with doping violations.

Harcourt said human-growth hormone releasing substances; sections of the HGH molecule; a dementia therapy drug and veterinary products were used.

“Most of the substances were just recently on to the WADA list or in the `and related substances’ sections of the list,” he said.

“The individuals who were going about this were trying to exploit the nuances of the WADA list and probably also had some understanding that some of these substances were so new, that the laboratories didn’t have the capability of dealing with them.”

Harcourt did not return calls and the AFL declined to comment.

The winning ticket, which is yet to be claimed, was sold at Princess Road News and Lotto, Balga, in Perth’s north-east.

Lotterywest is still waiting to hear from WA’s newest multi-millionaire.

It is the fourth Division 1 Lotto win in just three days and was the nation’s only Division One winner.

Lotterywest spokesperson Pina Compagnone said last night’s win follows a run of Division 1 Lotto wins in WA.

Two of these prizes, each worth $1.2 million, were from last weekend’s Saturday Lotto Superdraw and another $1 million win from Monday night’s Lotto draw.

“This is an incredible result for WA and we are delighted that we have added another local player to our Division 1 winners’ tally which has now reached 40 for the year,” she said.

Ms Compagnone said the $10 million win was the second largest in WA for the year after a couple from Perth’s southern suburbs collected a $15 million OZ Lotto prize in April.

A further 40,270 other WA players collected an OZ Lotto prize last night in the draw’s other Divisions.

Lotterywest encourages all players who may have purchased a ticket in the draw to check them as soon as possible for the winning numbers 10, 19, 44, 20, 15, 1 and 11.

Lotto winners are not the only ones who benefited from OZ Lotto’s jackpot run, with Lotterywest raising millions to support the WA community from the draws.

Local groups to benefit from Lotterywest funding include the WADJAK Northside Aboriginal community Group located in Balga. The group received a $14,865 Lotterywest Grant last year to help with the development of a resource centre for community members living in Perth’s northern suburbs.

WA players will have another chance to win big in Lotto tonight with Double Win Day.

Double Win Day will mean prizes across all Divisions in Wednesday Lotto (Draw 3361) will be doubled with a potential Division 1 winner taking home a topped up $2 million! Make sure to purchase your tickets by 6pm today to be in it to win it.

Tickets are available from Lotterywest retailers across WA, online and on mobile devices via Play Online at www.lotterywest.wa.gov.au

Lotterywest’s Spirit of Our Community

related.body:
The front crossed the South West coast overnight, dumping heavy rain across much of the South West of the state, with a top fall of 52mm at Payndale near Donnybrook.

Most centres in the region received between 30mm-50mm.

Jarrahwood had 51mm, Acton Park, 43mm, Capel 41mm, Busselton 37mm and Manjimup 32mm.

Perth recorded 18mm after heavy rain started falling at about 8.20am.

Falls were even heavier in southern and coastal suburbs, with Jandakot reaching 40mm, Garden Island 22mm, and Dwellingup, 97km south of Perth, 27mm, Champion Lakes 21mm, Swanbourne 20mm and Mandurah 12mm. Lancelin, north of Perth has had 20mm

A thick blanket of showers settled over the city from early today, promising more rain before it eases off this afternoon.

Some rain has already reached agricultural areas, with Wandering in the Great Southern recording 8mm and Katanning 4mm.

In the Central Wheatbelt, Badgingarra and Geraldton have both recorded 9mm.

The downpour made driving conditions horrendous with a spate of minor crashes causing problems across the city traffic grid.

TRAFFIC: Check our traffic site 

A multiple-car pile-up on Marmion Avenue, southbound in Tamala Park in Perth’s far north, caused severe problems just after 8am, but has since been cleared.

More recently, a truck breakdown on Beeliar Drive, eastbound, at the Kwinana Freeway intersection is causing delays.

A band of heavy showers was visible on the Bureau of Meteorology radar, with the most severe downpour having moved over the city by about 9am and heading inland.

However further showers are clearly visible and are expected to continue through the morning.

Perth can expect a wet day, with rain clearing later in the afternoon and a maximum of 20C.

The Bureau tipped between 15mm and 25mm for the city and some showers are forecast for the rest of the week and heading into the weekend.

THE WEEK AHEAD

related.body:
They will now stand trial later this year.

The four teenage boys, who cannot be named because they are all under 18, have been charged with murdering the 16-year-old on December 22 in Balga.

The four, who at the time were aged 15 and 16, have also been charged with stealing $175 cash from the 16-year-old as well as two debit cards.

The four youths appeared in the Perth Children’s Court via video link this morning.

They all pleaded not guilty to murder, aggravated robbery and the lesser charge of unlawfully causing grievous bodily harm.

The alleged victim was found injured in Princess Wallington Reserve in Balga on the afternoon of December 22. He died in Royal Perth Hospital the following day.

The four teens charged with his murder will stand trial on October 27.

The trial is expected to take four weeks.

related.body:
But Senior Sergeant Steve Principe said the officer managed to avoid the bite both times.

The 26-year-old woman was arrested at McDonalds in Busselton at midnight, after reports she had been disturbing other customers.

She was taken back to Busselton Police Station to be charged and processed.

Senior Sergeant Principe said the woman lashed out at a male Senior Constable in the charge room.

“She threw a cup of water at him, and then she went to bite him in the genital area,” he said.

“I don’t think she made contact — he pulled away.

“She then bit him on the hand — he had gloves on — and tried to spit at him.”

The bite broke the skin but did not puncture the glove.

The woman was then taken to Busselton Hospital, at her request, before being taken to Bunbury Regional Hospital for assessment and allegedly attacking the Senior Constable again in the carpark.

“She has then scratched the officer on the forearm, drawing blood, and then she again attempted to bite him on the crotch,” Senior Sergeant Principe said.

The Senior Constable has had a blood test to check for communicable diseases and will have to wait three months for the result.

The woman, of no fixed address, was charged with two counts of assaulting a public officer and will face court at a later date.

Police say the man was driving a Toyota ute on Cascades Road at Lake King, near Ravensthorpe, about 460km south-east of Perth, between 6.30pm and 7pm when the ute drifted on to the shoulder of the road.

The ute then lost control and rolled.

The driver was killed but his four male passengers, Thai nationals aged between 35 and 45, only sustained minor injuries.

All four passengers were taken to nearby Ravensthorpe and Esperance hospitals for treatment.

Police are still trying to contact the driver’s next of kin.

Anyone with information can contact Crimestoppers on 1800 333 000.

related.body:
The Stop the Mosque in Kalgoorlie Facebook page began last week and had amassed 729 likes by this morning.

It is linked to three other anti-mosque pages, including Stop the Mosque Bendigo which became national news last week after it was revealed it was funded by far-right lobby group Restore Australia.

The Stop the Mosque page, which bears the disclaimer, “no Islamic debate or trolls tolerated here,” has 727 followers.

Posts on the page object to the suggestion that it is racist, saying “it is not racist to oppose a religion that is not compatible with our way of life.”

“Islam is also NOT a religion. It is a dangerous, fascist political ideology like Nazism but it includes aspects of religion. For this reason, islam (sic) has been able to exploit our laws on religious freedom. If we are to defeat islam as we did Nazism, we have to put an end to this and strip islam (sic) of its status as a religion.

West Australians for Racial Equality president Suresh Rajan said content on the page was “extremely offensive.”

“It’s clearly and obviously based on bigotry and religious vilification,” Mr Rajan said.

“What’s scary is it got more than 700 likes in six days … it’s pretty frightening how quickly these things can proliferate.

“I just wonder how these people would react if a similar sort of thing was said about their particular religion.”

Mr Rajan said the popularity of the page was “extremely disappointing, but not surprising.”

“We haven’t really seen any strong leadership on this point from our political leaders to try and change this sort of behaviour,” he said.

The Kalgoorlie Islamic Community Centre lodged an application last month to build a mosque on Park Street. There are already Islamic centres offering a regular place to meet for prayer in the town.

A Change.org petition linked to the Facebook page and calling on the City of Kalgoorlie-Boulder to block the development application has already amassed more than 600 signatures.

Among the supporting statements offered by signatories were “because this is australia not arabia (sic)” and “until they assimilate I will NEVER agree to this.”

“These people do not fit in with our culture and demand us to change! I am totally fed up!”

The City of Kalgoorlie-Boulder has been contacted for comment
related.description: AN anti-Islamic Facebook page that opposes the construction of a mosque in Kalgoorlie has been branded as “based on bigotry” and “extremely offensive.”

Rodney Grljusich – who played junior football in the district before becoming a league player with South Fremantle and now working as an assistant at the junior club – said he had never heard such a remark made by a supporter to a player in all his years in the sport.

Mr Grljusich said the person shouted “try Jenny Craig’s you fat pig” loud enough for a number of supporters, plus coaching staff from both teams to hear it.

He said more needed to be done to try to stamp out abuse of this type at a junior level.

West Australian Football Commission corporate relations general manager Graeme Dix said player reports for inappropriate comments were more common than cases of supporters shouting something derogatory. “The WAFC very rarely receives reports about remarks made at junior football,” he said.

Read more at inmycommunity.com.au

And in the South West another man has been charged with exceeding 0.08 after his ute ended up crashed on its side in the driveway of a house in Collie.

Police were called to the corner of Hester Avenue and Connolly Drive in Merriwa at 11.20pm last night on reports a car had crashed into a street light pole.

An ambulance was also called, but the driver refused treatment.

The driver was then taken to Clarkson Police Station, and allegedly showed a blood-alcohol content of more than 0.3 per cent.

A spokesman for WA Police said the man collapsed at the police station as he was being processed and an ambulance was called to take him to Joondalup Health Campus.

“Officers checked on the man at a later time and were advised he seemed OK, and was sleeping off his intoxication,” the WA Police spokesman said.

The man will be charged via summons.

In another incident, a 48-year-old Collie man was charged with exceeding 0.08 and having no authority to drive after the Mitsubishi Triton ute he was driving lost control and landed on its side in the driveway of a home in Collie.

Collie Police spotted the ute on Prinsep Street about 10.45pm last night and swung around to follow it.

They lost sight of the ute over the crest of a hill and again around a right hand bend, before coming upon it lying on its side in the driveway of the home.

Police say it appeared to have crossed through the garden of one house, driven through a fence and struck a parked car, which then hit the house.

The windscreen had to be smashed out to free the trapped driver, and the crash cased structural damage to the house.

The man will appear in Collie Magistrates Court next week.

The City of Subiaco, the City of South Perth and the Shire of Serpentine-Jarrahdale have joined a Vincent resident Ian Ker in the legal battle.

They claim Local Government Minister Tony Simpson’s proposal to slash the number of metropolitan councils from 30 to 15 is “unlawful”.

Lawyer John Hammond, who is representing the councils, was unable to say how much the court action would cost ratepayers.

The City of South Perth, which is proposed to be abolished and taken over by the Town of Victoria Park, has committed up to $100,000.

South Perth councillors last week also voted for the new local government entity to be named South Park if the merger goes ahead next year.

Perth council votes to rename itself South Park 

The injunction bid is against Mr Simpson and the Local Government Advisory Board.

If granted, it could stop the board from considering Mr Simpson’s proposed boundary shake-up.

The Shire of Kalamunda confirmed it would provide financial support, but was not a named party in the action.

Mr Hammond told ABC radio this morning: “One of the arguments we run is that a number of councils that are about to be abolished, their electors do not have a say as to whether they should be abolished.

“That means they can’t go to a poll. We’re saying all councils and all electors should be able to go to a poll to make a decision on this.

“It’s important to remember that some of these local governments have been in existence for 100 years or more and to suddenly wipe them off the map isn’t something that should happen with just the stroke of a pen.”

Premier Colin Barnett has previously warned councils against wasting ratepayers’ money on court action.

Local Government Minister Tony Simpson said he was in Port Hedland today and had yet to see what the legal action actually entails.

“What I will say is that the Liberal-National Government remains committed and focused on the ultimate goal – strengthening the capacity and sustainability of local governments so they can deliver high-quality services to their communities,” he said.

“Ultimately, it’s up to the community to decide if their councils joining costly legal action against the State Government is a good use of their ratepayer dollars. If they lose, ratepayers could be liable for court costs, and the expenses could be very large.

“The South Perth community, in particular, would be understandably confused by this announcement. On the one hand, we’ve seen great engagement between the council and their community to name the new ‘South Park’ or ‘South Bank’.

“On the other, we’ve got the same council joining legal action to stop mergers.”

He said the board, due to make its recommendations to him shortly, would continue its deliberations.

“Local government reform has been talked about for years. I am confident the process we have followed is in line with the provisions of the Local Government Act,” he said.

“I am absolutely committed to seeing this process through.”

South Perth Mayor Sue Doherty said the council would continue to work closely with Victoria Park in an amalgamation process in good faith.

“While supportive of reform in general, the council and our community have repeatedly been let down by the State Government process,” Mayor Doherty said.

“The City has strongly objected to the Minister’s proposals to transfer part of the Burswood Peninsula into the City of Perth as well as abolish and disestablish the City of South Perth and have it taken over by our neighbours at the Town of Victoria Park.

“The most recent decision of the Government to allocate a miserly $15 million over three years for the Local Government Reform process for the whole of the metropolitan area is grossly inadequate.

“The State Government is blatantly disregarding its responsibility to meet the costs of the process that it has initiated.”
related.description: A BID for a Supreme Court injunction to stop the Barnett Government’s plan to halve the number of Perth councils will be lodged today.

related.subtitle: Perth councils launch Supreme Court battle to stop Barnett Government’s boundary shake-up

Amy Matthews, 21, was on a dream US holiday with a friend when she was caught in the middle of the shooting on New Orleans’ main tourist strip Bourbon Street.

Ms Matthews was one of 10 bystanders injured in the shooting on Sunday.

In her first TV interview, Ms Matthews told Nine News she did not immediately know what to think when she was hit by a bullet.

“I realised when I opened my mouth, my mouth started filling with blood, I opened my mouth into my hand and there was just blood and teeth and all sorts in my hand and I thought there was something more than just a knock to the face,” she said.

“I don’t really know what was going through my mind to be honest, it was full of adrenaline wondering what had happened, I just had no idea.”

Ms Matthews is lucky to be alive and plans to return home to Perth soon.

See Ms Matthews’ interview on Nine News at 4.30pm and 6pm
related.description: A YOUNG Perth woman who was shot in the face during a New Orleans gunfight says the terror of her near-death experience only dawned on her when broken teeth and blood gushed from her mouth.
related.standFirst: PERTH woman Amy Matthews is lucky to be alive after she was shot in the face during a gunfight in New Orleans.
related.subtitle: ‘I opened my mouth ... there was just blood and teeth’: Perth woman Amy Matthews shot in the face during New Orleans gunfight

That’s the advice of the Australian Medical Association of WA, who today warned our favourite devices were “Petri dishes for disease and germs.”

The shortest day of the year may already be behind us, but Health Department WA data suggests WA’s influenza season is only just starting.

AMA WA president Michael Gannon said mobile phone hygiene was crucial to warding off the flu.

“The winter flu season is just starting and people should remember the checklist of ways to

prevent catching or passing on the flu,” he said. said.

“Mobile phones are one of our most used personal items and have become Petri dishes for

disease and germs.

“We have to remember that we take our mobile phones everywhere — from our beds to our

kitchens, to work and to the toilet.

“Studies have shown that mobile phones are dirtier than toilet seats, and are one the

dirtiest things we come in contact with on a daily basis.

“We pass our phones around to our children, our friends and work colleagues and our

germs can soon become their diseases.”

Dr Gannon said recent studies had shown one-in-six mobile phones contained traces of E. coli bateria.

He said the best way to ensure your phone was germ-free was to use antibacterial wipes every few weeks, or to roll your mobile phone in your hands after using hand sanitiser.

The flu usually kills around 2800 Australians every year — more than the national road toll, Dr Gannon said.

“We urge all West Australians, particularly those in high risk groups, to be proactive this flu

season and get their flu shots when possible,” he said.
related.description: KEEP your mobile phone clean to avoid catching the flu.
related.standFirst: KEEP your mobile phone clean to avoid catching the flu — that’s the advice of the Australian Medical Association.
related.subtitle: Australian Medical Association of WA warns mobile phone hygiene crucial in flu fight

related.body:
These two beautiful, inspirational teenage girls I first met at Princess Margaret Hospital in December have inspired me in ways I never thought possible.

Chloe Clements was diagnosed with a brain cancer called medullablastoma and Caitlin Garrett with Ewing’s Sarcoma.

I cannot, and never will be able to, comprehend what they’ve been through nor will most of you. These little ladies, only 14 and 15, are the most bubbly, outgoing, funny teenagers who should not be battling what they are at their age.

These girls have had their teenage years taken away from them by these horrible diseases.

They should be out with their girlfriends chasing boys on weekends. They should be spending their days at school running amuck with their mates.

Not held up in hospital watching movies fighting for their lives.

It’s not fair that they have to go through this. It’s not fair they have to lose their hair, it’s not fair that they can’t be kids and it’s not fair that they have to spend hours, days and sometimes weeks at Princess Margaret Hospital.

I’m extremely lucky to have met Caitlin and Chloe, as it really hammers home that my worries in life are very small compared to what they’re going through on a daily basis.

I still remember the very first time I met them, their smiles lit up the entire room at PMH. When I think about them many words come to mind; inspirational, brave, courageous, beautiful, determined, strong, funny, hopeful, and caring. 

These girls have inspired me and I’m thankful they’ve come into my life.

After the first time I met them I went home upset that I couldn’t help them. I was upset that this was happening to them.

I spent hours that afternoon asking: Why has this happened to them? Why do they have to go through this?

The one reason I kept coming back to was because we need people like these girls in our lives to inspire us.

We need strong, brave, beautiful, courageous girls like Chloe and Caitlin to give us hope.

I’m in no way saying what they are going through is OK; I was just searching for some kind of answer.

Half the battle for Caitlin and Chloe is their need for blood. Your blood.

Within the past year alone Chloe has had 34 platelets and 29 blood transfusions and Caitlin over 45 procedures for both.

This is vital for their survival and for many others.

On numerous occasions the Australian Red Cross Blood Service has been short of blood, meaning these girls have been left waiting. And waiting. And waiting. And waiting, for help.

This is hugely stressful for them and their loved ones.

So what I’m asking of everyone, is to please roll up your sleeve today and donate blood.

Every donation helps save three lives. 

Did you know one in three people need blood but only one in 30 people donate?

Go on, do it today, call 13 95 96 to make an appointment or head to www.donateblood.com.au

No matter how sick these girls are, they can always crack a cheeky smile.

I reckon that’s because they have the most loving family and friends surrounding them who have not left their bedsides for the entire battle.

Their parents are beautiful in nature, determination and strength and I believe this shines through with these girls.

I hope one day you are lucky enough to meet Caitlin and Chloe.

They will change your life. They have changed mine and I’m so lucky I can call them both my friend.
related.description: I USED to believe that everything happens for a reason. Until I met Caitlin and Chloe.
related.standFirst: I USED to believe that everything happens for a reason. Until I met Caitlin and Chloe.
related.subtitle: Heidi Anderson: Inspirational girls a great reason to donate blood

The Education Department today released its latest report on suspensions and exclusions, which shows 11,768 pupils were suspended in 2013.

That represented 4.3 per cent of all students — and compares with 11,715, or 4.4 per cent of all pupils, in 2012.

Physical assault or intimidation of other students accounted for 30 per cent of last year’s suspensions, followed by violation of school rules (28.2 per cent), verbal abuse or harassment of staff (17 per cent), and physical assault or intimidation of staff (7.6 per cent).

Twenty students were also excluded from school in 2013 for particularly bad behaviour — a significant decline from a high of 54 exclusions in 2010.

A spokesman for the Education Department said “schools have access to a range of interventions to address the challenging behaviour of students before resorting to suspension and exclusion”.

“The percentage of students suspended has decreased by 0.5 per cent since 2010,” he said.

“Despite a significant increase in the student population, 430 fewer students were suspended in 2013 than in 2010.

“The number of students excluded has been falling consistently and significantly from 54 in 2010 to 20 in 2013.

“An exclusion order is the most extreme sanction that can be applied to a student in a public school and is reserved for the most serious and disruptive behaviour.”
related.description: MOST of the WA public school students who were suspended last year had physically assaulted or intimidated their classmates, new data shows.

Published on Friday, the video shows a truck turning onto Armstrong Rd from Anketell Rd cutting directly in front of an oncoming BGC tanker.

WATCH THE VIDEO ABOVE

Disaster was averted when the tanker’s truck driver desperately brakes and fortunately manages to slow down in time just in time for the truck to turn.

While many of Facebook shook their heads at disbelief at the turning truck driver, there were also equal numbers praising the efforts of the tanker’s driver to stop in the nick of time. Some social media users even called the tanker driver an “unsung hero”.

The video, posted on the Dash Cam Owners Australia Facebook page, has attracted more than 1500 likes and nearly 3000 shares and hundreds of comments from disgusted users at the “idiotic” actions.

A spokeswoman from WA Police said the 20-year-old man was driving a white Hyundai Excel on Fernhurst Crescent in Balga at 11pm last night.

She said the car “took off at speed” attempting to evade police, before turning into Flinders Avenue.

The Hyundai then swerved onto the wrong side of the road, hit the median strip and smashed into a brick wall.

Police say the driver attempted to reverse the damaged Hyundai away from the crash scene, but police got there first.

Neither the driver nor his 17-year-old passenger were injured. Both were arrested.

The Nollamara man was charged with failing to stop, reckless driving and other driving charges. The passenger was released without charge.

Anyone with information is asked to call Crimestoppers on 1800 333 000.

Rosa today inked a two-year extension at the club that drafted him in 2004, with the signing coming just days after his 150-game milestone.

“I was here in 2005 and 2006 when the club played in grand finals and won a premiership and I have been around for some other exciting finals campaigns,” Rosa said.

“I am confident we can build towards that with this group and I want to be a part of it.

“As a senior player, I believe I have an important role to play at the club and I have great faith in the playing and coaching groups.

“Adam Simpson is in his first year as senor coach and he has changed a few things, with the game plan and training.

“It is taking a little bit of time for us to get on the same page with all of that, but we are certainly moving in the right direction.

“I have been here for 10 years and it definitely feels like home. It also feels like there’s some unfinished business.”

After Darren Glass’ retirement earlier this season, Rosa is one of only three current Eagles to have played 150 games.

He made 15 appearances in the club’s 2006 premiership season, including two finals, but missed out on selection in the flag-winning side.

It caps a positive fortnight of re-signings for WA clubs. Nat Fyfe and David Mundy committed to Fremantle, while Jeremy McGovern will remain at West Coast after agreeing to a two-year deal.
related.description: WEST Coast wingman Matt Rosa says the lure of completing “unfinished business” helped his decision to re-sign with the Eagles.

On the same day WA Labor was hoping Mr Shorten would be addressing the party faithful at its biggest and most important day of the year, Mr Shorten will be addressing the party faithful in New Zealand.

The New Zealand Labour Party’s ‘Putting People First’ annual congress agenda has Mr Shorten speaking on Sunday, July 6 at 11.50am.

Mr Shorten was invited to attend this weekend’s WA Labor state conference but instead, headed to New Zealand.

Last year Mr Shorten went on holidays instead of attending WA Labor’s state conference.

Privately, senior Labor figures are angry that Mr Shorten will be a no show this weekend.

His non-appearance comes just a few months after Labor lost a WA senator — Louise Pratt — in the federal parliament because of a low vote.

This weekend’s state Labor conference is being held at Ascot Racecourse.

A statement from Mr Shorten’s office said the minister was “unfortunately unable to attend the WA State Conference due to commitments in New Zealand.”

The snub has infuriated senior members of the WA Labor Party, who are desperate for success after six years in the political abyss.

“First Julia (Gillard) wouldn’t come, now Billy,” a senior Labor MP told PerthNow.

“It’s incumbent on every federal leader to make every effort to come to what is WA Labor’s showcase on the political agenda.

“And certainly it’s disappointing

“It shows that wounds of (Julia) Gillard, (Kevin) Rudd and the WA Labor Party haven’t healed.

“It means there is a lot more work to be done restoring that relationship.

“Him (Bill Shorten) being new — you would have thought he would have wanted to come over for the conference.”

Another senior Labor source told PerthNow: “When he was here for the senate election he made all these promises about being a regular visitor to WA.

“Not being here for state conference sends out mixed messages.”

The agenda for this weekend’s state conference shows shadow assistant health minister Stephen Jones will address the gathering instead.

“Who?” one senior Labor source said, mocking the decision to replace Shorten with Jones.

Labor leader Mark McGowan will address the conference on the Sunday, at which he is expected to give details of party reform — including giving branch members a say in electing the leader of the WA Labor Party is and giving them a bigger say in preselections.

Labor has lost two state and two federal elections in WA since 2008.

It holds just 21 out of 59 seats in the WA Legislative Assembly and just three out of 15 federal seats.

Labor sources said the conference was “crucial” for Mr McGowan, as he prepared for the 2017 state election.
related.description: FEDERAL ALP leader Bill Shorten won’t be attending WA Labor’s state conference — instead he will be attending a Labour state conference in New Zealand.
related.standFirst: UPDATE: BILL Shorten won’t be at WA Labor’s state conference because he’s attending a New Zealand Labour Party event.
related.subtitle: Federal Labor leader Bill Shorten snubs WA ALP state conference

related.body:
Two women were attacked in the incident at a fast food store on Benningfield Road about 6:30pm.

Police will allege a man and a woman made racist remarks towards the pair before assaulting them. The man and woman then fled in a vehicle.

Both victims, aged 20 and 21, sustained cuts and bruises. The 20-year-old woman will require extensive dental treatment.

Murdoch detectives have charged a 32-year-old man and a 26-year-old woman over the attack.

The 32-year-old Leeming man has been charged with two counts of aggravated assault occasioning bodily harm (racially motivated).

He will face the Fremantle Magistrates court tomorrow.

The 26-year-old Willetton woman has also been charged with two counts of aggravated assault occasioning bodily harm (racially motivated). She will appear in the same court on July 11.

related.body:
It wasn’t the best performer of the capital cities and it wasn’t the worst, but the latest figures from the RP Data Rismark Hedonic Home Value Index shows Perth dwelling values performed solidly in the 2013-14 financial year.

Total dwelling values have lifted 1.2 per cent in the past month, the figures show.

Units performed particularly well in the past month with 3.2 per cent value growth while house values rose 1.2 per cent.

While the new data backs recent reports of a slowing market, Perth property values have increased overall since this time last year.

Total dwelling values have dropped 0.1 per cent since the start of the year but are up 5.2 per cent on June 2013.

House values have fallen 0.3 per cent since the start of the year but are up 5 per cent on last year.

Units have continued to rise over the past 12 months; up 8.9 per cent on this time last year.

Perth’s median house price for the June quarter, based on sales settled over the period, was $515,200.

The median unit sales price was $440,000.

The total rental yield for houses over the year was 4.2 per cent and the total rental yield for units was 4.7 per cent.

RP Data senior research analyst Cameron Kusher said the results showed demand for Perth property had slowed in the past six months.

“The market is nowhere near as strong as it was 12 months ago,” Mr Kusher said.

“Values have dropped 0.1 per cent over the first six months.

“Compare that to the six months before or the first half of 2013; values rose 4 per cent in the first six months of 2013.

“Our data has shown sales volumes are down as well.”

related.body:
The woman boarded the train at Perth Underground station about 6pm last Tuesday, entering the third or fourth carriage.

A man boarded at the same station and sat down next to the woman in the crowded carriage.

Kensington Detectives allege the man, described as between 20 and 30 years old, indecently assaulted the woman before getting off the train at Bull Creek station.

Police have released a photo of a man they can help them with their inquiries.

The man is described as 180cm tall with olive skin, short dark hair and a small patch of facial hair under his bottom lip. He was carrying a soft yellow cooler bag.

Detectives have asked anyone with information, particularly a male passenger who spoke to the woman after the alleged assault took place, to come forward.

Anyone with information can contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

related.body:
Justice John Middleton told the court today a decision on whether the players would be joined to the proceedings would be made on Friday. A consequence of the move could be that their names are disclosed at some stage during the trial.

Lawyers for the AFL Players’ Association, which is representing the 34 players, have until 10.15am on Friday to decide whether to join voluntarily or face the prospect of being included at the orders of the court. The players’ legal team is headed by David Grace QC.

“As Mr Grace QC made clear in court this morning, the players’ key concern is their anonymity,” AFLPA acting CEO Ian Prendergast said.

“Despite speculation as to which players have received show-cause notices, the 34 players have not been named, and nor should they. The players do not believe that the action taken by the club and James Hird — the involvement in which they resisted — should change this.”

Justice Middleton today ruled a tranche of secret ASADA documents about the joint investigation and its agreements with the AFL must be released to Essendon’s lawyers.

The swathe of documents would include ASADA’s interim report and any document between the AFL and ASADA related to the drafting and publication of the interim report. Hird’s legal team was given the green light to subpoena the AFL and its integrity chief Brett Clothier to supply them with some documents it received and sent to ASADA.

But the main argument was if the players themselves would be forced to join the proceedings and then publicly outed.

David Grace QC acting for the players said they would suffer “irreparable reputational harm” if their identities were disclosed.

He said the players would not join the club and its coach James Hird in its action against ASADA joint investigation unless their anonymity could be guaranteed.

Mr Grace said he would seek suppression orders for the player if they were named as parties in the case.

Justice Middleton did not rule out forcing the players to join the action as respondents and said while he understood the difficult position they were in, “hard decisions” would have to be made.

Justice Middleton said the issue of joining players would be resolved on Friday.

He also flagged that Essendon and Hird’s lawyers should be provided with the documents ASADA chief Ben McDevitt used to make his decision to issue the show-cause notices.

Daniel Star acting for ASADA revealed to the court there were 45,000 documents which could be relevant to the court action under discovery. He said the agency would provide a full defence to Essendon’s lawyers by July 9.

The direction hearing will continue on Friday.

Earlier, lawyers for 34 former and current Bombers issued with doping show-cause notices met players yesterday to discuss the move.

“We are working through a process with the players to determine whether they (the players) are willing to be joined as a party to the proceedings,” AFL Players’ Association acting chief Ian Prendergast told the Herald Sun last night.

“It is still being considered by the legal team. While we weren’t interested in being joined to the action initially, we understand any decision made by the Federal Court will impact on the interests of players.”

The move came as suspended Bombers coach James Hird yesterday declared players and officials were robbed of the right to stay silent during interviews with AFL and Australian Sports Anti-Doping Authority investigators.

In documents lodged with the Federal Court, Hird claimed the Bombers should have been afforded “the common law right against self-incrimination”.

Instead, Hird says, players and officials were “under threat of censure and sanction” from the AFL if they did not “answer every question asked”.

New details of the legal challenges mounted against ASADA by Essendon and Hird were revealed in documents lodged by both camps ahead of today’s Federal Court hearing.

The Bombers, Hird and ASADA will return to court at 10.15am to finalise which documents must be made available to parties and whether the players will join.

Federal Court Justice John Middleton could also be asked to rule on an application by Hird for AFL integrity boss Brett Clothier to provide documents and give evidence in the witness box.

A statement of claim lodged by Hird yesterday included the allegation that ASADA provided draft versions of its interim report to the AFL before it was completed.

The report was used by the AFL Commission as the basis for the heaviest penalties in football history slapped on the Bombers on August 27 last year.

“On dates known to the respondent, ASADA provided drafts or versions of the Interim Report or parts thereof to the AFL,” the Hird statement alleges.

Hird’s statement claims that his legal team raised concerns about the validity of the AFL-ASADA investigation at the start of his interview at Etihad Stadium on April 16 last year.

It includes an exchange between Hird’s former legal counsel Tony Nolan SC and AFL investigator Abraham Haddad.

Nolan: “Now, gentlemen, we don’t want to enter into any debate as to the legal arguments today as to the nature of the joint investigation as distinct from two separate investigations. We’ll put that debate to the side for a later time, if necessary.”

Haddad: “Okay. That’s good.”

Nolan: “We understand that’s what you say.”

Hird is studying in France and will return to Melbourne on July 28. His 12-month suspension from Essendon expires on August 25.

related.body:
And that seems to have been the template for a proven formula in this town. Organise a photograph with an AFL footballer and a woman in skimpy clothes and you have yourself a spot in the newspaper to promote your latest product/cause/event.

It could be anything from flavoured milk to ballet, but the formula has been used over and over again through the years.

So this week Retrogram has delved into the vault to find a few classic examples. If you can think of any we’ve missed, post a comment below or get in contact through Twitter at @_warwickgreen  and we’ll publish a selection next week.

1. DERMIE AND MILK

Victoria’s ailing dairy industry found a way to turn around its fortunes in the 1970s when it came up with the Big M concept. And a huge part of its marketing was “Big M Girls’’. How else was up-and-coming Hawks star Dermott Brereton going to manage to drink his carton of Big Chocolate back in 1983?

2. LETHAL AND MORE MILK

And without the help of Big M, Hawthorn skipper Leigh Matthews clearly would have struggled with this enormous football-shaped cake in 1982.

3. KB AND TEA 

The question is, did Kevin Bartlett take milk in his tea? Here he is pictured at Punt Rd Oval in 1980, getting a little help to promote Richmond’s sponsor, Tetley, and its upcoming Tetley Tea Party.

4. KOUTA, ANGE AND TOY CARS

Carlton pair Anthony Koutoufides and Ange Christou took time from pre-season training in 1999 to hop on to a Harley-Davidson with Hot Wheels representative Bianca Ross. Something to do with Hot Wheels sponsoring the V8 Supercar Showdown at the Australian Grand Prix apparently.

5. RHYCE SHAW AND FAST CARS

And while we’re on the Formula 1 and grid girls theme, then-Collingwood footballer Rhyce Shaw found himself at Fed Square in 2004. What else would you do but volunteer to have your head shaved by Fosters and Gillette GP reps Ana, Mieke and Katie and then hop into the cockpit of an FI car? Thumbs up, Rhyce.

6. SAM AND LACE

When Geelong ruckman Sam Newman wanted to display the Cats’ snappy lace-up guernsey in 1973, he enlisted the help of a model. Just so that we could compare it to the conventional woollen number, you understand.

7. NICK RIEWOLDT AND BEER

A decade ago the young Saints forward posed in this photo with VB Girls Julia Tink and Elisha Missen to help promote the Great Aussie Legends Evening at the Esplanade Hotel in St Kilda. What that actually involved was beer tasting with more than 650 publicans. Tough gig.

8. LLOYDY AND MUSICAL THEATRE

Also in 2004, Essendon’s Matthew Lloyd took time out from the forward line to join the chorus line. The photo at the top of this page was a cross promotion, with dancers from the musical comedy The Producers giving their show a kick along, while at the same time sporting the colours of the teams playing in that year’s finals series.

9. KEKA AND BOOTS

Long before he became a “lambassador’’, North Melbourne star Sam Kekovich was turning his attention to flogging products. Back in 1969 Keka enlisted the help of HSV7 ballet girls Joan Brockenshire and Heather Warnecke, presumably to promote the new range of locally made White Diamond football boots, famously worn by the likes of Peter Huddson, Ian Stewart and Ted Whitten.

10. ST KILDA AND … NOT SURE REALLY

No. Not a clue, to be honest. The year was 1982 and for some reason St Kilda footballers Darryl Hewitt (26 career games) and Wayne Slattery (11) were out on the Moorabbin turf with a wheelbarrow, in which sat a bikini-clad, high-heeled model. Unless the Saints had just signed a sponsorship deal with a wheelbarrow manufacturer, it’s hard to know how this photograph ever came to be.

RETROGRAM RECALL

FROM Countryfootyscores on Twitter: How rural for the Retrogram country footy list? Leigh Matthews qualifies because Chelsea is in the Mornington Peninsula Football League.

RETROGRAM SAYS: Fair suggestion, but I can’t have it. Chelsea is metro for mine. If you call it rural you have to say that St Kilda (which is further down the line at Seaford) is a country footy club.

FROM Tigerbob on Twitter: What about Graham Arthur and Fred Swift from Sandhurst?

RETROGRAM SAYS: Both outstanding players, who captained their clubs (Hawthorn and Richmond respectively) to premierships in the 1960s, but I couldn’t squeeze them in.

related.standFirst: IT’S an age-old formula — a footy star plus a pretty model equals marketing gold. Here are 10 classic images from the vault that milk the Big M girls for all their worth.
related.subtitle: Retrogram: 10 classic images from the Herald Sun vault of footy stars with girls

related.body:
1. HAWTHORN

44pts 147.9%

R16: North Melbourne (Etihad) W

R17: Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) W

R18: Sydney (MCG) W

R19: Western Bulldogs (Aurora) W

R20: Melbourne (MCG) W

R21: Fremantle (Patersons) L

R22: Geelong (MCG) W

R23: Collingwood (MCG) W

Matt says: This Hawthorn side just does not know how to lose despite everything that has been thrown at it. Remarkably remains in the box seat to claim top spot and now gets its coach and potentially one of its best players (Sam Mitchell) back. Still to play five of the teams currently in the top eight plus Adelaide away, but would only likely not start favourite in one of those games (Fremantle at Patersons).

2. PORT ADELAIDE

44pts 141.9%

R16: Essendon (Adelaide Oval) W

R17: Richmond (Etihad) W

R18: Melbourne (Adelaide Oval) W

R19: Collingwood (MCG) L

R20: Sydney (Adelaide Oval) L

R21: Gold Coast (Metricon) W

R22: Carlton (Adelaide Oval) W

R23: Fremantle (Patersons) L

Matt says: Could have almost locked up the minor premiership with a win over Sydney three weeks ago, now a top two spot is looking anything but secure after losses to the Swans and Adelaide. Securing a home qualifying final has to be the goal. From there, can you imagine what a preliminary final at a packed Adelaide Oval would be like?

RE-LIVE THE CHAT AND HAVE YOUR SAY BELOW

3. SYDNEY

44pts 137.9%

R16: West Coast (Patersons) W

R17: Carlton (SCG) W

R18: Hawthorn (MCG) L

R19: Essendon (SCG) W

R20: Port Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) W

R21: St Kilda (SCG) W

R22: Western Bulldogs (Etihad) W

R23: Richmond (ANZ) W

Matt says: Premiership favourites with Hawthorn and deservedly so based on its last two and a half months. Still, Sydney is no certainty to finish top two given the draws of Hawthorn, Port Adelaide and Fremantle. Luckily for the Swans, they play the Hawks and Power on the run home so they can shape their own destiny. Unluckily though they have to play them both away. Could it be that we’re still talking about that costly Round 1 loss to GWS come the end of the season?

4. FREMANTLE

40pts 132%

R16: Melbourne (TIO) W

R17: GWS (Patersons) W

R18: St Kilda (Etihad) W

R19: Carlton (Patersons) W

R20: Geelong (Simonds) L

R21: Hawthorn (Patersons) W

R22: Brisbane Lions (Gabba) W

R23: Port Adelaide (Patersons) W

Matt says: The derby win for an undermanned Fremantle was massive because it doesn’t play another side currently in the top eight until Round 20, by which stage it could have virtually locked up the double chance. Clashes with Geelong (away), Hawthorn and Port Adelaide (home) in the last month will determine the top two fate of last year’s runner-up.

5. GEELONG

40pts 106.8%

R16: Western Bulldogs (Simonds) W

R17: Melbourne (MCG) W

R18: GWS (Spotless) W

R19: North Melbourne (Etihad) L

R20: Fremantle (Simonds) W

R21: Carlton (Etihad) W

R22: Hawthorn (MCG) L

R23: Brisbane Lions (Simonds) W

Matt says: Great draw to come, one that is rated as one of the easiest by Champion Data. But Geelong’s loss to Gold Coast a couple of weeks ago puts it well and truly on the back foot in terms of taking a spot in the top four. The Cats will have to win at least one, if not two, of their games against North Melbourne (Etihad), Fremantle (Simonds) an Hawthorn (MCG) to have any realistic hope of securing the double chance.

6. COLLINGWOOD

36pts 114.1%

R16: Gold Coast (Metricon) L

R17: Essendon (MCG) W

R18: Adelaide (MCG) W

R19: Port Adelaide (MCG) W

R20: West Coast (Patersons) W

R21: Brisbane Lions (MCG) W

R22: GWS (Spotless) W

R23: Hawthorn (MCG) L

Matt says: Popular consensus suggests Collingwood’s top four hopes were shot the minute it dropped the game it shouldn’t have against the Western Bulldogs. Given the draw ahead, the Magpies are probably just a rung below those sides anyway. May already be sizing up a week one elimination final at the MCG against any one of North Melbourne, Geelong or Gold Coast by virtue of finishing between fifth and seventh.

7. NORTH MELBOURNE

32pts 110%

R16: Hawthorn (Etihad) L

R17: St Kilda (Blundstone) W

R18: Carlton (Etihad) W

R19: Geelong (Etihad) W

R20: GWS (Startrack) W

R21: Western Bulldogs (Etihad) W

R22: Adelaide (Blundstone) W

R23: Melbourne (Etihad) W

Matt says: North Melbourne has, according to Champion Data, the easiest run home of any team in the AFL. The question though is does that rating take in to account the inconsistencies of the Kangaroos? Hawthorn and Geelong stick out as the only two really difficult games left for Brad Scott’s men, who are still every chance of pushing further up the ladder despite the weekend’s shock loss to the Brisbane Lions.

8. GOLD COAST

32pts 101.2%

R16: Collingwood (Metricon) W

R17: Western Bulldogs (Cazaly’s) W

R18: Brisbane Lions (Gabba) W

R19: St Kilda (Metricon) W

R20: Carlton (Etihad) W

R21: Port Adelaide (Metricon) L

R22: Essendon (Etihad) L

R23: West Coast (Metricon) W

Matt says: Gold Coast is surely now headed for its first finals series after a historic win against Geelong a fortnight ago. Given the expectations around the Suns now, they should be favourites in home games against Collingwood, St Kilda and West Coast and away games against the Western Bulldogs (Cairns), Brisbane Lions (Gabba) and Carlton (Etihad). Wins in five of those games, maybe even four depending on percentage, should be enough to clinch a September berth.

9. ADELAIDE

28pts 105%

R16: GWS (Spotless) W

R17: Hawthorn (Adelaide Oval) L

R18: Collingwood (MCG) L

R19: West Coast (Adelaide Oval) W

R20: Brisbane Lions (Gabba) W

R21: Richmond (Adelaide Oval) W

R22: North Melbourne (Blundstone) L

R23: St Kilda (Adelaide Oval) W

Matt says: A shock win in the Showdown on the weekend puts Adelaide back in the hunt to make the eight. The Crows have now won seven of their past 11 games and should make that eight from 12 against Greater Western Sydney this week, which could catapult it — for a week at least — in to eighth. But from there it gets hard. Hawthorn (home) and Collingwood (away) are challenging games while Gold Coast takes on the Western Bulldogs and Brisbane Lions, while North Melbourne in Tassie also lies in waiting down the track. Can’t afford any slip-ups.

10. ESSENDON

28pts 104.9%

R16: Port Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

R17: Collingwood (MCG) L

R18: Western Bulldogs (Etihad) W

R19: Sydney (SCG) L

R20: Richmond (MCG) W

R21: West Coast (Etihad) W

R22: Gold Coast (Etihad) W

R23: Carlton (MCG) W

Matt says: Unfortunately, like last year, the great unknown about Essendon is not so much its fixture but how it will fare in terms of the ongoing supplements saga. All things being even, and if the Bombers are performing to their optimum, then the draw presents the club with a chance to make the finals despite it being rated as the toughest run home of any side. But, like Adelaide, the Bombers can’t afford any more slip-ups ahead of the Round 22 clash with Gold Coast. An upset victory over either Port Adelaide (away) this week or Collingwood next week would be a big help.

11. WEST COAST

24pts 110.6%

R16: Sydney (Patersons) L

R17: Brisbane Lions (Gabba) L

R18: Richmond (Patersons) W

R19: Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

R20: Collingwood (Patersons) L

R21: Essendon (Etihad) L

R22: Melbourne (Patersons) W

R23: Gold Coast (Metricon) L

Matt says: Couldn’t do what Adelaide did — win a game against the odds against its cross-town rivals. Big percentage remains a factor, but realistically now West Coast’s hopes of making the finals are gone. The Eagles have, after all, only won three games since winning their first three matches of the season.

12. WESTERN BULLDOGS

20pts 82.4%

R16: Geelong (Simonds) L

R17: Gold Coast (Cazaly’s) L

R18: Essendon (Etihad) L

R19: Hawthorn (Aurora) L

R20: St Kilda (Etihad) W

R21: North Melbourne (Etihad) L

R22: Sydney (Etihad) L

R23: GWS (Etihad) W

Matt says: Great win against Melbourne on the weekend. Beyond that though, only the most ardent of Western Bulldogs fans would argue it should start favourite in any game other than those against St Kilda and perhaps Greater Western Sydney.

13. RICHMOND

16pts 96.5%

R16: Brisbane Lions (MCG) W

R17: Port Adelaide (Etihad) L

R18: West Coast (Patersons) L

R19: GWS (MCG) W

R20: Essendon (MCG) L

R21: Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

R22: St Kilda (MCG) W

R23: Sydney (ANZ) L

Matt says: Finally Richmond has a bit of breathing space between itself and the wooden spoon. The draw actually doesn’t look too bad for the Tigers. A few wins against the likes of Brisbane Lions (MCG), Greater Western Sydney (MCG) and St Kilda (MCG) again may paper over some of the cracks, but at least they will put smiles on the faces of a few fans ahead of a long, hot summer.

14. CARLTON

16pts 87.1%

R16: St Kilda (Etihad) W

R17: Sydney (SCG) L

R18: North Melbourne (Etihad) L

R19: Fremantle (Patersons) L

R20: Gold Coast (Etihad) L

R21: Geelong (Etihad) L

R22: Port Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

R23: Essendon (MCG) L

Matt says: Shaping as being the season of ‘What ifs?’ for Carlton given close losses to Richmond (12 points), Greater Western Sydney (eight), Brisbane Lions (seven), Geelong (five), GWS (eight) and Collingwood (15). Finals chances were officially extinguished, if they weren’t already, with the loss to the Giants two weeks back.

15. MELBOURNE

16pts 78.1%

R16: Fremantle (TIO) L

R17: Geelong (MCG) L

R18: Port Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

R19: Brisbane Lions (Etihad) W

R20: Hawthorn (MCG) L

R21: GWS (MCG) L

R22: West Coast (Patersons) L

R23: North Melbourne (Etihad) L

Matt says: For the first time since 2007 Melbourne has beaten each of Essendon, Carlton and Richmond in a season. The form the Demons have displayed this year suggested they would take a top eight scalp at some stage, but perhaps the team is showing signs of tiring in the last couple of weeks.

16. GREATER WESTERN SYDNEY

16pts 77%

R16: Adelaide (Spotless) L

R17: Fremantle (Patersons) L

R18: Geelong (Spotless) L

R19: Richmond (MCG) L

R20: North Melbourne (Startrack) L

R21: Melbourne (MCG) W

R22: Collingwood (Spotless) L

R23: Western Bulldogs (Etihad) L

Matt says: You can’t sit here now and say with any confidence that Greater Western Sydney should start favourite in any of its remaining games. But you also know that the Giants will win again, at least once, somewhere, because their kids are just too good not to. Games against Melbourne and the Western Bulldogs in the last three rounds will be interesting tests.

17. BRISBANE LIONS

16pts 62%

R16: Richmond (MCG) L

R17: West Coast (Gabba) W

R18: Gold Coast (Gabba) L

R19: Melbourne (Etihad) L

R20: Adelaide (Gabba) L

R21: Collingwood (MCG) L

R22: Fremantle (Gabba) L

R23: Geelong (Simonds) L

Matt says: Gabba form — loss to GWS aside — has been relatively good this year. Game at home against West Coast and potentially trips to Victoria to play Richmond and Melbourne present the most realistic opportunities to avoid the wooden spoon.

18. ST KILDA

12pts 59.6%

R16: Carlton (Etihad) L

R17: North Melbourne (Blundstone) L

R18: Fremantle (Etihad) L

R19: Gold Coast (Metricon) L

R20: Western Bulldogs (Etihad) L

R21: Sydney (SCG) L

R22: Richmond (MCG) L

R23: Adelaide (Adelaide Oval) L

Matt says: The warm favourites to win the wooden spoon now after the Brisbane Lions’ win on the weekend. No one thought it would end this way after St Kilda won three of its first four games, but the draw does look bleak from here.

MATT WINDLEY’S PREDICTED LADDER

1. Hawthorn 18-4

2. Sydney 18-4

3. Fremantle 17-5

4. Port Adelaide 16-6

5. Geelong 16-6

6. Collingwood 15-7

7. North Melbourne 15-7

8. Gold Coast 14-8

----------------

9. Adelaide 12-10

10. Essendon 12-10

11. West Coast 8-12

12. Richmond 7-15

13. Western Bulldogs 7-15

14. Carlton 5-17

15. Melbourne 5-17

16. GWS 5-17

17. Brisbane Lions 5-17

18. St Kilda 3-19

WHICH WOULD MEAN ...

Finals, week one

First qualifying final: Hawthorn v Port Adelaide, MCG

Second qualifying final: Sydney v Fremantle, ANZ Stadium/SCG

First elimination final: Geelong v Gold Coast, Etihad Stadium/Simonds Stadium

related.body:
Ms Lau, a 32-year-old from Hong Kong who is formally known as Yuk Ling Lau, was allegedly brutally murdered and raped in Kings Domain on Saturday morning.

Mr Miller, a Californian-born man who has been living on Melbourne’s streets for at least two months, stared straight ahead as he was formally remanded in custody to reappear on October 24.

He has been charged with one count of murder and two counts of rape.

Dressed in a green long-sleeved T-shirt, he looked bewildered during the short hearing and yawned several times.

Legal aid lawyer Sarah Pratt said Mr Miller had been diagnosed with drug-induced psychosis in the past and was suffering a mouth infection.

“It’s his first time in custody,” Ms Pratt said.

A police application to retain a forensic sample was granted.

Friends yesterday described Ms Lau as a “beautiful lovely person” who would be sorely missed.

Family members are now on their way to Melbourne to identify her body.

Mr Miller was extradited back to Melbourne from Batemans Bay late yesterday afternoon.

He looked down throughout the brief hearing at Batemans Bay courthouse yesterday, with magistrate Doug Dick granting a warrant by Victorian detectives.

A makeshift shrine has appeared in Kings Domain near where Ms Lau died. It has drawn people who did not know the dead woman but were deeply affected by her plight.

A cyclist on her way to work left a card that read: “We are so sorry for the sadness and loss that your family is experiencing. Our city grieves with you and for you. I’m so sorry.”

The woman, who also did not know the victim, said it was time Melbourne united and stood up to the violence plaguing the city.

“I think the message that’s coming to us is we’re not safe on the way to work, on the way home from work, out cycling or going for a run,” she said.

“It’s time as women, and men, we stand up and say no to this violence.”

Another woman touched by the death wiped away tears as she left a note addressed to the victim.

“Dear unknown girl,” she wrote. “I’m sorry you had to lose your life in an unknown country at the hands of an evil mad man.

“I hope you managed to have some fun in your young life and lots of love.

“Although I didn’t know you, I will think of you everyday as I pass this spot.”

Ms Lau’s employer at a city chocolate shop said she had worked there since May 2012.

“She worked in our kitchen as a valued member of our pastry team. She will be terribly missed here.

“She was a wonderful person and a beautiful friend and colleague.

“We offer our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends and all our thoughts are with them.

He added: “She was a beautiful, lovely person and will be sorely missed.”

A friend who was laying flowers near the crime scene in Kings Domain told the Herald Sun: “I really liked her smile. She had a beautiful smile. I will never forget it.”

The friend, who did not want to be named, attended the same church as Ms Lau.

Mr Miller was nabbed at 3.30pm on Monday while he was sleeping on rocks in an idyllic coastal town more than 500km away from Melbourne.

He was spotted by off-duty police officers at Snug Cove, Eden, in southern NSW.

Detective Inspector John Potter said the attack on Miss Lau was particularly violent.

She was assaulted sexual and physically, he said.

Insp Potter said some of the woman’s family had been contacted in China and that they were to fly to Melbourne to formally identify her.

Insp Potter urged women not to walk alone, especially in the dark, and to travel by public transport or taxi where possible.

related.body:
Pusic told Confidential that the pressure on the show was “ridiculous,” but not the reason for the pair ultimately deciding too call it quits.

“I think we knew that going into the competition that we had doubts about our relationship,’’ he said.

“We don’t blame the show for not being together.

“There were other weaknesses in the competition.

“Even though we came out of the show not together, we loved the experience.

“I don’t look at it as a bad thing at all, it’s just the way the cookie crumbles.”

The pressure cooker environment of the show also caused conflict between the couples.

In a raging fight during tonight’s episode, Pusic and Stuart accused Perth couple Carol and Russell Bramston of sabotage after a dispute over a wall.

“We agreed at the start of the week what was happening with the wall and it was crucial to have the time,’’ Pusic said.

“Then with two-and-a-half days to go, Russell and Carol said what we agreed to, we were not going to do that anymore. We felt like we were sabotaged.”

Pusic said at the time the tension was crazy.

“Candy was very upset, she took off and I didn’t think she was going to come back,” he said.

“She didn’t think it was fair. I was stuck to pick up the pieces there for a while.

“I was on site trying to redesign a room in a day and half and deal with the missus who wanted to go home.”

The couple was interviewed in recent months by News Corp and spoke about their relationship, wedding plans and their experience on the show, giving no hint of their separation.

related.body:
The Herald Sun understands witnesses will detail claims about senior figures in the Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union.

At least one witness due to give evidence has received death threats from people linked to the union.

The Herald Sun understands footage of a senior Victorian CFMEU official intimidating a builder will be revealed at the hearings.

Links between the official, the union and an underworld figure will also be aired.

It is understood the whistleblower in the video was warned his business may be threatened if he released it.

Sources say he was approached by a person linked to the CFMEU.

He was told that the underworld figure would be able to smooth the way for his projects if he agreed to withhold the information.

Several building industry sources have confirmed the existence of the videos.

The union is preparing a media strategy to limit the damage of the exposure.

It comes after another whistleblower was stabbed in his driveway after he claimed earlier this year that a union official was given a free roof for his home in exchange for industrial peace.

The whistleblower, Andrew Zaf, was hit with a piece of wood and stabbed in the arm and leg in March, according to a police report.

Claims of bikie infiltration at Victoria’s desalination plant are also expected to be heard.

A separate source with knowledge of witness statements confirmed that the outlaw motorcycle gangs were a significant presence on the site.

The hearings are set down for three days from Monday.

stephen.drill@news.com.au

related.body:
Matchmaker Blue Label Life has been ordered to refund Sofia Baltatzidis her membership fee after a representative failed to show at a Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal hearing yesterday.

The Malvern businesswoman joined the service in January 2011 hoping to snare an “intelligent, caring, down-to-earth, genuine” partner.

“It’s hard to meet intelligent people. Every time you go on the RSVP website all they talk about is star signs and footy,” Ms Baltatzidis told the Herald Sun.

Ms Baltatzidis claimed a consultant insisted on introducing her to a primary school teacher despite her objection that he wasn’t suitable for her.

“When I called him he was unappealing and completely negative about his experience with Blue Label Life,” she claimed.

“He had no personality, no humour, no spark. He was a bit of a boring sod.”

She claimed she never heard from a second candidate and a phone introduction to another man proved unsuitable as he lived in Jan Juc and was a “weirdo”.

The consultant described the men as “wonderful, successful” and “genuine gentlemen” who were excited to meet Ms Baltatzidis.

Ms Baltatzidis said Blue Label Life sent her two more profiles of men it said were “extremely compatible” with her in July 2011 despite her demands for a refund, which the agency refused.

Blue Label Life claims all matches are “scientifically compatible” and hand-picked from an “extensive and elite pool of members”.

Director Samantha Jayne said she wasn’t notified of the VCAT hearing and a review of the order has since been recommended.

Ms Jayne said Ms Baltatzidis was given numerous opportunities to meet with suitable candidates.

“Between July 2011 and December 2011 I personally tried to engage with Ms Baltatzidis and to work out a way forward or a resolution to her issue, but Ms Baltatzidis’ behaviour and what we felt at the time were unreasonable demands made it impossible for a resolution to be found,” she told the Herald Sun.

angus.thompson@news.com.au

related.body:
As her family prepare to fly to Australia to be with their daughter, it can be revealed Ms Lau was walking to a dessert shop where she did the early morning shift when the unthinkable began to unfold.

Video footage from the cameras of high-end residential complex The Melburnian, which capture St Kilda Rd, show a woman running from a man before dawn on Saturday morning.

The confrontation on the street before Ms Lau was chased down is still unknown.

It will be the police case Ms Lau was confronted by accused man Scott Allen Miller as he walked home from a night at Bourke St hotel The Carlton after he was ejected about 5am.

What is known is Ms Lau was a devout Baptist Christian who was enjoying life in Melbourne. Although it is believed she had no family in Melbourne, Ms Lau, a Chinese national, had made industry friends here, particularly at the William Angliss Institute.

But those who placed cards and flowers at the site of her death were mainly from her church, who remembered Ms Lau for her faith and her smile.

Fellow colleagues of Renea Lau said she was a “beautiful, lovely person” who will be sorely missed.

“It is with deep sadness that we can confirm Renea Lau was an employee here,” Steven Kearney, her employer, said.

“She’s been with us since May 2012. She worked in our kitchen as a valued member of our pastry team. She will be terribly missed here.

“She was a wonderful person and a beautiful friend and colleague.

“We offer our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends and all our thoughts are with them.

He added: “She was a beautiful, lovely person and will be sorely missed. It is a difficult time for us and we do not wish to comment further.”

In contrast, the riches to rags story of Mr Miller had led him to Melbourne’s Janet Lady Clarke rotunda, opposite the tan track.

He had fallen on hard times since running a nightclub in the 1990s and reportedly until a couple of months ago was living in a shed on a property in Darwin and making didgeridoos.

It will be alleged their paths met for the first and only time as they walked along the tree-lined St Kilda Rd - one of Melbourne’s busiest streets.

The cameras capture Ms Lau running towards Kings Domain. Hours later a jogger would find her battered body near the Victoria Police Memorial.

Homicide investigators had the awful task of informing Ms Lau’s siblings of her death, who in turn told her parents.

Her alleged attacker was apprehended after a three-day manhunt sleeping on rocks in the southern NSW coastal town of Eden.

Mr Miller’s extradition to Victoria was granted by a Batemans Bay magistrate and he was flown to Melbourne for questioning at the St Kilda Road Police Complex today.

Mr Miller will appear in court tomorrow after he is remanded at the Melbourne Custody Centre.

Friends and complete strangers returned to the scene of Ms Lau’s murder today.

Despite not knowing the dead woman, a local resident who wished only to be known as Rod was so touched by her death that he laid a bunch of yellow flowers just metres from where her body was found before holding a minute’s silence.

“It’s terrible. I really feel sorry for her parents,” he said.

“It shouldn’t have happened here. It’s a beautiful spot.”

A cyclist on her way to work left a card that read: “We are so sorry for the sadness and loss that your family is experiencing.

“Our city grieves with you and for you. I’m so sorry.”

The woman, who also did not know the victim, said it was time Melbourne united and stood up to the violence plaguing the city.

“I think the message that’s coming to us is we’re not safe on the way to work, on the way home from work, out cycling or going for a run,” she said.

“It’s time as women, and men, we stand up and say no to this violence.”

Another woman touched by the death wiped away tears as she left a note addressed to the victim.

“Dear unknown girl,” she wrote. “I’m sorry you had to lose your life in an unknown country at the hands of an evil mad man.

“When WILL men stop killing women? Why was he not in an institution?

“I hope you managed to have some fun in your young life and lots of love.

“Although I didn’t know you, I will think of you everyday as I pass this spot.”
related.byline: Jon Kaila, Christopher Gillett, Rebekah Cavanagh
