related.body:
It’s a way of life. It’s heaven in a cup. It’s something you look forward to as soon as you get out of bed.

And, as expected, Herald Sun readers have come to the table in droves, keen to celebrate their favourite froth.

In fact, we’re the most-addicted coffee state in the country, downing an average 808 cups a year and forking out $1674 annually at cafes.

Scroll down to see more of the best Melbourne barista art - as submitted by you! 

A big part of that’s due to your hardworking baristas, who spend hours perfecting the ideal brew to satisfy your tastebuds.

But a cup of coffee is becoming more than just great taste. It’s an art form.

Barista art is a huge industry in Melbourne, and extra flare and creativity is greatly appreciated by coffee connoisseurs.

Rita Zhang from the Home Barista Institute has been working with coffee for 12 years and says the popularity of coffee art has grown considerably.

“Coffee art and any cafe business focus on coffee quality definitely helps their businesses to grow and attract clientele,” Ms Zhang said.

A lady trapped in a capp...Cafe Zen Den - Main Road, Eltham @theheraldsun #MelbCoffeeArt pic.twitter.com/SUKhhFsOgL

— Little Miss Lou Who (@LilMissLouWho) July 2, 2014 

“This is especially true in Melbourne, where the standards are very high. The quality of coffee is firstly judged by the presentation (the Coffee art skills), then the taste (Barista technical skills). Customer’s perception about coffee nowadays is “if it looks good, it must taste good”.

Any cafes that don’t take coffee or coffee art seriously will be left behind.”

A little bit of coffee art over @Melbourne 😀 #melbcoffeeart What do you think @theheraldsun? pic.twitter.com/Yuk4FGt20W

— Eureka Skydeck (@Eureka_Skydeck) July 2, 2014 

Elika Rowell has been a barista in Melbourne for five years and says it’s can be a difficult skill to master and something you can always learn and improve at.

“It’s certainly nice to see peoples’ reactions when you bring out a really good-looking coffee to them,” Ms Rowell said.

Do you have an example of great barista art you’d like to share? Tweet us using @theheraldsun, use #MelbCoffeeArt on Instagram or join the conversation on Facebook. 

MORE FROM THE DEPT OF INTERNET

CAKEGASM: OUR CITY’S FINEST DESSERTS

10 CHARTS MELBURNIANS WILL UNDERSTAND 
YOU’RE NOT A MELBURNIAN UNTIL ...

Working in a high-volume market at the popular Top Paddock in Richmond, their head barista admits some customers may not need the art, but it certainly adds to the experience.

“Plenty of people like to take pictures of their coffee and post on social media so that can be an attractive marketing tool for us,” Ms Rowell said.

Debate is piping hot between fellow baristas about free-pouring vs. using utensils to craft their coffee works of art — with many saying free pouring is a harder skill to master.

“Victoria has a big coffee culture that clearly enjoys latte art. We feel the art lies in the free pour designs, though can appreciate the talent exhibited in other forms,” Coffee Minded manager Jim Velmahos said.

“It took me more than one year to master the art of consistent good coffee and presentation,” Ms Zhang said. The amount of time that effort that goes into learning the craft certainly pays off – and gives baristas a chance to learn new skills when they get a number of different requests.

“When we get customers ask ‘can I have a latte with love heart today?’, it definitely makes our job interesting and satisfying,” Ms Zhang said.

@theheraldsun we love a little coffee art 😀 #melbcoffeeart pic.twitter.com/fb5eLuCfcD

— Macchinetta Coffee (@Macc_Coffee) July 2, 2014 

Managing director at Coffee Art School Australia Steven Fan has been training baristas for seven years - and says the art of communication is key to becoming a real coffee connoisseur.
“You can get the basics down in two days of proper training - but I recommend time to become a real pro is another 3 months,” Mr Fan said.

“And there 3 months must be in coffee shop, so barista can communicate with customers, and find what they really want. This is the soul of barista.”

“There are so many coffee shops in Melbourne, so most customers may feel valued or respected by giving them an artistic-coffee.”

.@BrendoHeraldSun @AnneWardell still maintain this from @ONACoffee in Manuka, Canberra is the best coffee art pic.twitter.com/EaoPGdm5zt

— Shobaz Kandola (@ShobazKandola) July 2, 2014 

Do you have an example of great barista art you’d like to share? Tweet us using @theheraldsun, use #MelbCoffeeArt on Instagram or join the conversation on Facebook.

related.body:
Little phoned AFL chief executive Gillon McLachlan at 9.30am after details of Dr Peter Harcourt’s address to a Zurich anti-doping conference were revealed.

“The AFL are not in any doubt about how we feel,” Little said.

“We’ve either got a doctor who is running his own agenda, or we’ve got an organisation which gave the approval (for him to speak) when they shouldn’t have.

“We now need to get the background behind why Dr Harcourt said what he said. Does he know information that we don’t?

“That needs to happen somewhat urgently I would have thought.”

Asked if Harcourt’s position was untenable, Little said: “I think if he acted above and beyond the brief that he had to speak at this international conference then he requires to be sanctioned. What that sanction is I’m not going to speculate about that.

“If he was exceeding his authority we have a problem with him. If he was doing what the AFL had signed off on, then we have a problem with the AFL.

“So we are not quite sure where that sits.”

EARLIER today, the AFL Players’ Association has condemned comments from the league’s chief medical officer suggesting “broad acceptance” by Essendon players of the club’s supplements program.

The AFL has sensationally revealed it sent specimens from Essendon players to Germany during 2012 — months before the club “self-reported” to the league and ASADA.

A video emerged yesterday where AFL chief medical officer Dr Harcourt stated that the AFL had caught “wind” that the Bombers were using exotic drugs.

In the video Dr Harcourt says “most athletes of the team were involved — so there was quite broad acceptance by the players of this program even though it involved quite unusual practices and hundreds of injections.”

ROBBO: AFL’S ACTIONS HARD TO FATHOM 

ESSENDON PLAYER IDENTITIES MAY BE REVEALED 

However the AFLPA hit back on Thursday morning, with acting CEO Ian Prendergast saying players didn’t expect to be subjected to such experimental substances. The players union says it will seek further information from the AFL regarding Dr Harcourt’s comments.

“We disagree with Dr Harcourt’s suggestion that players passively accepted the use of supplements and did not ‘jack up and say what the hell is going on’,” Prendergast said.

“As has been made abundantly clear on many occasions, players took an active role in ensuring that the substances they were to be administered were compliant with the WADA Code and were provided with written guarantees from the club to that effect. This is hardly what we would call ‘passive acceptance’.”

Harcourt’s explosive claims were made in an address to an anti-doping conference in Zurich last November and seized on by lawyers for suspended Essendon coach James Hird in the Federal Court today.

The revelations raise fresh questions about what was known and suspected within the AFL about Essendon’s 2012 drugs regime.

“We did have some wind of this during the course of the year — it was 2012,” Harcourt said in his address.

“And so we did arrange through ASADA to have a number of specimens of these players sent to the Cologne laboratory rather than the Sydney laboratory — but nothing came out of it.

“Most athletes of the team were involved — so there was quite broad acceptance by the players of this program even though it involved quite unusual practices and hundreds of injections.

“It was shocking the extent to which experimental drugs were given to young athletes.

“It highlighted the craziness or madness of certain individuals in the support staff who really didn’t come to grips with what they were doing.”

Harcourt also made the stunning claim in the video that “35-odd” Essendon players were being monitored for “potential hormonal issues or cancers”.

Prendergast was also critical of the AFL chief medical officer to speak publicly about any potential health issues.

“We also believe Dr Harcourt’s comments with regards to potential health consequences are unhelpful and have the potential to create unnecessary stress and anxiety for players and their families,” the acting AFLPA boss said.

“As has been reported, the Players’ Association has been working with the AFL and the club to implement a health protocol to monitor players’ health going forward.

“However, to publicly speculate on any potential health issues in the absence of any evidence is premature and inappropriate.

“We are seeking further information from the AFL in regards to Dr Harcourt’s comments.”

Six months after the video, show-cause notices would be issued to 34 former and current Essendon players by the Australian Sports Anti-Doping Authority.

VIDEO REVEALS WHY AFL TEAMED UP WITH ASADA 

“One thing that we have to deal with, and this is the sobering element, my job now is to work out a program to monitor the players for the next five to 10 years because they were given such exotic substances — many of them growth factors — which means that we are looking at potential hormonal issues or cancers,” Harcourt said.

“So now we have to go through a process of looking after this 35-odd players just to make sure that nothing really nasty happened to them from this crazy activity that individuals allowed to occur at the club.”

He told the conference Essendon’s governance in 2012 was “shocking” and that Bombers players did not “jack up” and protest against the drugs program.

“There was shocking corporate governance over the team … club officials who were blind to their accountability and (there was) fan syndrome — so the leadership within the club were ex-players who were icons of the game,” he said.

“And I think this intimidated a number of management staff. Basically we think there was a degree of fan syndrome in accepting the leadership knew what they were doing.

“Athletes passively accepted the use — this shocked us. Players did not jack up and say ‘what the hell is going on?’.

“There was probable use of performance enhancing drugs … there was clear risk of use.”

He explained why the AFL booted Essendon from last year’s finals before ASADA had finalised its case against the players.

“We had to deal with the team in the context of the competition,” Harcourt said.

HIRD MAKES EXPLOSIVE CLAIM AGAINST ASADA 

“We pushed for there to be some resolution about that in around about July/August because our finals are in September.

“There was an urgency within the league ... which was an issue we had to confront with ASADA who were focused on building there anti-doping cases which take longer.

“So in a sense we have separated those two issues, so that we can address the issues of the team, but keep the option open of dealing with the individuals with doping violations.

Harcourt said human-growth hormone releasing substances; sections of the HGH molecule; a dementia therapy drug and veterinary products were used.

“Most of the substances were just recently on to the WADA list or in the `and related substances’ sections of the list,” he said.

“The individuals who were going about this were trying to exploit the nuances of the WADA list and probably also had some understanding that some of these substances were so new, that the laboratories didn’t have the capability of dealing with them.”

Harcourt did not return calls and the AFL declined to comment.

related.body:
Edelsten has taken to social media the past week posting shots with a man who goes by the name of Red Ra on Facebook and Instagram.

He is as different as you can imagine to her ex-husband, Dr Geoffrey Edelsten.

On his social media profile it’s obvious that the musclebound Red is a competitive bodybuilder.

The pair have been on trips to the Great Ocean Rd and Tasmania together with Brynne’s beloved fur child, pooch Juddy.

Confidential approached Edelsten’s manager for more details about who exactly the man that goes by the name Red is, but didn’t hear back.

Edelsten perhaps hinted on Instagram last week that she had found new love, posting a cryptic picture.

“Sometimes you meet someone, and it’s so clear that the two of you, on some level, belong together,” the picture read.

It is no wonder Brynne was keen to find love again.

THE WEIRD ROMANCE OF BRYNNE AND GEOFFREY EDELSTEN 

MEET GABI GRECKO 

Her 71-year-old ex Geoffrey Edelsten certainly wasted no time in getting back in the saddle after he and Brynne officially called it quits earlier this year.

He has since hooked up with 25-year-old aspiring model and DJ Gabi Grecko.

Since arriving in Melbourne, the US-born glamour girl has wasted no time in letting her feelings be known about everything from Brynne, mental illness, and ‘corset training’.
related.byline: Luke Dennehy and Alice Coster Confidential

related.body:
Nothing that could taint the London jurors could be published in the UK until the verdict – meaning an internet blackout for some of the most shocking claims of all against the once-beloved entertainer.

Damning claims never heard by the jury were made during pre-trial argument, including that Harris downloaded child porn, cruised dirty sites with names like ‘Youngest Teen Porn’ and attempted to erase his browsing history.

GUILTY: Court rules Harris sexually assaulted teen girls 

VERDICT: Harris brought down by bizarre letters 

‘PREDATORY’: What the jury didn’t hear 

HARRIS’ DAUGHTER: I had him on a pedestal 

The jury was also banned from hearing from other witnesses who painted a picture of Harris as a lecherous old man, with a judge ruling their evidence prejudicial.

And they certainly didn’t get to read about long-standing rumours within Australian entertainment circles that Harris had abused young women.

Shocking allegations emerged during the pre-trial arguments that Harris had attempted to erase pornographic images of young girls from his computer in 2012.

Prosecutor Sasha Wass, QC, told the court that Harris, 84, had searched websites with names like Russian Virgins, My Little Nieces and Youngest Teen Porn, searching for images of underage girls.

Ms Wass said she would not describe the images due to their graphic nature.

The images were on galleries involving “very young people in various levels of forbidden poses”, and were believed to have been of girls under the age of 13.

Harris’s lawyers argued the images were the result of accidental downloads.

HUMILIATED: Rolf’s reputation savaged by trial 

PROSECUTION: Harris called a sinister pervert 

ADMISSIONS: Harris admits to ‘affair’ 

WITNESS CLAIM: Rolf just ‘love to hug’ 

The pre-trial hearing was told that 328 images of adult pornography also existed, and other suspect images could have been pictures of “models” aged 18.

One file called “watch my girlfriend” featured two girls with a teddy bear in the foreground while another deleted file, later retrieved, featured just a girl’s genitals.

Another was of a boy and girl in a pose that he allegedly downloaded and deleted four times

Ms Wass said Harris returned “over and over” to some of the images, including some of underdeveloped girls wearing nothing but socks.

She said Harris’ diary had handwriting detailing how to erase files from the browser history.

Ms Wass said an admission to seeking help to delete images led to the conclusion that he had not downloaded them by accident, and knew some were illegal.

“If it was an accident it appears it was one he had a number of times,” she said.

She conceded the ages of the girls shown was unknown but they appeared to be Ukrainian or another eastern European country known to traffic girls - and their ages would be hard to prove.

Ms Wass urged the Judge to let the jury decide if the underdeveloped bodies meant they were young.

Harris was not required to enter a plea on four charges relating to downloading indecent images of children, and the charges were not dealt with as part of his trial on 12 charges of indecently assaulting girls and a young woman between 1968 and 1986.

During the pre-trial hearing, Judge Nigel Sweeney also ruled that most of the prosecution’s “bad character” witnesses – other people who made allegations of lecherous behaviour - were admissible.

The hearing was delayed at one point when a member of the public tweeted three pages of evidence not meant for publication.

After being informed of the breach, Judge Sweeney called a halt to proceedings and asked the offender to own up – but nobody did.

The suspect tweeter was reported to have been a member of a child abuse activist group.

The trial hit other delays, including one caused by a missing box of evidence.

When contradictory old film footage surfaced that placed him in Cambridge — an area where he said he’d never been at the time – Harris’ lawyers tried to have it kept from the jury.

It was Thames Television footage of a 1978 celebrity sport game show starring Harris – and one of Harris’s accusers alleged she was waitress at the event, when she was 13 or 14.

A person following the case in the local media tipped the prosecution off about the footage, and in the jury’s absence the prosecutor urged the judge to admit the tape as evidence.

Harris’s lawyers unsuccessfully objected to the new evidence, claiming it would unfairly prejudice his case and he had a “less than perfect” memory, despite having been adamant in his evidence that he had not been there.

related.body:
Sources close to the pair told Confidential the pair became a “committed couple” in the past week.

While the two have been friends for a long time, sources say they have taken the “next step” recently, hanging out and going on dates.

The confirmation comes as Warne and Scott were out seen and about together all over Europe, snapping pictures of themselves in London on Tuesday, going to a Coldplay gig and watching Aussie tennis ace Nick Kyrgios’s fantastic win against Rafael Nadal.

There is unlikely to be any public declarations of love from the pair, other than the endless stream of social media pictures that Warne is posting.

Warne and Scott were first pictured together at Jeff Fenech’s 50th birthday last month, at the time he publicly gave the age-old adage that the two were “just friends”.

Scott is the first girlfriend for Warne after it was confirmed earlier this year that he had split with his fiancee Elizabeth Hurley.

It’s been a year of fresh starts for the Spin King, after he sold his Brighton mansion in Melbourne, the house he called home with when Hurley and he were in town.

The new couple are already getting lots of attention in the UK press, where Warne has a massive profile.

Scott also has a profile in the UK, thanks to appearing on the hit reality show I’m a Celebrity Get Me Out of Here in 2011.

EVERYTHING YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT SHANE WARNE’S NEW GIRLFRIEND 

ELIZABETH HURLEY SAYS SHE STILL LOVES SHANE WARNE

related.body:
And the Blues coach laid down the gauntlet to demoted pair Jarrad Waite and Jeff Garlett with their futures at Visy Park seemingly in limbo.

Waite, 31, was axed for the second time this season last week and Malthouse lashed the free agent’s competitiveness.

MICK WON’T NAG JUDD TO QUIT 

ROBBO: WHY MICK MY NEED TO QUIT 

“Jarrad needs to come to grips with what we’re trying to do here at Carlton. And that is build a side that is massively competitive,” he said.

Garlett, who led Carlton’s goalkicking with 43 majors last year, was last week axed for rookie Blaine Johnson.

LISTEN TO THE LATEST EPISODE OF THE SUPERFOOTY PODCAST BELOW OR CLICK HERE TO SUBSCRIBE FOR FREE IN ITUNES 

“We see that (selection) as a step in the right direction,” Malthouse said.

“Garlett’s just not kicking enough goals. And if you kick enough goals and don’t defend you can probably get away with it, but if you don’t do either you don’t play.”

Garlett’s manager Liam Pickering has backed the small forward to remain at Carlton next year.

Malthouse said prized pick Patrick Cripps was a chance to return from a broken leg against St Kilda on Sunday and tipped hard-working left-footer Nick Holman and Irish rookie Ciaran Sheehan to enter the selection frame.

Malthouse highlighted Ed Curnow’s basic skill blunder late against Collingwood which allowed Steele Sidebottom to slot the match-winner as symptomatic of where his side was falling down.

“The thing that beat us on the weekend was the talent level,” Malthouse said.

“It doesn’t say (anything) about the heart level, it doesn’t say (anything) about the running level, it doesn’t say (anything) about the competitiveness.

“It’s got nothing to do with the ability of want or courage.”

The dual premiership coach bemoaned Matthew Kreuzer’s long-term injury had stalled his development and also eliminated selection pressure on Carlton’s big men.

Malthouse said Sheehan, who won a place at the Blues after impressing in last year’s International Rules series against Australia, had improved on the back of a strong development program.

He said Mitch Robinson was remorseful after copping a two-match ban for striking but the incident would help the utility mature after “drastically improving” as a footballer under his tutelage.

The 4-10 Blues’ losing streak is second only to St Kilda’s run of nine games without a win.

Carlton’s run of losses is the longest a Malthouse-coach side has suffered since Collingwood dropped the final eight matches of 2005 as it secured a priority selection used to draft current-Blue Dale Thomas (No. 2) and Scott Pendlebury (5).

Tomic: Hi mate, it’s Bernard.

Kyrgios: Oh.

Tomic: Just wanted to ring and say well done.

Kyrgios: Thanks man. Appreciate it. Anyway, I better run…

Tomic: Hey, when you lost that second set, how come you didn’t just decide it was time to give in and go for drinks?

Kyrgios: Sorry?

Tomic: You know, when you realise it’s all too hard and you just want it to end as soon as possible?

Kyrgios: I can’t say I felt that. I just wanted to win no matter what. I just believed in myself.

Tomic: That makes absolutely no sense at all. Imagine if everyone just went around believing in themselves? Chaos.

Hey, for the next tournament, we should go out together to prepare. Do you prefer to train by getting a lap dance on stage or just drink all night in the VIP section?

I like to mix it up so I don’t get bored.

Kyrgios: Lately, I just pretty much live at the gym.

Tomic: I think I’ve been there. It’s in Miami right? With the rotating dance floor?

Kyrgios: Mate, I have to go, important people are trying to call and I want to get some sleep before my next match.

Tomic: Wait, a tournament goes more than four matches? Oh, you’ve hung up.

READ MORE TITUS O’REILY at the Herald Sun:

KNOW YOUR AFL STEREOTYPES? See the full list.

The unrestricted free agent, 27, is one of the few remaining Pies out of contract but his manager is far from satisfied with the club’s current offer.

Goldsack has already stated he wants to remain a Magpie, but manager Anthony McConville said he and the club were “not on the same page”.

The fan favourite and 2010 premiership player was nearly squeezed out by the Pies two years ago, but would attract rival interest given he can play forward, back, in the midfield and even tag if needed.

Most clubs in the league now have salary cap room given an increase in player payments and new rules allowing clubs to bank room in the cap and spend it the following year.

McConville is negotiating only with the Pies, but rivals might swoop given the remaining free agency pool is so weak this year.

McConville said he was hopeful of striking a deal but adamant it needed to be fair to Goldsack.

“We have had some discussions and we are not on the same page,’’ he told the Herald Sun.

“There needs to be more work done, particularly from their end, and we have got three or four months to work through it.

“They can suggest where he is in terms of their order of merit and that’s their prerogative, but we are a fair way off.

“He ticks a lot of boxes and he might not be a star, but he is 193cm and he can play forward and back and in the midfield.

“I am waiting on Collingwood to get back to me. At the moment there is a fair bit of daylight between what they are thinking and we are thinking. There is still time, but at the end of the day my job is to make sure Tyson is in a good place.”

In 2012 Goldsack had to wait until October to sign a new two-year deal as Collingwood attempted to recontract Travis Cloke despite 24 goals that year.

This year the Pies have already recontracted stars including Dane Swan, Harry O’Brien, Steele Sidebottom and Ben Reid.

related.body:
Victims’ groups said the league was sending a dangerous message that sexual assault is not a serious crime.

Majak Daw has been charged on three counts of rape relating to an alleged incident involving a 15-year-old victim in Altona North in 2007.

The 23-year-old forward has denied any wrongdoing, telling the Herald Sun the allegations were ‘100 per cent wrong”.

The club has vowed to stand by the Sudanese-born player.

Daw yesterday kept out of the spotlight while family and friends rallied together at the Wyndham Vale home of his parents, William and Elizabeth Daw.

William Daw appeared calm, but did not want to speak about the accusations or how his son was feeling.

Victim support groups said football authorities should stand Daw down or he should voluntarily step aside.

Centre Against Sexual Assault forum spokeswoman Carolyn Worth said it was time the AFL considered any player charged with sexual offences as ‘bringing the game into disrepute”.

Ms Worth said no other industry would tolerate a professional remaining in an influential role with sex charges hanging over their head.

‘Until your name is cleared you shouldn’t be in a position of influence and I think those boys (footballers) are in a position of influence,” she said.

Women’s Information and Referral Exchange network chief Samiro Douglas echoed the calls for tougher action. ‘It must have taken a lot of courage for this woman to put herself through the trauma and bring these charges against a high-profile player almost 10 years later,” Ms Douglas said.

When questioned by the Herald Sun in May, Daw denied the allegations. ‘I’m so shocked to even hear about this,” Daw said.

andrea.hamblin@news.com.au

related.body:
Almost 320 Victorian jobs hang in the balance — and more than 2200 nationally — after receivers took control of Ms Cameron’s private company, Discount Superstores Group.

Discount Superstores owns retail chains Crazy Clark’s and Sam’s Warehouse, which it bought out of administration for $59.8 million just 17 months ago.

The purchase in February 2013 was made four months after Ms Cameron, who founded outdoor clothing retailer Kathmandu, placed the chains’ former parent Retail Adventures into administration.

KordaMentha Restructuring has been appointed to take control of Discount Superstore’s 144 Crazy Clark’s and Sam’s Warehouse outlets. The businesses employ more than 2200 people nationwide and have 19 stores in Victoria.

It is the latest blow for Ms Cameron, who was once named Australia’s fourth richest woman and in 2006 sold her half-stake in Kathmandu for $250 million.

She bought Retail Adventures three years later for $85 million, but it collapsed in 2012 with $170 million in debt.

It is thought Ms Cameron had been searching for a buyer or investor to prop up the discount business before it collapsed, and had planned to close about 50 stores.

Receiver Rahul Goyal said the chains had struggled in a difficult consumer climate.

“It appears that the financial pressures of DSG have been caused by the general decline in the retail sector, and particularly the decreased demand for discretionary items like those found in Crazy Clark’s and Sam’s Warehouse stores,” he said.

It was too early to fully determine the receivership strategy, Mr Goyal said, and the immediate priority was to exit unprofitable stores while consolidating inventory.

Mr Goyal said the receivers were searching for buyers for at least some stores while stock was sold off.

“We will be immediately exploring the going concern sale of the profitable ... stores” he said.

Ms Cameron, who has campaigned on environmental and animal welfare issues, reportedly bought Retail Adventures with the aim of channelling proceeds towards her charitable causes.

But the group struggled, instead sucking up nearly all her proceeds from the sale of her Kathmandu stake.

jane.harper@news.com.au

The suspended Bombers coach also claims ASADA relied unlawfully on AFL powers to compel Essendon players and officials to attend interviews and answer questions about the club’s 2012 supplements program.

He asserts evidence used in issuing 34 show-cause notices against former and current Essendon players was “ultra vires” — beyond ASADA’s powers — and therefore the notices were “improperly issued”.

LIVE CHAT: SHEEDY SAYS BOMBERS NEED HIRD BACK 

New details of Hird’s legal challenge against the Australian Sports Anti-Doping Authority are revealed in a 19-page statement of claim lodged in the Federal Court ahead of tomorrow’s second directions hearing.

Lawyers for Essendon, Hird and ASADA will be back in court to finalise which documents must be made available to parties and whether the players should be joined to the proceedings.

A three-day trial in the Federal Court will begin on August 11 where the Bombers and Hird will fight to have the joint AFL-ASADA investigation chucked out.

Federal Court Justice John Middleton will also be asked to rule on an application by Hird for AFL integrity boss Brett Clothier to provide documents and give evidence in the witness box.

Hird’s statement of claim shows his case against the anti-doping authority focuses on the legality of the interim report and the right of ASADA to conduct tell-all interviews with Essendon players and officials.

The Hird camp asserts that both the AFL and ASADA failed to explain to Essendon players or officials that they had a right to silence under the ASADA legislative regime.

Instead, Hird says, they were warned that failure to answer questions and cooperate would be in breach of the AFL’s anti-doping code.

The Hird statement of claim includes the explosive allegation that ASADA provided draft versions of the interim report to the AFL before it was completed and used by the AFL Commission as the basis for the heaviest penalties in football history slapped on the Bombers on August 27 last year.

“On dates known to the respondent, ASADA provided drafts or versions of the Interim Report or parts thereof to the AFL,” the statement alleges.

Public comments made by Clothier and former AFL boss Andrew Demetriou in support of the joint investigation are also referenced by Hird.

“Mr Andrew Demetriou, then AFL CEO, on or about 27 May 2014 affirmed the fact of a joint investigation and further stated that the AFL’s resources and ability to compel people to give evidence had assisted the investigation,” the statement says.

Hird’s statement of claim asserts that his legal team raised concerns about the validity of the AFL-ASADA investigation at the start of his interview at Etihad Stadium on April 16.

It includes an exchange between Hird’s former legal counsel Tony Nolan SC and AFL investigator Abraham Haddad.

Nolan: “Now, gentlemen, we don’t want to enter into any debate as to the legal arguments today as to the nature of the joint investigation as distinct from two separate investigations. We’ll put that debate to the side for a later time, if necessary.”

Haddad: “Okay. That’s good.”

Nolan: “We understand that’s what you say.”

Haddad: “Yeah.”

Nolan: “And he understands what you say.”

Hird is studying in France and will return to Melbourne on July 28.

His 12-moth suspension expires on August 25.

related.body:
But local councillor Daphne McDonald said there was nothing Gold Coast City Council could do because the beach was theirs to take.

Cr McDonald said official surveys showed that the boundary of the blocks owned by several residents went well past the waterline and they paid rates on the whole space – including the beach section. “They are quite entitled to claim that bit of beach,” she said.

NEWS: ‘NOT THE NICEST’ BUT NO CAT KILLER 

NEWS: KATELYN’S LAST HOURS 

WEATHER: SO COLD EVEN THE DOGS ARE RUGGING UP 

Cr McDonald said residents might have also taken the step of putting up fencing because they were legally responsible for the beach portion of their block.

Long-term resident Leonie Clarke, who owns a modest property on Jefferson Lane, said she would be willing to give the sand back if it meant getting a discount on her rates.

“We pay about $10,000 a year here,” she said.

“When I found out that we owned part of the beach as well, I went to council to see if it was right. We thought that we could not own past the watermark.

“We were willing to give it back to council, but they said it was our responsibility and we had to pay for it.

“If we could get a discount, we would still give it back. It is expensive and a hassle to look after.”

Ms Clarke said she did not bother fencing off the beach she owned, but understood why her neighbours went to the effort.

“I am happy for people to sunbake on our bit of beach,” she said.

“I don’t care ... just as long as they don’t bother us. But I think it is important for people to understand that it is our property.”

Shane Watt, who has lived at Palm Beach for more than 20 years, said he would take the same step if he was lucky enough to own a property near the city’s rich and famous on Jefferson Lane.

“I would like to see no development on the beach at all,” she said.

“But that is not possible and if I owned one of those houses, I would have the beach fenced off too.”

Mitch Golledge agreed, saying he would love to have one of the prime spots on Jefferson Lane with a partial beach of his own.

Council first became aware of the boundaries of the properties on Jefferson Lane when they fined a dog owner for having the animal off the leash a few years ago.

They later found out that the dog owner also owned the section of beach where the fine was delivered and it could not be enforced.

related.body:
One tram has been sitting near the intersection of Surfers Paradise Blvd and Clifford St, guarded by security for four days.

How long do you think it will take for the tram to take passengers? Let us know below. 

GOLDLINQ ADMITS LIGHT RAIL CONCRETE CUT AND BASE MODIFIED 

Since Saturday, trams have been forced to run on a shortened track from the Gold Coast University Hospital to Southport Station.

The hurdle comes as speculation continues about when trams will start taking passengers with no official launch date set.

Surfers Paradise traders were told by email of a July 13 launch date for the light rail but then later told the launch date was still to be determined.

GoldLinQ said the incident would not delay trams from taking passengers.

Gold Coast Water work on the burst main finished on Sunday and GoldLinQ is now in the process of repairing the footpath and roadway.

Grace Selway, who works at the BWS on Surfers Paradise Boulevard, said the tram had been sitting in the same spot for the last four days.

“I think it’s a joke, the whole thing.” “I thought it would have been fixed by now.”

She said no one had come to let them know why the tram was stopped opposite the shop.

related.body:
Christie, 19, is accused of killing a cat, cutting off its paws and head and torching a car outside a home in Arundel on June 17.

After the bail application was rejected in Southport Magistrates Court his friends were quick to defend Christie – whom they described as a “decent bloke”.

NEWS: ACCUSED CAT KILLER LOSES JOB 

Josh Westhead said Christie was a good mate who was “incapable of mutilating a cat”.

“He’s not the nicest guy but there’s not a chance he’d mutilate a cat,” he said. 

“He loves to get on the (drink) and he loves to have a good time. I’ve only come up here today to support him as I don’t believe he’s done it at all.”

Another friend, Matt Cooper, said while Christie “didn’t look like the nicest person” he was a good person inside.

“He’s always tried his best to be a decent bloke,” he said.

“I’m really upset that they think he’s a threat to society – he’s a good bloke and I don’t think they should have held him in jail until his next court case. It takes a twisted person to do that to an animal and that’s not Jordan.”

Mr Cooper said Christie would be “devastated” to lose his job following the incident.

“As long as I’ve known him he’s always been working – he’s always been a hard worker, always been to work on time,” he said.

Christie applied for bail yesterday but the application was rejected because of an “unacceptable risk” of him reoffending.

The additional charge of extortion was added yesterday morning to the three other charges against Christie – including arson, killing of an animal and wilful damage.

The maximum penalty for the arson charge is life in jail.

Christie’s concrete rendering boss Nathan Avery has been charged with extorting Lewis Hallam and using a phone or internet service to harass him in the lead-up to the attack. Mr Avery was released on bail on condition that he does not contact Christie.

The court was told Christie was put on an 18-month probation on November 8 last year for assault occasioning bodily harm.

No conviction was recorded from the incident but Christie was given 150 hours of community service – of which he had completed 42 hours.

The court also heard Christie had lost his job as a result of the bail conditions for Mr Avery.

Christie’s lawyer Andrew Moloney told the court the charges against his client didn’t involve any “actual physical violence towards any person”.

Mr Moloney suggested his client would be at risk in custody because of his injuries – stating as he has five plates in his jaw he was “going to be a target”.

Christie will next appear in Southport Magistrates Court on August 22.
categories: /display/goldcoastbulletin.com.au/Gold Coast Bulletin/Gold Coast News and Galleries/

related.body:
A Bulletin report on Saturday revealed a contract dispute was sparked by promoters who were concerned about poor lead-up sales for the ticketed beach festival in April.

Former event and marketing employees also came forward with allegations of a toxic workplace where more than half the staff have resigned during the past 10 months.

NEWS: SURFERS OPEN FOR INFLUX 

MORE GOLD COAST NEWS & GALLERIES 

Business operators upset about SPA events being staged during peak tourism periods have formed the Surfers Paradise Traders Group and wanted a retailer and restaurateur to be appointed to the SPA board.

SPTG spokesman Robert Kearney said traders were furious after SPA responded with the offer of a single board position for a local trader.

“Considering SPA’s budget of $3.8 million, which is funded by Surfers Paradise traders, and its demonstrably dysfunctional operation over the past few years, it’s time for change at the top,” Mr Kearney said.

Traders are concerned about events being held in school holidays and an increase in scheduling of the beachfront markets.

“SPA is running a flea market down on the foreshore three nights a week which has a direct effect on the local businesses paying six-figure leases for the right to trade in Surfers Paradise,” Mr Kearney said.

Area councillor Lex Bell has met with the traders and also responded to emails from beachfront market stallholders concerned about fees being raised from $50 to $70.

A spokesman for stallholders, in an email to Cr Bell wrote: “I bring to your attention that local stallholders are signing off on the right of free speech within their binding contacts by SPA – this is illegal as traders are on ‘public land’.

“If SPA had their market on private land they can do whatever they want – but this is public land.”

But Cr Bell has defended the increase in fees and explained that sections of markets are on freehold land.

“Full council approved the increase of fees. There was a report to council showing these are the cheapest markets and undercutting other markets and certain business establishments that rent out market space,” Cr Bell said.

SPA chief executive Mike Winlaw also defended the commercial contracts for beachfront stall operators.

“Part of the agreed terms and conditions is the standard confidentiality agreement existing between the market operator and Surfers Paradise Alliance,” Mr Winlaw said.

“People applying for a position in the markets are made fully aware of the terms and conditions and their requirements to comply if they wish to operate as a stallholder.”

Mr Winlaw said a board position had become available and the vacancy would be advertised, with the Alliance’s trader base contacted.

“Board positions are publicly advertised, and we have clearly indicated on numerous occasions applications from experienced traders are much welcomed,” Mr Winlaw said.
categories: /display/goldcoastbulletin.com.au/Gold Coast Bulletin/Gold Coast News and Galleries/

related.body:
Drew “Bushy” McAlindon and partner Leah Gilleland say they are fed up with pedestrians — mostly mums — carelessly crossing the notorious intersection of Musgrave Ave and Clayton St and expecting motorists to stop for them.

“People just use their kids as airbags,” Mr McAlindon said.

NEWS: BABY ‘SERIOUS’ AFTER PRAM V CAR 

NEWS: ‘THIS BEACH IS OURS’: HOMEOWNERS 

“They are just using them (prams) as battering rams.

“Their brain stops at their head. They don’t realise they have another metre and a half of baby in front of them.”

Their concerns come after a six-month-old baby was seriously injured when a car hit the pram her mother was pushing last week.

Ms Gilleland said she was left shaken this week after a close call with a young child who rode out from the road without his mother stopping him.

She even wants to put signs up to say, ‘Pedestrians, watch for cars. This is not a crossing’.

“It’s a terrible intersection for cars and pedestrians,” Ms Gilleland said.

“They need a pedestrian crossing. Something needs to happen because there’s going to be a catastrophe.

“A baby being hit in a pram is catastrophe enough.”

Area councillor Dawn Crichlow said there had been no complaints received about the intersection but former divisional councillor Margaret Grummitt said historically it was a problem.

“We’ve had traffic engineers look at it, and if you take care it’s okay,” Cr Grummit said.

“The locals know it’s a nightmare. Care has to be taken by everybody.”

Mr McAlindon said local just wanted to raise awareness of the problem.

“At least just take a look, take five seconds of your life to make sure everything is OK,” he said.

“My mum said when she used to cross the road and it was busy she would pull the kids behind.

“There’s no way around it because they’ve got to have them in front, but don’t put them in danger.”
categories: /display/goldcoastbulletin.com.au/Gold Coast Bulletin/Gold Coast News and Galleries/

related.body:
On June 17 a cat was killed — with it’s paws and head cut off and left on the doorstep of a home in Hazel Court.

A car at the same address was also torched.

The message ‘whers my money tik tok’ was scrawled on the garage door of the home in a red substance thought to be cat’s blood.

Jordan Isaiah Christie, 19, has been charged with extortion, arson, wilful damage and killing an animal by night.

The court heard Mr Christie had lost his job following the incident.

The magistrate said there was an unacceptable risk of Mr Christie reoffending.

Mr Christie will remain in custody until his next court appearance on August 22.

After the court’s decision Mr Christie’s friend Matt cooper described him as a ‘really good mate’. Another friend josh westhead said he was ‘not the type of person to do something like that’.

related.body:
It was a piece of TV footage that didn’t show any form of abuse or even directly feature a victim, but it went to the heart of the 84-year-old’s credibility and in the moment it was shown in court, his fortunes were dramatically altered.

It was a turning point from which Harris’ case never truly recovered.

For days on the witness stand Harris had denied that he had indecently assaulted a then 14-year-old waitress at a celebrity sports contest in Cambridge in the 1970s for no other reason than he had never done the contest.

‘OMG I’M SO HAPPY’: Rolf’s victim Tonya Lee speaks out 

LINGERING FOREVER: The headlines that will haunt Rolf Harris 

CHILLING WORDS: Rolf Harris starred in Kids Can Say No! to sex abuse video 

ANOTHER VICTIM: Aussie woman claims rolf Harris assaulted her too 

Harris went further and said he had only ever done such a show in Florida in the US and had only been to the historic Cambridge city two years ago for the first time.

He was adamant, particularly about the latter point and mentioned it more than once, with his statements were widely reported.

It was then a member of the public tipped off authorities and they discovered not only was there such a celebrity sports event but it was a TV show called “Star Games”. Footage showed not only had Harris partaken but he captained the team and did a large televised painting at the event — all of which occurred at Cambridge.

The dramatic discovery of the 1978 TV footage disrupted the trial as the jury, which did not know then of the footage discovery, had to be retired to allow legal parties to argue for their respective inclusion and exclusion.

Defence lawyers knew its inclusion would go to the heart of their client’s credibility in the eyes of the jury since he was so sure on the stand of his evidence, with no-one at that point able to contradict.

His defence on that indictment — groping the 14-year-old on the buttocks in what she thought was about 1976 — revolved about his denial of the event and city. They tried unsuccessfully to have the footage blocked from inclusion on the grounds of fairness and prejudice and said their defence would have been different if the 1978 footage was known about.

Both prosecution and defence said it was not an ideal situation for either side but Justice Nigel Sweeney agreed while the case was at a sensitive stage he accepted the prosecution’s argument and allowed the footage to be shown.

Harris attempted to counter and said that he did not remember being on the program but accepted he was there but did not realise it was Cambridge and added no celebrities probably realised it was that city since they all just got bussed around the country and that was the nature of show business.

He repeatedly denied lying or tailoring his evidence to suit the evidence presented but the damage was done.
related.description: A MONTH into his trial, the prosecution case had finished presenting its case and Rolf Harris had been on the stand for four days when the entertainer was hit with his ‘gotcha’ moment.
related.standFirst: A MONTH into his trial, the prosecution had ended  its case and Rolf Harris was on the stand for four days when he was hit with his “gotcha” moment.

related.body:
NAME: Marki Stibi

AGE: 18

OCCUPATION: Surfers Paradise meter maid

You’ve been meter maid-ing four months - what’d you do prior?

I was a bikini waitress for PMA, Promotional Models Australia.

So walking around with not much on isn’t new for you?

Yeah, it’s all right. You’re by the beach anyway.

How many people do you save from parking fines a day?

It depends, some days motorists are really good (at paying for parking) but on days like Sunday, hardly anyone pays. I might do about 20, as a team we maybe save 60 in a day.

How much extra time do you buy them?

Eleven minutes - that’s 40 cents.

Looks pretty easy - you just swan around all day feeding meters, posing for photos and selling merchandise for commission?

Today (Sunday) was tough. People weren’t really interested - it was cold and we had jackets on...they want to see us in bikinis.

NEWS: METER MAIDS’ APP ATTACK 

MORE GOLD COAST NEWS & GALLERIES 

Have to get to a certain level of training or spray tan before you can start?

Haha...I went to an interview and started the next day. I got trained on the job, it’s not tough to get down - you just have to know the basic things people ask like ‘There’s no meters anymore so what’s the point of you guys?’ We now print tickets and put them on the windscreen.

How’d you end up on the Gold Coast?

I’m just taking a gap year. I graduated high school last year and didn’t know what I wanted to study so came here to figure it out. I go home in November.

So there’s life after meter maid-ing?

I’ve applied to go to college, I still don’t know what I’ll study.

Get asked out a lot on the job?

Yeah in the bars later, every day. I just use the old ‘I’ve got a boyfriend’ trick. We’re allowed in some of the bars. Sometimes I work nights as well, that’s when the guys get drunk but they’re more likely to give more money and buy more things.

Got a boyfriend?

Yeah I do, he came over with me, but guys never believe me though.

How’s he feel about you walking around Surfers all day in a skimpy gold bikini and high heels, selling calendars and key chains?

He’s all right with it.

Your folks?

They think it’s cool, just because there’s nothing like this in the world. They actually came to visit for 11 days and they were a bit disappointed because I’d taken the whole time off work so they didn’t get to see me.

Really? Dad’s okay with it?

(Laughs) Well, I don’t think he really understood the concept of why I was walking around in this and selling these things.

You must get some nice reactions?

Sometimes people come running back to their car as we’re saving them and we get a big hug and they give us a donations and thanks. We have a stalker. He takes photos of us every time he sees us. He has our key chains that we sell and photos of us around his neck. He’s our biggest fan. He comes every Thursday and Sunday, he’ll just run up to us around 3pm and literally follow us around the whole time - sometimes we’re like ‘Cameron, back up, please’.

Not threatening or creepy?

Oh no. I’ve asked him how long he’s been doing it and I think he said he’s the meter maids’ number one fan since 2003. I told him he must have heaps of photos of us - and he’s like ‘I have whole photo albums’...yeah, he’s funny.

Better or worse than bikini waitressing?

Better. With bikini waitressing you’re basically just serving drinks in an environment with old men frothing - and you can’t leave. With this, if someone is bothering me, I can walk away. With waitressing you can have someone kicked out, but they have to do something really wrong - and it has to be much more than ‘Hey sexy, fetch us another drink’.
categories: /display/goldcoastbulletin.com.au/Gold Coast Bulletin/Gold Coast News and Galleries/

Six crews responded to Surfers Paradise RSL on Beach Road at about 1.45am after reports of large amounts of smoke billowing from the building.

VIOLENT PIMP THAT USED GOLD COAST WOMEN CONVICTED IN FLORIDA 

On arrival the crews found smoke and fire in a chef’s office and commercial kitchen on the second level of the RSL.

Crews were able to extinguish the fire by 2.30am and spent hours following searching for a cause of the fire and conducting atmospheric testing.

Three crews remain on the scene investigating the cause of the blaze.

The club’s restaurant has reportedly sustained significant water and smoke damage, which parts of the floor above the main bar have collapsed.

Ot is believed an electrical fault may have started the blaze.

It is unknown how long the RSL will remain closed.

related.body:
In the almost two-and-a-half years since Katelyn mysteriously went missing, that man - known only as Rob - has sent a solitary text message to her family and friends saying she was gone.

Now, Katelyn’s family and friends are hoping the stranger, who was swimming with the 16-year-old in rough surf at The Spit, will reach out to them after a bone found in the Seaway earlier this year was positively identified as belonging to Katelyn. 

“We just want to know what happened in the water and even basic things like what she ate for lunch that day, or just anything she said that day, really,” her sister Shireen Hyland said. “We have always wanted to know how she was in those last moments but we’ve never heard from him.

“We would definitely be open for a conversation and we don’t hold it against him at all – it was a tragic accident.”

NEWS: BONE ID’D AS KATELYN’S 

MORE GOLD COAST NEWS & GALLERIES 

Best friend Talina Anderson said she only ever heard from Rob once – when he sent her a text message from the beach saying that Katelyn was gone.

“I didn’t understand, because he messaged me and said she was gone but when I asked what had happened he didn’t reply,” she said.

“I tried for weeks to get in touch with him but I couldn’t and I’d just love to be able to talk to him to see how she was that day in those final hours.”

Both Katelyn and 23-year-old Rob were caught in a strong rip, but Rob was rescued after he was found clinging to a jetty pylon. Police interviewed him at the time and said there was nothing to suggest Katelyn’s disappearance was anything but a tragic accident.

Talina said she and Katelyn had met Rob three months before Katelyn died, and she hoped he was at peace knowing that her remains had been found.

“I am sure over the last two years it’s played on his mind, so I hope he’s a bit relieved knowing the news,” she said.

Talina said it was hard to put into words how thankful she was to spearfisherman Drew Valentine for finding the bone and handing it to police.

“There are so many people who have lost people and they are never found, so I am just so grateful,” she said. “When I heard it was her I just cried and cried and then I sat down and thought about it and called her family. You are always going to have questions that will never be answered, but the big thing we wanted was to get her home and that’s happened now.”
categories: /display/goldcoastbulletin.com.au/Gold Coast Bulletin/Gold Coast News and Galleries/

related.body:
Police arrested a 19-year-old at a house in Broadbeach this week and he’s been extradited to New South Wales.

Police and firefighters were called to Coffs Harbour Marina about 12:15am on May 3 last year after reports a fishing trawler was on fire, a statement by New South Wales police says this afternoon.

NEWS: ‘THIS BEACH IS OURS’ 

NEWS: RUMBLES IN PARADISE 

While firefighters were attempting to extinguish the blaze, the engine of the vessel started and the trawler moved away from the mooring.

Firefighters were forced to jump from the vessel, which then crossed the harbour and collided with a yacht. The trawler continued along the harbour before crashing into rocks while the yacht sank.

Detectives from the Marine Area Command conducted investigations into the fire and determined it to be suspicious.

Acting on information provided by NSW Police, detectives from Queensland attended the Broadbeach house on Monday where they arrested the man.

The 19-year-old, allegedly employed as a deckhand on the trawler, was taken to Southport Watch House where he was charged with an outstanding arrest warrant and bail refused.

Yesterday, detectives from the NSW Police’s Marine Area Command attended Southport Local Court where they were granted permission to extradite him to NSW.

The teenager has been extradited to NSW and taken to Tweed Heads Local Court where he was granted conditional bail to appear in Coffs Harbour Local Court on Monday, July 21.
categories: /display/goldcoastbulletin.com.au/Gold Coast Bulletin/Gold Coast News and Galleries/

related.body:
The jury of seven women and five men in the US District Court in Miami took just six hours after a two-week trial to find Jamaican-born Damion St Patrick Baston guilty of all 21 charges, including sex trafficking and money laundering.

The 37-year-old former nightclub dancer, music producer and self-described entrepreneur faces life in prison at his sentencing on September 5, with a minimum mandatory sentence of 15 years.

VIOLENT PIMP TO FACE TRIAL IN THE US 

“It did not turn out the way Mr Baston wanted,” Baston’s lawyer, David Rowe, told AAP.

“He took it in a manly way.”

US prosecutors flew in two Australian women and one New Zealander to testify alongside three Americans who were turned into sex slaves by Baston.

Baston beat, threatened and raped his victims, bragged about being a member of violent LA street gang the Bloods, and then kept for himself the hundreds of thousands of dollars the women made.

Baston’s pimping began on Queensland’s Gold Coast, but led to the Middle East and the US.

In 2011 Baston, posing as a music producer looking for talent in Australia, met an Australian woman, known as KL, in a Gold Coast restaurant.

They began a romantic relationship and the woman believed they would open a restaurant together, but he began using violence and the threats of violence to coerce her into prostitution.

Baston drove KL to prostitution dates, posted her photographs and contact information on local escorting websites and newspapers and collected all of her earnings.

She had to refer to him as “Daddy”.

KL would return home with “thousands of dollars”, Baston would keep it and flaunt it, including posting Instagram photos of his $250,000 bank balance and $75,000 diamond-studded watch.

In 2011 Baston took KL to Dubai where she made large sums of cash as a prostitute and then they travelled to Miami, Florida, where he continued to pimp her.

The other Australian victim, TJM, met Baston at a party in Queensland in 2009 when she was 18 and they married in an Islamic ceremony in 2010.

In 2011 he was prostituting TJM and KL together out of several rental properties on the Gold Coast.

Mr Rowe told the jury KL was not the victim, but the “business genius” behind a Gold Coast escort agency known as Bachelors Club and Baston “was basically the security guard to make sure that the girls did not get assaulted”.

Baston was arrested in New York in December after KL flew from the US to Australia to renew her visa and her relatives alerted the US State Department.

In 2010, a 21-year-old Lithuanian woman, known as GP, told NSW police Baston had hung her by her feet over a fire escape, forced her to remain in a scalding shower for several hours and beat her relentlessly.

“According to the sexual battery detective who interviewed GP that night, GP was the most terrified victim she had ever encountered in her 25 years at the police department,” prosecutors said.

Baston remains in custody.
categories: /display/goldcoastbulletin.com.au/Gold Coast Bulletin/Gold Coast News and Galleries/

related.body:
It came as Opposition Leader Annastacia Palaszczuk asked “where are the trams?” as she arrived in Queen Street, Southport to meet with supporters and claim ownership of the project.

Residents contacted the Bulletin yesterday after the commissioning of trams stopped and work continued on several sections of the Broadbeach track at its southern end near Pacific Fair.

SCREECHING TRAMS DRIVE TOURISTS AWAY 

A GoldLinQ spokesman said workers had cut concrete around the rail and modified the base, which was required to complete construction.

A program of works continues to resolve noise problems with adjustments made to the automatic wheel oiling system and minor changes to wheel profiles.

Energex sources confirmed stray currents also remained an issue after a report in May confirmed “leakage” had occurred below ground near electricity, stormwater and communication wiring.

“We’ve raised our concerns with GoldLinQ. We can’t fix it. We don’t run the power lines. The trams are run by them,” an Energex source said.

Ms Palaszczuk yesterday met with Coast ALP supporters holding placards with the words “We built it” which revealed the theme of Labor’s campaign to win back seats on the Coast.

As Transport Minister in the former Bligh government, Ms Palaszczuk recalled being involved heavily in the planning of the project.

“I want Gold Coast residents and families to know that Labor built Gold Coast rapid transit,” she said.
categories: /display/goldcoastbulletin.com.au/Gold Coast Bulletin/Gold Coast News and Galleries/

related.body:
You fear they are going to sound glib, that they won’t do that person justice. And you know the person you are talking about wouldn’t want to be labelled with those terms either.

That he saw himself as just a regular bloke.

But Scott Sullivan wasn’t ordinary.

He was brave, he was selfless, he was inspiring. He was the one that covered my rent when as a broke backpacker, I moved into a share house in London. He was the one with the questionable affection for the Spice Girls. Yes, seriously.

The one with his yellow bomb called “Betsy” parked out the front of that southeast London home that ferried us to rugby games. A home filled with the optimism of being in your early 20s with barely a responsibility in the world with Europe and beyond at your doorstep. The kind of freedom you later realise is fleeting, a place where friendships are forged.

Scott or Sully, as everyone knows him, and I became mates in that house. I was just one of his many. Sully was also a son, a brother. He was to become a loving husband to Sarah, a father of two beautiful children, Abbey and Charlie.

He played rugby, an energetic half-back for Sunnybank, he loved to bark orders at the forwards. He had a special affection for the Rabbitohs, the Reds and Wallabies. He enjoyed a beer or, occasionally, some kind of fruity cocktail. Yes, seriously. He loved his Suncorp job. He loved his life.

But tragically, that life was cut short. Sully died two months ago. It was the end of a more than three-year battle with motor neurone disease, a cruel condition that kills the nerves that send signals to the muscles that allow us to move, eat, speak and breathe.

There is no known cure and life expectancy is three to five years after diagnosis. In late April, Sully fell and hit his head at his Brisbane home. He never recovered.

In the two months since his death there has been tears and laughter, as those that knew and loved Sully started to come to terms with him no longer being here. We’ve all thought a lot about Scott, about friendship and family and what is important in life. It’s been a confronting experience for many of us in our 30s and 40s who had never experienced the grief of losing a friend.

Now I have had a chance to reflect on the life of Scott Sullivan, if there is one word that I believe does sum him up, it is “teacher”. And we will still be learning the lessons he taught us for years to come.

During a speech at the inaugural MND Gala Ball in Brisbane in 2011, one of his many initiatives, he mentioned that he often told the risk team he managed at Suncorp that “setbacks were an opportunity to learn”, This was his approach to his diagnosis. Regardless of the outcome he was going to make every moment count.

Once Sully was told he had a terminal illness in 2010 he exposed his life to the world to give them greater understanding of what he and his family were going through.

In a similar situation I and probably many others would have retreated into their shell.

Not Sully. He did this, not for his own sake, but for others.

Realising that there was not enough support for those suffering MND, resources for their family members or funds for research, he established the MND and Me Foundation.

Not knowing where to turn himself, he immediately set about putting in place a structure to help ease the stress for others when confronted with the same diagnosis as him.

He was being educated and we in turn by him.

His fundraising efforts were tireless. Gala balls, corporate swimming and golf days, media appearances, he even rode a specially modified bike with fellow sufferer Ian Davis, a Melbourne doctor, from Brisbane to Sydney to spread the MND message.

I see the smile on his face as he and Ian cycled into Manly in Sydney, just over 12 months ago. The beers were well earned that night.

Two weeks pedalling took a toll on his health but, realising time was of the essence, Sully was desperate to ride to raise funds for and awareness about MND.

For the same reason he completed two Gold Coast Half Marathons after being diagnosed, the first in 2011 and then again in 2012 and, as his legs started to lose strength, he managed the 5.7km challenge last year.

Hundreds of thousands of dollars has been poured into research and on June 21 Sully’s vision, the Queensland MND Centre, a place for sufferers, carers, researchers and volunteers, officially opened.

To me, this resource, which will help thousands of people cope with the most traumatic event in their life, will be a way that they too will come to know Sully in the same way his friends and family knew him.

Despite not being with us anymore, this centre is testament to his generosity and desire to help others. The kind of bloke that would pay the rent of a broke backpacker at a share house in London.

The last time I saw Scott was the day after the most recent MND Gala Ball in March. Everyone was aware of the toll that the disease was having. He had already had a fall which he was unable to break because his arms no longer functioned. His speech was becoming increasingly hard to understand. For all of us it was heartbreaking but if Sully and his amazing wife Sarah could cope then so could we.

That afternoon we sat chatting at his house as he drank some sickly alcoholic cider out of a straw. “It’s my new drink,” he told me. He was like that with his drinks. Last time I joined him for breakfast he ordered an iced chocolate with whipped cream. That day, our kids played together and we watched the footy. He was more than likely secretly enjoying the fact that my Eels lost in the last minute.

I realised how lucky I was just to have an hour to sit there and chat and enjoy his company.

When I was leaving I said I was looking forward to seeing him on the Gold Coast as one of the dozens of his friends and family that were going to hit the road and raise money for the foundation at the marathon weekend.

Sully’s fall happened a month later. We have mourned and continue to but while he won’t be at the starting line this week as he has been for the past three years, trust me, he will be right there running every step with us.

related.body:
The State Government and Gold Coast Waterways Authority have been in talks on the plan for months.

The final hurdle was finding land at Coomera where the dredge spoil could be treated and a long-term lease has now been negotiated on a site, once earmarked for a Gold Coast TAFE facility.

MORE GOLD COAST NEWS 

Gold Coast Waterways Authority boss Hal Morris said the dredging was crucial to opening up what was one of the city’s main water highways.

“We’re pretty excited about the fact this has moved forward and the positive flow-on benefits for the marine industry,” he said.

“This is something that was supposed to be done from the time the marine precinct was built.”

Mr Morris said the authority was hopeful of starting dredging work in the second half of next year.

Gold Coast City Marina and Shipyard owner Trenton Gay said yesterday the deal had given him confidence to move forward with the expansion of the business – including the purchase of the city’s first 250-tonne travel lift.

The machine has a more than $1 million cost, but Mr Gay said the investment was worth it, especially since the dredging work could deliver $30 million worth of extra work to the marina and shipyard each year.

“Things are really starting to turn around for us, from a couple of years ago,” he said.

“Once the message starts spreading among boaties about the dredging work, it’ll make a big difference to the Gold Coast and send a message that this is the place to come.”

Mr Gay said the benefits for the marine precinct as a whole from the dredging plan could be more than three times that figure.

Mr Morris said the $1.5 million needed for the dredge spoil facility had already been set aside and discussions were going on with council to work out how to commercialise the sand.

“We’re looking at mixing the dredged sand with green waste and ... selling it as land fill or potting mix,” he said.
related.description: A DEAL’S been done that’ll see the Coomera River regularly dredged for the first time since the Gold Coast Marine precinct was established 14 years ago – paving the way for a $100 million annual boost to the marine industry.

related.body:
No, not New York, but our city by the sea and that anthem especially applies to the many business owners who ply their trade here.

Last week, the Gold Coast Business Awards winners for June met in the boardroom of KPMG in the Corporate Centre at Bundall. Trophies and certificates were handed out, el presidente waxed lyrical about the winner’s attributes and KPMG’s Paul Steer spoke about the good, bad and the ugly of the economy.

Given it was close to the extent of the end of the year - financial that is - a mock countdown and party poppers saw out the end of the night.

Emergency crews were called to the M1 northbound prior to Exit 41 about 11.18am following reports a truck had collided with two people on a moped.

An ambulance spokeswoman said there were no serious injuries.

“There was one male and one female who were taken to Gold Coast University Hospital with minor injuries as a precaution,” she said.

The truck driver was not injured.

related.body:
Octavia Watkins and her friends, aged eight to 14, had been to the Creekside Community Pool in Crowley, Texas, when they were met by Kisha Young, 39, and Octavia’s mother.

It was a one-minute trip from the pool to home but the women did not want the girls in Young’s Chevrolet Malibu in case their wet bathing suits damaged the vehicle’s upholstery, The Star-Telegraph reported.

The girls were made to sit on the roof of the car but four of them were thrown off when Young went around a corner.

Watkins and Octavia’s mother, who had been drinking, were unaware of what happened until a witness flagged down the car, NBC reported.

Octavia was knocked unconscious in the fall, suffering severe head injuries. She died in hospital after being kept alive by life support.

“I’ll never get my baby back,” Octavia’s father Desmond told Fox 4 News.

“I’ll never hear her say, ‘Hey, Daddy.’ I’m gonna have to live with that; they’ll have to live with their fate.”

Kisha Young was charged over Octavia’s death with intoxication assault — a third degree felony. She also faces charges of injury to a child and DWI with a child. She was released from jail on a $110,000 bond.

Crowley Police said they were working with the District Attorney before deciding if further charges would be laid.

Desmond Watkins said he had not told his other children, an 11-year-old daughter and son, eight, that the criminal charges may be laid against their mother.

“It’s already hard enough with their sister just passing,” he said.

“And then we don’t know about their mum. When they called me, I rushed to the hospital ... I was furious ... drinking and all that.”

Texas’ Child Protective Services is investigating both women.

The surviving children were all taken away from their mothers and placed in the custody of relatives.

“The adults involved are responsible for the children, and whatever happens to them while they are in their care,” said Crowley police officer CC Meadows.

“Well of course we don’t know what they were thinking. However, they weren’t thinking safety.”

Octavia’s funeral will be held today.

related.body:
The group repeatedly yelled out “no trucks, no dust, no Boral” in the hope Deputy Premier Jeff Seeney, who has the last say on the project, would hear their message.

Protesters included stay-at-home mother Brenda Davey, who said she was told nothing about the quarry when she moved to the Observatory with her family just 18 months ago.

“We planned to have a lovely family life here,” she said, explaining that the quarry would be less than 1km away from her house.

“We loved the location and the wildlife that we get there.”

Mrs Davey said the traffic congestion created by the quarry was her biggest concern.

“Right now the round trip to Varsity Lakes takes me 40 minutes, but it will soon be double that,” she said.

Eleanor and Michael Gardner, who have lived in Old Burleigh Town estate for 13 years, listed falling air quality as their biggest fear.

“Our house will be one of the closest to the new quarry,” said Mr Gardner.

“We already known what we are in for because of the existing quarry,” said Mrs Gardner.

Mr Gardner said he was doubtful that protesters could stop the quarry plan, but his wife still held out some hope.

“It is not lost until it’s lost,” said Mrs Gardner.

Barbara Edwards said she was not just protesting for herself, but for the lives and lifestyle of her grandchildren, who lived at the Observatory.

“There was never any mention of the quarry when we moved in here,” she said today.

“I want my grandchildren to have a good life here.”

related.body:
Transport and Main Roads Minister Scott Emerson this morning released the footage in a bid to discourage drivers and pedestrians from engaging in dangerous behaviour around level crossing following more than 130 incidents so far this year, including more than third at Coopers Plains train station.

“Of the 135 alarming incidents that have been reported this year, 46 have occurred at Coopers Plains train station,” Mr Emerson said.

“During the last school holidays at Easter, we had a shocking 17 motorists and pedestrians running the gauntlet in front of an oncoming train.

“Given a lot of families have almost two more weeks left to enjoy time off from school and work, we are encouraging everyone to pay attention and stay safe in and around level crossings.”

One of the most shocking pieces is of a man and woman running across train tracks with a pram, just seconds before a train flies through. It can be seen on the video above at 2.15mins in.

Pedestrians caught ignoring railway crossing protection could cop an on the spot fine of $220, and offending motorists could face a $330 penalty and three demerit points.

Motorists who damage railway crossings can also be fined up to $8800.

More than $239,000 in repair costs has been recovered by Queensland Rail since July last year.
related.description: FOOTAGE has been released showing shocking near misses between cars and trains.
related.standFirst: NEW FOOTAGE shows incredible near misses at train station level crossings across Queensland, including a man and woman running across tracks with a pram. SEE VIDEO
related.subtitle: Video released of near-misses at train station level crossings as Scott Emerson urges public to be safe
